text: <Disease>The associated urinary concentrating defect is reversible only during the early stages of structural damage to the inner medulla.</Disease>
<Disease>Less frequent lithium administration and lower urine volume.</Disease>
<Disease>OBJECTIVE:</Disease>

<Disease>This study was designed to determine whether patients maintained on a regimen of lithium on a once-per-day schedule have lower urine volumes than do patients receiving multiple doses per day.</Disease>
<Disease>METHOD:</Disease>
<Disease>This was a cross-sectional study of 85 patients from a lithium clinic who received different dose schedules.</Disease>
<Disease>Patients were admitted to the hospital for measurement of lithium level, creatinine clearance, urine volume, and maximum osmolality.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS: Multiple daily doses of lithium were associated with higher urine volumes.</Disease>
<Disease>The dosing schedule, duration of lithium treatment, and daily dose of lithium did not affect maximum osmolality or creatinine clearance.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Urine volume can be reduced by giving lithium once daily and/or by lowering the total daily dose.</Disease>
<Disease>Lithium-induced polyuria seems to be related to extrarenal as well as to renal effects.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Rebound hypertensive after sodium nitroprusside prevented by saralasin in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The role of the renin--angiotensin system in the maintenance of blood pressure during halothane anesthesia and sodium nitroprusside (SNP)-induced hypotension was evaluated.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Control rats received halothane anesthesia (1 MAC) for one hour, followed by SNP infusion, 40 microgram/kg/min, for 30 min, followed by a 30-min recovery period.</Disease>
<Disease>A second group of rats was treated identically and, in addition, received an infusion of saralasin (a competitive inhibitor of angiotensin II) throughout the experimental period.</Disease>
<Disease>In each group, SNP infusion resulted in an initial decrease in blood pressure from 86 torr and 83 torr, respectively, to 48 torr.</Disease>
<Disease>During the SNP infusion the control animals demonstrated a progressive increase in blood pressure to 61 torr, whereas the saralasin-treated animals showed no change.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Following discontinuation of SNP, blood pressure in the control animals rebounded to 94 torr, as compared with 78 torr in the saralasin-treated rats.</Disease>

<Disease>This study indicates that with stable halothane anesthesia, the partial recovery of blood pressure during SNP infusion and the post-SNP rebound of blood pressure can be completely blocked by saralasin.</Disease>
<Disease>This demonstrates the participation of the renin--angiotensin system in antagonizing the combined hypotensive effects of halothane and SNP.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Toxic hepatitis induced by antithyroid drugs: four cases including one with cross-reactivity between carbimazole and benzylthiouracil.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE:</Disease>
<Disease>This study was conducted to assess the occurrence of hepatic adverse effects encountered with antithyroid drugs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>Retrospective review of medical records of 236 patients with hyperthyroidism admitted in our department (in- or out-patients) from 1986 to 1992.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS: Four patients (1.7%) were identified with toxic hepatitis which could reasonably be attributed to the use of antithyroid agent.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two patients had a cholestatic hepatitis induced by carbimazole (N  omercazole).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two others had a mixed (cholestatic and cytolytic) hepatitis following carbimazole.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>One of the latter two patients further experienced a cytolytic hepatitis which appeared after Benzylthiouracil (Basd  ne) had replaced carbimazole.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Biological features of hepatitis disappeared in all cases after cessation of the incriminated drug, while biliary, viral and immunological searches were negative.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Only 2 patients of our retrospective study experienced a mild or severe neutropenia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>

<Disease>Toxic hepatitis is a potential adverse effect of antithyroid drugs which warrants, as for haematological disturbances, a pre-therapeutic determination and a careful follow-up of relevant biological markers.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Moreover, hepatotoxicity may not be restricted to one class of antithyroid agents.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Study of the role of vitamin B12 and folinic acid supplementation in preventing hematologic toxicity of zidovudine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A prospective, randomized study was conducted to evaluate the role of vitamin B12 and folinic acid supplementation in preventing zidovudine (ZDV)-induced bone marrow suppression.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Seventy-five human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-infected patients with CD4+ cell counts < 500/mm3 were randomized to receive either ZDV (500 mg daily) alone (group I, n = 38) or in combination with folinic acid (15 mg daily) and intramascular vitamin B12 (1000 micrograms monthly) (group II, n = 37).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Finally, 15 patients were excluded from the study (noncompliance 14, death 1); thus, 60 patients (31 in group I and 29 in group II) were eligible for analysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No significant differences between groups were found at enrollment.</Disease>

<Disease>During the study, vitamin B12 and folate levels were significantly higher in group II patients; however, no differences in hemoglobin, hematocrit, mean corpuscular volume, and white-cell, neutrophil and platelet counts were observed between groups at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months.</Disease>
<Disease>Severe hematologic toxicity (neutrophil count < 1000/mm3 and/or hemoglobin < 8 g/dl) occurred in 4 patients assigned to group I and 7 assigned to group II.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>There was no correlation between vitamin B12 or folate levels and development of myelosuppression.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Vitamin B12 and folinic acid supplementation of ZDV therapy does not seem useful in preventing or reducing ZDV-induced myelotoxicity in the overall treated population, although a beneficial effect in certain subgroups of patients cannot be excluded.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Acute confusion induced by a high-dose infusion of 5-fluorouracil and folinic acid.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A 61-year-old man was treated with combination chemotherapy incorporating cisplatinum, etoposide, high-dose 5-fluorouracil (2,250 mg/m2/24 hours) and folinic acid for an inoperable gastric adenocarcinoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>He developed acute neurologic symptoms of mental confusion, disorientation and irritability, and then lapsed into a deep coma, lasting for approximately 40 hours during the first dose (day 2) of 5-fluorouracil and folinic acid infusion.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This complication reappeared on day 25 during the second dose of 5-fluorouracil and folinic acid, which were then the only drugs given.</Disease>
<Disease>Because folinic acid was unlikely to be associated with this condition, neurotoxicity due to high-dose 5-fluorouracil was highly suspected.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The pathogenesis of 5-fluorouracil neurotoxicity may be due to a Krebs cycle blockade by fluoroacetate and fluorocitrate, thiamine deficiency, or dihydrouracil dehydrogenase deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>High-dose 5-fluorouracil/folinic acid infusion therapy has recently become a popular regimen for various cancers.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It is necessary that both oncologists and neurologists be fully aware of this unusual complication.</Disease>
<Disease>Effect of switching carbamazepine to oxcarbazepine on the plasma levels of neuroleptics. A case report.</Disease>

<Disease>Carbamazepine was switched to its 10-keto analogue oxcarbazepine among six difficult-to-treat schizophrenic or organic psychotic patients using concomitantly haloperidol, chlorpromazine or clozapine.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This change resulted within 2-4 weeks in the 50-200% increase in the plasma levels of these neuroleptics and the appearance of extrapyramidal symptoms.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>None of the patients showed any clinical deteriotation during the following 3-6 months.</Disease>

<Disease>The results of this case report support the idea that in contrast with carbamazepine oxcarbazepine does not induce the hepatic microsomal enzyme systems regulating the inactivation of antipsychotic drugs.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Positive MIF test for ampicillin showed sensitization of the patient's lymphocytes to ampicillin.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Immediate allergic reactions to amoxicillin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A large group of patients with suspected allergic reactions to beta-lactam antibiotics was evaluated.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A detailed clinical history, together with skin tests, RAST (radioallergosorbent test), and controlled challenge tests, was used to establish whether patients allergic to beta-lactam antibiotics had selective immediate allergic responses to amoxicillin (AX) or were cross-reacting with other penicillin derivatives.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Skin tests were performed with benzylpenicilloyl-poly-L-lysine (BPO-PLL), benzylpenicilloate, benzylpenicillin (PG), ampicillin (AMP), and AX.</Disease>
<Disease>RAST for BPO-PLL and AX-PLL was done.</Disease>
<Disease>When both skin test and RAST for BPO were negative, single-blind, placebo-controlled challenge tests were done to ensure tolerance of PG or sensitivity to AX.</Disease>
<Disease>A total of 177 patients were diagnosed as allergic to beta-lactam antibiotics.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We selected the 54 (30.5%) cases of immediate AX allergy with good tolerance of PG.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Anaphylaxis was seen in 37 patients (69%), the other 17 (31%) having urticaria and/or angioedema.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>All the patients were skin test negative to BPO; 49 of 51 (96%) were also negative to MDM, and 44 of 46 (96%) to PG.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Skin tests with AX were positive in 34 (63%) patients.</Disease>
<Disease>RAST was positive for AX in 22 patients (41%) and to BPO in just 5 (9%).</Disease>
<Disease>None of the sera with negative RAST for AX were positive to BPO.</Disease>

<Disease>Challenge tests with AX were performed in 23 subjects (43%) to establish the diagnosis of immediate allergic reaction to AX, and in 15 cases (28%) both skin test and RAST for AX were negative.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>PG was well tolerated by all 54 patients.</Disease>
<Disease>We describe the largest group of AX-allergic patients who have tolerated PG reported so far.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Diagnosis of these patients can be achieved only if specific AX-related reagents are employed.</Disease>
<Disease>Further studies are necessary to determine the exact extent of this problem and to improve the efficacy of diagnostic methods.</Disease>
<Disease>Persistent paralysis after prolonged use of atracurium in the absence of corticosteroids.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Neuromuscular blocking agents (NMBAs) are often used for patients requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation.</Disease>

<Disease>Reports of persistent paralysis after the discontinuance of these drugs have most often involved aminosteroid-based NMBAs such as vecuronium bromide, especially when used in conjunction with corticosteroids.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Atracurium besylate, a short-acting benzylisoquinolinium NMBA that is eliminated independently of renal or hepatic function, has also been associated with persistent paralysis, but only when used with corticosteroids.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report a case of atracurium-related paralysis persisting for approximately 50 hours in a patient who was not treated with corticosteroids.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Habitual use of acetaminophen as a risk factor for chronic renal failure: a comparison with phenacetin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Six epidemiologic studies in the United States and Europe indicate that habitual use of phenacetin is associated with the development of chronic renal failure and end-stage renal disease (ESRD), with a relative risk in the range of 4 to 19.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>As a result of these and other studies, phenacetin has now been withdrawn from the market in most countries.</Disease>

<Disease>However, three case control studies, one each in North Carolina, northern Maryland, and West Berlin, Germany, showed that habitual use of acetaminophen is also associated with chronic renal failure and ESRD, with a relative risk in the range of 2 to 4.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These studies suggest that both phenacetin and acetaminophen may contribute to the burden of ESRD, with the risk of the latter being somewhat less than that of the former.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This apparent difference in risk may not be due to differences in nephrotoxic potential of the drugs themselves.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A lower relative risk would be expected for acetaminophen if the risk of both drugs in combination with other analgesics was higher than the risk of either agent alone.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, acetaminophen has been used both as a single agent and in combination with other analgesics, whereas phenacetin was available only in combinations.</Disease>
<Disease>The possibility that habitual use of acetaminophen alone increases the risk of ESRD has not been clearly demonstrated, but cannot be dismissed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Reduction of heparan sulphate-associated anionic sites in the glomerular basement membrane of rats with streptozotocin-induced diabetic nephropathy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Heparan sulphate-associated anionic sites in the glomerular basement membrane were studied in rats 8 months after induction of diabetes by streptozotocin and in age-</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>adn sex-matched control rats, employing the cationic dye cuprolinic blue.</Disease>
<Disease>Morphometric analysis at the ultrastructural level was performed using a computerized image processor.</Disease>

<Disease>The heparan sulphate specificity of the cuprolinic blue staining was demonstrated by glycosaminoglycan-degrading enzymes, showing that pretreatment of the sections with heparitinase abolished all staining, whereas chondroitinase ABC had no effect.</Disease>
<Disease>The majority of anionic sites (74% in diabetic and 81% in control rats) were found within the lamina rara externa of the glomerular basement membrane.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A minority of anionic sites were scattered throughout the lamina densa and lamina rara interna, and were significantly smaller than those in the lamina rara externa of the glomerular basement membrane (p<0.001 and p<0.01 for diabetic and control rats, respectively).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Diabetic rats progressively developed albuminuria reaching</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>40.3 (32.2-62.0) mg/24 h after 8 months in contrast to the control animals (0.8 (0.2-0.9)</Disease>
<Disease>mg/24 h, p<0.002).</Disease>

<Disease>At the same time, the number of heparan sulphate anionic sites and the total anionic site surface (number of anionic sites x mean anionic site surface) in the lamina rara externa of the glomerular basement membrane was reduced by 19% (p<0.021) and by 26% (p<0.02), respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>Number and total anionic site surface in the remaining part of the glomerular basement membrane (lamina densa and lamina rara interna) were not significantly changed.</Disease>

<Disease>We conclude that in streptozotocin-diabetic rats with an increased urinary albumin excretion, a reduced heparan sulphate charge barrier/density is found at the lamina rara externa of the glomerular basement membrane.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Effect of some anticancer drugs and combined chemotherapy on renal toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The nephrotoxic action of anticancer drugs such as nitrogranulogen (NG), methotrexate (MTX), 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) and cyclophosphamide (CY) administered alone or in combination [MTX + 5-FU + CY (CMF)] was evaluated in experiments on Wistar rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>After drug administration, creatinine concentrations in the plasma and in the urine of the rats were determined, as well as creatinine clearance.</Disease>
<Disease>Histopathologic evaluation of the kidneys was also performed.</Disease>

<Disease>After MTX administration a significant increase (p = 0.0228) in the plasma creatinine concentration and a significant (p = 0.0001) decrease in creatinine clearance was noted compared to controls.</Disease>

<Disease>After the administration of NG, 5-FU and CY neither a statistically significant increase in creatinine concentration nor an increase in creatinine clearance was observed compared to the group receiving no cytostatics.</Disease>

<Disease>Following polytherapy according to the CMF regimen, a statistically significant decrease (p = 0.0343) in creatinine clearance was found, but creatinine concentration did not increase significantly compared to controls.</Disease>
<Disease>CY caused hemorrhagic cystitis in 40% of rats, but it did not cause this complication when combined with 5-FU and MTX.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Histologic changes were found in rat kidneys after administration of MTX, CY and NG, while no such change was observed after 5-FU and joint administration of MTX +</Disease>
<Disease>5-FU + CY compared to controls.</Disease>
<Disease>Our studies indicate that nephrotoxicity of MTX + 5-FU + CY administered jointly is lower than in monotherapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Lithium-associated cognitive and functional deficits reduced by a switch to divalproex sodium: a case series.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>Lithium remains a first-line treatment for the acute and maintenance treatment of bipolar disorder.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although much has been written about the management of the more common adverse effects of lithium, such as polyuria and tremor, more subtle lithium side effects such as cognitive deficits, loss of creativity, and functional impairments remain understudied.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This report summarizes our experience in switching bipolar patients from lithium to divalproex sodium to alleviate such cognitive and functional impairments.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHOD:</Disease>
<Disease>Open, case series design.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>

<Disease>We report seven cases where substitution of lithium, either fully or partially, with divalproex sodium was extremely helpful in reducing the cognitive, motivational, or creative deficits attributed to lithium in our bipolar patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>

<Disease>In this preliminary report, divalproex sodium was a superior alternative to lithium in bipolar patients experiencing cognitive deficits, loss of creativity, and functional impairments.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Treatment of previously treated metastatic breast cancer by mitoxantrone and 48-hour continuous infusion of high-dose 5-FU and leucovorin (MFL): low palliative benefit and high treatment-related toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>For previously treated advanced breast cancer, there is no standard second-line therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Combination chemotherapy with mitoxantrone, high-dose 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) and leucovorin (MFL regimen) had been reported as an effective and well tolerated regimen.</Disease>

<Disease>From October 1993 to November 1995, we treated 13 patients with previously chemotherapy-treated metastatic breast cancer by mitoxantrone, 12 mg/m2, on day 1 and continuous infusion of 5-FU, 3000 mg/m2, together with leucovorin, 300 mg/m2, for 48 h from day 1 to 2.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Each course of chemotherapy was given every 4 weeks.</Disease>
<Disease>Most of these patients had more than two metastatic sites, with lung metastasis predominant.</Disease>
<Disease>Seven patients had been treated with anthracycline.</Disease>
<Disease>Seven patients had previously received radiotherapy and seven had received hormone therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>Median number of courses of MFL regimen given was six and the median cumulative dose of mitoxantrone was 68.35 mg/m2.</Disease>
<Disease>One patient had complete response, seven had stable disease, none had partial response and five had progressive disease.</Disease>
<Disease>The overall objective response rate was 7.6%.</Disease>
<Disease>The median follow-up period was 14 months.</Disease>
<Disease>Median survival was 16 months.</Disease>
<Disease>Median progression-free survival was 5 months.</Disease>
<Disease>A complete responder had relapse-free survival up to 17 months.</Disease>
<Disease>Major toxicities were cardiotoxicity and leukopenia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Eight patients were dead in the last follow-up; two of them died of treatment-related toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The MFL regimen achieves little palliative benefit and induces severe toxicity at a fairly high rate.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Administration of this regimen to breast cancer patients who have been treated by chemotherapy and those with impaired heart function requires careful attention.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Upregulation of the expression of vasopressin gene in the paraventricular and supraoptic nuclei of the lithium-induced diabetes insipidus rat.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The expression of arginine vasopressin (AVP) gene in the paraventricular (PVN) and supraoptic nuclei (SON) was investigated in rats with lithium (Li)-induced polyuria, using in situ hybridization histochemistry and radioimmunoassay.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The male Wistar rats consuming a diet that contained LiCl (60 mmol/kg) for 4 weeks developed marked polyuria.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Li-treated rats produced a large volume of hypotonic urine with low ionic concentrations.</Disease>
<Disease>Plasma sodium concentrations were found to be slightly increased in the Li-treated rats compared with those in controls.</Disease>
<Disease>Plasma concentration of AVP and transcripts of AVP gene in the PVN and SON were significantly increased in the Li-treated rats compared with controls.</Disease>

<Disease>These results suggest that dehydration and/or the activation of visceral afferent inputs may contribute to the elevation of plasma AVP and the upregulation of AVP gene expression in the PVN and the SON of the Li-induced diabetes insipidus rat.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Suxamethonium-induced cardiac arrest and death following 5 days of immobilization.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The present report describes a case of cardiac arrest and subsequent death as a result of hyperkalaemia following the use of suxamethonium in a 23-year-old Malawian woman.</Disease>

text: <Disease>mg, for correction of Dupuytren's contracture.</Disease>
