text: <Disease>Acute effects of N-(2-propylpentanoyl)urea on hippocampal amino acid neurotransmitters in pilocarpine-induced seizure in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The present study aimed to investigate the anticonvulsant activity as well as the effects on the level of hippocampal amino acid neurotransmitters (glutamate, aspartate, glycine and GABA) of N-(2-propylpentanoyl)urea (VPU) in comparison to its parent compound, valproic acid (VPA).</Disease>

<Disease>VPU was more potent than VPA, exhibiting the median effective dose (ED(50)) of 49 mg/kg in protecting rats against pilocarpine-induced seizure whereas the corresponding value for VPA was 322 mg/kg.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In vivo microdialysis demonstrated that an intraperitoneal administration of pilocarpine induced a pronounced increment of hippocampal glutamate and aspartate whereas no significant change was observed on the level of glycine and GABA.</Disease>
<Disease>Pretreatment with either VPU (50 and 100 mg/kg) or VPA (300 and 600 mg/kg) completely abolished pilocarpine-evoked increases in extracellular glutamate and aspartate.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, a statistically significant reduction was also observed on the level of GABA and glycine but less than a drastic reduction of glutamate and aspartate level.</Disease>

<Disease>Based on the finding that VPU and VPA could protect the animals against pilocarpine-induced seizure it is suggested that the reduction of inhibitory amino acid neurotransmitters was comparatively minor and offset by a pronounced reduction of glutamate and aspartate.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Therefore, like VPA, the finding that VPU could drastically reduce pilocarpine-induced increases in glutamate and aspartate should account, at least partly, for its anticonvulsant activity observed in pilocarpine-induced seizure in experimental animals.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Some other mechanism than those being reported herein should be further investigated.</Disease>
<Disease>Acute hepatitis attack after exposure to telithromycin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>INTRODUCTION:</Disease>
<Disease>Antibiotic-associated hepatotoxicity is rare.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>With widespread use of antimicrobial agents, however, hepatic injury occurs frequently, and among adverse drug reactions, idiosyncratic reactions are the most serious.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CASE SUMMARY:</Disease>

<Disease>A 25-year-old male patient, with a height of 175 cm and weight of 72 kg presented to Marmara University Hospital Emergency Department, Istanbul, Turkey, with 5 days' history of jaundice, malaise, nausea, and vomiting.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>He had been prescribed telithromycin 400 mg/d PO to treat an upper respiratory tract infection 7 days prior.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Admission laboratory tests were as follows: alanine aminotransferase, 67 U/L (reference range, 10-37 U/L); aspartate aminotransferase, 98 U/L (10-40 U/L); alkaline phosphatase, 513 U/L (0-270 U/L); gamma-glutamyltransferase, 32 U/L (7-49 U/L); amylase, 46 U/L (0-220 U/L); total bilirubin, 20.1 mg/dL (0.2-1.0 mg/dL); direct bilirubin, 14.8 mg/dL (0-0.3 mg/dL); and albumin, 4.7 mg/dL (3.5-5.4 mg/dL).</Disease>
<Disease>No toxin, alcohol, or other drugs were reported.</Disease>
<Disease>The patient had suffered a previous episode of "acute hepatitis of unknown origin," that occurred after telithromycin usage.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Both incidents occurred within a year.</Disease>
<Disease>DISCUSSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Telithromycin is the first of the ketolide antibacterials to receive US Food and Drug Administration approval for clinical use.</Disease>
<Disease>It has been associated with infrequent and usually reversible severe hepatic dysfunction.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Based on a score of 8 on the Naranjo adverse drug reaction probability scale, telithromycin was the probable cause of acute hepatitis in this patient, and pathological findings suggested drug-induced toxic hepatitis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Recurrence of hepatitis attack might have been avoided if the initial incident had been communicated to the attending physician who prescribed telithromycin the second time.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Here we report a case of acute hepatitis probably associated with the administration of telithromycin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Spironolactone-induced renal insufficiency and hyperkalemia in patients with heart failure.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>A previous randomized controlled trial evaluating the use of spironolactone in heart failure patients reported a low risk of hyperkalemia (2%) and renal insufficiency (0%).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Because treatments for heart failure have changed since the benefits of spironolactone were reported, the prevalence of these complications may differ in current clinical practice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We therefore sought to determine the prevalence and clinical associations of hyperkalemia and renal insufficiency in heart failure patients treated with spironolactone.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>We performed a case control study of heart failure patients treated with spironolactone in our clinical practice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Cases were patients who developed hyperkalemia (K(+) ></Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>5.0 mEq/L) or renal insufficiency (Cr >or=2.5 mg/dL), and they were compared to 2 randomly selected controls per case.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Clinical characteristics, medications, and serum chemistries at baseline and follow-up time periods were compared.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS: Sixty-seven of 926 patients (7.2%) required discontinuation of spironolactone due to hyperkalemia (n = 33) or renal failure (n = 34).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Patients who developed hyperkalemia were older and more likely to have diabetes, had higher baseline serum potassium levels and lower baseline potassium supplement doses, and were more likely to be treated with beta-blockers than controls (n = 134).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Patients who developed renal insufficiency had lower baseline body weight and higher baseline serum creatinine, required higher doses of loop diuretics, and were more likely to be treated with thiazide diuretics than controls.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Spironolactone-induced hyperkalemia and renal insufficiency are more common in our clinical experience than reported previously.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This difference is explained by patient comorbidities and more frequent use of beta-blockers.</Disease>
<Disease>End-stage renal disease (ESRD) after orthotopic liver transplantation (OLTX) using calcineurin-based immunotherapy: risk of development and treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>The calcineurin inhibitors cyclosporine and tacrolimus are both known to be nephrotoxic.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Their use in orthotopic liver transplantation (OLTX) has dramatically improved success rates.</Disease>
<Disease>Recently, however, we have had an increase of patients who are presenting after OLTX with end-stage renal disease (ESRD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This retrospective study examines the incidence and treatment of ESRD and chronic renal failure (CRF) in OLTX patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>Patients receiving an OLTX only from June 1985 through December of 1994 who survived 6 months postoperatively were studied (n=834).</Disease>
<Disease>Our prospectively collected database was the source of information.</Disease>
<Disease>Patients were divided into three groups: Controls, no CRF or ESRD, n=748; CRF, sustained serum creatinine >2.5 mg/dl, n=41; and ESRD, n=45.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Groups were compared for preoperative laboratory variables, diagnosis, postoperative variables, survival, type of ESRD therapy, and survival from onset of ESRD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>At 13 years after OLTX, the incidence of severe renal dysfunction was 18.1% (CRF 8.6% and ESRD 9.5%).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Compared with control patients, CRF and ESRD patients had higher preoperative serum creatinine levels, a greater percentage of patients with hepatorenal syndrome, higher percentage requirement for dialysis in the first 3 months postoperatively, and a higher 1-year serum creatinine.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Multivariate stepwise logistic regression analysis using preoperative and postoperative variables identified that an increase of serum creatinine compared with average at 1 year, 3 months, and 4 weeks postoperatively were independent risk factors for the development of CRF or ESRD with odds ratios of 2.6, 2.2, and 1.6, respectively.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Overall survival from the time of OLTX was not significantly different among groups, but by year 13, the survival of the patients who had ESRD was only 28.2% compared with 54.6% in the control group.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Patients developing ESRD had a 6-year survival after onset of ESRD of 27% for the patients receiving hemodialysis versus 71.4% for the patients developing ESRD who subsequently received kidney transplants.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Patients who are more than 10 years post-OLTX have CRF and ESRD at a high rate.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The development of ESRD decreases survival, particularly in those patients treated with dialysis only.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Patients who develop ESRD have a higher preoperative and 1-year serum creatinine and are more likely to have hepatorenal syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, an increase of serum creatinine at various times postoperatively is more predictive of the development of CRF or ESRD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>New strategies for long-term immunosuppression may be needed to decrease this complication.</Disease>
<Disease>Effect of intravenous nimodipine on blood pressure and outcome after acute stroke.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE:</Disease>

<Disease>The Intravenous Nimodipine West European Stroke Trial (INWEST) found a correlation between nimodipine-induced reduction in blood pressure (BP) and an unfavorable outcome in acute stroke.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We sought to confirm this correlation with and without adjustment for prognostic variables and to investigate outcome in subgroups with increasing levels of BP reduction.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>Patients with a clinical diagnosis of ischemic stroke (within 24 hours) were consecutively allocated to receive placebo (n=100), 1 mg/h (low-dose) nimodipine (n=101), or 2 mg/h (high-dose) nimodipine (n=94).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The correlation between average BP change during the first 2 days and the outcome at day 21 was analyzed.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS: Two hundred sixty-five patients were included in this analysis (n=92, 93, and 80 for placebo, low dose, and high dose, respectively).</Disease>
<Disease>Nimodipine treatment resulted in a statistically significant reduction in systolic BP (SBP) and diastolic BP (DBP) from baseline compared with placebo during the first few days.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In multivariate analysis, a significant correlation between DBP reduction and worsening of the neurological score was found for the high-dose group (beta=0.49, P=0. 048).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Patients with a DBP reduction of > or =20% in the high-dose group had a significantly increased adjusted OR for the compound outcome variable death or dependency (Barthel Index <60) (n/N=25/26, OR 10. 16, 95% CI 1.02 to 101.74) and death alone (n/N=9/26, OR 4.336, 95% CI 1.131 16.619) compared with all placebo patients (n/N=62/92 and 14/92, respectively).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>There was no correlation between SBP change and outcome.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS: DBP, but not SBP, reduction was associated with neurological worsening after the intravenous administration of high-dose nimodipine after acute stroke.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>For low-dose nimodipine, the results were not conclusive.</Disease>
<Disease>These results do not confirm or exclude a neuroprotective property of nimodipine.</Disease>
<Disease>Transient neurologic symptoms after spinal anesthesia: a lower incidence with prilocaine and bupivacaine than with lidocaine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>Recent evidence suggests that transient neurologic symptoms (TNSs) frequently follow lidocaine spinal anesthesia but are infrequent with bupivacaine.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, identification of a short-acting local anesthetic to substitute for lidocaine for brief surgical procedures remains an important goal.</Disease>
<Disease>Prilocaine is an amide local anesthetic with a duration of action similar to that of lidocaine.</Disease>
<Disease>Accordingly, the present, prospective double-blind study compares prilocaine with lidocaine and bupivacaine with respect to duration of action and relative risk of TNSs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS: Ninety patients classified as American Society of Anesthesiologists physical status I or II who were scheduled for short gynecologic procedures under spinal anesthesia were randomly allocated to receive 2.5 ml 2% lidocaine in 7.5% glucose, 2% prilocaine in 7.5% glucose, or 0.5% bupivacaine in 7.5% glucose.</Disease>
<Disease>All solutions were provided in blinded vials by the hospital pharmacy.</Disease>
<Disease>Details of spinal puncture, extension and regression of spinal block, and the times to reach discharge criteria were noted.</Disease>
<Disease>In the evening of postoperative day 1, patients were evaluated for TNSs by a physician unaware of the drug administered and the details of the anesthetic procedure.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS: Nine of 30 patients receiving lidocaine experienced TNSs, 1 of 30 patients receiving prilocaine (P = 0.03) had them, and none of 30 patients receiving bupivacaine had TNSs.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Times to ambulate and to void were similar after lidocaine and prilocaine (150 vs. 165 min and 238 vs. 253 min, respectively) but prolonged after bupivacaine (200 and 299 min, respectively; P < 0.05).</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Prilocaine may be preferable to lidocaine for short surgical procedures because it has a similar duration of action but a lower incidence of TNSs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The role of nicotine in smoking-related cardiovascular disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Nicotine activates the sympathetic nervous system and in this way could contribute to cardiovascular disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Animal studies and mechanistic studies indicate that nicotine could play a role in accelerating atherosclerosis, but evidence among humans is too inadequate to be definitive about such an effect.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Almost certainly, nicotine via its hemodynamic effects contributes to acute cardiovascular events, although current evidence suggests that the effects of nicotine are much less important than are the prothrombotic effects of cigarette smoking or the effects of carbon monoxide.</Disease>
<Disease>Nicotine does not appear to enhance thrombosis among humans.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Clinical studies of pipe smokers and people using transdermal nicotine support the idea that toxins other than nicotine are the most important causes of acute cardiovascular events.</Disease>

<Disease>Finally, the dose response for cardiovascular events of nicotine appears to be flat, suggesting that if nicotine is involved, adverse effects might be seen with relatively low-level cigarette exposures.</Disease>
<Disease>Seizure resulting from a venlafaxine overdose.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To report a case of venlafaxine overdose.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CASE SUMMARY:</Disease>
<Disease>A 40-year-old woman with major depression took an overdose of venlafaxine in an apparent suicide attempt.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>After the ingestion of 26 venlafaxine 50-mg tablets, the patient experienced a witnessed generalized seizure.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>She was admitted to the medical intensive care unit, venlafaxine was discontinued, and no further sequelae were seen.</Disease>
<Disease>DISCUSSION:</Disease>
<Disease>To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of venlafaxine overdose that resulted in a generalized seizure.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Based on nonoverdose pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of venlafaxine and the potential risks of available interventions, no emergent therapy was instituted.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>The venlafaxine overdose in our patient resulted in a single episode of generalized seizure but elicited no further sequelae.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Effect of nifedipine on renal function in liver transplant recipients receiving tacrolimus.</Disease>
<Disease>The effect of nifedipine on renal function in liver transplant recipients who were receiving tacrolimus was evaluated between January 1992 and January 1996.</Disease>

<Disease>Two groups of patients receiving tacrolimus were compared over a period of 1 year, one group comprising hypertensive patients who were receiving nifedipine, and the other comprising nonhypertensive patients not receiving nifedipine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The time from transplant to baseline was similar in all patients.</Disease>
<Disease>Nifedipine significantly improved kidney function as indicated by a significant lowering of serum creatinine levels at 6 and 12 months.</Disease>

<Disease>The observed positive impact of nifedipine on reducing the nephrotoxicity associated with tacrolimus in liver transplant recipients should be an important factor in selecting an agent to treat hypertension in this population.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Sinus arrest associated with continuous-infusion cimetidine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The administration of intermittent intravenous infusions of cimetidine is infrequently associated with the development of bradyarrhythmias.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A 40-year-old man with leukemia and no history of cardiac disease developed recurrent, brief episodes of apparent sinus arrest while receiving continuous-infusion cimetidine 50 mg/hour.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The arrhythmias were temporally related to cimetidine administration, disappeared after dechallenge, and did not recur during ranitidine treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This is the first reported case of sinus arrest associated with continuous-infusion cimetidine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Composition of gall bladder stones associated with octreotide: response to oral ursodeoxycholic acid.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Octreotide, an effective treatment for acromegaly, induces gall bladder stones in 13-60% of patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Because knowledge of stone composition is essential for studies of their pathogenesis, treatment, and prevention, this was investigated by direct and indirect methods in 14 octreotide treated acromegalic patients with gall stones.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Chemical analysis of gall stones retrieved at cholecystectomy from two patients, showed that they contained 71% and 87% cholesterol by weight.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the remaining 12 patients, localised computed tomography of the gall bladder showed that eight had stones with maximum attenuation scores of < 100 Hounsfield units (values of < 100 HU predict cholesterol rich, dissolvable stones).</Disease>
<Disease>Gall bladder bile was obtained by ultrasound guided, fine needle puncture from six patients.</Disease>
<Disease>All six patients had supersaturated bile (mean (SEM) cholesterol saturation index of 1.19 (0.08)</Disease>

<Disease>(range 1.01-1.53)) and all had abnormally rapid cholesterol microcrystal nucleation times (< 4 days (range 1-4)), whilst in four, the bile contained cholesterol microcrystals immediately after sampling.</Disease>
<Disease>Of the 12 patients considered for oral ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) treatment, two had a blocked cystic duct and were not started on UDCA while one was lost to follow up.</Disease>

<Disease>After one year of treatment, five of the remaining nine patients showed either partial (n = 3) or complete (n = 2) gall stone dissolution, suggesting that their stones were cholesterol rich.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This corresponds, by actuarial (life table) analysis, to a combined gall stone dissolution rate of 58.3 (15.9%).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In conclusion, octreotide induced gall stones are generally small, multiple, and cholesterol rich although, in common with spontaneous gall stone disease, at presentation some patients will have a blocked cystic duct and some gall stones containing calcium.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Cardiovascular complications associated with terbutaline treatment for preterm labor.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Severe cardiovascular complications occurred in eight of 160 patients treated with terbutaline for preterm labor.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Associated corticosteroid therapy and twin gestations appear to be predisposing factors.</Disease>
<Disease>Potential mechanisms of the pathophysiology are briefly discussed.</Disease>
<Disease>Neurologic effects of subarachnoid administration of 2-chloroprocaine-CE, bupivacaine, and low pH normal saline in dogs.</Disease>
<Disease>The purpose of this study was to evaluate the neurologic consequences of deliberate subarachnoid injection of large volumes of 2-chloroprocaine-CE in experimental animals.</Disease>
<Disease>The possible role of low pH as well as total volume as potential factors in causing neurotoxicity was evaluated.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The 65 dogs in the study received injections in the subarachnoid space as follows: 6 to 8 ml of bupivacaine (N = 15), 2-chloroprocaine-CE (N = 20), low pH normal saline (pH 3.0) (N = 20), or normal saline (N = 10).</Disease>
<Disease>Of the 20 animals that received subarachnoid injection of 2-chloroprocaine-CE seven (35%) developed hind-limb paralysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>None of the animals that received bupivacaine, normal saline, or normal saline titrated to a pH 3.0 developed hind-limb paralysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Of the 15 spinal cords of the animals that received 2-chloroprocaine-CE, 13 showed subpial necrosis; the nerve roots and subarachnoid vessels were normal.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The spinal cords of the animals that received bupivacaine, low pH normal saline (pH 3.0), or normal saline did not show abnormal findings.</Disease>
<Disease>Early adjuvant adriamycin in superficial bladder carcinoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A multicenter study was performed in 110 patients with superficial transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Adriamycin (50 mg/50 ml) was administered intravesically within 24 h after transurethral resection of TA-T1 (O-A) bladder tumors.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Instillation was repeated twice during the first week, then weekly during the first month and afterwards monthly for 1 year.</Disease>
<Disease>The tolerance was evaluated in these 110 patients, and 29 patients presented with local side-effects.</Disease>
<Disease>In 24 of these patients chemical cystitis was severe enough for them to drop out of the study.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No systemic side-effects were observed.</Disease>
<Disease>Recurrence was studied in 82 evaluable patients after 1 year of follow-up and in 72 patients followed for 2-3 years (mean 32 months).</Disease>
<Disease>Of the 82 patients studied after 1 year, 23 had primary and 59 recurrent disease.</Disease>
<Disease>Of the 82 evaluable patients, 50 did not show any recurrence after 1 year (61%), while 32 presented with one or more recurrences (39%).</Disease>
<Disease>Of these recurrences, 27 were T1 tumors while five progressed to more highly invasive lesions.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In patients that were free of recurrence during the first year, 80% remained tumor-free during the 2- to 3-year follow-up period.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Of the patients developing one or more recurrences during the first year, only 50% presented with further recurrence once the instillations were stopped.</Disease>
<Disease>The beneficial effect of Adriamycin appears obvious and might be related to the drug itself, the early and repeated instillations after TUR, or both.</Disease>
<Disease>Hyperkalemia associated with sulindac therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Hyperkalemia has recently been recognized as a complication of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents (NSAID) such as indomethacin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Several recent studies have stressed the renal sparing features of sulindac, owing to its lack of interference with renal prostacyclin synthesis.</Disease>
<Disease>We describe 4 patients in whom hyperkalemia ranging from 6.1 to 6.9 mEq/l developed within 3 to 8 days of sulindac administration.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In all of them normal serum potassium levels reached within 2 to 4 days of stopping sulindac.</Disease>

<Disease>As no other medications known to effect serum potassium had been given concomitantly, this course of events is suggestive of a cause-and-effect relationship between sulindac and hyperkalemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These observations indicate that initial hopes that sulindac may not be associated with the adverse renal effects of other NSAID are probably not justified.</Disease>
<Disease>Ventricular tachyarrhythmias during cesarean section after ritodrine therapy: interaction with anesthetics.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This case illustrates that patients receiving ritodrine for preterm labor may risk interactions between the residual betamimetic effects of ritodrine and the effects of anesthetics during cesarean section.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Such interactions may result in serious cardiovascular complications even after cessation of an infusion of ritodrine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Preoperative assessment should focus on cardiovascular status and serum potassium level.</Disease>
<Disease>Delaying induction of anesthesia should be considered whenever possible.</Disease>
<Disease>Careful fluid administration and cautious use of titrated doses of ephedrine are advised.</Disease>

<Disease>After delivery of the infant, there should be no contraindication to the use of an alpha-adrenergic vasopressor such as phenylephrine to treat hypotensive patients with tachycardia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Immunohistochemical, electron microscopic and morphometric studies of estrogen-induced rat prolactinomas after bromocriptine treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To clarify the effects of bromocriptine on prolactinoma cells in vivo, immunohistochemical, ultrastructural and morphometrical analyses were applied to estrogen-induced rat prolactinoma cells 1 h and 6 h after injection of bromocriptine (3 mg/kg of body weight).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>One h after treatment, serum prolactin levels decreased markedly.</Disease>
<Disease>Electron microscopy disclosed many secretory granules, slightly distorted rough endoplasmic reticulum, and partially dilated Golgi cisternae in the prolactinoma cells.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Morphometric analysis revealed that the volume density of secretory granules increased, while the volume density of cytoplasmic microtubules decreased.</Disease>

<Disease>These findings suggest that lowered serum prolactin levels in the early phase of bromocriptine treatment may result from an impaired secretion of prolactin due to decreasing numbers of cytoplasmic microtubules.</Disease>
<Disease>At 6 h after injection, serum prolactin levels were still considerably lower than in controls.</Disease>
<Disease>The prolactinoma cells at this time were well granulated, with vesiculated rough endoplasmic reticulum and markedly dilated Golgi cisternae.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Electron microscopical immunohistochemistry revealed positive reaction products noted on the secretory granules, Golgi cisternae, and endoplasmic reticulum of the untreated rat prolactinoma cells.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, only secretory granules showed the positive reaction products for prolactin 6 h after bromocriptine treatment of the adenoma cells.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>An increase in the volume density of secretory granules and a decrease in the volume densities of rough endoplasmic reticulum and microtubules was determined by morphometric analysis, suggesting that bromocriptine inhibits protein synthesis as well as bringing about a disturbance of the prolactin secretion.</Disease>
<Disease>On two paradoxical side-effects of prednisolone in rats, ribosomal RNA biosyntheses, and a mechanism of action.</Disease>
<Disease>Liver enlargement and muscle wastage occurred in Wistar rats following the subcutaneous administration of prednisolone.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the liver both the content of RNA and the biosynthesis of ribosomal RNA increased while both the RNA content and ribosomal RNA biosynthesis were reduced in the gastrocnemius muscle.</Disease>
<Disease>It is suggested that the drug acted in a selective and tissue-specific manner to enhance ribosomal RNA synthesis in the liver and depress such synthesis in the muscle.</Disease>
<Disease>This view supports the contention that the liver and muscle are independent sites of prednisolone action.</Disease>
<Disease>Possible intramuscular midazolam-associated cardiorespiratory arrest and death.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Midazolam hydrochloride is commonly used for dental or endoscopic procedures.</Disease>
<Disease>Although generally consisted safe when given intramuscularly, intravenous administration is known to cause respiratory and cardiovascular depression.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This report describes the first published case of cardiorespiratory arrest and death associated with intramuscular administration of midazolam.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Information regarding midazolam use is reviewed to provide recommendation for safe administration.</Disease>
<Disease>Serial epilepsy caused by levodopa/carbidopa administration in two patients on hemodialysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two patients with similar clinical features are presented: both patients had chronic renal failure, on hemodialysis for many years but recently begun on a high-flux dialyzer; both had been receiving a carbidopa/levodopa preparation; and both had the onset of hallucinosis and recurrent seizures, which were refractory to anticonvulsants.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The first patient died without a diagnosis; the second patient had a dramatic recovery following the administration of vitamin B6.</Disease>
<Disease>Neither patient was considered to have a renal state sufficiently severe enough to explain their presentation.</Disease>
<Disease>Effect of L-alpha-glyceryl-phosphorylcholine on amnesia caused by scopolamine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The present study was carried out to test the effects of L-alpha-glycerylphosphorylcholine (L-alpha-GFC) on memory impairment induced by scopolamine in man.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thirty-two healthy young volunteers were randomly allocated to four different groups.</Disease>

<Disease>They were given a ten day pretreatment with either L-alpha-GFC or placebo, p.o., and on the eleventh day either scopolamine or placebo, i.m. Before and 0.5, 1, 2, 3, and 6 h after injection the subjects were given attention and mnemonic tests.</Disease>
<Disease>The findings of this study indicate that the drug is able to antagonize impairment of attention and memory induced by scopolamine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Seizures induced by the cocaine metabolite benzoylecgonine in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The half-life (t1/2) of cocaine is relatively short, but some of the consequences of its use, such as seizures and strokes, can occur hours after exposure.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This led us to hypothesize that a metabolite of cocaine may be responsible for some of those delayed sequelae.</Disease>
<Disease>We evaluated the potential of the major metabolite of cocaine, benzoylecgonine (BE), to cause seizures.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two separate equimolar doses (0.2 and 0.4 mumol) of either cocaine or BE were injected ventricularly in unanesthetized juvenile rats.</Disease>
<Disease>Treated rats were then evaluated for incidence, latency, and seizure pattern or for locomotor activity in animals without seizures.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>BE-Induced seizures occurred more frequently and had significantly longer latencies than those induced by equimolar amounts of cocaine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Whereas cocaine-induced seizures were best characterized as brief, generalized, and tonic and resulted in death, those induced by BE were prolonged, often multiple and mixed in type, and rarely resulted in death.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Electrical recordings from the hippocampus showed a rhythmic progression in EEG frequency and voltage with clinical seizure expression.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BE-Injected rats that did not have seizures had significantly more locomotor activity than cocaine-injected animals without seizures.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The finding that cocaine- and BE-induced seizures differ in several respects suggests more than one mechanism for cocaine-induced seizures and emphasizes the importance of a cocaine metabolite, BE.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Protection against amphetamine-induced neurotoxicity toward striatal dopamine neurons in rodents by LY274614, an excitatory amino acid antagonist.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>LY274614, 3SR,4aRS,6SR,8aRS-6-[phosphonomethyl]decahydr oisoquinoline-3- carboxylic acid, has been described as a potent antagonist of the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) subtype of glutamate receptor.</Disease>
<Disease>Here its ability to antagonize the prolonged depletion of dopamine in the striatum by amphetamine in iprindole-treated rats is reported.</Disease>

<Disease>A single 18.4 mg/kg (i.p.) dose of (+/-)-amphetamine hemisulfate, given to rats pretreated with iprindole, resulted in persistent depletion of dopamine in the striatum 1 week later.</Disease>

<Disease>This prolonged depletion of dopamine in the striatum was antagonized by dizocilpine (MK-801, a non-competitive antagonist of NMDA receptors) or by LY274614 (a competitive antagonist of NMDA receptors).</Disease>
<Disease>The protective effect of LY274614 was dose-dependent, being maximum at 10-40 mgkg (i.p.).</Disease>

<Disease>A 10 mg/kg dose of LY274614 was effective in antagonizing the depletion of dopamine in the striatum, when given as long as 8 hr prior to amphetamine but not when given 24 hr prior to amphetamine.</Disease>

<Disease>Depletion of dopamine in the striatum was also antagonized when LY274614 was given after the injection of amphetamine; LY274614 protected when given up to 4 hr after but not when given 8 or 24 hr after amphetamine.</Disease>
<Disease>The prolonged depletion of dopamine in the striatum in mice, given multiple injections of methamphetamine, was also antagonized dose-dependently and completely by LY274614.</Disease>

<Disease>The data strengthen the evidence that the neurotoxic effect of amphetamine and related compounds toward nigrostriatal dopamine neurons involves NMDA receptors and that LY274614 is an NMDA receptor antagonist with long-lasting in vivo effects in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Neonatal pyridoxine responsive convulsions due to isoniazid therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A 17-day-old infant on isoniazid therapy 13 mg/kg daily from birth because of maternal tuberculosis was admitted after 4 days of clonic fits.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>No underlying infective or biochemical cause could be found.</Disease>
<Disease>The fits ceased within 4 hours of administering intramuscular pyridoxine, suggesting an aetiology of pyridoxine deficiency secondary to isoniazid medication.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Reversal by phenylephrine of the beneficial effects of intravenous nitroglycerin in patients with acute myocardial infarction.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Nitroglycerin has been shown to reduce ST-segment elevation during acute myocardial infarction, an effect potentiated in the dog by agents that reverse nitroglycerin-induced hypotension.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Our study was designed to determine the effects of combined nitroglycerin and phenylephrine therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>Ten patients with acute transmural myocardial infarctions received intravenous nitroglycerin, sufficient to reduce mean arterial pressure from 107 +/- 6 to 85 +/- 6 mm</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Hg (P less than 0.001), for 60 minutes.</Disease>
<Disease>Left ventricular filling pressure decreased from 19 +/- 2 to 11 +/- 2 mm</Disease>
<Disease>Hg (P less than 0.001).</Disease>
<Disease>SigmaST, the sum of ST-segment elevations in 16 precordial leads, decreased (P less than 0.02) with intravenous nitroglycerin.</Disease>
<Disease>Subsequent addition of phenylephrine infusion, sufficient to re-elevate mean arterial pressure to 106 +/- 4 mm</Disease>
<Disease>Hg (P less than 0.001) for 30 minutes, increased left ventricular filling pressure to 17 +/- 2</Disease>
<Disease>mm</Disease>
<Disease>Hg (P less than 0.05) and also significantly increased sigmaST (P less than 0.05).</Disease>
<Disease>Our results suggest that addition of phenylephrine to nitroglycerin is not beneficial in the treatment of patients with acute myocardial infarction.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Elevation of ADAM10, ADAM17, MMP-2 and MMP-9 expression with media degeneration features CaCl2-induced thoracic aortic aneurysm in a rat model.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>PURPOSE:</Disease>

<Disease>This study was designed to establish a rat model of thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA) by calcium chloride (CaCl(2))-induced arterial injury and to explore the potential role of a disintegrin and metalloproteinase (ADAM), matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) and their endogenous inhibitors (TIMPs) in TAA formation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>Thoracic aorta of male Sprague-Dawley rats was exposed to 0.5M CaCl(2) or normal saline (NaCl).</Disease>

<Disease>After 12weeks, animals were euthanized, and CaCl(2)-treated, CaCl(2)-untreated (n=12) and NaCl-treated aortic segments (n=12) were collected for histological and molecular assessments.</Disease>
<Disease>MMP-TIMP and ADAM mRNAs were semi-quantitatively analyzed and protein expressions were determined by immunohistochemistry.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>

<Disease>Despite similar external diameters among CaCl(2)-treated, non-CaCl(2)-treated and NaCl-treated segments, aneurymal alteration (n=6, 50%), media degeneration with regional disruption, fragmentation of elastic fiber, and increased collagen deposition (n=12, 100%) were demonstrated in CaCl(2)-treated segments.</Disease>

<Disease>MMP-2, MMP-9, ADAM-10 and ADAM-17 mRNA levels were increased in CaCl(2)-treated segments (all p<0.01), with trends of elevation in CaCl(2)-untreated segments, as compared with NaCl-treated segments.</Disease>
<Disease>Immunohistochemistry displayed significantly increased expressions of MMP-2, MMP-9, ADAM-10 and ADAM-17 (all p<0.01) in intima and media for CaCl(2)-treated segments.</Disease>
<Disease>TIMP mRNA and tissue levels did not differ obviously among the three aortic segments.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>

<Disease>This study establishes a TAA model by periarterial CaCl(2) exposure in rats, and demonstrates a significant elevation of expression of MMP-2, MMP-9, ADAM10 and ADAM17 in the pathogenesis of vascular remodeling.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>When drugs disappear from the patient: elimination of intravenous medication by hemodiafiltration.</Disease>
<Disease>Twenty-three hours after heart transplantation, life-threatening acute right heart failure was diagnosed in a patient requiring continuous venovenous hemodiafiltration (CVVHDF).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Increasing doses of catecholamines, sedatives, and muscle relaxants administered through a central venous catheter were ineffective.</Disease>
<Disease>However, a bolus of epinephrine injected through an alternative catheter provoked a hypertensive crisis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, interference with the central venous infusion by the dialysis catheter was suspected.</Disease>
<Disease>The catheters were changed, and hemodynamics stabilized at lower catecholamine doses.</Disease>
<Disease>When the effects of IV drugs are inadequate in patients receiving CVVHDF, interference with adjacent catheters resulting in elimination of the drug by CVVHDF should be suspected.</Disease>
<Disease>Long-term glutamate supplementation failed to protect against peripheral neurotoxicity of paclitaxel.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Toxic peripheral neuropathy is still a significant limiting factor for chemotherapy with paclitaxel (PAC), although glutamate and its closely related amino acid glutamine were claimed to ameliorate PAC neurotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This pilot trial aimed to evaluate the role of glutamate supplementation for preventing PAC-induced peripheral neuropathy in a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blinded clinical and electro-diagnostic study.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Forty-three ovarian cancer patients were available for analysis following six cycles of the same PAC-containing regimen: 23 had been supplemented by glutamate all along the treatment period, at a daily dose of three times 500 mg (group G), and 20 had received a placebo (group P).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Patients were evaluated by neurological examinations, questionnaires and sensory-motor nerve conduction studies.</Disease>

<Disease>There was no significant difference in the frequency of signs or symptoms between the two groups although neurotoxicity symptoms presented mostly with lower scores of severity in group G. However, this difference reached statistical significance only with regard to reported pain sensation (P = 0.011).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Also the frequency of abnormal electro-diagnostic findings showed similarity between the two groups (G: 7/23 = 30.4%; P: 6/20 = 30%).</Disease>
<Disease>This pilot study leads to the conclusion that glutamate supplementation at the chosen regimen fails to protect against peripheral neurotoxicity of PAC.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Attentional modulation of perceived pain intensity in capsaicin-induced secondary hyperalgesia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Perceived pain intensity is modulated by attention.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, it is not known that how pain intensity ratings are affected by attention in capsaicin-induced secondary hyperalgesia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Here we show that perceived pain intensity in secondary hyperalgesia is decreased when attention is distracted away from the painful pinprick stimulus with a visual task.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Furthermore, it was found that the magnitude of attentional modulation in secondary hyperalgesia is very similar to that of capsaicin-untreated, control condition.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our findings, showing no interaction between capsaicin treatment and attentional modulation suggest that capsaicin-induced secondary hyperalgesia and attention might affect mechanical pain through independent mechanisms.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Testosterone-dependent hypertension and upregulation of intrarenal angiotensinogen in Dahl salt-sensitive rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Blood pressure (BP) is more salt sensitive in men than in premenopausal women.</Disease>
<Disease>In Dahl salt-sensitive rats (DS), high-salt (HS) diet increases BP more in males than females.</Disease>

<Disease>In contrast to the systemic renin-angiotensin system, which is suppressed in response to HS in male DS, intrarenal angiotensinogen expression is increased, and intrarenal levels of ANG II are not suppressed.</Disease>

<Disease>In this study, the hypothesis was tested that there is a sexual dimorphism in HS-induced upregulation of intrarenal angiotensinogen mediated by testosterone that also causes increases in BP and renal injury.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>On a low-salt (LS) diet, male DS had higher levels of intrarenal angiotensinogen mRNA than females.</Disease>
<Disease>HS diet for 4 wk increased renal cortical angiotensinogen mRNA and protein only in male DS, which was prevented by castration.</Disease>
<Disease>Ovariectomy of female DS had no effect on intrarenal angiotensinogen expression on either diet.</Disease>
<Disease>Radiotelemetric BP was similar between males and castrated rats on LS diet.</Disease>
<Disease>HS diet for 4 wk caused a progressive increase in BP, protein and albumin excretion, and glomerular sclerosis in male DS rats, which were attenuated by castration.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Testosterone replacement in castrated DS rats increased BP, renal injury, and upregulation of renal angiotensinogen associated with HS diet.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Testosterone contributes to the development of hypertension and renal injury in male DS rats on HS diet possibly through upregulation of the intrarenal renin-angiotensin system.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Prenatal protein deprivation alters dopamine-mediated behaviors and dopaminergic and glutamatergic receptor binding.</Disease>
<Disease>Epidemiological evidence indicates that prenatal nutritional deprivation may increase the risk of schizophrenia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The goal of these studies was to use an animal model to examine the effects of prenatal protein deprivation on behaviors and receptor binding with relevance to schizophrenia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report that prenatally protein deprived (PD) female rats showed an increased stereotypic response to apomorphine and an increased locomotor response to amphetamine in adulthood.</Disease>
<Disease>These differences were not observed during puberty.</Disease>
<Disease>No changes in haloperidol-induced catalepsy or MK-801-induced locomotion were seen following PD.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, PD female rats showed increased (3)H-MK-801 binding in the striatum and hippocampus, but not in the cortex.</Disease>
<Disease>PD female rats also showed increased (3)H-haloperidol binding and decreased dopamine transporter binding in striatum.</Disease>
<Disease>No statistically significant changes in behavior or receptor binding were found in PD males with the exception of increased (3)H-MK-801 binding in cortex.</Disease>

<Disease>This animal model may be useful to explore the mechanisms by which prenatal nutritional deficiency enhances risk for schizophrenia in humans and may also have implications for developmental processes leading to differential sensitivity to drugs of abuse.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>mToR inhibitors-induced proteinuria: mechanisms, significance, and management.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Massive urinary protein excretion has been observed after conversion from calcineurin inhibitors to mammalian target of rapamycin (mToR) inhibitors, especially sirolimus, in renal transplant recipients with chronic allograft nephropathy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Because proteinuria is a major predictive factor of poor transplantation outcome, many studies focused on this adverse event during the past years.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Whether proteinuria was due to sirolimus or only a consequence of calcineurin inhibitors withdrawal remained unsolved until high range proteinuria has been observed during sirolimus therapy in islet transplantation and in patients who received sirolimus de novo.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Podocyte injury and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis have been related to mToR inhibition in some patients, but the pathways underlying these lesions remain hypothetic.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We discuss herein the possible mechanisms and the significance of mToR blockade-induced proteinuria.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Hypothalamic prolactin receptor messenger ribonucleic acid levels, prolactin signaling, and hyperprolactinemic inhibition of pulsatile luteinizing hormone secretion are dependent on estradiol.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Hyperprolactinemia can reduce fertility and libido.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although central prolactin actions are thought to contribute to this, the mechanisms are poorly understood.</Disease>
<Disease>We first tested whether chronic hyperprolactinemia inhibited two neuroendocrine parameters necessary for female fertility: pulsatile LH secretion and the estrogen-induced LH surge.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Chronic hyperprolactinemia induced by the dopamine antagonist sulpiride caused a 40% reduction LH pulse frequency in ovariectomized rats, but only in the presence of chronic low levels of estradiol.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Sulpiride did not affect the magnitude of a steroid-induced LH surge or the percentage of GnRH neurons activated during the surge.</Disease>
<Disease>Estradiol is known to influence expression of the long form of prolactin receptors (PRL-R) and components of prolactin's signaling pathway.</Disease>

<Disease>To test the hypothesis that estrogen increases PRL-R expression and sensitivity to prolactin, we next demonstrated that estradiol greatly augments prolactin-induced STAT5 activation.</Disease>
<Disease>Lastly, we measured PRL-R and suppressor of cytokine signaling (SOCS-1 and -3 and CIS, which reflect the level of prolactin signaling) mRNAs in response to sulpiride and estradiol.</Disease>

<Disease>Sulpiride induced only SOCS-1 in the medial preoptic area, where GnRH neurons are regulated, but in the arcuate nucleus and choroid plexus, PRL-R, SOCS-3, and CIS mRNA levels were also induced.</Disease>
<Disease>Estradiol enhanced these effects on SOCS-3 and CIS.</Disease>
<Disease>Interestingly, estradiol also induced PRL-R, SOCS-3, and CIS mRNA levels independently.</Disease>
<Disease>These data show that GnRH pulse frequency is inhibited by chronic hyperprolactinemia in a steroid-dependent manner.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>They also provide evidence for estradiol-dependent and brain region-specific regulation of PRL-R expression and signaling responses by prolactin.</Disease>
<Disease>Estrogen prevents cholesteryl ester accumulation in macrophages induced by the HIV protease inhibitor ritonavir.</Disease>
<Disease>Individuals with HIV can now live long lives with drug therapy that often includes protease inhibitors such as ritonavir.</Disease>
<Disease>Many patients, however, develop negative long-term side effects such as premature atherosclerosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have previously demonstrated that ritonavir treatment increases atherosclerotic lesion formation in male mice to a greater extent than in female mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Furthermore, peripheral blood monocytes isolated from ritonavir-treated females had less cholesteryl ester accumulation.</Disease>

<Disease>In the present study, we have investigated the molecular mechanisms by which female hormones influence cholesterol metabolism in macrophages in response to the HIV protease inhibitor ritonavir.</Disease>
<Disease>We have utilized the human monocyte cell line, THP-1 as a model to address this question.</Disease>

<Disease>Briefly, cells were differentiated for 72 h with 100 nM PMA to obtain a macrophage-like phenotype in the presence or absence of 1 nM 17beta-estradiol (E2), 100 nM progesterone or vehicle (0.01% ethanol).</Disease>
<Disease>Cells were then treated with 30 ng/ml ritonavir or vehicle in the presence of aggregated LDL for 24 h. Cell extracts were harvested, and lipid or total RNA was isolated.</Disease>
<Disease>E2 decreased the accumulation of cholesteryl esters in macrophages following ritonavir treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>Ritonavir increased the expression of the scavenger receptor, CD36 mRNA, responsible for the uptake of LDL.</Disease>
<Disease>Additionally, ritonavir treatment selectively increased the relative levels of PPARgamma mRNA, a transcription factor responsible for the regulation of CD36 mRNA expression.</Disease>
<Disease>Treatment with E2, however, failed to prevent these increases at the mRNA level.</Disease>
<Disease>E2 did, however, significantly suppress CD36 protein levels as measured by fluorescent immunocytochemistry.</Disease>

<Disease>This data suggests that E2 modifies the expression of CD36 at the level of protein expression in monocyte-derived macrophages resulting in reduced cholesteryl ester accumulation following ritonavir treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>Upregulation of brain expression of P-glycoprotein in MRP2-deficient TR(-) rats resembles seizure-induced up-regulation of this drug efflux transporter in normal rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>PURPOSE:</Disease>

<Disease>The multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP2) is a drug efflux transporter that is expressed predominantly at the apical domain of hepatocytes but seems also to be expressed at the apical membrane of brain capillary endothelial cells that form the blood-brain barrier (BBB).</Disease>
<Disease>MRP2 is absent in the transport-deficient (TR(-))</Disease>

<Disease>Wistar rat mutant, so that this rat strain was very helpful in defining substrates of MRP2 by comparing tissue concentrations or functional activities of compounds in MRP2-deficient rats with those in transport-competent Wistar rats.</Disease>
<Disease>By using this strategy to study the involvement of MRP2 in brain access of antiepileptic drugs (AEDs), we recently reported that phenytoin is a substrate for MRP2 in the BBB.</Disease>
<Disease>However, one drawback of such studies in genetically deficient rats is the fact that compensatory changes with upregulation of other transporters can occur.</Disease>

<Disease>This prompted us to study the brain expression of P-glycoprotein (Pgp), a major drug efflux transporter in many tissues, including the BBB, in TR(-) rats compared with nonmutant (wild-type) Wistar rats.</Disease>
<Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>The expression of MRP2 and Pgp in brain and liver sections of TR(-) rats and normal Wistar rats was determined with immunohistochemistry, by using a novel, highly selective monoclonal MRP2 antibody and the monoclonal Pgp antibody C219, respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>

<Disease>Immunofluorescence staining with the MRP2 antibody was found to label a high number of microvessels throughout the brain in normal Wistar rats, whereas such labeling was absent in TR(-) rats.</Disease>
<Disease>TR(-)</Disease>
<Disease>rats exhibited a significant up-regulation of Pgp in brain capillary endothelial cells compared with wild-type controls.</Disease>
<Disease>No such obvious upregulation of Pgp was observed in liver sections.</Disease>
<Disease>A comparable overexpression of Pgp in the BBB was obtained after pilocarpine-induced seizures in wild-type Wistar rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Experiments with systemic administration of the Pgp substrate phenobarbital and the selective Pgp inhibitor tariquidar in TR(-) rats substantiated that Pgp is functional and compensates for the lack of MRP2 in the BBB.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>The data on TR(-) rats indicate that Pgp plays an important role in the compensation of MRP2 deficiency in the BBB.</Disease>

<Disease>Because such a compensatory mechanism most likely occurs to reduce injury to the brain from cytotoxic compounds, the present data substantiate the concept that MRP2 performs a protective role in the BBB.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Furthermore, our data suggest that TR(-) rats are an interesting tool to study consequences of overexpression of Pgp in the BBB on access of drugs in the brain, without the need of inducing seizures or other Pgp-enhancing events for this purpose.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Use of chromosome substitution strains to identify seizure susceptibility loci in mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Seizure susceptibility varies among inbred mouse strains.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Chromosome substitution strains (CSS), in which a single chromosome from one inbred strain (donor) has been transferred onto a second strain (host) by repeated backcrossing, may be used to identify quantitative trait loci (QTLs) that contribute to seizure susceptibility.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>QTLs for susceptibility to pilocarpine-induced seizures, a model of temporal lobe epilepsy, have not been reported, and CSS have not previously been used to localize seizure susceptibility genes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We report QTLs identified using a B6 (host) x A/J (donor) CSS panel to localize genes involved in susceptibility to pilocarpine-induced seizures.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Three hundred fifty-five adult male CSS mice, 58 B6, and 39 A/J were tested for susceptibility to pilocarpine-induced seizures.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Highest stage reached and latency to each stage were recorded for all mice.</Disease>
<Disease>B6 mice were resistant to seizures and slower to reach stages compared to A/J mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The CSS for Chromosomes 10 and 18 progressed to the most severe stages, diverging dramatically from the B6 phenotype.</Disease>
<Disease>Latencies to stages were also significantly shorter for CSS10 and CSS18 mice.</Disease>
<Disease>CSS mapping suggests seizure susceptibility loci on mouse Chromosomes 10 and 18.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This approach provides a framework for identifying potentially novel homologous candidate genes for human temporal lobe epilepsy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Investigation of mitochondrial involvement in the experimental model of epilepsy induced by pilocarpine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mitochondrial abnormalities have been associated with several aspects of epileptogenesis, such as energy generation, control of cell death, neurotransmitter synthesis, and free radical (FR) production.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Increased production of FRs may cause mtDNA damage leading to decreased activities of oxidative phosphorylation complexes containing mtDNA-encoded subunits.</Disease>

<Disease>In this study, we investigated whether increased generation of FR during status epilepticus would be sufficient to provoke abnormalities in mtDNA and in the expression and activity of cytochrome c oxidase (CCO), complex IV of the respiratory chain, in the chronic phase of the pilocarpine model of temporal lobe epilepsy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>DNA analysis revealed low amounts of a 4.8 kb mtDNA deletion but with no differences in frequency or quantity in the control and experimental groups.</Disease>

<Disease>We did not find abnormalities in the expression and distribution of an mtDNA-encoded subunit of CCO (CCO-I) or a relative decrease in CCO-I when compared with nuclear-encoded subunits (CCO-IV and SDH-fp).</Disease>
<Disease>No abnormality in CCO activity was observed through histochemistry.</Disease>

<Disease>Although evidences of mitochondrial abnormalities were found in previously published studies, our results do not suggest that the FRs, generated during the acute phase, determined important abnormalities in mtDNA, in expression of CCO-I, and in CCO activity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Causes of acute thrombotic microangiopathy in patients receiving kidney transplantation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVES:</Disease>
<Disease>Thrombotic microangiopathy is a well-known problem in patients following renal transplantation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In postrenal transplantation, thrombotic microangiopathy is often a reflection of hemolytic uremic syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We aimed to determine the causes of thrombotic microangiopathy in a population of renal transplantation recipients and discuss the literature.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>We investigated the causes of thrombotic microangiopathy during a 1-year period, from June 2003 to June 2004, at the King Fahad National Guard Hospital in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, by reviewing the slides of all transplant biopsies (n=25) performed during this interval.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pre- and posttransplant crossmatching was done when possible.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS: Five cases of thrombotic microangiopathy were found.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Three of these cases were from the 25 transplantations performed at King Fahad National Guard Hospital, while the other 2 transplantations had been performed abroad and were referred to us for follow-up.</Disease>
<Disease>Three cases were related to cyclosporine, and 1 case was secondary to both cyclosporine and tacrolimus.</Disease>
<Disease>The fifth case had features of thrombotic microangiopathy related to an antiphospholipid syndrome in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>In the literature, the most-frequent cause of hemolytic uremic syndrome in patients following renal transplantation is recurrence of the hemolytic uremic syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Other causes include drug-related (cyclosporine, tacrolimus) toxicity, procoagulant status, and antibody-mediated rejection.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We found that the most-frequent cause of thrombotic microangiopathy was drug related, secondary mainly to cyclosporine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the current study, the frequency of thrombotic microangiopathy was similar to the percentage reported in the literature (20%).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Severe reversible left ventricular systolic and diastolic dysfunction due to accidental iatrogenic epinephrine overdose.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy due to chronic excess of endogenous catecholamines has been recognized for decades as a clinical phenomenon.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In contrast, reports of myocardial dysfunction due to acute iatrogenic overdose are rare.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A 35-year-old woman whose cervix uteri was inadvertently injected with 8 mg of epinephrine developed myocardial stunning that was characterized by severe hemodynamic compromise, profound, albeit transient, left ventricular systolic and diastolic dysfunction, and only modestly elevated biochemical markers of myocardial necrosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Our case illustrates the serious consequences of medical errors that can be avoided through improved medication labeling and staff supervision.</Disease>
<Disease>Urinary bladder cancer in Wegener's granulomatosis: risks and relation to cyclophosphamide.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To assess and characterise the risk of bladder cancer, and its relation to cyclophosphamide, in patients with Wegener's granulomatosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>In the population based, nationwide Swedish Inpatient Register a cohort of 1065 patients with Wegener's granulomatosis, 1969-95, was identified.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Through linkage with the Swedish Cancer Register, all subjects in this cohort diagnosed with bladder cancer were identified.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Nested within the cohort, a matched case-control study was performed to estimate the association between cyclophosphamide and bladder cancer using odds ratios (ORs) as relative risk.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the cohort the cumulative risk of bladder cancer after Wegener's granulomatosis, and the relative prevalence of a history of bladder cancer at the time of diagnosis of Wegener's granulomatosis, were also estimated.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>The median cumulative doses of cyclophosphamide among cases (n = 11) and controls (n = 25) were 113 g and 25 g, respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>The risk of bladder cancer doubled for every 10 g increment in cyclophosphamide (OR = 2.0, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.8 to 4.9).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Treatment duration longer than 1 year was associated with an eightfold increased risk (OR = 7.7, 95% CI 0.9 to 69).</Disease>

<Disease>The absolute risk for bladder cancer in the cohort reached 10% 16 years after diagnosis of Wegener's granulomatosis, and a history of bladder cancer was (non-significantly) twice as common as expected at the time of diagnosis of Wegener's granulomatosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>

<Disease>The results indicate a dose-response relationship between cyclophosphamide and the risk of bladder cancer, high cumulative risks in the entire cohort, and also the possibility of risk factors operating even before Wegener's granulomatosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>L-arginine transport in humans with cortisol-induced hypertension.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A deficient L-arginine-nitric oxide system is implicated in cortisol-induced hypertension.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We investigate whether abnormalities in L-arginine uptake contribute to this deficiency.</Disease>
<Disease>Eight healthy men were recruited.</Disease>
<Disease>Hydrocortisone acetate (50 mg) was given orally every 6 hours for 24 hours after a 5-day fixed-salt diet (150 mmol/d).</Disease>
<Disease>Crossover studies were performed 2 weeks apart.</Disease>
<Disease>Thirty milliliters of blood was obtained for isolation of peripheral blood mononuclear cells after each treatment period.</Disease>

<Disease>L-arginine uptake was assessed in mononuclear cells incubated with L-arginine (1 to 300 micromol/L), incorporating 100 nmol/L [3H]-l-arginine for a period of 5 minutes at 37 degrees C. Forearm [3H]-L-arginine extraction was calculated after infusion of [3H]-L-arginine into the brachial artery at a rate of 100 nCi/min for 80 minutes.</Disease>
<Disease>Deep forearm venous samples were collected for determination of L-arginine extraction.</Disease>
<Disease>Plasma cortisol concentrations were significantly raised during the active phase (323+/-43 to 1082+/-245 mmol/L, P<0.05).</Disease>
<Disease>Systolic blood pressure was elevated by an average of 7 mm Hg.</Disease>

<Disease>Neither L-arginine transport into mononuclear cells (placebo vs active, 26.3+/-3.6 vs 29.0+/-2.1 pmol/10 000 cells per 5 minutes, respectively, at an l-arginine concentration of 300 micromol/L) nor L-arginine extraction in the forearm (at 80 minutes, placebo vs active, 1 868 904+/-434 962 vs 2 013 910+/-770 619 disintegrations per minute) was affected by cortisol treatment; ie, that L-arginine uptake is not affected by short-term cortisol treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>We conclude that cortisol-induced increases in blood pressure are not associated with abnormalities in the l-arginine transport system.</Disease>

text: <Disease>MR imaging with quantitative diffusion mapping of tacrolimus-induced neurotoxicity in organ transplant patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our objective was to investigate brain MR imaging findings and the utility of diffusion-weighted (DW) imaging in organ transplant patients who developed neurologic symptoms during tacrolimus therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>Brain MR studies, including DW imaging, were prospectively performed in 14 organ transplant patients receiving tacrolimus who developed neurologic complications.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In each patient who had abnormalities on the initial MR study, a follow-up MR study was performed 1 month later.</Disease>
<Disease>Apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) values on the initial MR study were correlated with reversibility of the lesions.</Disease>
<Disease>Of the 14 patients, 5 (35.7%) had white matter abnormalities, 1 (7.1%) had putaminal hemorrhage, and 8 (57.1%) had normal findings on initial MR images.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Among the 5 patients with white matter abnormalities, 4 patients (80.0%) showed higher than normal ADC values on initial MR images, and all showed complete resolution on follow-up images.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The remaining 1 patient (20.0%) showed lower than normal ADC value and showed incomplete resolution with cortical laminar necrosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Diffusion-weighted imaging may be useful in predicting the outcomes of the lesions of tacrolimus-induced neurotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

<Disease>Sequential observations of exencephaly and subsequent morphological changes by mouse exo utero development system: analysis of the mechanism of transformation from exencephaly to anencephaly.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Anencephaly has been suggested to develop from exencephaly; however, there is little direct experimental evidence to support this, and the mechanism of transformation remains unclear.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We examined this theory using the exo utero development system that allows direct and sequential observations of mid- to late-gestation mouse embryos.</Disease>
<Disease>We observed the exencephaly induced by 5-azacytidine at embryonic day 13.5 (E13.5), let the embryos develop exo utero until E18.5, and re-observed the same embryos at E18.5.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We confirmed several cases of transformation from exencephaly to anencephaly.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, in many cases, the exencephalic brain tissue was preserved with more or less reduction during this period.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To analyze the transformation patterns, we classified the exencephaly by size and shape of the exencephalic tissue into several types at E13.5 and E18.5.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It was found that the transformation of exencephalic tissue was not simply size-dependent, and all cases of anencephaly at E18.5 resulted from embryos with a large amount of exencephalic tissue at E13.5.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Microscopic observation showed the configuration of exencephaly at E13.5, frequent hemorrhaging and detachment of the neural plate from surface ectoderm in the exencephalic head at E15.5, and multiple modes of reduction in the exencephalic tissue at E18.5.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>From observations of the vasculature, altered distribution patterns of vessels were identified in the exencephalic head.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These findings suggest that overgrowth of the exencephalic neural tissue causes the altered distribution patterns of vessels, subsequent peripheral circulatory failure and/or hemorrhaging in various parts of the exencephalic head, leading to the multiple modes of tissue reduction during transformation from exencephaly to anencephaly.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Acute cocaine-induced seizures: differential sensitivity of six inbred mouse strains.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mature male and female mice from six inbred stains were tested for susceptibility to behavioral seizures induced by a single injection of cocaine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Cocaine was injected ip over a range of doses (50-100 mg/kg) and behavior was monitored for 20 minutes.</Disease>
<Disease>Seizure end points included latency to forelimb or hindlimb clonus, latency to clonic running seizure and latency to jumping bouncing seizure.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A range of strain specific sensitivities was documented with A/J and SJL mice being most sensitive and C57BL/6J most resistant.</Disease>
<Disease>DBA/2J, BALB/cByJ and NZW/LacJ strains exhibited intermediate sensitivity.</Disease>
<Disease>EEG recordings were made in SJL, A/J and C57BL/6J mice revealing a close correspondence between electrical activity and behavior.</Disease>
<Disease>Additionally, levels of cocaine determined in hippocampus and cortex were not different between sensitive and resistant strains.</Disease>
<Disease>Additional studies of these murine strains may be useful for investigating genetic influences on cocaine-induced seizures.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia complicating FK506 (tacrolimus) therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We describe 3 episodes of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) in 2 solid organ recipients under FK506 (tacrolimus) therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In both cases, discontinuation of FK506 and treatment with plasma exchange, fresh frozen plasma replacement, corticosteroids, aspirin, and dipyridamole led to resolution of MAHA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In one patient, reintroduction of FK506 led to rapid recurrence of MAHA.</Disease>

text: <Disease>FK506-associated MAHA is probably rare but physicians must be aware of this severe complication.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In our experience and according to the literature, FK506 does not seem to cross-react with cyclosporin A (CyA), an immuno-suppressive drug already known to induce MAHA.</Disease>
