text: <Disease>Desipramine-induced delirium at "subtherapeutic" concentrations: a case report.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>An elderly patient treated with low dose Desipramine developed a delirium while her plasma level was in the "subtherapeutic" range.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Delirium, which may be induced by tricyclic drug therapy in the elderly, can be caused by tricyclics with low anticholinergic potency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Therapeutic ranges for antidepressants that have been derived from general adult population studies may not be appropriate for the elderly.</Disease>
<Disease>Further studies of specifically elderly patients are now required to establish safer and more appropriate guidelines for drug therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>Mouse strain-dependent effect of amantadine on motility and brain biogenic amines.</Disease>
<Disease>The effect of amantadine hydrochloride, injected i.p.</Disease>
<Disease>in 6 increments of 100 mg/kg each over 30 hr, on mouse motility and whole brain content of selected biogenic amines and major metabolites was studied in 4 strains of mice.</Disease>
<Disease>These were the albino Sprague-Dawley ICR and BALB/C, the black C57BL/6 and the brown CDF-I mouse strains.</Disease>
<Disease>Amantadine treatment produced a biphasic effect on mouse motility.</Disease>
<Disease>The initial dose of amantadine depressed locomotor activity in all mouse strains studied with the BALB/C mice being the most sensitive.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Subsequent amantadine treatments produced enhancement of motility from corresponding control in all mouse strains with the BALB/C mice being the least sensitive.</Disease>

<Disease>The locomotor activity was decreased from corresponding controls in all strains studied, except for the ICR mice, during an overnight drug-free period following the fourth amantadine treatment.</Disease>

<Disease>Readministration of amantadine, after a drug-free overnight period, increased motility from respective saline control in all strains with exception of the BALB/C mice where suppression of motility occurred.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Treatment with amantadine did not alter whole brain dopamine levels but decreased the amounts of 3,4-dihydroxyphenylacetic acid in the BALB/C mice compared to saline control.</Disease>
<Disease>Conversely, brain normetanephrine concentration was increased from saline control by amantadine in the BALB/C mice.</Disease>
<Disease>The results suggest a strain-dependent effect of amantadine on motility and indicate a differential response to the acute and multiple dose regimens used.</Disease>
<Disease>The BALB/C mouse was the most sensitive strain and could serve as the strain of choice for evaluating the side effects of amantadine.</Disease>

<Disease>The biochemical results of brain biogenic amines of BALB/C mouse strain suggest a probable decrease of catecholamine turnover rate and/or metabolism by monoamine oxidase and a resulting increase in O-methylation of norepinephrine which may account for a behavioral depression caused by amantadine in the BALB/C mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No enhancement by phenobarbital of the hepatocarcinogenicity of a choline-devoid diet in the rat.</Disease>
<Disease>An experiment was performed to test whether inclusion of phenobarbital in a choline-devoid diet would increase the hepatocarcinogenicity of the diet.</Disease>
<Disease>Groups of 5-week old male Fischer-344 rats were fed for 7-25 months semipurified choline-devoid or choline-supplemented diets, containing or not 0.06% phenobarbital.</Disease>

<Disease>No hepatic preneoplastic nodules or hepatocellular carcinomas developed in rats fed the plain choline-supplemented diet, while one preneoplastic nodule and one hepatocellular carcinoma developed in two rats fed the same diet containing phenobarbital.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The incidence of preneoplastic nodules and of hepatocellular carcinomas was 10% and 37%, respectively, in rats fed the plain choline-devoid diet, and 17% and 30%, in rats fed the phenobarbital-containing choline-devoid diet.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The results evinced no enhancement of the hepatocarcinogenicity of the choline-devoid diet by phenobarbital.</Disease>
<Disease>Sporadic neoplastic lesions were observed in organs other than the liver of some of the animals, irrespective of the diet fed.</Disease>
<Disease>Effect of direct intracoronary administration of methylergonovine in patients with and without variant angina.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>Methylergonovine was administered continuously at a rate of 10 micrograms/min up to 50 micrograms.</Disease>
<Disease>In all patients with variant angina, coronary spasm was provoked at a mean dose of 28 +/- 13 micrograms (mean +/- SD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the control group neither ischemic ST change nor localized spasm occurred.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The basal tone of the right coronary artery was significantly lower than that of the left coronary artery.</Disease>
<Disease>The percentage of vasoconstriction of the right coronary artery was significantly higher than that of the left coronary artery.</Disease>

<Disease>These results suggest that spasm provocation tests, which use an intracoronary injection of a relatively low dose of methylergonovine, have a high sensitivity in variant angina and the vasoreactivity of the right coronary artery may be greater than that of the other coronary arteries.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Dobutamine stress echocardiography: a sensitive indicator of diminished myocardial function in asymptomatic doxorubicin-treated long-term survivors of childhood cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Doxorubicin is an effective anticancer chemotherapeutic agent known to cause acute and chronic cardiomyopathy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To develop a more sensitive echocardiographic screening test for cardiac damage due to doxorubicin, a cohort study was performed using dobutamine infusion to differentiate asymptomatic long-term survivors of childhood cancer treated with doxorubicin from healthy control subjects.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Echocardiographic data from the experimental group of 21 patients (mean age 16 +/- 5 years) treated from 1.6 to 14.3 years (median 5.3) before this study with 27 to 532 mg/m2 of doxorubicin (mean 196)</Disease>
<Disease>were compared with echocardiographic data from 12 normal age-matched control subjects.</Disease>
<Disease>Graded dobutamine infusions of 0.5, 2.5, 5 and 10 micrograms/kg per min were administered.</Disease>
<Disease>Echocardiographic Doppler studies were performed before infusion and after 15 min of infusion at each rate.</Disease>
<Disease>Dobutamine infusion at 10 micrograms/kg per min was discontinued after six studies secondary to a 50% incidence rate of adverse symptoms.</Disease>

<Disease>The most important findings were that compared with values in control subjects, end-systolic left ventricular posterior wall dimension and percent of left ventricular posterior wall thickening in doxorubicin-treated patients were decreased at baseline study and these findings were more clearly delineated with dobutamine stimulation.</Disease>

<Disease>End-systolic left ventricular posterior wall dimension at baseline for the doxorubicin-treated group was 11 +/- 1.9 mm versus 13.1 +/- 1.5 mm for control subjects (p less than 0.01).</Disease>

<Disease>End-systolic left ventricular posterior wall dimension at the 5-micrograms/kg per min dobutamine infusion for the doxorubicin-treated group was 14.1 +/- 2.4 mm versus 19.3 +/- 2.6 mm for control subjects (p less than 0.01).(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)</Disease>
<Disease>Effects of aminophylline on the threshold for initiating ventricular fibrillation during respiratory failure.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Cardiac arrhythmias have frequently been reported in association with respiratory failure.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The possible additive role of pharmacologic agents in precipitating cardiac disturbances in patients with respiratory failure has only recently been emphasized.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The effects of aminophylline on the ventricular fibrillation threshold during normal acid-base conditions and during respiratory failure were studied in anesthetized open chest dogs.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The ventricular fibrillation threshold was measured by passing a gated train of 12 constant current pulses through the ventricular myocardium during the vulnerable period of the cardiac cycle.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>During the infusion of aminophylline, the ventricular fibrillation threshold was reduced by 30 to 40 percent of the control when pH and partial pressures of oxygen (PO2) and carbon dioxide (CO2) were kept within normal limits.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>When respiratory failure was produced by hypoventilation (pH 7.05 to 7.25; PC02 70 to 100 mm Hg: P02 20 to 40 mm Hg), infusion of aminophylline resulted in an even greater decrease in ventricular fibrillation threshold to 60 percent of the control level.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These experiments suggest that although many factors may contribute to the increased incidence of ventricular arrhythmias in respiratory failure, pharmacologic agents, particularly aminophylline, may play a significant role.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Case report: acute unintentional carbachol intoxication.</Disease>
<Disease>INTRODUCTION: Intoxications with carbachol, a muscarinic cholinergic receptor agonist are rare.</Disease>
<Disease>We report an interesting case investigating a (near) fatal poisoning.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>The son of an 84-year-old male discovered a newspaper report stating clinical success with plant extracts in Alzheimer's disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mode of action was said to be comparable to that of the synthetic compound 'carbamylcholin'; that is, carbachol.</Disease>
<Disease>He bought 25 g of carbachol as pure substance in a pharmacy, and the father was administered 400 to 500 mg.</Disease>
<Disease>Carbachol concentrations in serum and urine on day 1 and 2 of hospital admission were analysed by HPLC-mass spectrometry.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>Minutes after oral administration, the patient developed nausea, sweating and hypotension, and finally collapsed.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Bradycardia, cholinergic symptoms and asystole occurred.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Initial cardiopulmonary resuscitation and immediate treatment with adrenaline (epinephrine), atropine and furosemide was successful.</Disease>
<Disease>On hospital admission, blood pressure of the intubated, bradyarrhythmic patient was 100/65 mmHg.</Disease>
<Disease>Further signs were hyperhidrosis, hypersalivation, bronchorrhoea, and severe miosis; the electrocardiographic finding was atrio-ventricular dissociation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>High doses of atropine (up to 50 mg per 24 hours), adrenaline and dopamine were necessary.</Disease>
<Disease>The patient was extubated 1 week later.</Disease>
<Disease>However, increased dyspnoea and bronchospasm necessitated reintubation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Respiratory insufficiency was further worsened by Proteus mirabilis infection and severe bronchoconstriction.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>One week later, the patient was again extubated and 3 days later was transferred to a peripheral ward.</Disease>
<Disease>On the next day he died, probably as a result of heart failure.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Serum samples from the first and second days contained 3.6 and 1.9 mg/l carbachol, respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>The corresponding urine concentrations amounted to 374 and 554 mg/l. CONCLUSION:</Disease>

<Disease>This case started with a media report in a popular newspaper, initiated by published, peer-reviewed research on herbals, and involved human failure in a case history, medical examination and clinical treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>For the first time, an analytical method for the determination of carbachol in plasma and urine has been developed.</Disease>
<Disease>The analysed carbachol concentration exceeded the supposed serum level resulting from a therapeutic dose by a factor of 130 to 260.</Disease>
<Disease>Especially in old patients, intensivists should consider intoxications (with cholinergics) as a cause of acute cardiovascular failure.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Crossover comparison of efficacy and preference for rizatriptan 10 mg versus ergotamine/caffeine in migraine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Rizatriptan is a selective 5-HT(1B/1D) receptor agonist with rapid oral absorption and early onset of action in the acute treatment of migraine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This randomized double- blind crossover outpatient study assessed the preference for 1 rizatriptan 10 mg tablet to 2 ergotamine 1 mg/caffeine 100 mg tablets in 439 patients treating a single migraine attack with each therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Of patients expressing a preference (89.1%), more than twice as many preferred rizatriptan to ergotamine/caffeine (69.9 vs. 30.1%, p < or = 0.001).</Disease>
<Disease>Faster relief of headache was the most important reason for preference, cited by 67.3% of patients preferring rizatriptan and 54.2% of patients who preferred ergotamine/caffeine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The co-primary endpoint of being pain free at 2 h was also in favor of rizatriptan.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Forty-nine percent of patients were pain free 2 h after rizatriptan, compared with 24.3% treated with ergotamine/caffeine (p < or = 0.001), rizatriptan being superior within 1 h of treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Headache relief at 2 h was 75.9% for rizatriptan and 47.3% for ergotamine/caffeine (p < or = 0.001), with rizatriptan being superior to ergotamine/caffeine within 30 min of dosing.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Almost 36% of patients taking rizatriptan were pain free at 2 h and had no recurrence or need for additional medication within 24 h, compared to 20% of patients on ergotamine/caffeine (p < or = 0.001).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Rizatriptan was also superior to ergotamine/caffeine in the proportions of patients with no nausea, vomiting, phonophobia or photophobia and for patients with normal function 2 h after drug intake (p < or = 0.001).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>More patients were (completely, very or somewhat) satisfied 2 h after treatment with rizatriptan (69.8%) than at 2 h after treatment with ergotamine/caffeine (38.6%, p < or = 0.001).</Disease>
<Disease>Recurrence rates were 31.4% with rizatriptan and 15.3% with ergotamine/caffeine.</Disease>
<Disease>Both active treatments were well tolerated.</Disease>

<Disease>The most common adverse events (incidence > or = 5% in one group) after rizatriptan and ergotamine/caffeine, respectively, were dizziness (6.7 and 5.3%), nausea (4.2 and 8.5%) and somnolence (5.5 and 2.3%).</Disease>

text: <Disease>Salvage therapy with nelarabine, etoposide, and cyclophosphamide in relapsed/refractory paediatric T-cell lymphoblastic leukaemia and lymphoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A combination of 5 d of nelarabine (AraG) with 5 d of etoposide (VP) and cyclophosphamide (CPM) and prophylactic intrathecal chemotherapy was used as salvage therapy in seven children with refractory or relapsed T-cell leukaemia or lymphoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The most common side effects attributable to the AraG included Grade 2 and 3 sensory and motor neuropathy and musculoskeletal pain.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Haematological toxicity was greater for the combination than AraG alone, although median time to neutrophil and platelet recovery was consistent with other salvage therapies.</Disease>

text: <Disease>All patients had some response to the combined therapy and five of the seven went into complete remission after one or two courses of AraG/VP/CPM.</Disease>
<Disease>Our experience supports the safety of giving AraG as salvage therapy in synchrony with etoposide and cyclophosphamide, although neurological toxicity must be closely monitored.</Disease>

<Disease>Survey of complications of indocyanine green angiography in Japan.</Disease>
<Disease>PURPOSE:</Disease>
<Disease>We evaluated the safety of indocyanine green for use in fundus angiography.</Disease>
<Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>We sent a questionnaire concerning complications of indocyanine green to 32 institutions in Japan, which were selected on the basis of the client list from the Topcon Company, which manufactures the indocyanine green fundus camera.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>Ophthalmologists at 15 institutions responded, reporting a total of 3,774 indocyanine green angiograms performed on 2,820 patients between June 1984 and September 1992.</Disease>
<Disease>Before angiography, intradermal or intravenous indocyanine green testing, or both was performed at 13 of 15 institutions.</Disease>
<Disease>For three patients, the decision was made not to proceed with angiography after positive preangiographic testing.</Disease>
<Disease>The dosage of indocyanine green used for angiography varied from 25 to 75 mg, depending upon the institution.</Disease>

<Disease>There were 13 cases of adverse reactions (0.34%), ten of which were mild reactions such as nausea, exanthema, urtication, itchiness, and urgency to defecate, and did not require treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Also recorded were one case of pain of the vein, which required treatment, and two cases of hypotension.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The two hypotensive patients required treatment for shock.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>

<Disease>A comparison of frequency of adverse reactions to indocyanine green with the previously reported frequency of such reactions to fluorescein sodium indicated that indocyanine green is a safe as fluorescein for use in angiography.</Disease>

text: <Disease>PURPOSE:</Disease>

<Disease>The influence of an irreversible inhibitor of constitutive NO synthase (L-NOArg; 1.0 mg/kg ip), a relatively selective inhibitor of inducible NO synthase (L-NIL; 1.0 mg/kg ip) and a relatively specific inhibitor of neuronal NO synthase (7-NI; 0.1 mg/kg ip), on antihyperalgesic action of selective antagonists of B2 and B1 receptors: D-Arg-[Hyp3,Thi5,D-Tic7,Oic8] bradykinin (HOE 140; 70 nmol/kg ip) or des Arg10 HOE 140 (70 nmol/kg ip) respectively, in model of diabetic (streptozotocin-induced) and toxic (vincristine-induced) neuropathy was investigated.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pretreatment with L-NOArg and L-NIL but not 7-NI, significantly increases antihyperalgesic activity both HOE 140 and des Arg10 HOE 140.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>Moreover, L-NOArg and 7-NI but not L-NIL intensify antihyperalgesic activity of HOE 140 or des-Arg10HOE 140 in toxic neuropathy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>In streptozotocin-induced hyperalgesia, inducible NO synthase participates in pronociceptive activity of bradykinin, whereas in vincristine-induced hyperalgesia bradykinin seemed to activate neuronal NO synthase pathway.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Therefore, concomitant administration of small doses of bradykinin receptor antagonists and NO synthase inhibitors can be effective in alleviation of neuropathic pain, even in hospital care.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Cardiac toxicity observed in association with high-dose cyclophosphamide-based chemotherapy for metastatic breast cancer.</Disease>

text: <Disease>INTRODUCTION:</Disease>

text: <Disease>STUDY DESIGN:</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>Analysis was performed on 61 women with chemotherapy-responsive metastatic breast cancer receiving 96-h infusional cyclophosphamide as part of a triple sequential high-dose regimen to assess association between presence of peritransplant congestive heart failure (CHF) and the following pretreatment characteristics: presence of electrocardiogram (EKG) abnormalities, age, hypertension, prior cardiac history, smoking, diabetes mellitus, prior use of anthracyclines, and left-sided chest irradiation.</Disease>
label: Disease

Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS: Six of 61 women (10%) developed clinically reversible grade 3 CHF following infusional cyclophosphamide with a median percent decline in ejection fraction of 31%.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Incidence of transient cyclophosphamide-related cardiac toxicity (10%) is comparable to previous recorded literature.</Disease>

<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>As a result of these findings, oncologists should carefully monitor fluid balance in older patients.</Disease>

<Disease>Hemolytic anemia associated with the use of omeprazole.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Omeprazole is the first drug designed to block the final step in the acid secretory process within the parietal cell.</Disease>
<Disease>It has been shown to be extremely effective in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease, reflux esophagitis, and the Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.</Disease>

Disease

text: <Disease>Although clinical experience with omeprazole is still limited, many controlled studies have established the short-term safety of this drug.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two weeks after the initiation of therapy, her hematocrit had decreased from 44.1% to 20.4%, and she had a positive direct Coombs antiglobulin test and an elevated indirect bilirubin.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Can angiogenesis be a target of treatment for ribavirin associated hemolytic anemia?</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND/AIMS:</Disease>
<Disease>Recently ribavirin has been found to inhibit angiogenesis and a number of angiogenesis inhibitors such as sunitinib and sorafenib have been found to cause acute hemolysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We aimed to investigate whether there is a relation between hemoglobin, haptoglobin and angiogenesis soluble markers which are modifiable and can help in developing strategies against anemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS: Fourteen patients chronically infected with hepatitis C virus were treated by pegylated interferon alpha 2a and ribavirin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Serum hemoglobin, haptoglobin and angiogenesis markers of vascular endothelial growth factor and angiopoetin-2 were investigated before and after therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>We observed a significant decrease in haptoglobin levels at the end of the treatment period.</Disease>
<Disease>Hemoglobin levels also decreased but insignificantly by treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast with the literature, serum levels of angiogenesis factors did not change significantly by pegylated interferon and ribavirin therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>We found no correlation of angiogenesis soluble markers with either hemoglobin or haptoglobin.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>

<Disease>This is the first study in the literature investigating a link between angiogenesis soluble markers and ribavirin induced anemia in patients with hepatitis C and we could not find any relation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Future research with larger number of patients is needed to find out modifiable factors that will improve the safety of ribavirin therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>Cocaine causes memory and learning impairments in rats: involvement of nuclear factor kappa B and oxidative stress, and prevention by topiramate.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Different mechanisms have been suggested for cocaine toxicity including an increase in oxidative stress but the association between oxidative status in the brain and cocaine induced-behaviour is poorly understood.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Nuclear factor kappa B (NFkappaB) is a sensor of oxidative stress and participates in memory formation that could be involved in drug toxicity and addiction mechanisms.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Therefore NFkappaB activity, oxidative stress, neuronal nitric oxide synthase (nNOS) activity, spatial learning and memory as well as the effect of topiramate, a previously proposed therapy for cocaine addiction, were evaluated in an experimental model of cocaine administration in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>NFkappaB activity was decreased in the frontal cortex of cocaine treated rats, as well as GSH concentration and glutathione peroxidase activity in the hippocampus, whereas nNOS activity in the hippocampus was increased.</Disease>
<Disease>Memory retrieval of experiences acquired prior to cocaine administration was impaired and negatively correlated with NFkappaB activity in the frontal cortex.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast, learning of new tasks was enhanced and correlated with the increase of nNOS activity and the decrease of glutathione peroxidase.</Disease>
<Disease>These results provide evidence for a possible mechanistic role of oxidative and nitrosative stress and NFkappaB in the alterations induced by cocaine.</Disease>
<Disease>Topiramate prevented all the alterations observed, showing novel neuroprotective properties.</Disease>
<Disease>Antinociceptive and antiamnesic properties of the presynaptic cholinergic amplifier PG-9.</Disease>
<Disease>The antinociceptive effect of 3 alpha-tropyl 2-(p-bromophenyl)propionate</Disease>

<Disease>[(+/-)-PG-9] (10-40 mg kg-1 s.c.; 30-60 mg kg-1 p.o.; 10-30 mg kg-1 i.v.; 10-30 micrograms/mouse i.c.v.) was examined in mice, rats and guinea pigs by use of the hot-plate, abdominal-constriction, tail-flick and paw-pressure tests.</Disease>
<Disease>(+/-)-PG-9 antinociception peaked 15 min after injection and then slowly diminished.</Disease>

<Disease>The antinociception produced by (+/-)-PG-9 was prevented by the unselective muscarinic antagonist atropine, the M1-selective antagonists pirenzepine and dicyclomine and the acetylcholine depletor hemicholinium-3, but not by the opioid antagonist naloxone, the gamma-aminobutyric acidB antagonist 3-aminopropyl-diethoxy-methyl-phosphinic acid, the H3 agonist R-(alpha)-methylhistamine, the D2 antagonist quinpirole, the 5-hydroxytryptamine4 antagonist 2-methoxy-4-amino-5-chlorobenzoic acid 2-(diethylamino)ethyl ester hydrochloride, the 5-hydroxytryptamin1A antagonist 1-(2-methoxyphenyl)-4-[4-(2-phthalimido)butyl]piperazine hydrobromide and the polyamines depletor reserpine.</Disease>
<Disease>Based on these data, it can be postulated that (+/-)-PG-9 exerted an antinociceptive effect mediated by a central potentiation of cholinergic transmission.</Disease>
<Disease>(+/-)-PG-9 (10-40 mg kg-1 i.p.) was able to prevent amnesia induced by scopolamine (1 mg kg-1 i.p.)</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>and dicyclomine (2 mg kg-1 i.p.) in the mouse passive-avoidance test.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the antinociceptive and antiamnesic dose range, (+/-)-PG-9 did not impair mouse performance evaluated by the rota-rod test and Animex apparatus.</Disease>
<Disease>Hyperbaric oxygen therapy for control of intractable cyclophosphamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis.</Disease>

Disease

text: <Disease>Conservative treatment, including bladder irrigation with physiological saline and instillation of prostaglandin F2 alpha, failed to totally control hemorrhage.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We then used hyperbaric oxygen at an absolute pressure of 2 atm, 5 days a week for 8 consecutive weeks.</Disease>

text: <Disease>No side effect was noted during the course of therapy.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Clinical experiences in an open and a double-blind trial.</Disease>

<Disease>A total of sixty patients were trated with bromperidol first in open conditions (20 patients), then on a double blind basis (40 patients) with haloperidol as the reference substance.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The results of detailed laboratory tests and evaluations of various quantitative and qualitative tolerability parameters were not indicative of toxic effects.</Disease>

<Disease>Curcumin ameliorates cognitive dysfunction and oxidative damage in phenobarbitone and carbamazepine administered rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The antiepileptic drugs, phenobarbitone and carbamazepine are well known to cause cognitive impairment on chronic use.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The increase in free radical generation has been implicated as one of the important mechanisms of cognitive impairment by antiepileptic drugs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Curcumin has shown antioxidant, anti-inflammatory and neuro-protective properties.</Disease>

<Disease>Therefore, the present study was carried out to investigate the effect of chronic curcumin administration on phenobarbitone- and carbamazepine-induced cognitive impairment and oxidative stress in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pharmacokinetic interactions of curcumin with phenobarbitone and carbamazepine were also studied.</Disease>
<Disease>Vehicle/drugs were administered daily for 21days to male Wistar rats.</Disease>
<Disease>Passive avoidance paradigm and elevated plus maze test were used to assess cognitive function.</Disease>
<Disease>At the end of study period, serum phenobarbitone and carbamazepine, whole brain malondialdehyde and reduced glutathione levels were estimated.</Disease>
<Disease>The administration of phenobarbitone and carbamazepine for 21days caused a significant impairment of learning and memory as well as an increased oxidative stress.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Concomitant curcumin administration prevented the cognitive impairment and decreased the increased oxidative stress induced by these antiepileptic drugs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Curcumin co-administration did not cause any significant alteration in the serum concentrations of both phenobarbitone as well as carbamazepine.</Disease>

<Disease>These results show that curcumin has beneficial effect in mitigating the deterioration of cognitive functions and oxidative damage in rats treated with phenobarbitone and carbamazepine without significantly altering their serum concentrations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The findings suggest that curcumin can be considered as a potential safe and effective adjuvant to phenobarbitone and carbamazepine therapy in preventing cognitive impairment associated with these drugs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate protects the piriform cortex in the pilocarpine status epilepticus model.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate (PDTC) has a dual mechanism of action as an antioxidant and an inhibitor of the transcription factor kappa-beta.</Disease>

<Disease>Both, production of reactive oxygen species as well as activation of NF-kappaB have been implicated in severe neuronal damage in different sub-regions of the hippocampus as well as in the surrounding cortices.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The effect of PDTC on status epilepticus-associated cell loss in the hippocampus and piriform cortex was evaluated in the rat fractionated pilocarpine model.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Treatment with 150 mg/kg PDTC before and following status epilepticus significantly increased the mortality rate to 100%.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Administration of 50 mg/kg PDTC (low-dose) did not exert major effects on the development of a status epilepticus or the mortality rate.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In vehicle-treated rats, status epilepticus caused pronounced neuronal damage in the piriform cortex comprising both pyramidal cells and interneurons.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Low-dose PDTC treatment almost completely protected from lesions in the piriform cortex.</Disease>
<Disease>A significant decrease in neuronal density of the hippocampal hilar formation was identified in vehicle- and PDTC-treated rats following status epilepticus.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In conclusion, the NF-kappaB inhibitor and antioxidant PDTC protected the piriform cortex, whereas it did not affect hilar neuronal loss.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These data might indicate that the generation of reactive oxygen species and activation of NF-kappaB plays a more central role in seizure-associated neuronal damage in the temporal cortex as compared to the hippocampal hilus.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, future investigations are necessary to exactly analyze the biochemical mechanisms by which PDTC exerted its beneficial effects in the piriform cortex.</Disease>
<Disease>Safety profile of a nicotine lozenge compared with that of nicotine gum in adult smokers with underlying medical conditions: a 12-week, randomized, open-label study.</Disease>
<Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>Nicotine polacrilex lozenges deliver 25% to 27% more nicotine compared with equivalent doses of nicotine polacrilex gum.</Disease>
<Disease>The increased nicotine exposure from the lozenge has raised questions about the relative safety of the lozenge and gum.</Disease>
<Disease>OBJECTIVE:</Disease>
<Disease>The objective of this study was to compare the safety profiles of the 4-mg nicotine lozenge and 4-mg nicotine gum in smokers with selected label-restricted diseases.</Disease>
<Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>This was a multicenter, randomized, open-label study in adult smokers with heart disease, hypertension not controlled by medication, and/or diabetes mellitus.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Patients were randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive the 4-mg nicotine lozenge or 4-mg nicotine gum.</Disease>
<Disease>Safety assessments were made at baseline and at 2, 4, 6, and 12 weeks after the start of product use.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS: Nine hundred one patients were randomized to treatment, 447 who received the lozenge and 454 who received the gum (safety population).</Disease>
<Disease>The majority were women (52.7%).</Disease>
<Disease>Patients' mean age was 53.9 years, their mean weight was 193.9 pounds, and they smoked a mean of 25.2 cigarettes per day at baseline.</Disease>
<Disease>Five hundred fifty-three patients, 264 taking the lozenge and 289 taking the gum, used the study product for > or =4 days per week during the first 2 weeks (evaluable population).</Disease>
<Disease>The nicotine lozenge and nicotine gum were equally well tolerated, despite increased nicotine exposure from the lozenge.</Disease>

<Disease>The incidence of adverse events in the 2 groups was similar during the first 2 weeks of product use (evaluation population: 55.3% lozenge, 54.7% gum), as well as during the entire study (safety population: 63.8% and 58.6%, respectively).</Disease>

<Disease>Stratification of patients by sex, age, extent of concurrent smoking, extent of product use, and severity of adverse events revealed no clinically significant differences between the lozenge and gum.</Disease>
<Disease>The most common adverse events were nausea (17.2% and 16.1%; 95% CI, -3.7 to 6.0), hiccups (10.7% and 6.6%; 95% CI, 0.5 to 7.8), and headache (8.7% and 9.9%; 95% Cl, -5.0 to 2.6).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Serious adverse events were reported in 11 and 13 patients in the respective groups.</Disease>
<Disease>Fewer than 6% of patients in either group were considered by the investigator to have a worsening of their overall disease condition during the study.</Disease>
<Disease>The majority of patients (>60%) experienced no change in their disease status from baseline.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>The 4-mg nicotine lozenge and 4-mg nicotine gum had comparable safety profiles in these patients with label-restricted medical conditions.</Disease>
<Disease>Development of levodopa-induced dyskinesias in parkinsonian monkeys may depend upon rate of symptom onset and/or duration of symptoms.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Levodopa-induced dyskinesias (LIDs) present a major problem for the long-term management of Parkinson's disease (PD) patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Due to the interdependence of risk factors in clinical populations, it is difficult to independently examine factors that may influence the development of LIDs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Using macaque monkeys with different types of MPTP-induced parkinsonism, the current study evaluated the degree to which rate of symptom progression, symptom severity, and response to and duration of levodopa therapy may be involved in the development of LIDs.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Monkeys with acute (short-term) MPTP exposure, rapid symptom onset and short symptom duration prior to initiation of levodopa therapy developed dyskinesia between 11 and 24 days of daily levodopa administration.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In contrast, monkeys with long-term MPTP exposure, slow symptom progression and/or long symptom duration prior to initiation of levodopa therapy were more resistant to developing LIDs (e.g., dyskinesia developed no sooner than 146 days of chronic levodopa administration).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>All animals were similarly symptomatic at the start of levodopa treatment and had similar therapeutic responses to the drug.</Disease>

<Disease>These data suggest distinct differences in the propensity to develop LIDs in monkeys with different rates of symptom progression or symptom durations prior to levodopa and demonstrate the value of these models for further studying the pathophysiology of LIDs.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Propylthiouracil-induced perinuclear-staining antineutrophil cytoplasmic autoantibody-positive vasculitis in conjunction with pericarditis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To describe a case of propylthiouracil-induced vasculitis manifesting with pericarditis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>We present the first case report of a woman with hyperthyroidism treated with propylthiouracil in whom a syndrome of pericarditis, fever, and glomerulonephritis developed.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Serologic testing and immunologic studies were done, and a pericardial biopsy was performed.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>A 25-year-old woman with Graves' disease had a febrile illness and evidence of pericarditis, which was confirmed by biopsy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Serologic evaluation revealed the presence of perinuclear-staining antineutrophil cytoplasmic autoantibodies (pANCA) against myeloperoxidase (MPO).</Disease>
<Disease>Propylthiouracil therapy was withdrawn, and she was treated with a 1-month course of prednisone, which alleviated her symptoms.</Disease>
<Disease>A literature review revealed no prior reports of pericarditis in anti-MPO pANCA-positive vasculitis associated with propylthio- uracil therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Pericarditis may be the initial manifestation of drug-induced vasculitis attributable to propylthio- uracil therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Two mouse lines selected for differential sensitivities to beta-carboline-induced seizures are also differentially sensitive to various pharmacological effects of other GABA(A) receptor ligands.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two mouse lines were selectively bred according to their sensitivity (BS line) or resistance (BR line) to seizures induced by a single i.p. injection of methyl beta-carboline-3-carboxylate (beta-CCM), an inverse agonist of the GABA(A) receptor benzodiazepine site.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our aim was to characterize both lines' sensitivities to various physiological effects of other ligands of the GABA(A) receptor.</Disease>

<Disease>We measured diazepam-induced anxiolysis with the elevated plus-maze test, diazepam-induced sedation by recording the vigilance states, and picrotoxin- and pentylenetetrazol-induced seizures after i.p. injections.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Results presented here show that the differential sensitivities of BS and BR lines to beta-CCM can be extended to diazepam, picrotoxin, and pentylenetetrazol, suggesting a genetic selection of a general sensitivity and resistance to several ligands of the GABA(A) receptor.</Disease>
<Disease>Analgesic effect of intravenous ketamine in cancer patients on morphine therapy: a randomized, controlled, double-blind, crossover, double-dose study.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pain not responsive to morphine is often problematic.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Animal and clinical studies have suggested that N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) antagonists, such as ketamine, may be effective in improving opioid analgesia in difficult pain syndromes, such as neuropathic pain.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A slow bolus of subhypnotic doses of ketamine (0.25 mg/kg or 0.50 mg/kg) was given to 10 cancer patients whose pain was unrelieved by morphine in a randomized, double-blind, crossover, double-dose study.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Pain intensity on a 0 to 10 numerical scale; nausea and vomiting, drowsiness, confusion, and dry mouth, using a scale from 0 to 3 (not at all, slight, a lot, awful); Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) (0-30); and arterial pressure were recorded before administration of drugs (T0) and after 30 minutes (T30), 60 minutes (T60), 120 minutes (T120), and 180 minutes (T180).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Ketamine, but not saline solution, significantly reduced the pain intensity in almost all the patients at both doses.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This effect was more relevant in patients treated with higher doses.</Disease>
<Disease>Hallucinations occurred in 4 patients, and an unpleasant sensation ("empty head") was also reported by 2 patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These episodes reversed after the administration of diazepam 1 mg intravenously.</Disease>
<Disease>Significant increases in drowsiness were reported in patients treated with ketamine in both groups and were more marked with ketamine 0.50 mg/kg.</Disease>
<Disease>A significant difference in MMSE was observed at T30 in patients who received 0.50 mg/kg of ketamine.</Disease>
<Disease>Ketamine can improve morphine analgesia in difficult pain syndromes, such as neuropathic pain.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, the occurrence of central adverse effects should be taken into account, especially when using higher doses.</Disease>
<Disease>This observation should be tested in studies of prolonged ketamine administration.</Disease>
<Disease>Endocrine screening in 1,022 men with erectile dysfunction: clinical significance and cost-effective strategy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>PURPOSE:</Disease>

<Disease>We reviewed the results of serum testosterone and prolactin determination in 1,022 patients referred because of erectile dysfunction and compared the data with history, results of physical examination, other etiological investigations and effects of endocrine therapy to refine the rules of cost-effective endocrine screening and to pinpoint actual responsibility for hormonal abnormalities.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>Testosterone and prolactin were determined by radioimmunoassay.</Disease>
<Disease>Every patient was screened for testosterone and 451 were screened for prolactin on the basis of low sexual desire, gynecomastia or testosterone less than 4 ng./ml.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Determination was repeated in case of abnormal first results.</Disease>
<Disease>Prolactin results were compared with those of a previous personal cohort of 1,340 patients with erectile dysfunction and systematic prolactin determination.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Main clinical criteria tested regarding efficiency in hormone determination were low sexual desire, small testes and gynecomastia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Endocrine therapy consisted of testosterone heptylate or human chorionic gonadotropin for hypogonadism and bromocriptine for hyperprolactinemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>Testosterone was less than 3 ng./ml.</Disease>
<Disease>in 107 patients but normal in 40% at repeat determination.</Disease>
<Disease>The prevalence of repeatedly low testosterone increased with age (4% before age 50 years and 9% 50 years or older).</Disease>
<Disease>Two pituitary tumors were discovered after testosterone determination.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Most of the other low testosterone levels seemed to result from nonorganic hypothalamic dysfunction because of normal serum luteinizing hormone and prolactin and to have only a small role in erectile dysfunction (definite improvement in only 16 of 44</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>[36%] after androgen therapy, normal morning or nocturnal erections in 30% and definite vasculogenic contributions in 42%).</Disease>

<Disease>Determining testosterone only in cases of low sexual desire or abnormal physical examination would have missed 40% of the cases with low testosterone, including 37% of those subsequently improved by androgen therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Prolactin exceeded 20 ng./ml.</Disease>
<Disease>in 5 men and was normal in 2 at repeat determination.</Disease>
<Disease>Only 1 prolactinoma was discovered.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These data are lower than those we found during the last 2 decades (overall prolactin greater than 20 ng./ml.</Disease>
<Disease>in 1.86% of 1,821 patients, prolactinomas in 7, 0.38%).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Bromocriptine was definitely effective in cases with prolactin greater than 35 ng./ml.</Disease>
<Disease>(8 of 12 compared to only 9 of 22 cases with prolactin between 20 and 35 ng./ml.).</Disease>
<Disease>Testosterone was low in less than 50% of cases with prolactin greater than 35 ng./ml.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Low prevalences and effects of low testosterone and high prolactin in erectile dysfunction cannot justify their routine determination.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, cost-effective screening strategies recommended so far missed 40 to 50% of cases improved with endocrine therapy and the pituitary tumors.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We now advocate that before age 50 years testosterone be determined only in cases of low sexual desire and abnormal physical examination but that it be measured in all men older than 50 years.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Prolactin should be determined only in cases of low sexual desire, gynecomastia and/or testosterone less than 4 ng./ml.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Thiopentone pretreatment for propofol injection pain in ambulatory patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This study investigated propofol injection pain in patients undergoing ambulatory anaesthesia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In a randomized, double-blind trial, 90 women were allocated to receive one of three treatments prior to induction of anaesthesia with propofol.</Disease>
<Disease>Patients in Group C received 2 ml normal saline, Group L, 2 ml, lidocaine 2% (40 mg) and Group T, 2 ml thiopentone 2.5% (50 mg).</Disease>
<Disease>Venous discomfort was assessed with a visual analogue scale (VAS) 5-15 sec after commencing propofol administration using an infusion pump (rate 1000 micrograms.kg-1.min-1).</Disease>
<Disease>Loss of consciousness occurred in 60-90 sec.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Visual analogue scores (mean +/- SD) during induction were lower in Groups L (3.3 +/- 2.5) and T (4.1 +/- 2.7) than in Group C (5.6 +/- 2.3); P = 0.0031.</Disease>
<Disease>The incidence of venous discomfort was lower in Group L (76.6%; P < 0.05) than in Group C (100%) but not different from Group T (90%).</Disease>
<Disease>The VAS scores for recall of pain in the recovery room were correlated with the VAS scores during induction (r = 0.7045; P < 0.0001).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Recovery room discharge times were similar: C (75.9 +/- 19.4 min);</Disease>
<Disease>L 73.6 +/- 21.6 min); T (77.1 +/- 18.9 min).</Disease>
<Disease>Assessing their overall satisfaction, 89.7% would choose propofol anaesthesia again.</Disease>
<Disease>We conclude that lidocaine reduces the incidence and severity of propofol injection pain in ambulatory patients whereas thiopentone only reduces its severity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Comparison of i.v. glycopyrrolate and atropine in the prevention of bradycardia and arrhythmias following repeated doses of suxamethonium in children.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The effectiveness of administration of glycopyrrolate 5 and 10 micrograms kg-1 and atropine 10 and 20 micrograms kg-1 i.v. immediately before the induction of anaesthesia, to prevent arrhythmia and bradycardia following repeated doses of suxamethonium in children, was studied.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A control group was included for comparison with the lower dose range of glycopyrrolate and atropine.</Disease>
<Disease>A frequency of bradycardia of 50% was noted in the control group, but this was not significantly different from the frequency with the active drugs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Bradycardia (defined as a decrease in heart rate to less than 50 beat min-1) was prevented when the larger dose of either active drug was used.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It is recommended that either glycopyrrolate 10 micrograms kg-1 or atropine 20 micrograms kg-1 i.v. should immediately precede induction of anaesthesia, in children, if the repeated administration of suxamethonium is anticipated.</Disease>
<Disease>Reduction in caffeine toxicity by acetaminophen.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A patient who allegedly consumed 100 tablets of an over-the-counter analgesic containing sodium acetylsalicylate, caffeine, and acetaminophen displayed no significant CNS stimulation despite the presence of 175 micrograms of caffeine per mL of serum.</Disease>

<Disease>Because salicylates have been reported to augment the stimulatory effects of caffeine on the CNS, attention was focused on the possibility that the presence of acetaminophen (52 micrograms/mL) reduced the CNS toxicity of caffeine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Studies in DBA/2J mice showed that: 1) pretreatment with acetaminophen (100 mg/kg) increased the interval between the administration of caffeine (300 to 450 mg/kg IP) and the onset of fatal convulsions by a factor of about two; and 2) pretreatment with acetaminophen (75 mg/kg) reduced the incidence of audiogenic seizures produced in the presence of caffeine (12.5 to 75 mg/kg IP).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The frequency of sound-induced seizures after 12.5 or 25 mg/kg caffeine was reduced from 50 to 5% by acetaminophen.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the absence of caffeine, acetaminophen (up to 300 mg/kg) did not modify the seizures induced by maximal electroshock and did not alter the convulsant dose of pentylenetetrezol in mice (tests performed by the Anticonvulsant Screening Project of NINCDS).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Acetaminophen (up to 150 micrograms/mL) did not retard the incorporation of radioactive adenosine into ATP in slices of rat cerebral cortex.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus the mechanism by which acetaminophen antagonizes the actions of caffeine in the CNS remains unknown.</Disease>
<Disease>Flestolol: an ultra-short-acting beta-adrenergic blocking agent.</Disease>
<Disease>Flestolol (ACC-9089) is a nonselective, competitive, ultra-short-acting beta-adrenergic blocking agent, without any intrinsic sympathomimetic activity.</Disease>
<Disease>Flestolol is metabolized by plasma esterases and has an elimination half-life of approximately 6.5 minutes.</Disease>
<Disease>This agent was well tolerated in healthy volunteers at doses up to 100 micrograms/kg/min.</Disease>
<Disease>In long-term infusion studies, flestolol was well tolerated at the effective beta-blocking dose (5 micrograms/kg/min) for up to seven days.</Disease>
<Disease>Flestolol blood concentrations increased linearly with increasing dose and good correlation exists between blood concentrations of flestolol and beta-adrenergic blockade.</Disease>
<Disease>Flestolol produced a dose-dependent attenuation of isoproterenol-induced tachycardia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Electrophysiologic and hemodynamic effects of flestolol are similar to those of other beta blockers.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast with other beta blockers, flestolol-induced effects reverse rapidly (within 30 minutes) following discontinuation because of its short half-life.</Disease>
<Disease>Flestolol effectively reduced heart rate in patients with supraventricular tachyarrhythmia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In patients with unstable angina, flestolol infusion was found to be safe and effective in controlling chest pain.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It is concluded that flestolol is a potent, well-tolerated, ultra-short-acting beta-adrenergic blocking agent.</Disease>
<Disease>Use of flestolol in the critical care setting is currently undergoing investigation.</Disease>
<Disease>Adverse effect of the calcium channel blocker nitrendipine on nephrosclerosis in rats with renovascular hypertension.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The effect of a 6-week treatment with the calcium channel blocker nitrendipine or the angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor enalapril on blood pressure, albuminuria, renal hemodynamics, and morphology of the nonclipped kidney was studied in rats with two-kidney, one clip renovascular hypertension.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Six weeks after clipping of one renal artery, hypertensive rats (178 +/- 4 mm Hg) were randomly assigned to three groups: untreated hypertensive controls (n = 8), enalapril-treated (n = 8), or nitrendipine-treated (n = 10).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Sham-operated rats served as normotensive controls (128 +/- 3 mm Hg, n = 8).</Disease>
<Disease>After 6 weeks of treatment, renal hemodynamics (glomerular filtration rate and renal plasma flow) were measured in the anesthetized rats.</Disease>
<Disease>Renal tissue was obtained for determination of glomerular size and sclerosis.</Disease>
<Disease>Enalapril but not nitrendipine reduced blood pressure significantly.</Disease>
<Disease>After 6 weeks of therapy, glomerular filtration rate was not different among the studied groups.</Disease>
<Disease>Renal plasma flow increased, but albumin excretion and glomerulosclerosis did not change after enalapril treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In contrast, in the nitrendipine-treated group albuminuria increased from 12.8 +/- 2 progressively to 163 +/- 55 compared with 19.2 +/- 9 mg/24 hr in the hypertensive controls.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Furthermore, glomerulosclerosis index was significantly increased in the nitrendipine-treated group compared with the hypertensive controls (0.38 +/- 0.1 versus 0.13 +/- 0.04).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, glomerular size was higher in the nitrendipine-treated group (14.9 +/- 0.17 10(-3) mm2) but lower in the enalapril-treated group (11.5 +/- 0.15 10(-3) mm2) compared with the hypertensive controls (12.1 +/- 0.17 10(-3)</Disease>
label: Disease

<Disease>Treatment of tinnitus by intratympanic instillation of lignocaine (lidocaine) 2 per cent through ventilation tubes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Idiopathic subjective tinnitus (IST) is one of the most obscure otological pathologies.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This paper presents the results of treating IST by intratympanic instillation of lignocaine (lidocaine) 2 per cent through a grommet, for five weekly courses.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Fifty-two patients suffering from intractable tinnitus entered this therapeutic trial, but only nine finished all five courses.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In one patient, the tinnitus was almost completely abolished, but in all the nine patients the decompensated tinnitus changed to a compensated one.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We suggest this mode of treatment for patients that were previously treated by drugs, acupuncture and biofeedback, with disappointing results.</Disease>

<Disease>Patients should be warned about the side effects of vertigo and vomiting, which subsides gradually with every new instillation, and that the tinnitus may not disappear but will be alleviated, enabling them to cope more easily with the disease and lead a more normal life.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Perhexiline maleate and peripheral neuropathy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Peripheral neuropathy has been noted as a complication of therapy with perhexiline maleate, a drug widely used in France (and in clinical trials in the United States) for the prophylactic treatment of angina pectoris.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In 24 patients with this complication, the marked slowing of motor nerve conduction velocity and the electromyographic changes imply mainly a demyelinating disorder.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Improvement was noted with cessation of therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>In a few cases the presence of active denervation signified a poor prognosis, with only slight improvement.</Disease>
<Disease>The underlying mechanism causing the neuropathy is not yet fully known, although some evidence indicates that it may be a lipid storage process.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Effect of humoral modulators of morphine-induced increase in locomotor activity of mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The effect of humoral modulators on the morphine-induced increase in locomotor activity of mice was studied.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The subcutaneous administration of 10 mg/kg of morphine-HC1 produced a marked increase in locomotor activity in mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The morphine-induced hyperactivity was potentiated by scopolamine and attenuated by physostigmine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In contrast, both methscopolamine and neostigmine, which do not penetrate the blood-brain barrier, had no effect on the hyperactivity produced by morphine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pretreatment of mice with alpha-methyltyrosine (20 mg/kg i.p., one hour), an inhibitor of tyrosine hydroxylase, significantly decreased the activity-increasing effects of morphine.</Disease>
<Disease>On the other hand, pretreatment with p-chlorophenylalamine (3 X 320 mg/kg i.p., 24 hr), a serotonin depletor, caused no significant change in the hyperactivity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The study suggests that the activity-increasing effects of morphine are mediated by the release of catecholamines from adrenergic neurons in the brain.</Disease>
<Disease>And the results are consistent with the hypothesis that morphine acts by retarding the release of acetylcholine at some central cholinergic synapses.</Disease>

<Disease>It is also suggested from collected evidence that the activity-increasing effects of morphine in mice are mediated by mechanisms different from those which mediate the activity-increasing effects of morphine in rats.</Disease>
<Disease>Mechanisms of FK 506-induced hypertension in the rat.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>-Tacrolimus (FK 506) is a powerful, widely used immunosuppressant.</Disease>
<Disease>The clinical utility of FK 506 is complicated by substantial hypertension and nephrotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To clarify the mechanisms of FK 506-induced hypertension, we studied the chronic effects of FK 506 on the synthesis of endothelin-1 (ET-1), the expression of mRNA of ET-1 and endothelin-converting enzyme-1 (ECE-1), the endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS) activity, and the expression of mRNA of eNOS and C-type natriuretic peptide (CNP) in rat blood vessels.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, the effect of the specific endothelin type A receptor antagonist FR 139317 on FK 506-induced hypertension in rats was studied.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>FK 506, 5 mg. kg-1. d-1 given for 4 weeks, elevated blood pressure from 102+/-13 to 152+/-15 mm</Disease>
<Disease>Hg and increased the synthesis of ET-1 and the levels of ET-1 mRNA in the mesenteric artery (240% and 230%, respectively).</Disease>
<Disease>Little change was observed in the expression of ECE-1 mRNA and CNP mRNA.</Disease>
<Disease>FK 506 decreased eNOS activity and the levels of eNOS mRNA in the aorta (48% and 55%, respectively).</Disease>
<Disease>The administration of FR 139317 (10 mg. kg-1. d-1) prevented FK 506-induced hypertension in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These results indicate that FK 506 may increase blood pressure not only by increasing ET-1 production but also by decreasing NO synthesis in the vasculature.</Disease>
<Disease>Suxamethonium induced prolonged apnea in a patient receiving electroconvulsive therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Suxamethonium causes prolonged apnea in patients in whom pseudocholinesterase enzyme gets deactivated by organophosphorus (OP) poisons.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Here, we present a similar incident in a severely depressed patient who received electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Prolonged apnea in our case ensued because the information about suicidal attempt by OP compound was concealed from the treating team.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The effects of the adjunctive bupropion on male sexual dysfunction induced by a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor: a double-blind placebo-controlled and randomized study.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To determine the safety and efficacy of adjunctive bupropion sustained-release (SR) on male sexual dysfunction (SD) induced by a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), as SD is a common side-effect of SSRIs and the most effective treatments have yet to be determined.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>The randomized sample consisted of 234 euthymic men who were receiving some type of SSRI.</Disease>
<Disease>The men were randomly assigned to bupropion SR (150 mg twice daily, 117) or placebo (twice daily, 117) for 12 weeks.</Disease>

<Disease>Efficacy was evaluated using the Clinical Global Impression-Sexual Function (CGI-SF; the primary outcome measure), the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF), Arizona Sexual Experience Scale (ASEX), and Erectile Dysfunction Inventory of Treatment Satisfaction (EDITS) (secondary outcome measures).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Participants were followed biweekly during study period.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>

<Disease>After 12 weeks of treatment, the mean (sd) scores for CGI-SF were significantly lower, i.e. better, in patients on bupropion SR, at 2.4 (1.2), than in the placebo group, at 3.9 (1.1) (P= 0.01).</Disease>
<Disease>Men who received bupropion had a significant increase in the total IIEF score (54.4% vs 1.2%; P= 0.003), and in the five different domains of the IIEF.</Disease>
<Disease>Total ASEX scores were significantly lower, i.e. better, among men who received bupropion than placebo, at 15.5 (4.3) vs 21.5 (4.7) (P= 0.002).</Disease>
<Disease>The EDITS scores were 67.4 (10.2) for the bupropion and 36.3 (11.7) for the placebo group (P= 0.001).</Disease>
<Disease>The ASEX score and CGI-SF score were correlated (P= 0.003).</Disease>
<Disease>In linear regression analyses the CGI-SF score was not affected significantly by the duration of SD, type of SSRI used and age.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Bupropion is an effective treatment for male SD induced by SSRIs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These results provide empirical support for conducting a further study of bupropion.</Disease>
<Disease>Lamivudine for the prevention of hepatitis B virus reactivation in hepatitis-B surface antigen (HBSAG) seropositive cancer patients undergoing cytotoxic chemotherapy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is one of the major causes of chronic liver disease worldwide.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Cancer patients who are chronic carriers of HBV have a higher hepatic complication rate while receiving cytotoxic chemotherapy (CT) and this has mainly been attributed to HBV reactivation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In this study, cancer patients who have solid and hematological malignancies with chronic HBV infection received the antiviral agent lamivudine prior and during CT compared with historical control group who did not receive lamivudine.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The objectives were to assess the efficacy of lamivudine in reducing the incidence of HBV reactivation, and diminishing morbidity and mortality during CT.</Disease>
<Disease>Two groups were compared in this study.</Disease>
<Disease>The prophylactic lamivudin group consisted of 37 patients who received prophylactic lamivudine treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>The historical controls consisted of 50 consecutive patients who underwent CT without prophylactic lamivudine.</Disease>
<Disease>They were followed up during and for 8 weeks after CT.</Disease>
<Disease>The outcomes were compared for both groups.</Disease>
<Disease>Of our control group (n= 50), 21 patients (42%) were established hepatitis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Twelve (24%) of them were evaluated as severe hepatitis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the prophylactic lamivudine group severe hepatitis were observed only in 1 patient (2.7%) of 37 patients (p < 0.006).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Comparison of the mean ALT values revealed significantly higher mean alanine aminotransferase (ALT) values in the control group than the prophylactic lamivudine group;</Disease>
<Disease>154:64 (p < 0.32).</Disease>

<Disease>Our study suggests that prophylactic lamivudine significantly decreases the incidence of HBV reactivation and overall morbidity in cancer patients during and after immunosuppressive therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Further studies are needed to determine the most appropriate nucleoside or nucleotide analogue for antiviral prophylaxis during CT and the optimal duration of administration after completion of CT.</Disease>
<Disease>Ginsenoside Rg1 restores the impairment of learning induced by chronic morphine administration in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Rg1, as a ginsenoside extracted from Panax ginseng, could ameliorate spatial learning impairment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Previous studies have demonstrated that Rg1 might be a useful agent for the prevention and treatment of the adverse effects of morphine.</Disease>
<Disease>The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of Rg1 on learning impairment by chronic morphine administration and the mechanism responsible for this effect.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Male rats were subcutaneously injected with morphine (10 mg/kg) twice a day at 12 hour intervals for 10 days, and Rg1 (30 mg/kg) was intraperitoneally injected 2 hours after the second injection of morphine once a day for 10 days.</Disease>
<Disease>Spatial learning capacity was assessed in the Morris water maze.</Disease>
<Disease>The results showed that rats treated with Morphine/Rg1 decreased escape latency and increased the time spent in platform quadrant and entering frequency.</Disease>

<Disease>By implantation of electrodes and electrophysiological recording in vivo, the results showed that Rg1 restored the long-term potentiation (LTP) impaired by morphine in both freely moving and anaesthetised rats.</Disease>

<Disease>The electrophysiological recording in vitro showed that Rg1 restored the LTP in slices from the rats treated with morphine, but not changed LTP in the slices from normal saline- or morphine/Rg1-treated rats; this restoration could be inhibited by N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist MK801.</Disease>
<Disease>We conclude that Rg1 may significantly improve the spatial learning capacity impaired by chonic morphine administration and restore the morphine-inhibited LTP.</Disease>
<Disease>This effect is NMDA receptor dependent.</Disease>
<Disease>A study on the effect of the duration of subcutaneous heparin injection on bruising and pain.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>AIM:</Disease>
<Disease>This study was carried out to determine the effect of injection duration on bruising and pain following the administration of the subcutaneous injection of heparin.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>

<Disease>Although different methods to prevent bruising and pain following the subcutaneous injection of heparin have been widely studied and described, the effect of injection duration on the occurrence of bruising and pain is little documented.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>DESIGN:</Disease>
<Disease>This study was designed as within-subject, quasi-experimental research.</Disease>
<Disease>METHOD:</Disease>
<Disease>The sample for the study consisted of 50 patients to whom subcutaneous heparin was administered.</Disease>
<Disease>Heparin was injected over 10 seconds on the right abdominal site and 30 seconds on the left abdominal site.</Disease>
<Disease>Injections areas were assessed for the presence of bruising at 48 and 72 hours after each injection.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Dimensions of the bruising on the heparin applied areas were measured using transparent millimetric measuring paper.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The visual analog scale (VAS) was used to measure pain intensity and a stop-watch was used to time the pain period.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Data were analysed using chi-square test, Mann-Whitney U, Wilcoxon signed ranks tests and correlation.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>The percentage of bruising occurrence was 64% with the injection of 10 seconds duration and 42% in the 30-second injection.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It was determined that the size of the bruising was smaller in the 30-second injection.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pain intensity and pain period were statistically significantly lower for the 30-second injection than for the 10-second injection.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>It was determined that injection duration had an effect on bruising and pain following the subcutaneous administration of heparin.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This study should be repeated on a larger sample.</Disease>
<Disease>RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE:</Disease>
<Disease>When administering subcutaneous heparin injections, it is important to extend the duration of the injection.</Disease>
<Disease>Acute reserpine and subchronic haloperidol treatments change synaptosomal brain glutamate uptake and elicit orofacial dyskinesia in rats.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Reserpine- and haloperidol-induced orofacial dyskinesia are putative animal models of tardive dyskinesia (TD) whose pathophysiology has been related to free radical generation and oxidative stress.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The effect of treatment with gum Arabic on gentamicin nephrotoxicity in rats: a preliminary study.</Disease>

Disease

<Disease>GLEPP1 receptor tyrosine phosphatase (Ptpro) in rat PAN nephrosis. A marker of acute podocyte injury.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Glomerular epithelial protein 1 (GLEPP1) is a podocyte receptor membrane protein tyrosine phosphatase located on the apical cell membrane of visceral glomerular epithelial cell and foot processes.</Disease>
<Disease>This receptor plays a role in regulating the structure and function of podocyte foot process.</Disease>

<Disease>To better understand the utility of GLEPP1 as a marker of glomerular injury, the amount and distribution of GLEPP1 protein and mRNA were examined by immunohistochemistry, Western blot and RNase protection assay in a model of podocyte injury in the rat.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Puromycin aminonucleoside nephrosis was induced by single intraperitoneal injection of puromycin aminonucleoside (PAN, 20 mg/100g BW).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Tissues were analyzed at 0, 5, 7, 11, 21, 45, 80 and 126 days after PAN injection so as to include both the acute phase of proteinuria associated with foot process effacement (days 5-11) and the chronic phase of proteinuria associated with glomerulosclerosis (days 45-126).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>At day 5, GLEPP1 protein and mRNA were reduced from the normal range (265.2 +/- 79.6 x 10(6) moles/glomerulus and 100%) to 15% of normal (41.8 +/- 4.8 x 10(6) moles/glomerulus, p < 0.005).</Disease>
<Disease>This occurred in association with an increase in urinary protein content from 1.8 +/- 1 to 99.0 +/- 61 mg/day (p < 0.001).</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast, podocalyxin did not change significantly at this time.</Disease>
<Disease>By day 11, GLEPP1 protein and mRNA had begun to return towards baseline.</Disease>

<Disease>By day 45-126, at a time when glomerular scarring was present, GLEPP1 was absent from glomerulosclerotic areas although the total glomerular content of GLEPP1 was not different from normal.</Disease>
<Disease>We conclude that GLEPP1 expression, unlike podocalyxin, reflects podocyte injury induced by PAN.</Disease>
<Disease>GLEPP1 expression may be a useful marker of podocyte injury.</Disease>

<Disease>Test conditions influence the response to a drug challenge in rodents.</Disease>

<Disease>These studies were conducted to examine the differential response to a drug challenge under varied experimental test conditions routinely employed to study drug-induced behavioral and neurophysiological responses in rodents.</Disease>

<Disease>Apomorphine, a nonselective dopamine agonist, was selected due to its biphasic behavioral effects, its ability to induce hypothermia, and to produce distinct changes to dopamine turnover in the rodent brain.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>From such experiments there is evidence that characterization and detection of apomorphine-induced activity in rodents critically depends upon the test conditions employed.</Disease>
<Disease>In rats, detection of apomorphine-induced hyperactivity was facilitated by a period of acclimatization to the test conditions.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Moreover, test conditions can impact upon other physiological responses to apomorphine such as drug-induced hypothermia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In mice, apomorphine produced qualitatively different responses under novel conditions when compared to those behaviors elicited in the home test cage.</Disease>

<Disease>By contrast, apomorphine-induced locomotion was more prominent in the novel exploratory box.</Disease>
<Disease>Dopamine turnover ratios (DOPAC:DA and HVA:DA) were found to be lower in those animals exposed to the exploratory box when compared to their home cage counterparts.</Disease>
<Disease>However, apomorphine-induced reductions in striatal dopamine turnover were detected in both novel and home cage environments.</Disease>
<Disease>The implications of these findings are discussed with particular emphasis upon conducting psychopharmacological challenge tests in rodents.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Ketanserin pretreatment reverses alfentanil-induced muscle rigidity.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Glycopyrronium requirements for antagonism of the muscarinic side effects of edrophonium.</Disease>
