text: <Disease>Reversal of central benzodiazepine effects by flumazenil after intravenous conscious sedation with diazepam and opioids: report of a double-blind multicenter study. The Flumazenil in Intravenous Conscious Sedation with Diazepam Multicenter Study Group II.</Disease>
<Disease>The efficacy and safety of a new benzodiazepine antagonist, flumazenil, were assessed in a double-blind multicenter study.</Disease>

<Disease>Flumazenil (mean dose, 0.76 mg) or placebo (mean dose, 8.9 ml) was administered intravenously to 130 and 67 patients, respectively, who had been given diazepam in conjunction with an opioid (fentanyl, meperidine, or morphine) for the induction and maintenance of intravenous conscious sedation for diagnostic or therapeutic surgical procedures.</Disease>
<Disease>The group assessable for efficacy comprised 122 patients treated with flumazenil and 64 patients given placebo.</Disease>

<Disease>After 5 minutes, 80/115 (70%) flumazenil-treated patients, compared with 21/63 (33%) placebo-treated patients, were completely awake and alert, as indicated by a score of 5 on the Observer's Assessment of Alertness/Sedation Scale.</Disease>
<Disease>Ninety-five percent of patients in each group who attained a score of 5 at the 5-minute assessment showed no loss of alertness throughout the 180-minute assessment period.</Disease>
<Disease>Flumazenil-treated patients also performed significantly better on the Finger-to-Nose Test and the recall of pictures shown at the 5-minute assessment.</Disease>
<Disease>Flumazenil was well tolerated, with no serious adverse effects reported.</Disease>
<Disease>Thirty-nine (30%) of flumazenil-treated patients, compared with 17 (25%) of placebo-treated patients had one or more drug-related adverse experiences.</Disease>
<Disease>The most common adverse effects were nausea and vomiting in the flumazenil group and nausea and injection-site pain in the placebo group.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Flumazenil was found to promptly reverse sedation induced by diazepam in the presence of opioids.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The clinically apparent occlusion may be preceded by gastrointestinal and musculoskeletal symptoms that appear to be ischemic in origin, and might serve to warn the clinician of these complications.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Previous reports of these phenomena as well as recent studies of the effect of heparin are reviewed.</Disease>
<Disease>The common factor relating thromboembolism and thrombocytopenia is heparin-induced platelet aggregation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Appropriate treatment consists of discontinuation of heparin, and anticoagulation with sodium warfarin if necessary.</Disease>
<Disease>Vascular procedures are performed as indicated.</Disease>
<Disease>Long-term prognosis for transplant-free survivors of paracetamol-induced acute liver failure.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>The prognosis for transplant-free survivors of paracetamol-induced acute liver failure remains unknown.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>AIM: To examine whether paracetamol-induced acute liver failure increases long-term mortality.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>We followed up all transplant-free survivors of paracetamol-induced acute liver injury, hospitalized in a Danish national referral centre during 1984-2004.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We compared age-specific mortality rates from 1 year post-discharge through 2008 between those in whom the liver injury led to an acute liver failure and those in whom it did not.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>We included 641 patients.</Disease>

<Disease>On average, age-specific mortality rates were slightly higher for the 101 patients whose paracetamol-induced liver injury had caused an acute liver failure (adjusted mortality rate ratio = 1.70, 95% CI 1.02-2.85), but the association was age-dependent, and no survivors of acute liver failure died of liver disease, whereas suicides were frequent in both groups.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These observations speak against long-term effects of acute liver failure.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>More likely, the elevated mortality rate ratio resulted from incomplete adjustment for the greater prevalence of substance abuse among survivors of acute liver failure.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS: Paracetamol-induced acute liver failure did not affect long-term mortality.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Clinical follow-up may be justified by the cause of the liver failure, but not by the liver failure itself.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Serotonin 6 receptor gene is associated with methamphetamine-induced psychosis in a Japanese population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND: Altered serotonergic neural transmission is hypothesized to be a susceptibility factor for psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The serotonin 6 (5-HT6) receptor is therapeutically targeted by several second generation antipsychotics, such as clozapine and olanzapine, and d-amphetamine-induced hyperactivity in rats is corrected with the use of a selective 5-HT6 receptor antagonist.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, the disrupted prepulse inhibition induced by d-amphetamine or phencyclidine was restored by 5-HT6 receptor antagonist in an animal study using rats.</Disease>

<Disease>These animal models were considered to reflect the positive symptoms of schizophrenia, and the above evidence suggests that altered 5-HT6 receptors are involved in the pathophysiology of psychotic disorders.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The symptoms of methamphetamine (METH)-induced psychosis are similar to those of paranoid type schizophrenia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Therefore, we conducted an analysis of the association of the 5-HT6 gene (HTR6) with METH-induced psychosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHOD:</Disease>

<Disease>Using five tagging SNPs (rs6693503, rs1805054, rs4912138, rs3790757 and rs9659997), we conducted a genetic association analysis of case-control samples (197 METH-induced psychosis patients and 337 controls) in the Japanese population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The age and sex of the control subjects did not differ from those of the methamphetamine dependence patients.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS: rs6693503 was associated with METH-induced psychosis patients in the allele/genotype-wise analysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Moreover, this association remained significant after Bonferroni correction.</Disease>

<Disease>In the haplotype-wise analysis, we detected an association between two markers (rs6693503 and rs1805054) and three markers (rs6693503, rs1805054 and rs4912138) in HTR6 and METH-induced psychosis patients, respectively.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>HTR6 may play an important role in the pathophysiology of METH-induced psychosis in the Japanese population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Effect of increasing intraperitoneal infusion rates on bupropion hydrochloride-induced seizures in mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>It is not known if there is a relationship between input rate and incidence of bupropion-induced seizures.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This is important, since different controlled release formulations of bupropion release the active drug at different rates.</Disease>
<Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>We investigated the effect of varying the intraperitoneal infusion rates of bupropion HCl 120 mg/kg, a known convulsive dose 50 (CD50), on the incidence and severity of bupropion-induced convulsions in the Swiss albino mice.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A total of 69 mice, approximately 7 weeks of age, and weighing 21.0 to 29.1 g were randomly assigned to bupropion HCl 120 mg/kg treatment by intraperitoneal (IP) administration in 7 groups (9 to 10 animals per group).</Disease>
<Disease>Bupropion HCl was infused through a surgically implanted IP dosing catheter with infusions in each group of 0 min, 15 min, 30 min, 60 min, 90 min, 120 min, and 240 min.</Disease>
<Disease>The number, time of onset, duration and the intensity of the convulsions or absence of convulsions were recorded.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>The results showed that IP administration of bupropion HCl 120 mg/kg by bolus injection induced convulsions in 6 out of 10 mice (60% of convulsing mice) in group 1.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Logistic regression analysis revealed that infusion time was significant (p = 0.0004; odds ratio = 0.974) and increasing the IP infusion time of bupropion HCl 120 mg/kg was associated with a 91% reduced odds of convulsions at infusion times of 15 to 90 min compared to bolus injection.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Further increase in infusion time resulted in further reduction in the odds of convulsions to 99.8% reduction at 240 min. CONCLUSION:</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In conclusion, the demonstration of an inverse relationship between infusion time of a fixed and convulsive dose of bupropion and the risk of convulsions in a prospective study is novel.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Detailed spectral profile analysis of penicillin-induced epileptiform activity in anesthetized rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Penicillin model is a widely used experimental model for epilepsy research.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the present study we aimed to portray a detailed spectral analysis of penicillin-induced epileptiform activity in comparison with basal brain activity in anesthetized Wistar rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Male Wistar rats were anesthetized with i.p. urethane and connected to an electrocorticogram setup.</Disease>

<Disease>After a short period of basal activity recording, epileptic focus was induced by injecting 400IU/2 microl penicillin-G potassium into the left lateral ventricle while the cortical activity was continuously recorded.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Basal activity, latent period and the penicillin-induced epileptiform activity periods were then analyzed using both conventional methods and spectral analysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Spectral analyses were conducted by dividing the whole spectrum into different frequency bands including delta, theta (slow and fast), alpha-sigma, beta (1 and 2) and gamma (1 and 2) bands.</Disease>

<Disease>Our results show that the most affected frequency bands were delta, theta, beta-2 and gamma-2 bands during the epileptiform activity and there were marked differences in terms of spectral densities between three investigated episodes (basal activity, latent period and epileptiform activity).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Our results may help to analyze novel data obtained using similar experimental models and the simple analysis method described here can be used in similar studies to investigate the basic neuronal mechanism of this or other types of experimental epilepsies.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>High dose dexmedetomidine as the sole sedative for pediatric MRI.</Disease>
<Disease>OBJECTIVE:</Disease>
<Disease>This large-scale retrospective review evaluates the sedation profile of dexmedetomidine.</Disease>

<Disease>AIM: To determine the hemodynamic responses, efficacy and adverse events associated with the use of high dose dexmedetomidine as the sole sedative for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) studies.</Disease>
<Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>Dexmedetomidine has been used at our institution since 2005 to provide sedation for pediatric radiological imaging studies.</Disease>
<Disease>Over time, an effective protocol utilizing high dose dexmedetomidine as the sole sedative agent has evolved.</Disease>
<Disease>METHODS/MATERIALS:</Disease>
<Disease>As part of the ongoing Quality Assurance process, data on all sedations are reviewed monthly and protocols modified as needed.</Disease>
<Disease>Data were analyzed from all 747 consecutive patients who received dexmedetomidine for MRI sedation from April 2005 to April 2007.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>Since 2005, the 10-min loading dose of our dexmedetomidine protocol increased from 2 to 3 microg.kg(-1), and the infusion rate increased from 1 to 1.5 to 2 microg.kg(-1).h(-1).</Disease>

<Disease>The current sedation protocol progressively increased the rate of successful sedation (able to complete the imaging study) when using dexmedetomidine alone from 91.8% to 97.6% (P = 0.009), reducing the requirement for adjuvant pentobarbital in the event of sedation failure with dexmedetomidine alone and decreased the mean recovery time by 10 min (P < 0.001).</Disease>

<Disease>Although dexmedetomidine sedation was associated with a 16% incidence of bradycardia, all concomitant mean arterial blood pressures were within 20% of age-adjusted normal range and oxygen saturations were 95% or higher.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION: Dexmedetomidine in high doses provides adequate sedation for pediatric MRI studies.</Disease>

<Disease>While use of high dose dexmedetomidine is associated with decreases in heart rate and blood pressure outside the established 'awake' norms, this deviation is generally within 20% of norms, and is not associated with adverse sequelae.</Disease>
<Disease>Dexmedetomidine is useful as the sole sedative for pediatric MRI.</Disease>
<Disease>Methamphetamine causes alterations in the MAP kinase-related pathways in the brains of mice that display increased aggressiveness.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Aggressive behaviors have been reported in patients who suffer from some psychiatric disorders, and are common in methamphetamine (METH) abusers.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Herein, we report that multiple (but not single) injections of METH significantly increased aggressiveness in male CD-1 mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This increase in aggressiveness was not secondary to METH-induced hyperactivity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Analysis of protein expression using antibody microarrays and Western blotting revealed differential changes in MAP kinase-related pathways after multiple and single METH injections.</Disease>
<Disease>There were statistically significant (p<0.05) decreases in MEK1, Erk2p, GSK3alpha, 14-3-3e, and MEK7 in the striata of mice after multiple injections of METH.</Disease>
<Disease>MEK1 was significantly decreased also after a single injection of METH, but to a much lesser degree than after multiple injections of METH.</Disease>
<Disease>In the frontal cortex, there was a statistically significant decrease in GSK3alpha after multiple (but not single) injections of METH.</Disease>
<Disease>These findings suggest that alterations in MAP kinase-related pathways in the prefronto-striatal circuitries might be involved in the manifestation of aggressive behaviors in mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Lamotrigine associated with exacerbation or de novo myoclonus in idiopathic generalized epilepsies.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Five patients with idiopathic generalized epilepsies (IGE) treated with lamotrigine (LTG) experienced exacerbation or de novo appearance of myoclonic jerks (MJ).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In three patients, LTG exacerbated MJ in a dose-dependent manner with early aggravation during titration.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>MJ disappeared when LTG dose was decreased by 25 to 50%.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In two patients, LTG exacerbated MJ in a delayed but more severe manner, with myoclonic status that only ceased after LTG withdrawal.</Disease>

text: <Disease>rTMS of supplementary motor area modulates therapy-induced dyskinesias in Parkinson disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The neural mechanisms and circuitry involved in levodopa-induced dyskinesia are unclear.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Using repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) over the supplementary motor area (SMA) in a group of patients with advanced Parkinson disease, the authors investigated whether modulation of SMA excitability may result in a modification of a dyskinetic state induced by continuous apomorphine infusion.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>rTMS</Disease>
<Disease>at 1 Hz was observed to markedly reduce drug-induced dyskinesias, whereas 5-Hz rTMS induced a slight but not significant increase.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Assessment of the onset and persistence of amnesia during procedural sedation with propofol.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVES:</Disease>

<Disease>To assess patients' ability to repeat and recall words presented to them while undergoing procedural sedation with propofol, and correlate their recall with their level of awareness as measured by bispectral index (BIS) monitoring.</Disease>
<Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>This was a prospective, single-intervention study of consenting adult patients undergoing procedural sedation with propofol between December 28, 2002, and October 31, 2003.</Disease>
<Disease>BIS monitoring was initiated starting 3 minutes before the procedure and continuing until the patient had regained baseline mental status.</Disease>

<Disease>At 1-minute intervals during the procedural sedation, until the patient regained baseline mental status at the end of the procedure, a word from a standardized list was read aloud, and the patient was asked to immediately repeat the word to the investigator.</Disease>
<Disease>The BIS score at the time the word was read and the patient's ability to repeat the word were recorded.</Disease>

<Disease>After the procedure, the patient was asked to state all of the words from the list that he or she could recall, and to identify the last word recalled from prior to the start of the procedure and the first word recalled from after the procedure was completed.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS: Seventy-five consenting patients were enrolled; one patient was excluded from data analysis for a protocol violation.</Disease>
<Disease>No serious adverse events were noted during the procedural sedations.</Disease>
<Disease>The mean (+/-standard deviation) time of data collection was 16.4 minutes (+/-7.1; range 5 to 34 minutes).</Disease>
<Disease>The mean initial (preprocedure)</Disease>
<Disease>BIS score was 97.1 (+/-2.3; range 92 to 99).</Disease>
<Disease>The mean lowest BIS score occurring during these procedural sedations was 66.9 (+/-14.4; range 33 to 91).</Disease>
<Disease>The mean lowest BIS score corresponding to the ability of the patient to immediately repeat words read from the list was 77.1 (95% CI = 74.3 to 80.0).</Disease>
<Disease>The mean highest BIS score corresponding to the inability to repeat words was 81.5 (95% CI = 78.1 to 84.8).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mean BIS score corresponding to the last word recalled from prior to the initiation of the sedation was 96.7 (+/-2.4; range 84 to 98).</Disease>
<Disease>The mean BIS score corresponding to the first word recalled after the procedure was completed was 91.2 (95% CI = 88.1 to 94.3).</Disease>
<Disease>All patients recalled at least one word that had been read to them during the protocol.</Disease>
<Disease>The mean lowest BIS score for any recalled word was 91.5 (+/-11.1; range 79 to 98), and no words were recalled when the corresponding BIS score was less than 90.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>There is a range of BIS scores during which sedated patients are able to repeat words read to them but are not able to subsequently recall these words.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, patients had no recall of words repeated prior to procedural sedation in BIS ranges associated with recall after procedural sedation, suggestive of retrograde amnesia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Assessment of perinatal hepatitis B and rubella prevention in New Hampshire delivery hospitals.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To evaluate current performance on recommended perinatal hepatitis B and rubella prevention practices in New Hampshire.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>Data were extracted from 2021 paired mother-infant records for the year 2000 birth cohort in New Hampshire's 25 delivery hospitals.</Disease>

<Disease>Assessment was done on the following: prenatal screening for hepatitis B and rubella, administration of the hepatitis B vaccine birth dose to all infants, administration of hepatitis B immune globulin to infants who were born to hepatitis B surface antigen-positive mothers, rubella immunity, and administration of in-hospital postpartum rubella vaccine to rubella nonimmune women.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>Prenatal screening rates for hepatitis B (98.8%) and rubella (99.4%) were high.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Hepatitis B vaccine birth dose was administered to 76.2% of all infants.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>All infants who were born to hepatitis B surface antigen-positive mothers also received hepatitis B immune globulin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Multivariate logistic regression showed that the month of delivery and infant birth weight were independent predictors of hepatitis B vaccination.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The proportion of infants who were vaccinated in January and February 2000 (48.5% and 67.5%, respectively) was less than any other months, whereas the proportion who were vaccinated in December 2000 (88.2%) was the highest.</Disease>
<Disease>Women who were born between 1971 and 1975 had the highest rate of rubella nonimmunity (9.5%).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In-hospital postpartum rubella vaccine administration was documented for 75.6% of nonimmune women.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>

<Disease>This study documents good compliance in New Hampshire's birthing hospitals with national guidelines for perinatal hepatitis B and rubella prevention and highlights potential areas for improvement.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Expression of p300 protects cardiac myocytes from apoptosis in vivo.</Disease>
<Disease>Doxorubicin is an anti-tumor agent that represses cardiac-specific gene expression and induces myocardial cell apoptosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Doxorubicin depletes cardiac p300, a transcriptional coactivator that is required for the maintenance of the differentiated phenotype of cardiac myocytes.</Disease>
<Disease>However, the role of p300 in protection against doxorubicin-induced apoptosis is unknown.</Disease>
<Disease>Transgenic mice overexpressing p300 in the heart and wild-type mice were subjected to doxorubicin treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>Compared with wild-type mice, transgenic mice exhibited higher survival rate as well as more preserved left ventricular function and cardiac expression of alpha-sarcomeric actin.</Disease>
<Disease>Doxorubicin induced myocardial cell apoptosis in wild-type mice but not in transgenic mice.</Disease>
<Disease>Expression of p300 increased the cardiac level of bcl-2 and mdm-2, but not that of p53 or other members of the bcl-2 family.</Disease>

<Disease>These findings demonstrate that overexpression of p300 protects cardiac myocytes from doxorubicin-induced apoptosis and reduces the extent of acute heart failure in adult mice in vivo.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mitochondrial DNA and its respiratory chain products are defective in doxorubicin nephrosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>Doxorubicin induces a self-perpetuating nephropathy characterized by early glomerular and late-onset tubular lesions in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We investigated the potential role of mitochondrial injury in the onset of these lesions.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>Rats were treated with intravenous doxorubicin (1 mg kg(-1) week(-1)) for 7 weeks and were sacrificed either 1 week ('short-term') or 30 weeks ('long-term') following the last dose.</Disease>
<Disease>Additional rats received a single dose either 6 days or 2 h prior to euthanasia.</Disease>
<Disease>All rats were killed at 48 weeks of age.</Disease>
<Disease>Glomerular and tubular injury was monitored and correlated to the activity or expression of respiratory chain components.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Finally, we quantified both nuclear and mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) as well as superoxide production and the 4834 base pair 'common' mtDNA deletion.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>

<Disease>The 'long-term' group had significant glomerular and tubular lesions, depressed activities of mtDNA-encoded NADH dehydrogenase and cytochrome-c oxidase (COX) and increased citrate synthase activity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, expression of the mtDNA-encoded COX subunit I was reduced and mtDNA levels were decreased.</Disease>
<Disease>In 'short-term' rats, there were fewer tubular lesions, but similar numbers of glomerular lesions activity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Among all animals, glomerular and tubular injury were inversely correlated with mtDNA levels, mtDNA-encoded respiratory chain activities and with the expression of the mtDNA-encoded respiratory chain subunit COX-I. Injury was positively correlated with superoxide production and the activities of nucleus-encoded mitochondrial or cytoplasmic enzymes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Kidneys from the 'long-term' group showed more mtDNA deletions than in 'short-term' animals and these were not observed in the other groups.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>

<Disease>These results suggest an important role for quantitative and qualitative mtDNA alterations through the reduction of mtDNA-encoded respiratory chain function and induction of superoxide in doxorubicin-induced renal lesions.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Amphotericin B-induced seizures in a patient with AIDS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To report a case of multiple episodes of seizure activity in an AIDS patent following amphotericin B infusion.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CASE SUMMARY:</Disease>

<Disease>A 46-year-old African-American man experienced recurrent grand mal seizures during intravenous infusion of amphotericin B, then petit mal seizures as the infusion was stopped and the drug concentrations decreased with time.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The patients concurrent medications included didanosine, hydroxyzine, promethazine, hydrocortisone, and prochlorperazine.</Disease>
<Disease>Despite administration of phenytoin and lorazepam, the seizures persisted and occurred only during amphotercin B administration.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>DISCUSSION:</Disease>
<Disease>AIDS and cryptococcal meningitis, both of which the patient had, can potentially cause seizures.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The patient had a history of alcohol abuse; alcohol intake as well as withdrawal can also cause seizures.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Didanosine also has a potential for inducing seizures.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, these other potential causes of seizure were ruled out.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The time course of events suggested that amphotericin B was the cause of the seizures in this AIDS patient.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS: Amphotericin B seems to be the probable cause of the seizures.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To date, only three cases of seizures associated with amphotericin B have been reported in the literature, but healthcare providers should be aware of the potential for this rare adverse effect.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Therapeutic drug monitoring of tobramycin: once-daily versus twice-daily dosage schedules.</Disease>
<Disease>OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effect of dosage regimen (once-daily vs. twice-daily) of tobramicyn on steady-state serum concentrations and toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>Patients undergoing treatment with i.v. tobramycin (4 mg/kg/day) were randomised to two groups.</Disease>
<Disease>Group OD (n = 22) received a once-daily dose of tobramycin and group TD (n = 21) received the same dose divided into two doses daily.</Disease>
<Disease>Tobramycin serum concentrations (peak and trough) were measured by enzyme multiplied immunoassay.</Disease>
<Disease>The renal and auditory functions of the patients were monitored before, during and immediately after treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>The two groups were comparable with respect to sex, age, body weight and renal function.</Disease>
<Disease>No statistically significant differences were found in mean daily dose, duration of treatment, or cumulative dose.</Disease>
<Disease>Trough concentrations were < 2 g/ml in the two groups (100%).</Disease>
<Disease>Peak concentrations were > 6 microg/ml in 100% of the OD group and in 67% of the TD group (P< 0.01).</Disease>
<Disease>Mean peak concentrations were markedly different: 11.00+/-2.89 microg/ml in OD vs. 6.53+/-1.45 microg/ml in TD (P< 0.01).</Disease>
<Disease>The pharmacokinetics parameters were: Ke, (0.15+/-0.03/h in OD vs. 0.24+/-0.06/h in TD), t1/2, (4.95+/-1.41 h in OD vs. 3.07+/-0.71 h in TD),</Disease>
<Disease>Vd (0.35+/-0.11 l/kg in OD vs. 0.33+/-0.09 l/kg in TD), Cl (0.86+/-0.29 ml/min/kg in OD vs. 1.28+/-0.33 ml/min/kg in TD).</Disease>
<Disease>Increased serum creatinine was observed in 73% of patients in OD versus 57% of patients in TD, without evidence of nephrotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In TD group, three patients developed decreased auditory function, of which one presented with an auditory loss of -30 dB, whereas in the OD group only one patient presented decreased auditory function.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>This small study suggests that a once-daily dosing regimen of tobramycin is at least as effective as and is no more and possibly less toxic than the twice-daily regimen.</Disease>
<Disease>Using a single-dose therapy, peak concentration determination is not necessary, only trough samples should be monitored to ensure levels below 2 microg/ml.</Disease>
<Disease>Chronic effects of a novel synthetic anthracycline derivative (SM-5887) on normal heart and doxorubicin-induced cardiomyopathy in beagle dogs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This study was designed to investigate the chronic cardiotoxic potential of SM-5887 and a possible deteriorating effect of SM-5887 on low-grade cardiotoxicity pre-induced by doxorubicin in beagle dogs.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the chronic treatment, beagle dogs of each sex were given intravenously once every 3 weeks, either a sublethal dose of doxorubicin (1.5 mg/kg) or SM-5887 (2.5 mg/kg).</Disease>
<Disease>The experiment was terminated 3 weeks after the ninth dosing.</Disease>

<Disease>Animals which received over six courses of doxorubicin demonstrated the electrocardiogram (ECG) changes, decrease of blood pressure and high-grade histopathological cardiomyopathy, while animals which were terminally sacrificed after the SM-5887 administration did not show any changes in ECG, blood pressure and histopathological examinations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To examine a possibly deteriorating cardiotoxic effect of SM-5887, low-grade cardiomyopathy was induced in dogs by four courses of doxorubicin (1.5 mg/kg).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Nine weeks after pre-treatment, dogs were given four courses of either doxorubicin (1.5 mg/kg) or SM-5887 (2.5 mg/kg) once every 3 weeks.</Disease>
<Disease>The low-grade cardiotoxic changes were enhanced by the additional doxorubicin treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>On the contrary, the SM-5887 treatment did not progress the grade of cardiomyopathy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In conclusion, SM-5887 does not have any potential of chronic cardiotoxicity and deteriorating effect on doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity in dogs.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Posteroventral medial pallidotomy in advanced Parkinson's disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>

<Disease>Posteroventral medial pallidotomy sometimes produces striking improvement in patients with advanced Parkinson's disease, but the studies to date have involved small numbers of patients and short-term follow-up.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS: Forty patients with Parkinson's disease underwent serial, detailed assessments both after drug withdrawal ("off" period) and while taking their optimal medical regimens ("on" period).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>All patients were examined preoperatively and 39 were examined at six months; 27 of the patients were also examined at one year, and 11 at two years.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>

<Disease>The percent improvements at six months were as follows: off-period score for overall motor function, 28 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 19 to 38 percent), with most of the improvement in the contralateral limbs; off-period score for activities of daily living, 29 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 19 to 39 percent); on-period score for contralateral dyskinesias, 82 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 72 to 91 percent); and on-period score for ipsilateral dyskinesias, 44 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 29 to 59 percent).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The improvements in dyskinesias and the total scores for off-period parkinsonism, contralateral bradykinesia, and rigidity were sustained in the 11 patients examined at two years.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The improvement in ipsilateral dyskinesias was lost after one year, and the improvements in postural stability and gait lasted only three to six months.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Approximately half the patients who had been dependent on assistance in activities of daily living in the off period before surgery became independent after surgery.</Disease>
<Disease>The complications of surgery were generally well tolerated, and there were no significant changes in the use of medication.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>In late-stage Parkinson's disease, pallidotomy significantly reduces levodopa-induced dyskinesias and off-period disability.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Much of the benefit is sustained at two years, although some improvements, such as those on the ipsilateral side and in axial symptoms, wane within the first year.</Disease>
<Disease>The on-period symptoms that are resistant to dopaminergic therapy do not respond to pallidotomy.</Disease>
<Disease>Neuropeptide-Y immunoreactivity in the pilocarpine model of temporal lobe epilepsy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Neuropeptide-Y (NPY) is expressed by granule cells and mossy fibres of the hippocampal dentate gyrus during experimental temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This expression may represent an endogenous damping mechanism since NPY has been shown to block seizure-like events following high-frequency stimulation in hippocampal slices.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The pilocarpine (PILO) model of epilepsy is characterized by an acute period of status epilepticus followed by spontaneous recurrent seizures and related brain damage.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We report peroxidase-antiperoxidase immunostaining for NPY in several brain regions in this model.</Disease>

<Disease>PILO-injected animals exhibited NPY immunoreactivity in the region of the mossy fibre terminals, in the dentate gyrus inner molecular layer and, in a few cases, within presumed granule cells.</Disease>
<Disease>NPY immunoreactivity was also dramatically changed in the entorhinal cortex, amygdala and sensorimotor areas.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, PILO injected animals exhibited a reduction in the number of NPY-immunoreactive interneurons compared with controls.</Disease>

<Disease>The results demonstrate that changes in NPY expression, including expression in the granule cells and mossy fibres and the loss of vulnerable NPY neurons, are present in the PILO model of TLE.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, the significance of this changed synthesis of NPY remains to be determined.</Disease>

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>

<Disease>Relation of perfusion defects observed with myocardial contrast echocardiography to the severity of coronary stenosis: correlation with thallium-201 single-photon emission tomography.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It has been previously shown that myocardial contrast echocardiography is a valuable technique for delineating regions of myocardial underperfusion secondary to coronary occlusion and to critical coronary stenoses in the presence of hyperemic stimulation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The aim of this study was to determine whether myocardial contrast echocardiography performed with a stable solution of sonicated albumin could detect regions of myocardial underperfusion resulting from various degrees of coronary stenosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The perfusion defect produced in 16 open chest dogs was compared with the anatomic area at risk measured by the postmortem dual-perfusion technique and with thallium-201 single-photon emission tomography (SPECT).</Disease>
<Disease>During a transient (20-s) coronary occlusion, a perfusion defect was observed with contrast echocardiography in 14 of the 15 dogs in which the occlusion was produced.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The perfusion defect correlated significantly with the anatomic area at risk (r = 0.74; p less than 0.002).</Disease>
<Disease>During dipyridamole-induced hyperemia, 12 of the 16 dogs with a partial coronary stenosis had a visible area of hypoperfusion by contrast echocardiography.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The four dogs without a perfusion defect had a stenosis that resulted in a mild (0% to 50%) reduction in dipyridamole-induced hyperemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The size of the perfusion defect during stenosis correlated significantly with the anatomic area at risk (r = 0.61; p = 0.02).</Disease>

<Disease>Thallium-201 SPECT demonstrated a perfusion defect in all 14 dogs analyzed during dipyridamole-induced hyperemia; the size of the perfusion defect correlated with the anatomic area at risk (r = 0.58; p less than 0.03) and with the perfusion defect by contrast echocardiography (r = 0.58; p less than 0.03).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, myocardial contrast echocardiography can be used to visualize and quantitate the amount of jeopardized myocardium during moderate to severe degrees of coronary stenosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The results obtained show a correlation with the anatomic area at risk similar to that obtained with thallium-201 SPECT.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Graft-versus-host disease prophylaxis with everolimus and tacrolimus is associated with a high incidence of sinusoidal obstruction syndrome and microangiopathy: results of the EVTAC trial.</Disease>

text: <Disease>A calcineurin inhibitor combined with methotrexate is the standard prophylaxis for graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).</Disease>

text: <Disease>Everolimus, a derivative of sirolimus, seems to mediate antileukemia effects.</Disease>

<Disease>We report on a combination of everolimus and tacrolimus in 24 patients (median age, 62 years) with either myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS; n = 17) or acute myeloid leukemia (AML; n = 7) undergoing intensive conditioning followed by HSCT from related (n = 4) or unrelated (n = 20) donors.</Disease>

text: <Disease>All patients engrafted, and only 1 patient experienced grade IV mucositis.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Nine patients (37%) developed acute grade II-IV GVHD, and 11 of 17 evaluable patients (64%) developed chronic extensive GVHD.</Disease>

text: <Disease>With a median follow-up of 26 months, the 2-year overall survival rate was 47%.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Effect of some convulsants on the protective activity of loreclezole and its combinations with valproate or clonazepam in amygdala-kindled rats.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>The combinations of loreclezole (2.5 mg/kg) with valproate, clonazepam, or carbamazepine (applied at their subprotective doses) also exhibited antiseizure effect in this test.</Disease>
<Disease>However, only two first combinations occurred to be of pharmacodynamic nature.</Disease>

<Disease>Among several chemoconvulsants, bicuculline, N-methyl-D-aspartic acid and BAY k-8644 (the opener of L-type calcium channels) reversed the protective activity of loreclezole alone and its combination with valproate.</Disease>
<Disease>On the other hand, bicuculline, aminophylline and BAY k-8644 inhibited the anticonvulsive action of loreclezole combined with clonazepam.</Disease>

<Disease>Acute liver failure with concurrent bupropion and carbimazole therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To report a case of fatal liver failure possibly associated with concurrent use of bupropion and carbimazole.</Disease>

text: <Disease>CASE SUMMARY:</Disease>

text: <Disease>He received a 10-day course of bupropion as an aid for smoking cessation 10 weeks prior to presentation.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Liver biopsy showed evidence of nonspecific drug-induced acute liver injury.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>His condition was further complicated by sepsis and coagulopathy.</Disease>

Disease

text: <Disease>Death resulted 19 days after the onset of symptoms.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>DISCUSSION:</Disease>

Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>

text: <Disease>Long term hormone therapy for perimenopausal and postmenopausal women.</Disease>
<Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>

<Disease>Hormone therapy (HT) is widely used for controlling menopausal symptoms and has also been used for the management and prevention of cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis and dementia in older women.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This is an updated version of the original Cochrane review first published in 2005.</Disease>
<Disease>OBJECTIVES:</Disease>
<Disease>To assess the effect of long-term HT on mortality, cardiovascular outcomes, cancer, gallbladder disease, cognition, fractures and quality of life.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>SEARCH STRATEGY:</Disease>

<Disease>We searched the following databases to November 2007: Trials Register of the Cochrane Menstrual Disorders and Subfertility Group, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, MEDLINE, EMBASE, Biological Abstracts.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Also relevant non-indexed journals and conference abstracts.</Disease>
<Disease>SELECTION CRITERIA:</Disease>
<Disease>Randomised double-blind trials of HT versus placebo, taken for at least one year by perimenopausal or postmenopausal women.</Disease>
<Disease>HT included oestrogens, with or without progestogens, via oral, transdermal, subcutaneous or transnasal routes.</Disease>
<Disease>DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two authors independently assessed trial quality and extracted data.</Disease>
<Disease>MAIN RESULTS: Nineteen trials involving 41,904 women were included.</Disease>

<Disease>In relatively healthy women, combined continuous HT significantly increased the risk of venous thrombo-embolism or coronary event (after one year's use), stroke (after three years), breast cancer and gallbladder disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Long-term oestrogen-only HT significantly increased the risk of venous thrombo-embolism, stroke and gallbladder disease (after one to two years, three years and seven years' use respectively), but did not significantly increase the risk of breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The only statistically significant benefits of HT were a decreased incidence of fractures and (for combined HT) colon cancer, with long-term use.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Among women aged over 65 who were relatively healthy (i.e. generally fit, without overt disease) and taking continuous combined HT, there was a statistically significant increase in the incidence of dementia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Among women with cardiovascular disease, long-term use of combined continuous HT significantly increased the risk of venous thrombo-embolism.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>One trial analysed subgroups of 2839 relatively healthy 50 to 59 year old women taking combined continuous HT and 1637 taking oestrogen-only HT, versus similar-sized placebo groups.</Disease>
<Disease>The only significantly increased risk reported was for venous thrombo-embolism in women taking combined continuous HT: their absolute risk remained low, at less than 1/500.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, this study was not powered to detect differences between groups of younger women.</Disease>
<Disease>AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>HT is not indicated for the routine management of chronic disease.</Disease>
<Disease>We need more evidence on the safety of HT for menopausal symptom control, though short-term use appears to be relatively safe for healthy younger women.</Disease>
<Disease>Passage of mannitol into the brain around gliomas: a potential cause of rebound phenomenon. A study on 21 patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>AIM:</Disease>
<Disease>Widespread use of mannitol to reduce brain edema and lower elevated ICP in brain tumor patients continues to be afflicted by the so-called rebound phenomenon.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Leakage of mannitol into the brain parenchyma through an altered BBB and secondary reversal of osmotic gradient is considered the major cause of rebound .</Disease>
<Disease>This has only been demonstrated experimentally in animals.</Disease>
<Disease>As a contribution to this issue we decided to research the possible passage of mannitol into the brain after administration to 21 brain tumor patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>Mannitol (18% solution; 1 g/kg) was administered as a bolus to patients (ten had malignant glioma, seven brain metastases and four meningioma) about 30 minutes before craniotomy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>During resection, a sample of the surrounding edematous white matter was taken at the same time as a 10 ml venous blood sample.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mannitol concentrations were measured in plasma and white matter by a modified version of the enzyme assay of Blonquist et al. RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>In most glioma patients, mannitol concentrations in white matter were 2 to 6 times higher than in plasma (mean 3.5 times).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In meningioma and metastases patients plasma concentrations of mannitol were higher than white matter concentrations except in three cases with infiltration by neoplastic cells.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>

<Disease>The results of our study show that even after a single bolus, mannitol may leak through the altered BBB near gliomas, reversing the initial plasma-to-blood osmotic gradient, aggravating peritumoral edema and promoting rebound of ICP.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Can lidocaine reduce succinylcholine induced postoperative myalgia?</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This study was undertaken to determine the effect of lidocaine pretreatment on reduction of succinylcholine-induced myalgia in patients undergoing general anesthesia for gynecological surgery.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One hundred and thirty-five patients were assigned to one of three groups in a prospective, double blind, randomized manner.</Disease>

<Disease>Group PS, the control group, received normal saline and succinylcholine 1.5 mg x kg(-1); Group LS, lidocaine 1.5 mg x kg(-1) and succinylcholine 1.5 mg x kg(-1); Group PR, normal saline and rocuronium 0.6 mg x kg(-1).</Disease>
<Disease>Morphine 0.1 mg x kg(-1) iv was given for premedication and all patients were monitored with a noninvasive blood pressure monitor, ECG and pulse oximetry.</Disease>
<Disease>Anesthesia was induced with 5 mg.kg(-1) thiopental iv. followed by succinylcholine (Group PS, LS) or rocuronium (Group PR) for tracheal intubation.</Disease>

<Disease>Following administration of these agents, the presence, and degree of fasciculation were assessed visually on a four point scale by one investigator who was blinded to the drug administered.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The blood pressure and heart rate of each patient were monitored on nine occasions.</Disease>

<Disease>Twenty-four hours later, any myalgia experienced was assessed according to a structured questionaire and graded by a four point scale by one investigator blinded to the intraoperative management.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The results indicate that muscle fasciculation was not found in Group PR while the patients in Group LS had a lower incidence of muscle fasciculation than those in Group PS (p < 0.001).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>At 24 h, the incidence of myalgia was higher in Group PS than in Group LS and PR (p < 0.05).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A correlation was not found between the incidence of myalgia and the occurrence of muscle fasciculation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The changes in systolic and diastolic blood pressure and heart rate were not significant among the three groups.</Disease>
<Disease>In conclusion, where succinylcholine is used, lidocaine is proven to be the useful pretreatment agent for the reduction of postoperative myalgia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Open-label assessment of levofloxacin for the treatment of acute bacterial sinusitis in adults.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>PURPOSE:</Disease>
<Disease>To evaluate the efficacy and safety of levofloxacin (500 mg orally once daily for 10 to 14 days) in treating adult outpatients with acute bacterial sinusitis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>A total of 329 patients enrolled in the study at 24 centers.</Disease>
<Disease>All patients had a pre-therapy Gram's stain and culture of sinus exudate obtained by antral puncture or nasal endoscopy.</Disease>
<Disease>Clinical response was assessed on the basis of signs and symptoms and sinus radiograph or computed tomography results.</Disease>
<Disease>Microbiologic cure rates were determined on the basis of presumed plus documented eradication of the pre-therapy pathogen(s).</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>The most common pathogens were Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Moraxella catarrhalis.</Disease>
<Disease>Of 300 clinically evaluable patients, 175 (58%) were cured and 90 (30%) were improved at the post-therapy evaluation, resulting in a clinical success rate of 88%.</Disease>
<Disease>Thirty-five patients (12%) clinically failed treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>The microbiologic eradication rate (presumed plus documented) among 138 microbiologically evaluable patients was 92%.</Disease>
<Disease>Microbiologic eradication rates (presumed plus documented) of the most common pathogens ranged from 93% (M. catarrhalis) to 100% (S. pneumoniae) at the post-therapy visit.</Disease>

<Disease>All but one of the 265 patients who were cured or improved at post-therapy returned for a long-term follow-up visit; 243 (92%) remained well 4 to 6 weeks after therapy; and 21 (8%) had a relapse of symptoms.</Disease>
<Disease>Adverse events considered to be related to levofloxacin administration were reported by 29 patients (9%).</Disease>
<Disease>The most common drug-related adverse events were diarrhea, flatulence, and nausea; most adverse events were mild to moderate in severity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>The results of this study indicate that levofloxacin 500 mg once daily is an effective and safe treatment for acute bacterial sinusitis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Clinical evaluation on combined administration of oral prostacyclin analogue beraprost and phosphodiesterase inhibitor cilostazol.</Disease>

<Disease>Among various oral antiplatelets, a combination of a novel prostacyclin analogue beraprost (BPT) and a potent phosphodiesterase inhibitor cilostazol (CLZ) may result in untoward clinical effects due to possible synergistic elevation of intracellular cAMP (cyclic adenosine 3',5'-monophosphate).</Disease>
<Disease>Thereby, a clinical study of the combined administration of the two agents was attempted.</Disease>
<Disease>Twelve healthy volunteers were assigned to take BPT/CLZ in the following schedule; BPT: 40 micrograms at day 1 and 120 micrograms t.i.d.</Disease>
<Disease>from day 7 to 14, CLZ: 200 mg t.i.d.</Disease>
<Disease>from day 3 to 14.</Disease>
<Disease>At various time intervals, physical examination and blood collection for ex vivo platelet aggregation and determination of intraplatelet cAMP were performed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Throughout the observation period, no significant alteration in vital signs was observed.</Disease>
<Disease>Seven out of 12 subjects experienced headache of a short duration accompanying facial flush in one and nausea in one, especially after ingestion of CLZ.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>All of these symptoms, probably caused by the vasodilating effect of the two agents, were of mild degree and no special treatment was required.</Disease>
<Disease>Intraplatelet cAMP content was gradually but significantly increased to 9.84 +/- 4.59 pmol per 10(9) platelets at day 14 in comparison with the initial value (6.87 +/- 2.25 pmol).</Disease>
<Disease>The platelet aggregability was significantly suppressed at various time intervals but no additive or synergistic inhibitory effect by the combined administration was noted.</Disease>

<Disease>In conclusion, the combined administration of BPT/CLZ is safe at doses used in the study, though the beneficial clinical effect of the combined administration has yet to be elucidated.</Disease>

<Disease>Gastrointestinal tolerability of etoricoxib in rheumatoid arthritis patients: results of the etoricoxib vs diclofenac sodium gastrointestinal tolerability and effectiveness trial (EDGE-II).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE:</Disease>
<Disease>A randomised, double-blind study to compare the gastrointestinal (GI) tolerability, safety and efficacy of etoricoxib and diclofenac in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>A total of 4086 patients (mean age 60.8 years) diagnosed with RA were enrolled and received etoricoxib 90 mg daily (n = 2032) or diclofenac 75 mg twice daily (n = 2054).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Use of gastroprotective agents and low-dose aspirin was allowed.</Disease>
<Disease>The prespecified primary end point consisted of the cumulative rate of patient discontinuations due to clinical and laboratory GI adverse experiences (AEs).</Disease>
<Disease>General safety was also assessed, including adjudicated thrombotic cardiovascular event data.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Efficacy was evaluated using the Patient Global Assessment of Disease Status (PGADS; 0-4 point scale).</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>Mean (SD; maximum) duration of treatment was 19.3 (10.3; 32.9) and 19.1 (10.4; 33.1) months in the etoricoxib and diclofenac groups, respectively.</Disease>

<Disease>The cumulative discontinuation rate due to GI AEs was significantly lower with etoricoxib than diclofenac (5.2 vs 8.5 events per 100 patient-years, respectively; hazard ratio 0.62 (95% CI: 0.47, 0.81; p<or=0.001)).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The incidence of discontinuations for hypertension-related and oedema-related AEs were significantly higher with etoricoxib (2.5% and 1.1% respectively) compared with diclofenac (1.5% and 0.4% respectively; p<0.001 for hypertension and p<0.01 for oedema).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Etoricoxib and diclofenac treatment resulted in similar efficacy (PGADS mean changes from baseline -0.62 vs -0.58, respectively).</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Etoricoxib 90 mg demonstrated a significantly lower risk for discontinuing treatment due to GI AEs compared with diclofenac 150 mg.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Discontinuations from renovascular AEs, although less common than discontinuations from GI AEs, were significantly higher with etoricoxib.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Placebo-level incidence of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) with quetiapine in controlled studies of patients with bipolar mania.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVES: To evaluate extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), including akathisia, with quetiapine in patients with bipolar mania.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>Data were analyzed from four similarly designed, randomized, double-blind, 3- to 12-week studies.</Disease>
<Disease>Two studies evaluated quetiapine monotherapy (up to 800 mg/day) (n = 209) versus placebo (n = 198), with lithium or haloperidol monotherapy as respective active controls.</Disease>

<Disease>Two studies evaluated quetiapine (up to 800 mg/day) in combination with a mood stabilizer (lithium or divalproex, QTP + Li/DVP) (n = 196) compared to placebo and mood stabilizer (PBO + Li/DVP) (n = 203).</Disease>
<Disease>Extrapyramidal symptoms were evaluated using the Simpson-Angus Scale (SAS), the Barnes Akathisia Rating Scale (BARS), adverse event reports and anticholinergic drug usage.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>The incidence of EPS-related adverse events, including akathisia, was no different with quetiapine monotherapy (12.9%) than with placebo (13.1%).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Similarly, EPS-related adverse events with QTP + Li/DVP (21.4%) were no different than with PBO + Li/DVP (19.2%).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Adverse events related to EPS occurred in 59.6% of patients treated with haloperidol (n = 99) monotherapy, whereas 26.5% of patients treated with lithium (n = 98) monotherapy experienced adverse events related to EPS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The incidence of akathisia was low and similar with quetiapine monotherapy (3.3%) and placebo (6.1%), and with QTP + Li/DVP (3.6%) and PBO + Li/DVP (4.9%).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Lithium was associated with a significantly higher incidence (p < 0.05) of tremor (18.4%) than quetiapine (5.6%); cerebellar tremor, which is a known adverse effect of lithium, may have contributed to the elevated rate of tremor in patients receiving lithium therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Haloperidol induced a significantly higher incidence (p < 0.001) of akathisia (33.3% versus 5.9%), tremor (30.3% versus 7.8%), and extrapyramidal syndrome (35.4% versus 5.9%) than quetiapine.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>No significant differences were observed between quetiapine and placebo on SAS and BARS scores.</Disease>
<Disease>Anticholinergic use was low and similar with quetiapine or placebo.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>In bipolar mania, the incidence of EPS, including akathisia, with quetiapine therapy is similar to that with placebo.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Contribution of the sympathetic nervous system to salt-sensitivity in lifetime captopril-treated spontaneously hypertensive rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To test the hypothesis that, in lifetime captopril-treated spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR), the sympathetic nervous system contributes importantly to the hypertensive effect of dietary sodium chloride supplementation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>Male SHR (aged 6 weeks) that had been treated from conception onward with either captopril or vehicle remained on a basal sodium chloride diet or were fed a high sodium chloride diet.</Disease>
<Disease>After 2 weeks, the rats were subjected to ganglionic blockade and 2 days later, an infusion of clonidine.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>Lifetime captopril treatment significantly lowered mean arterial pressure in both groups.</Disease>
<Disease>Intravenous infusion of the ganglionic blocker hexamethonium resulted in a rapid decline in MAP that eliminated the dietary sodium chloride-induced increase in MAP in both groups.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Infusion of the central nervous system alpha2-adrenergic receptor agonist clonidine also resulted in a greater reduction in MAP in both groups of SHR that were fed the high (compared with the basal) sodium chloride diet.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>In both lifetime captopril-treated and control SHR, the sympathetic nervous system contributes to the pressor effects of a high sodium chloride diet.</Disease>
<Disease>Dose-related beneficial and adverse effects of dietary corticosterone on organophosphorus-induced delayed neuropathy in chickens.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Tri-ortho-tolyl phosphate (TOTP), 360 mg/kg, po, and 0,0'-diisopropyl phosphorofluoridate (DFP), 1 mg/kg sc, were administered to adult White Leghorn chickens 24 hr after they were placed on diets containing 0 to 300 ppm corticosterone.</Disease>
<Disease>Supplemented diets were continued until clinical signs and lesions of delayed neuropathy appeared.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although low concentrations (less than or equal to 50 ppm) of corticosterone had beneficial effects on TOTP-induced neuropathy, greater than or equal to 200 ppm exacerbated clinical signs in chickens given either TOTP or DFP.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Neurotoxic esterase activities 24 hr after TOTP or DFP were less than 20% of values measured in chickens not given organophosphorous compounds.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Chickens given 200 ppm corticosterone without TOTP or DFP had significantly elevated activity of plasma cholinesterase and significantly inhibited activity of liver carboxylesterase.</Disease>
<Disease>Degenerating myelinated fibers were also evident in distal levels of the peripheral nerves of chickens given TOTP or DFP.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In vivo characterization of a dual adenosine A2A/A1 receptor antagonist in animal models of Parkinson's disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The in vivo characterization of a dual adenosine A(2A)/A(1) receptor antagonist in several animal models of Parkinson's disease is described.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Discovery and scale-up syntheses of compound 1 are described in detail, highlighting optimization steps that increased the overall yield of 1 from 10.0% to 30.5%.</Disease>
<Disease>Compound 1 is a potent A(2A)/A(1) receptor antagonist in vitro (A(2A) K(i) = 4.1 nM; A(1)</Disease>

<Disease>K(i) = 17.0 nM) that has excellent activity, after oral administration, across a number of animal models of Parkinson's disease including mouse and rat models of haloperidol-induced catalepsy, mouse model of reserpine-induced akinesia, rat 6-hydroxydopamine (6-OHDA) lesion model of drug-induced rotation, and MPTP-treated non-human primate model.</Disease>
