text: <Disease>An extremely rare case of delusional parasitosis in a chronic hepatitis C patient during pegylated interferon alpha-2b and ribavirin treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>During treatment of chronic hepatitis C patients with interferon and ribavirin, a lot of side effects are described.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Twenty-three percent to 44% of patients develop depression.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A minority of patients evolve to psychosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To the best of our knowledge, no cases of psychogenic parasitosis occurring during interferon therapy have been described in the literature.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We present a 49-year-old woman who developed a delusional parasitosis during treatment with pegylated interferon alpha-2b weekly and ribavirin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>She complained of seeing parasites and the larvae of fleas in her stools.</Disease>
<Disease>This could not be confirmed by any technical examination.</Disease>
<Disease>All the complaints disappeared after stopping pegylated interferon alpha-2b and reappeared after restarting it.</Disease>
<Disease>She had a complete sustained viral response.</Disease>
<Disease>Possible neuroleptic malignant syndrome related to concomitant treatment with paroxetine and alprazolam.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A 74-year-old man with depressive symptoms was admitted to a psychiatric hospital due to insomnia, loss of appetite, exhaustion, and agitation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Medical treatment was initiated at a daily dose of 20 mg paroxetine and 1.2 mg alprazolam.</Disease>
<Disease>On the 10th day of paroxetine and alprazolam treatment, the patient exhibited marked psychomotor retardation, disorientation, and severe muscle rigidity with tremors.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The patient had a fever (38.2 degrees C), fluctuating blood pressure (between 165/90 and 130/70</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>mg mm Hg), and severe extrapyramidal symptoms.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Laboratory tests showed an elevation of creatine phosphokinase (2218 IU/L), aspartate aminotransferase (134 IU/L), alanine aminotransferase (78 IU/L), and BUN (27.9 mg/ml) levels.</Disease>
<Disease>The patient received bromocriptine and diazepam to treat his symptoms.</Disease>
<Disease>7 days later, the fever disappeared and the patient's serum CPK levels were normalized (175 IU/L).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This patient presented with symptoms of neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), thus demonstrating that NMS-like symptoms can occur after combined paroxetine and alprazolam treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The adverse drug reaction score obtained by the Naranjo algorithm was 6 in our case, indicating a probable relationship between the patient's NMS-like adverse symptoms and the combined treatment used in this case.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The involvement of physiologic and environmental aspects specific to this patient was suspected.</Disease>
<Disease>Several risk factors for NMS should be noted in elderly depressive patients whose symptoms often include dehydration, agitation, malnutrition, and exhaustion.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Careful therapeutic intervention is necessary in cases involving elderly patients who suffer from depression.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pilocarpine seizures cause age-dependent impairment in auditory location discrimination.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Children who have status epilepticus have continuous or rapidly repeating seizures that may be life-threatening and may cause life-long changes in brain and behavior.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The extent to which status epilepticus causes deficits in auditory discrimination is unknown.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A naturalistic auditory location discrimination method was used to evaluate this question using an animal model of status epilepticus.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Male Sprague-Dawley rats were injected with saline on postnatal day (P) 20, or a convulsant dose of pilocarpine on P20 or P45.</Disease>

<Disease>Pilocarpine on either day induced status epilepticus; status epilepticus at P45 resulted in CA3 cell loss and spontaneous seizures, whereas P20 rats had no cell loss or spontaneous seizures.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Mature rats were trained with sound-source location and sound-silence discriminations.</Disease>
<Disease>Control (saline P20)</Disease>
<Disease>rats acquired both discriminations immediately.</Disease>
<Disease>In status epilepticus (P20) rats, acquisition of the sound-source location discrimination was moderately impaired.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Status epilepticus (P45) rats failed to acquire either sound-source location or sound-silence discriminations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Status epilepticus in rat causes an age-dependent, long-term impairment in auditory discrimination.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This impairment may explain one cause of impaired auditory location discrimination in humans.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Cardiovascular risk with cyclooxygenase inhibitors: general problem with substance specific differences?</Disease>

<Disease>Randomised clinical trials and observational studies have shown an increased risk of myocardial infarction, stroke, hypertension and heart failure during treatment with cyclooxygenase inhibitors.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Adverse cardiovascular effects occurred mainly, but not exclusively, in patients with concomitant risk factors.</Disease>
<Disease>Cyclooxygenase inhibitors cause complex changes in renal, vascular and cardiac prostanoid profiles thereby increasing vascular resistance and fluid retention.</Disease>
<Disease>The incidence of cardiovascular adverse events tends to increase with the daily dose and total exposure time.</Disease>

<Disease>A comparison of individual selective and unselective cyclooxygenase inhibitors suggests substance-specific differences, which may depend on differences in pharmacokinetic parameters or inhibitory potency and may be contributed by prostaglandin-independent effects.</Disease>

<Disease>Diagnostic markers such as N-terminal pro brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) or high-sensitive C-reactive protein might help in the early identification of patients at risk, thus avoiding the occurrence of serious cardiovascular toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Predictors of decreased renal function in patients with heart failure during angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor therapy: results from the studies of left ventricular dysfunction (SOLVD)</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>Although angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor therapy reduces mortality rates in patients with congestive heart failure (CHF), it may also cause decreased renal function.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Little information is available to predict which patients are at highest risk for this complication.</Disease>
<Disease>OBJECTIVE:</Disease>
<Disease>To quantify specific clinical predictors of reduction in renal function in patients with CHF who are prescribed angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHOD:</Disease>
<Disease>We analyzed data from the Studies of Left Ventricular Dysfunction (SOLVD), a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of enalapril for the treatment of CHF.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>There were 3379 patients randomly assigned to enalapril with a median follow-up of 974 days and 3379 patients randomly assigned to placebo with a mean follow-up of 967 days.</Disease>
<Disease>Decreased renal function was defined as a rise in serum creatinine >/=0.5</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>mg/dL (44 micromol/L) from baseline.</Disease>

<Disease>We used time-to-event analysis to identify potential predictors of decrease in renal function including age, baseline ejection fraction, baseline creatinine, low systolic blood pressure (<100 mm Hg), history of hypertension, diabetes, and use of antiplatelet, diuretic, and beta-blocker therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>Patients randomly assigned to enalapril had a 33% greater likelihood of decreased renal function than controls (P =.003).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>By multivariate analysis, in both the placebo and enalapril groups older age, diuretic therapy, and diabetes were associated with decreased renal function, whereas beta-blocker therapy and higher ejection fraction were renoprotective.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Older age was associated with a greater risk of developing decreased renal function in both groups, but significantly more so in the enalapril group (enalapril: risk ratio [RR] 1.42 per 10 years, 95% confidence interval</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>[CI] 1.32-1.52 with enalapril; placebo: RR 1.18, 95% CI 1.12-1.25).</Disease>

<Disease>Diuretic therapy was likewise associated with a greater risk of decreased renal function in the enalapril group (RR 1.89, 95% CI 1.70-2.08) than in the placebo group (RR 1.35, 95% CI 1.09-1.66).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Conversely, enalapril had a relative renoprotective effect (RR 1.33, 95% CI 1.13-1.53) compared with placebo (RR 1.96, 95% CI 1.57-2.44) in patients with diabetes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A lower risk of renal impairment was seen in both groups with beta-blocker therapy (RR 0.70, 95% CI 0.57-0.85) and higher baseline ejection fraction (RR 0.93 per 5% increment, 95% CI 0.91-0. 96).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Enalapril use caused a 33% increase in the risk of decreased renal function in patients with CHF.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Diuretic use and advanced age increased this risk.</Disease>
<Disease>Diabetes was associated with an increased risk of renal impairment in all patients with CHF, but this risk was reduced in the enalapril group compared with the placebo group.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>beta-Blocker therapy and higher ejection fraction were renoprotective in all patients regardless of therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>Pemoline induced acute choreoathetosis: case report and review of the literature.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>Pemoline is an oxazolidine derivative that is structurally different from amphetamines and used in the treatment of attention deficit disorder.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pemoline has not been commonly associated in the literature as a cause of acute movement disorders.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The following case describes two children acutely poisoned with pemoline who experienced profound choreoathetosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CASE REPORT: Two, 3-year-old male, identical twin siblings presented to the emergency department after found playing with a an empty bottle of pemoline originally containing 59 tablets.</Disease>
<Disease>The children had a medical history significant for attention deficit disorder previously treated with methylphenidate without success.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This was their first day of pemoline therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>The choreoathetoid movements began 45 min to 1 h after ingestion.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The children gave no history of prior movement disorders and there was no family history of movement disorders.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The children received gastrointestinal decontamination and high doses of intravenous benzodiazepines in an attempt to control the choreoathetoid movements.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Despite treatment, the children continued to have choreoathetosis for approximately 24 hours.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Forty-eight hours after admission, the children appeared to be at their baseline and were discharged home.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Pemoline associated movement disorder has been rarely reported in the acute toxicology literature.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The possibility of choreoathetoid movements should be considered in patients presenting after pemoline overdose.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Continuous subcutaneous administration of mesna to prevent ifosfamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Hemorrhagic cystitis is a major potential toxicity of ifosfamide that can be prevented by administering mesna along with the cytotoxic agent.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Mesna is generally administered by the intravenous route, although experience with oral delivery of the drug has increased.</Disease>
<Disease>The continuous subcutaneous administration of mesna has the advantage of not requiring intravenous access.</Disease>

<Disease>In addition, subcutaneous delivery of the neutralizing agent will not be associated with the risk of inadequate urinary mesna concentrations, such as in a patient taking oral mesna who experiences severe ifosfamide-induced emesis and is unable to absorb the drug.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Limited clinical experience with continuous subcutaneous mesna administration suggests it is a safe, practical, and economic method of drug delivery that permits ifosfamide to be administered successfully in the outpatient setting.</Disease>
<Disease>Modification of drug action by hyperammonemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pretreatment with ammonium acetate (NH4Ac) (6 mmol/kg s.c.) approximately doubled the time morphine-treated mice remained on a hot surface and similarly increased muscular incoordination by diazepam, but NH4Ac treatment alone had no effect.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, hyperammonemia is capable of altering drug action and must be considered along with impaired drug metabolism in enhanced drug responses associated with liver disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Experiments in vitro showed that acetylcholine-induced catecholamine release from bovine adrenal medulla is depressed as much as 50% by 0.3 mM NH4Ac and KCl-induced contractions of guinea-pig ileum were inhibited 20% by 5 mM NH4Ac.</Disease>
<Disease>Addition of excess calcium reversed the depression in both tissues, but calcium-independent catecholamine release by acetaldehyde was not blocked by NH4Ac.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These results suggested that ammonia blocks calcium channels.</Disease>
<Disease>Parallels in the actions of NH4Ac and the calcium channel blocker verapamil support this concept.</Disease>

<Disease>Both verapamil (10 mg/kg i.p.) and NH4Ac pretreatment enhanced morphine analgesia- and diazepam-induced muscular incoordination and antagonized amphetamine-induced motor activity, and neither verapamil nor NH4Ac affected the convulsant action of metrazol.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The data suggest that hyperammonemia exerts a calcium channel blocking action which enhances the effects of central nervous system depressants and certain opioid analgesics.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Risk of nephropathy after consumption of nonionic contrast media by children undergoing cardiac angiography: a prospective study.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Despite increasing reports on nonionic contrast media-induced nephropathy (CIN) in hospitalized adult patients during cardiac procedures, the studies in pediatrics are limited, with even less focus on possible predisposing factors and preventive measures for patients undergoing cardiac angiography.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This prospective study determined the incidence of CIN for two nonionic contrast media (CM), iopromide and iohexol, among 80 patients younger than 18 years and compared the rates for this complication in relation to the type and dosage of CM and the presence of cyanosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The 80 patients in the study consecutively received either iopromide (group A, n = 40) or iohexol (group B, n = 40).</Disease>
<Disease>Serum sodium (Na), potassium (K), and creatinine (Cr) were measured 24 h before angiography as baseline values, then measured again at 12-, 24-, and 48-h intervals after CM use.</Disease>
<Disease>Urine samples for Na and Cr also were checked at the same intervals.</Disease>

<Disease>Risk of renal failure, Injury to the kidney, Failure of kidney function, Loss of kidney function, and End-stage renal damage (RIFLE criteria) were used to define CIN and its incidence in the study population.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Accordingly, among the 15 CIN patients (18.75%), 7.5% of the patients in group A had increased risk and 3.75% had renal injury, whereas 5% of group B had increased risk and 2.5% had renal injury.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Whereas 33.3% of the patients with CIN were among those who received the proper dosage of CM, the percentage increased to 66.6% among those who received larger doses, with a significant difference in the incidence of CIN related to the different dosages of CM (p = 0.014).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Among the 15 patients with CIN, 6 had cyanotic congenital heart diseases, but the incidence did not differ significantly from that for the noncyanotic patients (p = 0.243).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Although clinically silent, CIN is not rare in pediatrics.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The incidence depends on dosage but not on the type of consumed nonionic CM, nor on the presence of cyanosis, and although CIN usually is reversible, more concern is needed for the prevention of such a complication in children.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A case of ventricular tachycardia related to caffeine pretreatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Suboptimal seizure duration is commonly encountered in electroconvulsive therapy practice, especially in older patients with higher seizure thresholds.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Intravenous caffeine is commonly used to improve seizure duration and quality in such patients and is generally well tolerated aside from occasional reports of relatively benign ventricular ectopy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We describe a patient with no previous history of cardiac disease or arrhythmia who developed sustained bigeminy and 2 brief runs of ventricular tachycardia after caffeine administration.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Although intravenous caffeine is generally well tolerated, the clinician should be aware of the potential for unpredictable and serious ventricular arrhythmias.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Optical coherence tomography can measure axonal loss in patients with ethambutol-induced optic neuropathy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>PURPOSE:</Disease>
<Disease>To map and identify the pattern, in vivo, of axonal degeneration in ethambutol-induced optic neuropathy using optical coherence tomography (OCT).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Ethambutol is an antimycobacterial agent often used to treat tuberculosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A serious complication of ethambutol is an optic neuropathy that impairs visual acuity, contrast sensitivity, and color vision.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, early on, when the toxic optic neuropathy is mild and partly reversible, the funduscopic findings are often subtle and easy to miss.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>Three subjects with a history of ethambutol (EMB)-induced optic neuropathy of short-, intermediate-, and long-term visual deficits were administered a full neuro-ophthalmologic examination including visual acuity, color vision, contrast sensitivity, and fundus examination.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, OCT (OCT 3000, Humphrey-Zeiss, Dublin, CA) was performed on both eyes of each subject using the retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL) analysis protocol.</Disease>
<Disease>OCT interpolates data from 100 points around the optic nerve to effectively map out the RNFL.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>The results were compared to the calculated average RNFL of normal eyes accumulated from four prior studies using OCT, n=661.</Disease>

<Disease>In all subjects with history of EMB-induced optic neuropathy, there was a mean loss of 72% nerve fiber layer thickness in the temporal quadrant (patient A, with eventual recovery of visual acuity and fields, 58% loss; patient B, with intermediate visual deficits, 68% loss; patient C, with chronic visual deficits, 90% loss), with an average mean optic nerve thickness of 26+/-16 microm.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>There was a combined mean loss of 46% of fibers from the superior, inferior, and nasal quadrants in the (six) eyes of all three subjects (mean average thickness of 55+/-29 microm).</Disease>
<Disease>In both sets (four) of eyes of the subjects with persistent visual deficits (patients B and C), there was an average loss of 79% of nerve fiber thickness in the temporal quadrant.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>The OCT results in these patients with EMB-induced optic neuropathy show considerable loss especially of the temporal fibers.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This is consistent with prior histopathological studies that show predominant loss of parvo-cellular axons (or small-caliber axons) within the papillo-macular bundle in toxic or hereditary optic neuropathies.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OCT can be a valuable tool in the quantitative analysis of optic neuropathies.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Additionally, in terms of management of EMB-induced optic neuropathy, it is important to properly manage ethambutol dosing in patients with renal impairment and to achieve proper transition to a maintenance dose once an appropriate loading dose has been reached.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Effects of the cyclooxygenase-2 specific inhibitor valdecoxib versus nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents and placebo on cardiovascular thrombotic events in patients with arthritis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>There have been concerns that the risk of cardiovascular thrombotic events may be higher with cyclooxygenase (COX)-2-specific inhibitors than nonselective nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We evaluated cardiovascular event data for valdecoxib, a new COX-2-specific inhibitor in approximately 8000 patients with osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis treated with this agent in randomized clinical trials.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The incidence of cardiovascular thrombotic events (cardiac, cerebrovascular and peripheral vascular, or arterial thrombotic) was determined by analyzing pooled valdecoxib (10-80 mg daily), nonselective NSAID (diclofenac 75 mg bid, ibuprofen 800 mg tid, or naproxen 500 mg bid) and placebo data from 10 randomized osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis trials that were 6-52 weeks in duration.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The incidence rates of events were determined in all patients (n = 7934) and in users of low-dose (< or =325 mg daily) aspirin (n = 1051) and nonusers of aspirin (n = 6883).</Disease>
<Disease>Crude and exposure-adjusted incidences of thrombotic events were similar for valdecoxib, NSAIDs, and placebo.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The risk of serious thrombotic events was also similar for each valdecoxib dose.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thrombotic risk was consistently higher for users of aspirin users than nonusers of aspirin (placebo, 1.4% vs. 0%; valdecoxib, 1.7% vs. 0.2%; NSAIDs, 1.9% vs. 0.5%).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The rates of events in users of aspirin were similar for all 3 treatment groups and across valdecoxib doses.</Disease>

<Disease>Short- and intermediate-term treatment with therapeutic (10 or 20 mg daily) and supratherapeutic (40 or 80 mg daily) valdecoxib doses was not associated with an increased incidence of thrombotic events relative to nonselective NSAIDs or placebo in osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis patients in controlled clinical trials.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A randomized, placebo-controlled, crossover study of ephedrine for SSRI-induced female sexual dysfunction.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The objective of this study was to determine whether ephedrine, an alpha- and beta-adrenergic agonist previously shown to enhance genital blood flow in women, has beneficial effects in reversing antidepressant-induced sexual dysfunction.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Nineteen sexually dysfunctional women receiving either fluoxetine, sertraline, or paroxetine participated in an eight-week, double-blind, placebo-controlled, cross-over study of the effects of ephedrine (50 mg) on self-report measures of sexual desire, arousal, orgasm, and sexual satisfaction.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although there were significant improvements relative to baseline in sexual desire and orgasm intensity/pleasure on 50 mg ephedrine 1-hr prior to sexual activity, significant improvements in these measures, as well as in sexual arousal and orgasmic ability also were noted with placebo.</Disease>
<Disease>These findings highlight the importance of conducting placebo-controlled trials for this condition.</Disease>
<Disease>Erectile dysfunction occurs following substantia nigra lesions in the rat.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Erectile function was assessed 6 weeks following uni- and bilateral injections of 6-hydroxydopamine in the substantia nigra nucleus of the brain.</Disease>
<Disease>Behavioral apomorphine-induced penile erections were reduced (5/8) and increased (3/8) in uni- and bilateral lesioned animals.</Disease>
<Disease>Intracavernous pressures, following electrical stimulation of the cavernous nerve, decreased in lesioned animals.</Disease>
<Disease>Lesions of the substantia nigra were confirmed by histology.</Disease>
<Disease>Concentration of dopamine and its metabolites were decreased in the striatum of substantia nigra lesioned rats.</Disease>
<Disease>Lesions of the substantia nigra are therefore associated with erectile dysfunction in rats and may serve as a model to study erectile dysfunction in Parkinson's disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Potential therapeutic use of the selective dopamine D1 receptor agonist, A-86929: an acute study in parkinsonian levodopa-primed monkeys.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The clinical utility of dopamine (DA) D1 receptor agonists in the treatment of Parkinson's disease (PD) is still unclear.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The therapeutic use of selective DA D1 receptor agonists such as SKF-82958 (6-chloro-7,8-dihydroxy-3-allyl-1-phenyl-2,3,4,5-tetrahydro-1H-3-benzaze pine hydrobromide) and A-77636 ([1R, 3S]</Disease>

<Disease>3-[1'-admantyl]-1-aminomethyl-3,4-dihydro-5,6-dihydroxy-1H-2-benzo pyran hydrochloride) seems limited because of their duration of action, which is too short for SKF-82958 (< 1 hr) and too long for A-77636 (> 20 hr, leading to behavioral tolerance).</Disease>

<Disease>We therefore conducted the present acute dose-response study in four 1-methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine (MPTP)-exposed cynomolgus monkeys primed to exhibit levodopa-induced dyskinesias to evaluate the locomotor and dyskinetic effects on challenge with four doses (from 0.03 to 1.0 mg/kg) of A-86929 ([-]-[5aR,11bS]-4,5,5a,6,7,11b-hexahydro-2-propyl-3-thia-5-+ ++azacyclopent-1- ena[c]phenathrene-9-10-diol), a selective and full DA D1-like receptor agonist with an intermediate duration of action.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Levodopa and the DA D2-like receptor agonist, LY-171555 ([4aR-trans]-4,4a,5,6,7,8,8a,9-o-dihydro-5n-propyl-2H-pyrazo lo-3-4-quinoline hydrochloride) were also used for comparison.</Disease>

<Disease>Acute administration of A-86929 was as efficacious in alleviating MPTP-induced parkinsonism as levodopa and LY-171555, but was less likely to reproduce the levodopa-induced dyskinesias in these animals than with either LY-171555 or subsequent challenge of levodopa.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Selective stimulation of the DA D1 receptor may provide better integration of neural inputs transmitted to the internal segment of the globus pallidus (referred to as the basal ganglia output) compared with levodopa and selective DA D2 receptor agonist.</Disease>

<Disease>Potent DA D1 receptor agents with an intermediate duration of efficacy such as A-86929 (approximately 4 hr at higher doses tested) are potential therapeutic tools in PD and merit further attention.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Deaths from local anesthetic-induced convulsions in mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Median convulsant (CD50) and median lethal (LD50) doses of three representative local anesthetics were determined in adult mice to evaluate the threat to life of local anesthetic-induced convulsions.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The CD50 and LD50, respectively, were 57.7 and 58.7 mg/kg for bupivacaine, 111.0 and 133.1 mg/kg for lidocaine, and 243.4 and 266.5 mg/kg for chloroprocaine.</Disease>
<Disease>When given intraperitoneally, bupivacaine thus was only about twice as toxic as lidocaine and four times as toxic as chloroprocaine.</Disease>
<Disease>Convulsions always preceded death, except after precipitous cardiopulmonary arrest from extreme doses.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A CD50 dose of local anesthetic (causing convulsions in 50% of mice) was fatal in 90% of bupivacaine-induced seizures, in 57% of the chloroprocaine group, and in 6% of the lidocaine group.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The narrow gap between convulsant and lethal doses of local anesthetics indicates that untreated convulsions present much more of a threat to life than heretofore appreciated.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Myoclonic, atonic, and absence seizures following institution of carbamazepine therapy in children.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Five children, aged 3 to 11 years, treated with carbamazepine for epilepsy, had an acute aberrant reaction characterized by the onset of myoclonic, atypical absence and/or atonic (minor motor) seizures within a few days.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>When the carbamazepine was discontinued, two of the children returned to their former state very quickly, two had the minor motor seizures resolve in 3 and 6 months, and one had the seizures persist.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The child in whom the seizures persisted was later found to have ceroid lipofuscinosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The other children are doing well on other anticonvulsants.</Disease>
<Disease>Naloxone reversal of hypotension due to captopril overdose.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The hemodynamic effects of captopril and other angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors may be mediated by the endogenous opioid system.</Disease>
<Disease>The opioid antagonist naloxone has been shown to block or reverse the hypotensive actions of captopril.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report a case of an intentional captopril overdose, manifested by marked hypotension, that resolved promptly with the administration of naloxone.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of captopril-induced hypotension treated with naloxone.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our experience demonstrates a possible role of naloxone in the reversal of hypotension resulting from captopril.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Carbamazepine-induced cardiac dysfunction. Characterization of two distinct clinical syndromes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A patient with sinus bradycardia and atrioventricular block, induced by carbamazepine, prompted an extensive literature review of all previously reported cases.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>From the analysis of these cases, two distinct forms of carbamazepine-associated cardiac dysfunction emerged.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One patient group developed sinus tachycardias in the setting of a massive carbamazepine overdose.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The second group consisted almost exclusively of elderly women who developed potentially life-threatening bradyarrhythmias or atrioventricular conduction delay, associated with either therapeutic or modestly elevated carbamazepine serum levels.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Because carbamazepine is widely used in the treatment of many neurologic and psychiatric conditions, the recognition of the latter syndrome has important implications for the use of this drug in elderly patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Glutamatergic neurotransmission mediated by NMDA receptors in the inferior colliculus can modulate haloperidol-induced catalepsy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The inferior colliculus (IC) is primarily involved in the processing of auditory information, but it is distinguished from other auditory nuclei in the brainstem by its connections with structures of the motor system.</Disease>

<Disease>Functional evidence relating the IC to motor behavior derives from experiments showing that activation of the IC by electrical stimulation or excitatory amino acid microinjection causes freezing, escape-like behavior, and immobility.</Disease>
<Disease>However, the nature of this immobility is still unclear.</Disease>

<Disease>The present study examined the influence of excitatory amino acid-mediated mechanisms in the IC on the catalepsy induced by the dopamine receptor blocker haloperidol administered systemically (1 or 0.5 mg/kg) in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Haloperidol-induced catalepsy was challenged with prior intracollicular microinjections of glutamate NMDA receptor antagonists, MK-801 (15 or 30 mmol/0.5 microl) and AP7 (10 or 20 nmol/0.5 microl), or of the NMDA receptor agonist N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA, 20 or 30 nmol/0.5 microl).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The results showed that intracollicular microinjection of MK-801 and AP7 previous to systemic injections of haloperidol significantly attenuated the catalepsy, as indicated by a reduced latency to step down from a horizontal bar.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Accordingly, intracollicular microinjection of NMDA increased the latency to step down the bar.</Disease>

<Disease>These findings suggest that glutamate-mediated mechanisms in the neural circuits at the IC level influence haloperidol-induced catalepsy and participate in the regulation of motor activity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Metabotropic glutamate 7 receptor subtype modulates motor symptoms in rodent models of Parkinson's disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Metabotropic glutamate (mGlu) receptors modulate synaptic transmission in the central nervous system and represent promising therapeutic targets for symptomatic treatment of Parkinson's disease (PD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Among the eight mGlu receptor subtypes, mGlu7 receptor is prominently expressed in the basal ganglia, but its role in restoring motor function in animal models of PD is not known.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The effects of N,N'-dibenzhydrylethane-1,2-diamine dihydrochloride (AMN082), the first selective allosteric activator of mGlu7 receptors, were thus tested in different rodent models of PD.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Here, we show that oral (5 mg/kg) or intrastriatal administration (0.1 and 0.5 nmol) of AMN082 reverses haloperidol-induced catalepsy in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>AMN082 (2.5 and 5 mg/kg) reduces apomorphine-induced rotations in unilateral 6-hydroxydopamine (6-OHDA)-lesioned rats.</Disease>

<Disease>In a more complex task commonly used to evaluate major akinetic symptoms of PD patients, 5 mg/kg AMN082 reverses the increased reaction time to respond to a cue of bilateral 6-OHDA-lesioned rats.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, AMN082 reduces the duration of haloperidol-induced catalepsy in a mGlu7 receptor-dependent manner in wild-type but not mGlu7 receptor knockout mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Higher doses of AMN082 (10 and 20 mg/kg p.o.) have no effect on the same models of PD.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Overall these findings suggest that mGlu7 receptor activation can reverse motor dysfunction associated with reduced dopamine activity.</Disease>
<Disease>Selective ligands of mGlu7 receptor subtypes may thus be considered as promising compounds for the development of antiparkinsonian therapeutic strategies.</Disease>
<Disease>Nimodipine prevents memory impairment caused by nitroglycerin-induced hypotension in adult mice.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND: Hypotension and a resultant decrease in cerebral blood flow have been implicated in the development of cognitive dysfunction.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We tested the hypothesis that nimodipine (NIMO) administered at the onset of nitroglycerin (NTG)-induced hypotension would preserve long-term associative memory.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>The passive avoidance (PA) paradigm was used to assess memory retention.</Disease>
<Disease>For PA training, latencies (seconds) were recorded for entry from a suspended platform into a Plexiglas tube where a shock was automatically delivered.</Disease>
<Disease>Latencies were recorded 48 h later for a testing trial.</Disease>

<Disease>Ninety-six Swiss-Webster mice (30-35 g, 6-8 wk), were randomized into 6 groups 1) saline (control), 2) NTG immediately after learning, 3) NTG 3 h after learning, 4) NTG and NIMO, 5) vehicle, and 6) NIMO alone.</Disease>
<Disease>The extent of hypotension and changes in brain tissue oxygenation (PbtO(2)) and in cerebral blood flow were studied in a separate group of animals.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS: All groups exhibited similar training latencies (17.0 +/- 4.6 s).</Disease>

<Disease>Mice subjected to hypotensive episodes showed a significant decrease in latency time (178 +/- 156 s) compared with those injected with saline, NTG + NIMO, or delayed NTG (580 +/- 81 s, 557 +/- 67 s, and 493 +/- 146 s, respectively).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A Kruskal-Wallis 1-way analysis of variance indicated a significant difference among the 4 treatment groups (H = 15.34; P < 0.001).</Disease>

<Disease>In a separate group of mice not subjected to behavioral studies, the same dose of NTG (n = 3) and NTG + NIMO (n = 3) caused mean arterial blood pressure to decrease from 85.9 +/- 3.8 mm Hg sem to 31.6 +/- 0.8 mm</Disease>
<Disease>Hg sem and from 86.2 +/-</Disease>
<Disease>3.7 mm</Disease>
<Disease>Hg sem to 32.6 +/- 0.2</Disease>
<Disease>mm</Disease>
<Disease>Hg sem, respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>Mean arterial blood pressure in mice treated with NIMO alone decreased from 88.1 +/- 3.8 mm</Disease>
<Disease>Hg to 80.0 +/- 2.9 mm Hg.</Disease>
<Disease>The intergroup difference was statistically significant (P < 0.05).</Disease>
<Disease>PbtO(2) decreased from 51.7 +/- 4.5 mm Hg sem to 33.8 +/- 5.2 mm</Disease>
<Disease>Hg sem in the NTG group and from 38.6 +/- 6.1 mm Hg sem to 25.4 +/- 2.0 mm Hg sem in the NTG + NIMO groups, respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>There were no significant differences among groups.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>

<Disease>In a PA retention paradigm, the injection of NTG immediately after learning produced a significant impairment of long-term associative memory in mice, whereas delayed induced hypotension had no effect.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>NIMO attenuated the disruption in consolidation of long-term memory caused by NTG but did not improve latency in the absence of hypotension.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The observed effect of NIMO may have been attributable to the preservation of calcium homeostasis during hypotension, because there were no differences in the PbtO(2) indices among groups.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Fatal haemopericardium and gastrointestinal haemorrhage due to possible interaction of cranberry juice with warfarin.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We report a case of fatal internal haemorrhage in an elderly man who consumed only cranberry juice for two weeks while maintaining his usual dosage of warfarin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We propose that naturally occurring compounds such as flavonoids, which are present in fruit juices, may increase the potency of warfarin by competing for the enzymes that normally inactivate warfarin.</Disease>
<Disease>While traditionally regarded as foodstuffs, consumption of fruit juices should be considered when patients develop adverse drug reactions.</Disease>
<Disease>Isoproterenol induces primary loss of dystrophin in rat hearts: correlation with myocardial injury.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mechanism of isoproterenol-induced myocardial damage is unknown, but a mismatch of oxygen supply vs. demand following coronary hypotension and myocardial hyperactivity is the best explanation for the complex morphological alterations observed.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Severe alterations in the structural integrity of the sarcolemma of cardiomyocytes have been demonstrated to be caused by isoproterenol.</Disease>

<Disease>Taking into account that the sarcolemmal integrity is stabilized by the dystrophin-glycoprotein complex (DGC) that connects actin and laminin in contractile machinery and extracellular matrix and by integrins, this study tests the hypothesis that isoproterenol affects sarcolemmal stability through changes in the DGC and integrins.</Disease>
<Disease>We found different sensitivity of the DGC and integrin to isoproterenol subcutaneous administration.</Disease>
<Disease>Immunofluorescent staining revealed that dystrophin is the most sensitive among the structures connecting the actin in the cardiomyocyte cytoskeleton and the extracellular matrix.</Disease>
<Disease>The sarcomeric actin dissolution occurred after the reduction or loss of dystrophin.</Disease>

<Disease>Subsequently, after lysis of myofilaments, gamma-sarcoglycan, beta-dystroglycan, beta1-integrin, and laminin alpha-2 expressions were reduced followed by their breakdown, as epiphenomena of the myocytolytic process.</Disease>

<Disease>In conclusion, administration of isoproterenol to rats results in primary loss of dystrophin, the most sensitive among the structural proteins that form the DGC that connects the extracellular matrix and the cytoskeleton in cardiomyocyte.</Disease>

<Disease>These changes, related to ischaemic injury, explain the severe alterations in the structural integrity of the sarcolemma of cardiomyocytes and hence severe and irreversible injury induced by isoproterenol.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>High fat diet-fed obese rats are highly sensitive to doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Often, chemotherapy by doxorubicin (Adriamycin) is limited due to life threatening cardiotoxicity in patients during and posttherapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Recently, we have shown that moderate diet restriction remarkably protects against doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This cardioprotection is accompanied by decreased cardiac oxidative stress and triglycerides and increased cardiac fatty-acid oxidation, ATP synthesis, and upregulated JAK/STAT3 pathway.</Disease>

<Disease>In the current study, we investigated whether a physiological intervention by feeding 40% high fat diet (HFD), which induces obesity in male Sprague-Dawley rats (250-275 g), sensitizes to doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A LD(10) dose (8 mg doxorubicin/kg, ip) administered on day 43 of the HFD feeding regimen led to higher cardiotoxicity, cardiac dysfunction, lipid peroxidation, and 80% mortality in the obese (OB) rats in the absence of any significant renal or hepatic toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Doxorubicin toxicokinetics studies revealed no change in accumulation of doxorubicin and doxorubicinol (toxic metabolite) in the normal diet-fed (ND) and OB hearts.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mechanistic studies revealed that OB rats are sensitized due to: (1) higher oxyradical stress leading to upregulation of uncoupling proteins 2 and 3, (2) downregulation of cardiac peroxisome proliferators activated receptor-alpha, (3) decreased plasma adiponectin levels, (4) decreased cardiac fatty-acid oxidation (666.9+/-14.0 nmol/min/g heart in ND versus 400.2+/-11.8 nmol/min/g heart in OB), (5) decreased mitochondrial AMP-alpha2 protein kinase, and (6) 86% drop in cardiac ATP levels accompanied by decreased ATP/ADP ratio after doxorubicin administration.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Decreased cardiac erythropoietin and increased SOCS3 further downregulated the cardioprotective JAK/</Disease>
<Disease>STAT3 pathway.</Disease>

<Disease>In conclusion, HFD-induced obese rats are highly sensitized to doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity by substantially downregulating cardiac mitochondrial ATP generation, increasing oxidative stress and downregulating the JAK/STAT3 pathway.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Complete atrioventricular block secondary to lithium therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Sinus node dysfunction has been reported most frequently among the adverse cardiovascular effects of lithium.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the present case, complete atrioventricular (AV) block with syncopal attacks developed secondary to lithium therapy, necessitating permanent pacemaker implantation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Serum lithium levels remained under or within the therapeutic range during the syncopal attacks.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Lithium should be used with extreme caution, especially in patients with mild disturbance of AV conduction.</Disease>
<Disease>Neuroleptic malignant syndrome induced by ziprasidone on the second day of treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is the rarest and most serious of the neuroleptic-induced movement disorders.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We describe a case of neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) associated with the use of ziprasidone.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Although conventional neuroleptics are more frequently associated with NMS, atypical antipsychotic drugs like ziprasidone may also be a cause.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The patient is a 24-year-old male with a history of schizophrenia who developed signs and symptoms of NMS after 2 days of treatment with an 80-mg/day dose of orally administrated ziprasidone.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This case is the earliest (second day of treatment)</Disease>
<Disease>NMS due to ziprasidone reported in the literature.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Role of mangiferin on biochemical alterations and antioxidant status in isoproterenol-induced myocardial infarction in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The current study dealt with the protective role of mangiferin, a polyphenol from Mangifera indica Linn.</Disease>
<Disease>(Anacardiaceae), on isoproterenol (ISPH)-induced myocardial infarction (MI) in rats through its antioxidative mechanism.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Subcutaneous injection of ISPH (200 mg/kg body weight in 1 ml saline) to rats for 2 consecutive days caused myocardial damage in rat heart, which was determined by the increased activity of serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and creatine phosphokinase isoenzymes (CK-MB), increased uric acid level and reduced plasma iron binding capacity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The protective role of mangiferin was analyzed by triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC) test used for macroscopic enzyme mapping assay of the ischemic myocardium.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The heart tissue antioxidant enzymes such as superoxide dismutase, catalase, glutathione peroxidase, glutathione transferase and glutathione reductase activities, non-enzymic antioxidants such as cerruloplasmin, Vitamin C, Vitamin E and glutathione levels were altered in MI rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Upon pretreatment with mangiferin (100 mg/kg body weight suspended in 2 ml of dimethyl sulphoxide) given intraperitoneally for 28 days to MI rats protected the above-mentioned parameters to fall from the normal levels.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Activities of heart tissue enzymic antioxidants and serum non-enzymic antioxidants levels rose significantly upon mangiferin administration as compared to ISPH-induced MI rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>From the present study it is concluded that mangiferin exerts a beneficial effect against ISPH-induced MI due to its antioxidant potential, which regulated the tissues defense system against cardiac damage.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Remifentanil pretreatment reduces myoclonus after etomidate.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>STUDY OBJECTIVE:</Disease>

<Disease>The aim of the study was to compare the effect of pretreatment with remifentanil 1 microg/kg and the effect of gender on the incidence of myoclonus after anesthesia induction with etomidate.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>DESIGN:</Disease>
<Disease>This was a randomized, double-blind study.</Disease>
<Disease>SETTING:</Disease>
<Disease>The study was conducted at a university hospital.</Disease>
<Disease>PATIENTS: Sixty patients were pretreated in a randomized double-blinded fashion with remifentanil 1 microg/kg or placebo.</Disease>
<Disease>Two minutes after remifentanil or placebo injection, etomidate 0.3 mg/kg was given.</Disease>
<Disease>MEASUREMENTS:</Disease>
<Disease>Myoclonus was recorded with a scale of 0 to 3.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The grade of sedation (none, mild, moderate, severe), nausea, pruritus, and apnea were recorded after injection of both drugs.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>MAIN RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>The incidence of myoclonus was significantly lower in the remifentanil group (6.7%) than in the placebo group (70%) (P < 0.001).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>None of the patients experienced sedation, apnea, nausea, or pruritus after injection of both drugs.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the placebo group, male patients were associated with significantly increased incidence of myoclonus after etomidate administration.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION: Pretreatment with remifentanil 1 microg/kg reduced myoclonus after etomidate induction without side effects such as sedation, apnea, nausea, or pruritus.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Men experience increased incidence of myoclonus than women after etomidate administration.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Daidzein activates choline acetyltransferase from MC-IXC cells and improves drug-induced amnesia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The choline acetyltransferase (ChAT) activator, which enhances cholinergic transmission via an augmentation of the enzymatic production of acetylcholine (ACh), is an important factor in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease (AD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Methanolic extracts from Pueraria thunbergiana exhibited an activation effect (46%) on ChAT in vitro.</Disease>
<Disease>Via the sequential isolation of Pueraria thunbergiana, the active component was ultimately identified as daidzein (4',7-dihydroxy-isoflavone).</Disease>
<Disease>In order to investigate the effects of daidzein from Pueraria thunbergiana on scopolamine-induced impairments of learning and memory, we conducted a series of in vivo tests.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Administration of daidzein (4.5 mg/kg body weight) to mice was shown significantly to reverse scopolamine-induced amnesia, according to the results of a Y-maze test.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Injections of scopolamine into mice resulted in impaired performance on Y-maze tests (a 37% decreases in alternation behavior).</Disease>

<Disease>By way of contrast, mice treated with daidzein prior to the scopolamine injections were noticeably protected from this performance impairment (an approximately 12%-21% decrease in alternation behavior).</Disease>
<Disease>These results indicate that daidzein might play a role in acetylcholine biosynthesis as a ChAT activator, and that it also ameliorates scopolamine-induced amnesia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Possible azithromycin-associated hiccups.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To report a case of persistent hiccups associated by azithromycin therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CASE SUMMARY:</Disease>
<Disease>A 76-year-old man presented with persistent hiccups after beginning azithromycin for the treatment of pharyngitis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Hiccups were persistent and exhausting.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Discontinuation of azithromycin and therapy with baclofen finally resolved hiccups.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No organic cause of hiccups was identified despite extensive investigation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>DISCUSSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Pharmacotherapeutic agents have been uncommonly associated with hiccups.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Corticosteroids (dexamethasone and methylprednisolone), benzodiazepines (midazolam) and general anaesthesia have been the specific agents mentioned most frequently in the literature as being associated with the development of hiccups.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Few cases of drug-induced hiccups have been reported related to macrolide antimicrobials.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Using the Naranjo adverse effect reaction probability scale this event could be classified as possible (score 5 points), mostly because of the close temporal sequence, previous reports on this reaction with other macrolides and the absence of any alternative explanation for hiccups.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our hypothesis is that a vagal mechanism mediated by azithromycin could be the pathogenesis of hiccups in our patient.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Diagnosis of drug-induced hiccups is difficult and often achieved only by a process of elimination.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, macrolide antimicrobials have been reported to be associated with hiccups and vagal mechanism could explain the development of this side-effect.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Time trends in warfarin-associated hemorrhage.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The annual incidence of warfarin-related bleeding at Brigham and Women's Hospital increased from 0.97/1,000 patient admissions in the first time period (January 1995 to October 1998) to 1.19/1,000 patient admissions in the second time period (November 1998 to August 2002) of this study.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The proportion of patients with major and intracranial bleeding increased from 20.2% and 1.9%, respectively, in the first time period, to 33.3% and 7.8%, respectively, in the second.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Fatal haemorrhagic myocarditis secondary to cyclophosphamide therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Haemorrhagic myocarditis is a rare but important complication of cyclophosphamide therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Echocardiographic identification of the disorder can be made.</Disease>
<Disease>We believe that the ultrasound features of this disorder have not been previously reported.</Disease>
<Disease>Glyceryl trinitrate induces attacks of migraine without aura in sufferers of migraine with aura.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Migraine with aura and migraine without aura have the same pain phase, thus indicating that migraine with aura and migraine without aura share a common pathway of nociception.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In recent years, increasing evidence has suggested that the messenger molecule nitric oxide (NO) is involved in pain mechanisms of migraine without aura.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In order to clarify whether the same is true for migraine with aura, in the present study we examined the headache response to intravenous infusion of glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) (0.5 microg/kg/min for 20 min) in 12 sufferers of migraine with aura.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The specific aim was to elucidate whether an aura and/or an attack of migraine without aura could be induced.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Fourteen healthy subjects served as controls.</Disease>
<Disease>Aura symptoms were not elicited in any subject.</Disease>
<Disease>Headache was more severe in migraineurs than in the controls during and immediately after GTN infusion (p=0.037) as well as during the following 11 h (p = 0.008).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the controls, the GTN-induced headache gradually disappeared, whereas in migraineurs peak headache intensity occurred at a mean time of 240 min post-infusion.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>At this time the induced headache in 6 of 12 migraineurs fulfilled the diagnostic criteria for migraine without aura of the International Headache Society.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The results therefore suggest that NO is involved in the pain mechanisms of migraine with aura.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Since cortical spreading depression has been shown to liberate NO in animals, this finding may help our understanding of the coupling between cortical spreading depression and headache in migraine with aura.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Stroke and cocaine or amphetamine use.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The association of cocaine and amphetamine use with hemorrhagic and ischemic stroke is based almost solely on data from case series.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The limited number of epidemiologic studies of stroke and use of cocaine and/or amphetamine have been done in settings that serve mostly the poor and/or minorities.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This case-control study was conducted in the defined population comprising members of Kaiser Permanente of Northern and Southern California.</Disease>

<Disease>We attempted to identify all incident strokes in women ages 15-44 years during a 3-year period using hospital admission and discharge records, emergency department logs, and payment requests for out-of-plan hospitalizations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We selected controls, matched on age and facility of usual care, at random from healthy members of the health plan.</Disease>
<Disease>We obtained information in face-to-face interviews.</Disease>
<Disease>There were 347 confirmed stroke cases and 1,021 controls.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The univariate matched odds ratio for stroke in women who admitted to using cocaine and/or amphetamine was 8.5 (95% confidence interval = 3.6-20.0).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>After further adjustment for potential confounders, the odds ratio in women who reported using cocaine and/or amphetamine was 7.0 (95% confidence interval = 2.8-17.9).</Disease>
<Disease>The use of cocaine and/or amphetamine is a strong risk factor for stroke in this socioeconomically heterogeneous, insured urban population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Prevention of breast cancer with tamoxifen: preliminary findings from the Italian randomised trial among hysterectomised women. Italian Tamoxifen Prevention Study.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>Tamoxifen is a candidate chemopreventive agent in breast cancer, although the drug may be associated with the development of endometrial cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Therefore we did a trial in hysterectomised women of tamoxifen as a chemopreventive.</Disease>
<Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>In October, 1992, we started a double-blind placebo-controlled, randomised trial of tamoxifen in women (mainly in Italy) who did not have breast cancer and who had had a hysterectomy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Women were randomised to receive tamoxifen 20 mg per day or placebo, both orally for 5 years.</Disease>
<Disease>The original plan was to follow the intervention phase by 5 years' follow-up.</Disease>
<Disease>In June, 1997, the trialists and the data-monitoring committee decided to end recruitment primarily because of the number of women dropping out of the study.</Disease>
<Disease>Recruitment ended on July 11, 1997, and the study will continue as planned.</Disease>
<Disease>The primary endpoints are the occurrence of and deaths from breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This preliminary interim analysis is based on intention-to-treat.</Disease>
<Disease>FINDINGS: 5408 women were randomised; participating women have a median follow-up of 46 months for major endpoints.</Disease>
<Disease>41 cases of breast cancer occurred so far; there have been no deaths from breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>There is no difference in breast-cancer frequency between the placebo (22 cases) and tamoxifen (19) arms.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>There is a statistically significant reduction of breast cancer among women receiving tamoxifen who also used hormone-replacement therapy during the trial: among 390 women on such therapy and allocated to placebo, we found eight cases of breast cancer compared with one case among 362 women allocated to tamoxifen.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Compared with the placebo group, there was a significantly increased risk of vascular events and hypertriglyceridaemia among women on tamoxifen.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>INTERPRETATION:</Disease>

<Disease>Although this preliminary analysis has low power, in this cohort of women at low-to-normal risk of breast cancer, the postulated protective effects of tamoxifen are not yet apparent.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Women using hormone-replacement therapy appear to have benefited from use of tamoxifen.</Disease>
<Disease>There were no deaths from breast cancer recorded in women in the study.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It is essential to continue follow-up to quantify the long-term risks and benefits of tamoxifen therapy.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>A case of necrotizing myopathy due to a short epsilon-aminocaproic acid (EACA) treatment in a 72 year-old patient with subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) is described.</Disease>

<Disease>Comparison of the effectiveness of ranitidine and cimetidine in inhibiting acid secretion in patients with gastric hypersecretory states.</Disease>

<Disease>The H2-histamine receptor antagonists ranitidine and cimetidine were compared for their abilities to control gastric acid hypersecretion on a short- and long-term basis in 22 patients with gastric acid hypersecretory states.</Disease>
<Disease>Nineteen patients had Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, one patient had systemic mastocytosis, and two patients had idiopathic hypersecretion.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The rates of onset of the action of cimetidine and ranitidine were the same.</Disease>

<Disease>The actions of both drugs were increased by anticholinergic agents, and there was a close correlation between the daily maintenance dose of each drug needed to control acid secretion.</Disease>

<Disease>However, ranitidine was threefold more potent than cimetidine both in acute inhibition studies and in the median maintenance dose needed (1.2 g per day for ranitidine and 3.6 g per day for cimetidine).</Disease>
<Disease>Sixty percent of the males developed breast changes or impotence while taking cimetidine and in all cases these changes disappeared when cimetidine was replaced by ranitidine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Treatment with high doses of cimetidine (one to 60 months; median, 11 months) or ranitidine (two to 31 months; median, 14 months) was not associated with hepatic or hematologic toxicity or alterations of serum gastrin concentrations, but ranitidine therapy was associated with a significantly lower serum creatinine level than seen with cimetidine therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The results show that both drugs can adequately inhibit acid secretion in patients with gastric hypersecretory states.</Disease>
<Disease>Both are safe at high doses, but ranitidine is threefold more potent and does not cause the antiandrogen side effects frequently seen with high doses of cimetidine.</Disease>
<Disease>A catch in the Reye.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Twenty-six cases of Reye syndrome from The Children's Hospital, Camperdown, Australia, occurring between 1973 and 1982 were reviewed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Of these, 20 cases met the US Public Health Service Centers for Disease Control criteria for the diagnosis of Reye syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Aspirin or salicylate ingestion had occurred in only one of the 20 cases (5%), and paracetamol (acetaminophen) had been administered in only six of the cases (30%).</Disease>
<Disease>Pathologic confirmation of the diagnosis of Reye syndrome was accomplished in 90% of the cases.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The incidence of Reye syndrome in New South Wales, Australia, is estimated from this study to be approximately nine cases per 1 million children compared with recent US data of ten to 20 cases per 1 million children and three to seven cases per 1 million children in Great Britain.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mortality for these Reye syndrome cases in Australia was 45% as compared with a 32% case-fatality rate in the United States.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In Australia, the pediatric usage of aspirin has been extremely low for the past 25 years (less than 1% of total dosage units sold), with paracetamol (acetaminophen) dominating the pediatric analgesic and antipyretic market.</Disease>

<Disease>Reye syndrome may be disappearing from Australia despite a total lack of association with salicylates or aspirin ingestion, since there were no cases found at The Children's Hospital in 1983, 1984, or 1985.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A rare case of morbid vasospasm, together with striking angiographic findings, is described secondary to the ingestion of methysergide by a 48-year-old woman.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A brief review of the literature on similar cases is presented.</Disease>

<Disease>A discussion of the history of ergot includes its original discovery, the epidemics of gangrene that it has caused through the ages and its past and present role in the management of migraine headache.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Despite the advent of calcium channel blockers and beta-adrenergic antagonists, ergot preparations continue to play a major role in migraine therapy, so that the danger of St. Anthony's fire persists.</Disease>
