text: <Disease>Delayed leukoencephalopathy with stroke-like presentation in chemotherapy recipients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>

<Disease>A transient leukoencephalopathy mimicking cerebrovascular accident has been described as a complication of chemotherapy, most commonly in recipients of intrathecal methotrexate for childhood leukaemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Recently published neuroimaging data suggest a common pathophysiology associated with a variety of chemotherapy agents and modes of administration.</Disease>
<Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>We reviewed the medical literature for single reports and case series of patients presenting with stroke-like episodes while receiving systemic or intrathecal chemotherapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We only included studies providing detailed neuroimaging data.</Disease>
<Disease>Patients with cerebrovascular accidents were excluded.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>We identified 27 reports of toxic leukoencephalopathy in patients treated with methotrexate (intrathecal, systemic), 5-fluorouracil and its derivative carmofur, and capecitabine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Diffusion weighted imaging (DWI) of all patients revealed well demarcated hyperintense lesions within the subcortical white matter of the cerebral hemispheres and the corpus callosum, corresponding to areas of decreased proton diffusion on apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) maps (available in 21/27 patients).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Lesions exceeded the confines of adjacent vascular territories.</Disease>
<Disease>Complete resolution of symptoms within 1-4 days was accompanied by normalisation of ADC abnormalities.</Disease>
<Disease>However, fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) sequences frequently revealed persistent white matter abnormalities.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Several pathophysiological models of delayed leukoencephalopathy after exposure to intrathecal or systemic chemotherapy have been proposed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>DWI findings in this cohort are indicative of cytotoxic oedema within cerebral white matter and lend support to an at least partially reversible metabolic derangement as the basis for this syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Down-regulation of norepinephrine transporter function induced by chronic administration of desipramine linking to the alteration of sensitivity of local-anesthetics-induced convulsions and the counteraction by co-administration with local anesthetics.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Alterations of norepinephrine transporter (NET) function by chronic inhibition of NET in relation to sensitization to seizures induce by cocaine and local anesthetics were studied in mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Daily administration of desipramine, an inhibitor of the NET, for 5 days decreased [(3)H]norepinephrine uptake in the P2 fractions of hippocampus but not cortex, striatum or amygdalae.</Disease>
<Disease>Co-administration of lidocaine, bupivacaine or tricaine with desipramine reversed this effect.</Disease>
<Disease>Daily treatment of cocaine increased [(3)H]norepinephrine uptake into the hippocampus.</Disease>
<Disease>Daily administration of desipramine increased the incidence of appearance of lidocaine-induced convulsions and decreased that of cocaine-induced convulsions.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Co-administration of lidocaine with desipramine reversed the changes of convulsive activity of lidocaine and cocaine induced by repeated administration of desipramine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These results suggest that down-regulation of hippocampal NET induced by chronic administration of desipramine may be relevant to desipramine-induced sensitization of lidocaine convulsions.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Inhibition of Na(+) channels by local anesthetics may regulate desipramine-induced down-regulation of NET function.</Disease>
<Disease>Repeated administration of cocaine induces up-regulation of hippocampal NET function.</Disease>
<Disease>Desipramine-induced sensitization of lidocaine seizures may have a mechanism distinct from kindling resulting from repeated administration of cocaine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Definition and management of anemia in patients infected with hepatitis C virus.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Chronic infection with hepatitis C virus (HCV) can progress to cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma, and end-stage liver disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The current best treatment for HCV infection is combination therapy with pegylated interferon and ribavirin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although this regimen produces sustained virologic responses (SVRs) in approximately 50% of patients, it can be associated with a potentially dose-limiting hemolytic anemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Hemoglobin concentrations decrease mainly as a result of ribavirin-induced hemolysis, and this anemia can be problematic in patients with HCV infection, especially those who have comorbid renal or cardiovascular disorders.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In general, anemia can increase the risk of morbidity and mortality, and may have negative effects on cerebral function and quality of life.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although ribavirin-associated anemia can be reversed by dose reduction or discontinuation, this approach compromises outcomes by significantly decreasing SVR rates.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Recombinant human erythropoietin has been used to manage ribavirin-associated anemia but has other potential disadvantages.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Viramidine, a liver-targeting prodrug of ribavirin, has the potential to maintain the virologic efficacy of ribavirin while decreasing the risk of hemolytic anemia in patients with chronic hepatitis C.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Calcium carbonate toxicity: the updated milk-alkali syndrome; report of 3 cases and review of the literature.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To describe 3 patients with calcium carbonate-induced hypercalcemia and gain insights into the cause and management of the milk-alkali syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>We report the clinical and laboratory data in 3 patients who presented with severe hypercalcemia (corrected serum calcium > or = 14 mg/dL) and review the pertinent literature on milk-alkali syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>The 3 patients had acute renal insufficiency, relative metabolic alkalosis, and low parathyroid hormone (PTH), PTH-related peptide, and 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D concentrations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>No malignant lesion was found.</Disease>
<Disease>Treatment included aggressive hydration and varied amounts of furosemide.</Disease>
<Disease>The 2 patients with the higher serum calcium concentrations received pamidronate intravenously (60 and 30 mg, respectively), which caused severe hypocalcemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Of the 3 patients, 2 were ingesting acceptable doses of elemental calcium (1 g and 2 g daily, respectively) in the form of calcium carbonate.</Disease>

<Disease>In addition to our highlighted cases, we review the history, classification, pathophysiologic features, and treatment of milk-alkali syndrome and summarize the cases reported from early 1995 to November 2003.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION: Milk-alkali syndrome may be a common cause of unexplained hypercalcemia and can be precipitated by small amounts of orally ingested calcium carbonate in susceptible persons.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Treatment with hydration, furosemide, and discontinuation of the calcium and vitamin D source is adequate.</Disease>
<Disease>Pamidronate treatment is associated with considerable risk for hypocalcemia, even in cases of initially severe hypercalcemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Management strategies for ribavirin-induced hemolytic anemia in the treatment of hepatitis C: clinical and economic implications.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVES:</Disease>

<Disease>Recently published studies have demonstrated increased efficacy and cost-effectiveness of combination therapy with interferon and alpha-2b/ribavirin compared with interferon-alpha monotherapy in the treatment of chronic hepatitis C (CHC).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Combination therapy is associated with a clinically important adverse effect: ribavirin-induced hemolytic anemia (RIHA).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The objective of this study was to evaluate the direct health-care costs and management of RIHA during treatment of CHC in a clinical trial setting.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>A systematic literature review was conducted to synthesize information on the incidence and management of RIHA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Decision-analytic techniques were used to estimate the cost of treating RIHA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Uncertainty was evaluated using sensitivity analyses.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS: RIHA, defined as a reduction in hemoglobin to less than 100 g/L, occurs in approximately 7% to 9% of patients treated with combination therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The standard of care for management of RIHA is reduction or discontinuation of the ribavirin dosage.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We estimated the direct cost of treating clinically significant RIHA to be  170 per patient receiving combination therapy per 48-week treatment course (range  68- 692).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The results of the one-way sensitivity analyses ranged from  57 to  317.</Disease>
<Disease>In comparison, the cost of 48 weeks of combination therapy is  16,459.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>The direct cost of treating clinically significant RIHA is 1% ( 170/ 16,459) of drug treatment costs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Questions remain about the optimal dose of ribavirin and the incidence of RIHA in a real-world population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Despite these uncertainties, this initial evaluation of the direct cost of treating RIHA provides an estimate of the cost and management implications of this clinically important adverse effect.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Effects of amine pretreatment on ketamine catatonia in pinealectomized or hypophysectomized animals.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The present studies were designed to clarify the role of catecholamines and pineal idolamines on ketamine-induced catatonia in the intact, pinealectomized or hypophysectomized chick and rat.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the pinealectomized chick, pretreatment with dopamine increased the duration of catatonia (DOC) after ketamine, but pretreatment with norepinephrine did not.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The pineal indolamines exhibited mixed actions.</Disease>

<Disease>Serotonin and N-acetyl serotonin which augmented ketamine DOC, did not do so in the absence of the pineal gland, whereas melatonin potentiated the ketamine DOC in both the intact and pinealectomized chick.</Disease>

<Disease>Ketamine was more potent in the hypophysectomized chick and the circadian rhythm noted in the intact chick was absent; furthermore, melatonin did not augment the ketamine DOC whereas dopamine continued to do so.</Disease>

<Disease>This study did not demonstrate a species difference regarding the role of the amines on the pineal in spite of the immature blood-brain barrier in the young chick and the intact barrier in the rat.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, these data indicate a direct role of the pituitary in the augmentation of ketamine DOC induced by melatonin.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, dopamine appeared to act on systems more closely involved with the induction of ketamine catatonia rather than directly on the pituitary.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Multicenter, double-blind, multiple-dose, parallel-groups efficacy and safety trial of azelastine, chlorpheniramine, and placebo in the treatment of spring allergic rhinitis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Azelastine, a novel antiallergic medication, was compared with chlorpheniramine maleate and placebo for efficacy and safety in the treatment of spring allergic rhinitis in a multicenter, double-blind, multiple-dose, parallel-groups study.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One hundred fifty-five subjects participated.</Disease>
<Disease>Subjects ranged in age from 18 to 60 years of age and had at least a 2-year history of spring allergic rhinitis, confirmed by positive skin test to spring aeroallergens.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Medications were given four times daily; the azelastine groups received 0.5, 1.0, or 2.0 mg in the morning and evening with placebo in the early and late afternoon; the chlorpheniramine group received 4.0 mg four times daily.</Disease>
<Disease>Daily subject symptom cards were completed during a screening period to assess pretreatment symptoms and during a 4-week treatment period while subjects received study medications.</Disease>
<Disease>Individual symptoms, total symptoms, and major symptoms were compared to determine efficacy of medication.</Disease>
<Disease>Elicited, volunteered, and observed adverse experiences were recorded for each subject and compared among groups.</Disease>
<Disease>Vital signs, body weights, serum chemistry values, complete blood cell counts, urine studies, and electrocardiograms were obtained for each subject and compared among groups.</Disease>

<Disease>Symptoms relief in the group receiving the highest concentration of azelastine (2.0 mg twice daily) was statistically greater than in the placebo group during all weeks of the study.</Disease>
<Disease>Lower doses of azelastine were statistically more effective than placebo only during portions of the first 3 weeks of the study.</Disease>

<Disease>In contrast, although the chlorpheniramine group did have fewer symptoms than the placebo group during the study, the difference never reached statistical significance during any week of the study.</Disease>
<Disease>There were no serious side effects in any of the treatment groups.</Disease>
<Disease>Drowsiness and altered taste perception were increased significantly over placebo only in the high-dose azelastine group.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Azelastine appears to be a safe, efficacious medication for seasonal allergic rhinitis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Obsolete but dangerous antacid preparations.</Disease>

<Disease>One case of acute hypercalcaemia and two of recurrent nephrolithiasis are reported in patients who had regularly consumed large amounts of calcium carbon-ate-sodium bicarbonate powders for more than 20 years.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The powders had been obtained from pharmacists unknown to the patients' medical practitioners.</Disease>
<Disease>It is suggested that these preparations were responsible for the patient's problems, and that such powders should no longer be freely obtainable.</Disease>
<Disease>Prolonged paralysis due to nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents and corticosteroids.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The long-term use of nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents (ND-NMBA) has recently been implicated as a cause of prolonged muscle weakness, although the site of the lesion and the predisposing factors have been unclear.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report 3 patients (age 37-52 years) with acute respiratory insufficiency who developed prolonged weakness following the discontinuation of ND-NMBAs.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Two patients also received intravenous corticosteroids.</Disease>
<Disease>Renal function was normal but hepatic function was impaired in all patients, and all had acidosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Electrophysiologic studies revealed low amplitude compound motor action potentials, normal sensory studies, and fibrillations.</Disease>
<Disease>Repetitive stimulation at 2 Hz showed a decremental response in 2 patients.</Disease>
<Disease>The serum vecuronium level measured in 1 patient 14 days after the drug had been discontinued was 172 ng/mL. A muscle biopsy in this patient showed loss of thick, myosin filaments.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The weakness in these patients is due to pathology at both the neuromuscular junction (most likely due to ND-NMBA) and muscle (most likely due to corticosteroids).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Hepatic dysfunction and acidosis are contributing risk factors.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Prostaglandin E2-induced bladder hyperactivity in normal, conscious rats: involvement of tachykinins?</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In normal conscious rats investigated by continuous cystometry, intravesically instilled prostaglandin (PG) E2 facilitated micturition and increased basal intravesical pressure.</Disease>

<Disease>The effect was attenuated by both the NK1 receptor selective antagonist RP 67,580 and the NK2 receptor selective antagonist SR 48,968, given intra-arterially, suggesting that it was mediated by stimulation of both NK1 and NK2 receptors.</Disease>

<Disease>Intra-arterially given PGE2 produced a distinct increase in bladder pressure before initiating a micturition reflex, indicating that the PG had a direct contractant effect on the detrusor smooth muscle.</Disease>

<Disease>The effect of intra-arterial PGE2 could not be blocked by intra-arterial RP 67,580 or SR 48,968, which opens the possibility that the micturition reflex elicited by intra-arterial PGE2 was mediated by pathways other than the reflex initiated when the PG was given intravesically.</Disease>

<Disease>The present results thus suggest that intra-arterial PGE2, given near the bladder, may initiate micturition in the normal rat chiefly by directly contracting the smooth muscle of the detrusor.</Disease>
<Disease>However, when given intravesically, PGE2 may stimulate micturition by releasing tachykinins from nerves in and/or immediately below the urothelium.</Disease>
<Disease>These tachykinins, in turn, initiate a micturition reflex by stimulating NK1 and NK2 receptors.</Disease>
<Disease>Prostanoids may, via release of tachykinins, contribute to both urge and bladder hyperactivity seen in inflammatory conditions of the lower urinary tract.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thiazide diuretics, hypokalemia and cardiac arrhythmias.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Thiazide diuretics are widely accepted as the cornerstone of antihypertensive treatment programs.</Disease>
<Disease>Hypokalemia is a commonly encountered metabolic consequence of chronic thiazide therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We treated 38 patients (22 low renin, 16 normal renin) with moderate diastolic hypertension with hydrochlorothiazide (HCTC) administered on a twice daily schedule.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Initial dose was 50 mg and the dose was increased at monthly intervals to 100 mg, 150 mg and 200 mg daily until blood pressure normalized.</Disease>
<Disease>The serum K during the control period was 4.5 +/- 0.2 mEq/l an on 50, 100, 150 and 200 mg HCTZ daily 3.9 +/- 0.3, 3.4 +/- 0.2, 2.9 +/- 0.2, and 2.4 +/- 0.3 mEq/l, respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>Corresponding figures for whole body K were 4107 +/- 208, 3722 +/- 319, 3628 +/- 257, 3551 +/- 336, and 3269 +/- 380 mEq, respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>In 13 patients we observed the effects of HCTZ therapy (100 mg daily) on the occurrence of PVC's during rest as well as during static and dynamic exercise.</Disease>
<Disease>During rest we observed 0.6 +/- 0.08 PVC beats/min +/- SEM and during static and dynamic exercise 0.6 +/- 0.06 and 0.8 +/- 0.15, respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>Corresponding figures during HCTZ therapy 100 mg daily were 1.4 +/- 0.1, 3.6 +/- 0.7 and 5.7 4/- 0.8, respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>The occurrence of PVC's correlated significantly with the fall in serum K+ observed r = 0.72, p less than 0.001.</Disease>
<Disease>In conclusion we found that thiazide diuretics cause hypokalemia and depletion of body potassium.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The more profound hypokalemia, the greater the propensity for the occurrence of PVC's.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Diuretics, potassium and arrhythmias in hypertensive coronary disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It has been proposed that modest changes in plasma potassium can alter the tendency towards cardiac arrhythmias.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>If this were so, patients with coronary artery disease might be especially susceptible.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, myocardial electrical excitability was measured in patients with mild essential hypertension and known coronary artery disease after 8 weeks of treatment with a potassium-conserving diuretic (amiloride) and a similar period on a potassium-losing diuretic (chlorthalidone) in a randomised study.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Plasma potassium concentrations were on average 1 mmol/L lower during the chlorthalidone phase compared to amiloride therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>Blood pressure and volume states as assessed by bodyweight, plasma renin and noradrenaline (norepinephrine) concentrations were similar on the 2 regimens.</Disease>

<Disease>Compared to amiloride treatment, the chlorthalidone phase was associated with an increased frequency of ventricular ectopic beats (24-hour Holter monitoring) and a higher Lown grading, increased upslope and duration of the monophasic action potential, prolonged ventricular effective refractory period, and increased electrical instability during programmed ventricular stimulation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The above results indicate that because potassium-losing diuretic therapy can increase myocardial electrical excitability in patients with ischaemic heart disease, even minor falls in plasma potassium concentrations are probably best avoided in such patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>GABA involvement in naloxone induced reversal of respiratory paralysis produced by thiopental.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No agent is yet available to reverse respiratory paralysis produced by CNS depressants, such as general anesthetics.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In this study naloxone reversed respiratory paralysis induced by thiopental in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>25 mg/kg, i.v. thiopental produced anesthesia without altering respiratory rate, increased GABA, decreased glutamate, and had no effect on aspartate or glycine levels compared to controls in rat cortex and brain stem.</Disease>
<Disease>Pretreatment of rats with thiosemicarbazide for 30 minutes abolished the anesthetic action as well as the respiratory depressant action of thiopental.</Disease>

<Disease>50 mg/kg, i.v. thiopental produced respiratory arrest with further increase in GABA and decrease in glutamate again in cortex and brain stem without affecting any of the amino acids studied in four regions of rat brain.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Naloxone (2.5 mg/kg, i.v.) reversed respiratory paralysis, glutamate and GABA levels to control values in brain stem and cortex with no changes in caudate or cerebellum.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These data suggest naloxone reverses respiratory paralysis produced by thiopental and involves GABA in its action.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>National project on the prevention of mother-to-infant infection by hepatitis B virus in Japan.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In Japan, a nationwide prevention program against mother-to-infant infection by hepatitis B virus (HBV) started in 1985.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This program consists of double screenings of pregnant women and prophylactic treatment to the infants born to both hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) positive mothers.</Disease>
<Disease>These infants are treated with two injections of hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG) and at least three injections of plasma derived hepatitis B vaccine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We sent questionnaires about the numbers of each procedure or examination during nine months of investigation period to each local government in 1986 and 1987.</Disease>
<Disease>93.4% pregnant women had the chance to be examined for HBsAg, and the positive rate was 1.4 to 1.5%.</Disease>
<Disease>The HBeAg positive rate in HBsAg positive was 23 to 26%.</Disease>
<Disease>The HBsAg positive rate in neonates and in infants before two months were 3% and 2% respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>Some problems may arise, because 27 to 30% of infants need the fourth vaccination in some restricted areas.</Disease>
<Disease>Nociceptive effects induced by intrathecal administration of prostaglandin D2, E2, or F2 alpha to conscious mice.</Disease>
<Disease>The effects of intrathecal administration of prostaglandins on pain responses in conscious mice were evaluated by using hot plate and acetic acid writhing tests.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Prostaglandin D2 (0.5-3 ng/mouse) had a hyperalgesic action on the response to a hot plate during a 3-60 min period after injection.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Prostaglandin E2 showed a hyperalgesic effect at doses of 1 pg to 10 ng/mouse, but the effect lasted shorter (3-30 min) than that of prostaglandin D2.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Similar results were obtained by acetic acid writhing tests.</Disease>

<Disease>The hyperalgesic effect of prostaglandin D2 was blocked by simultaneous injection of a substance P antagonist (greater than or equal to 100 ng) but not by AH6809, a prostanoid EP1-receptor antagonist.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Conversely, prostaglandin E2-induced hyperalgesia was blocked by AH6809 (greater than or equal to 500 ng) but not by the substance P antagonist.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Prostaglandin F2 alpha had little effect on pain responses.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These results demonstrate that both prostaglandin D2 and prostaglandin E2 exert hyperalgesia in the spinal cord, but in different ways.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Swallowing-induced atrial tachyarrhythmia triggered by salbutamol: case report and review of the literature.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CASE:</Disease>
<Disease>A 49-year-old patient experienced chest discomfort while swallowing.</Disease>
<Disease>On electrocardiogram, episodes of atrial tachyarrhythmia were recorded immediately after swallowing; 24-hour Holter monitoring recorded several events.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The arrhythmia resolved after therapy with atenolol, but recurred a year later.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The patient noticed that before these episodes he had been using an inhalator of salbutamol.</Disease>
<Disease>After stopping the beta-agonist, and after a week with the atenolol, the arrhythmia disappeared.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>DISCUSSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Swallowing-induced atrial tachyarrhythmia (SIAT) is a rare phenomenon.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Fewer than 50 cases of SIAT have been described in the literature.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This article summarizes all the cases published, creating a comprehensive review of the current knowledge and approach to SIAT.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It discusses demographics, clinical characteristics and types of arrhythmia, postulated mechanisms of SIAT, and different treatment possibilities such as medications, surgery, and radiofrequency catheter ablation (RFCA).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Salbutamol is presented here as a possible trigger for SIAT.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although it is difficult to define causality in a case report, it is logical to think that a beta-agonist like salbutamol (known to induce tachycardia) may be the trigger of adrenergic reflexes originating in the esophagus while swallowing and that a beta-blocker such as atenolol (that blocks the adrenergic activity) may relieve it.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Coenzyme Q10 treatment ameliorates acute cisplatin nephrotoxicity in mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The nephroprotective effect of coenzyme Q10 was investigated in mice with acute renal injury induced by a single i.p. injection of cisplatin (5 mg/kg).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Coenzyme Q10 treatment (10 mg/kg/day, i.p.) was applied for 6 consecutive days, starting 1 day before cisplatin administration.</Disease>
<Disease>Coenzyme Q10 significantly reduced blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine levels which were increased by cisplatin.</Disease>

<Disease>Coenzyme Q10 significantly compensated deficits in the antioxidant defense mechanisms (reduced glutathione level and superoxide dismutase activity), suppressed lipid peroxidation, decreased the elevations of tumor necrosis factor-alpha, nitric oxide and platinum ion concentration, and attenuated the reductions of selenium and zinc ions in renal tissue resulted from cisplatin administration.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Also, histopathological renal tissue damage mediated by cisplatin was ameliorated by coenzyme Q10 treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Immunohistochemical analysis revealed that coenzyme Q10 significantly decreased the cisplatin-induced overexpression of inducible nitric oxide synthase, nuclear factor-kappaB, caspase-3 and p53 in renal tissue.</Disease>
<Disease>It was concluded that coenzyme Q10 represents a potential therapeutic option to protect against acute cisplatin nephrotoxicity commonly encountered in clinical practice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Metformin prevents experimental gentamicin-induced nephropathy by a mitochondria-dependent pathway.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The antidiabetic drug metformin can diminish apoptosis induced by oxidative stress in endothelial cells and prevent vascular dysfunction even in nondiabetic patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Here we tested whether it has a beneficial effect in a rat model of gentamicin toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mitochondrial analysis, respiration intensity, levels of reactive oxygen species, permeability transition, and cytochrome c release were assessed 3 and 6 days after gentamicin administration.</Disease>
<Disease>Metformin treatment fully blocked gentamicin-mediated acute renal failure.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This was accompanied by a lower activity of N-acetyl-beta-D-glucosaminidase, together with a decrease of lipid peroxidation and increase of antioxidant systems.</Disease>
<Disease>Metformin also protected the kidney from histological damage 6 days after gentamicin administration.</Disease>
<Disease>These in vivo markers of kidney dysfunction and their correction by metformin were complemented by in vitro studies of mitochondrial function.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We found that gentamicin treatment depleted respiratory components (cytochrome c, NADH), probably due to the opening of mitochondrial transition pores.</Disease>
<Disease>These injuries, partly mediated by a rise in reactive oxygen species from the electron transfer chain, were significantly decreased by metformin.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, our study suggests that pleiotropic effects of metformin can lessen gentamicin nephrotoxicity and improve mitochondrial homeostasis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Sedation depth during spinal anesthesia and the development of postoperative delirium in elderly patients undergoing hip fracture repair.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To determine whether limiting intraoperative sedation depth during spinal anesthesia for hip fracture repair in elderly patients can decrease the prevalence of postoperative delirium.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>We performed a double-blind, randomized controlled trial at an academic medical center of elderly patients (>or=65 years) without preoperative delirium or severe dementia who underwent hip fracture repair under spinal anesthesia with propofol sedation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Sedation depth was titrated using processed electroencephalography with the bispectral index (BIS), and patients were randomized to receive either deep (BIS, approximately 50) or light (BIS, >or=80) sedation.</Disease>

<Disease>Postoperative delirium was assessed as defined by Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (Third Edition Revised) criteria using the Confusion Assessment Method beginning at any time from the second day after surgery.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>From April 2, 2005, through October 30, 2008, a total of 114 patients were randomized.</Disease>

<Disease>The prevalence of postoperative delirium was significantly lower in the light sedation group (11/57 [19%] vs 23/57 [40%] in the deep sedation group; P=.02), indicating that 1 incident of delirium will be prevented for every 4.7 patients treated with light sedation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The mean +/- SD number of days of delirium during hospitalization was lower in the light sedation group than in the deep sedation group (0.5+/-1.5 days vs 1.4+/-4.0 days; P=.01).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>The use of light propofol sedation decreased the prevalence of postoperative delirium by 50% compared with deep sedation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Limiting depth of sedation during spinal anesthesia is a simple, safe, and cost-effective intervention for preventing postoperative delirium in elderly patients that could be widely and readily adopted.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Sorafenib-induced acute myocardial infarction due to coronary artery spasm.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A 65-year-old man with advanced renal cell carcinoma was admitted due to continuing chest pain at rest.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Two weeks before his admission, sorafenib had been started.</Disease>
<Disease>He was diagnosed with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction by laboratory data and electrocardiogram.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Enhanced heart magnetic resonance imaging also showed subendocardial infarction.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, there was no stenosis in coronary arteries on angiography.</Disease>
<Disease>Coronary artery spasm was induced by a provocative test.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Cessation of sorafenib and administration of Ca-channel blocker and nitrates ameliorated his symptoms, but relapse occurred after resumption of sorafenib.</Disease>
<Disease>Addition of oral nicorandil reduced his symptoms and maintained stable angina status.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report the first case of sorafenib-induced coronary artery spasm.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Sorafenib is a multikinase inhibitor that targets signaling pathways necessary for cellular proliferation and survival.</Disease>
<Disease>On the other hand, the Rho/ROCK pathway has an important role in the pathogenesis of coronary artery spasm.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our report may show an adverse effect on the Rho/ROCK pathway by sorafenib use.</Disease>
<Disease>Anxiogenic potential of ciprofloxacin and norfloxacin in rats.</Disease>
<Disease>INTRODUCTION:</Disease>

<Disease>The possible anxiogenic effects of fluoroquinolones, namely ciprofloxacin and norfloxacin, were investigated in adult Charles Foster albino rats of either sex, weighing 150-200 g. METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>The drugs were given orally, in doses of 50 mg/kg for five consecutive days and the experiments were performed on the fifth day.</Disease>
<Disease>The tests included open-field exploratory behaviour, elevated plus maze and elevated zero maze, social interaction and novelty-suppressed feeding latency behaviour.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>The results indicate that ciprofloxacin- and norfloxacin-treated rats showed anxious behaviour in comparison to control rats in all the parameters studied.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, ciprofloxacin- and norfloxacin-treated rats did not differ significantly from each other in various behavioural parameters.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>The present experimental findings substantiate the clinically observed anxiogenic potential of ciprofloxacin and norfloxacin.</Disease>
<Disease>Myocardial Fas ligand expression increases susceptibility to AZT-induced cardiomyopathy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND: Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) and myocarditis occur in many HIV-infected individuals, resulting in symptomatic heart failure in up to 5% of patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) has significantly reduced morbidity and mortality of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), but has resulted in an increase in cardiac and skeletal myopathies.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS AND RESULTS:</Disease>

<Disease>In order to investigate whether the HAART component zidovudine (3'-azido-2',3'-deoxythymidine; AZT) triggers the Fas-dependent cell-death pathway and cause cytoskeletal disruption in a murine model of DCM, 8-week-old transgenic (expressing Fas ligand in the myocardium: FasL Tg) and non-transgenic (NTg)</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>mice received water ad libitum containing different concentrations of AZT (0, 0.07, 0.2, and 0.7 mg/ml).</Disease>
<Disease>After 6 weeks, cardiac function was assessed by echocardiography and morphology was assessed by histopathologic and immunohistochemical methods.</Disease>
<Disease>NTg and untreated FasL</Disease>
<Disease>Tg mice showed little or no change in cardiac structure or function.</Disease>

<Disease>In contrast, AZT-treated FasL Tg mice developed cardiac dilation and depressed cardiac function in a dose-dependent manner, with concomitant inflammatory infiltration of both ventricles.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These changes were associated with an increased sarcolemmal expression of Fas and FasL, as well as increased activation of caspase 3, translocation of calpain 1 to the sarcolemma and sarcomere, and increased numbers of cells undergoing apoptosis.</Disease>
<Disease>These were associated with changes in dystrophin and cardiac troponin I localization, as well as loss of sarcolemmal integrity.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>

<Disease>The expression of Fas ligand in the myocardium, as identified in HIV-positive patients, might increase the susceptibility to HAART-induced cardiomyopathy due to activation of apoptotic pathways, resulting in cardiac dilation and dysfunction.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Valproate-induced chorea and encephalopathy in atypical nonketotic hyperglycinemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Nonketotic hyperglycinemia is a disorder of amino acid metabolism in which a defect in the glycine cleavage system leads to an accumulation of glycine in the brain and other body compartments.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the classical form it presents as neonatal apnea, intractable seizures, and hypotonia, followed by significant psychomotor retardation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>An important subset of children with nonketotic hyperglycinemia are atypical variants who present in a heterogeneous manner.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This report describes a patient with mild language delay and mental retardation, who was found to have nonketotic hyperglycinemia following her presentation with acute encephalopathy and chorea shortly after initiation of valproate therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Microinjection of ritanserin into the CA1 region of hippocampus improves scopolamine-induced amnesia in adult male rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The effect of ritanserin (5-HT2 antagonist) on scopolamine (muscarinic cholinergic antagonist)-induced amnesia in Morris water maze (MWM) was investigated.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Rats were divided into eight groups and bilaterally cannulated into CA1 region of the hippocampus.</Disease>

<Disease>One week later, they received repeatedly vehicles (saline, DMSO, saline+DMSO), scopolamine (2 microg/0.5 microl saline/side; 30 min before training), ritanserin (2, 4 and 8 microg/0.5 microl DMSO/side; 20 min before training) and scopolamine (2 microg/0.5 microl; 30 min before ritanserin injection)+ritanserin (4 microg/0.5 microl DMSO) through cannulae each day.</Disease>
<Disease>Animals were tested for four consecutive days (4 trial/day) in MWM during which the position of hidden platform was unchanged.</Disease>
<Disease>In the fifth day, the platform was elevated above the water surface in another position to evaluate the function of motor, motivational and visual systems.</Disease>
<Disease>The results showed a significant increase in escape latencies and traveled distances to find platform in scopolamine-treated group as compared to saline group.</Disease>
<Disease>Ritanserin-treated rats (4 microg/0.5 microl/side) showed a significant decrease in the mentioned parameters as compared to DMSO-treated group.</Disease>
<Disease>However, scopolamine and ritanserin co-administration resulted in a significant decrease in escape latencies and traveled distances as compared to the scopolamine-treated rats.</Disease>
<Disease>Our findings show that microinjection of ritanserin into the CA1 region of the hippocampus improves the scopolamine-induced amnesia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Hypoxia in renal disease with proteinuria and/or glomerular hypertension.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Despite the increasing need to identify and quantify tissue oxygenation at the cellular level, relatively few methods have been available.</Disease>

<Disease>In this study, we developed a new hypoxia-responsive reporter vector using a hypoxia-responsive element of the 5' vascular endothelial growth factor untranslated region and generated a novel hypoxia-sensing transgenic rat.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We then applied this animal model to the detection of tubulointerstitial hypoxia in the diseased kidney.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>With this model, we were able to identify diffuse cortical hypoxia in the puromycin aminonucleoside-induced nephrotic syndrome and focal and segmental hypoxia in the remnant kidney model.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Expression of the hypoxia-responsive transgene increased throughout the observation period, reaching 2.2-fold at 2 weeks in the puromycin aminonucleoside model and 2.6-fold at 4 weeks in the remnant kidney model, whereas that of vascular endothelial growth factor showed a mild decrease, reflecting distinct behaviors of the two genes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The degree of hypoxia showed a positive correlation with microscopic tubulointerstitial injury in both models.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Finally, we identified the localization of proliferating cell nuclear antigen-positive, ED-1-positive, and terminal dUTP nick-end labeled-positive cells in the hypoxic cortical area in the remnant kidney model.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We propose here a possible pathological tie between chronic tubulointerstitial hypoxia and progressive glomerular diseases.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Consensus statement concerning cardiotoxicity occurring during haematopoietic stem cell transplantation in the treatment of autoimmune diseases, with special reference to systemic sclerosis and multiple sclerosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Autologous haematopoietic stem cell transplantation is now a feasible and effective treatment for selected patients with severe autoimmune diseases.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Worldwide, over 650 patients have been transplanted in the context of phase I and II clinical trials.</Disease>
<Disease>The results are encouraging enough to begin randomised phase III trials.</Disease>
<Disease>However, as predicted, significant transplant-related morbidity and mortality have been observed.</Disease>
<Disease>This is primarily due to complications related to either the stage of the disease at transplant or due to infections.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The number of deaths related to cardiac toxicity is low.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, caution is required when cyclophosphamide or anthracyclines such as mitoxantrone are used in patients with a possible underlying heart damage, for example, systemic sclerosis patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In November 2002, a meeting was held in Florence, bringing together a number of experts in various fields, including rheumatology, cardiology, neurology, pharmacology and transplantation medicine.</Disease>

<Disease>The object of the meeting was to analyse existing data, both published or available, in the European Group for Blood and Marrow Transplantation autoimmune disease database, and to propose a safe approach to such patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A full cardiological assessment before and during the transplant emerged as the major recommendation.</Disease>

<Disease>Immunohistochemical study on inducible type of nitric oxide (iNOS), basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF) and tumor growth factor-beta1 (TGF-beta1) in arteritis induced in rats by fenoldopam and theophylline, vasodilators.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Arteritis induced in rats by vasodilators, fenoldopam and theophylline, was examined immunohistochemically for expressions of inducible type of nitric oxide synthase (iNOS), basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF) and tumor growth factor-beta1 (TGF-beta1).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Rats were administered fenoldopam for 24 hours by intravenous infusion with or without following repeated daily oral administrations of theophylline.</Disease>

<Disease>Irrespective of theophylline administration, iNOS antigens were remarkably abundant in ED-1-positive cells on day 5 and 8 post-fenoldopam-infusion (DPI); bFGF antigens were remarkably abundant in ED-1-positive cells on 1 and 3 DPI; TGF-beta1 antigens were observed in ED-1-positive cells on and after 5 DPI.</Disease>

<Disease>These results suggest that the peak expression of iNOS antigen was followed by that of bFGF antigen, and bFGF may have a suppressive effect on iNOS expression in these rat arteritis models.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>On the other hand, TGF-beta1 was not considered to have a suppressive effect on iNOS expression in these models.</Disease>
<Disease>Low-molecular-weight heparin for the treatment of patients with mechanical heart valves.</Disease>
<Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>

<Disease>The interruption of oral anticoagulant (OAC) administration is sometimes indicated in patients with mechanical heart valves, mainly before noncardiac surgery, non-surgical interventions, and pregnancy.</Disease>
<Disease>Unfractionated heparin (UH) is currently the substitute for selected patients.</Disease>

<Disease>Low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) offers theoretical advantages over UH, but is not currently considered in clinical guidelines as an alternative to UH in patients with prosthetic valves.</Disease>
<Disease>HYPOTHESIS:</Disease>
<Disease>The aim of the present study was to review the data accumulated so far on the use of LMWH in this patient population and to discuss its applicability in common practice.</Disease>
<Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>For this paper, the current medical literature on LMWH in patients with mechanical heart valves was extensively reviewed.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>There were eight series and six case reports.</Disease>
<Disease>None of the studies was randomized, and only one was prospective.</Disease>
<Disease>Data to establish the thromboembolic risk were incomplete.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>After excluding case reports, the following groups were constructed: (a) short-term administration, after valve insertion (n = 212); (b) short-term, perioperative (noncardiac)/periprocedural (n = 114); (c) long-term, due to intolerance to OAC (n = 16); (d) long-term, in pregnancy (n = 10).</Disease>

<Disease>The incidence rate of thromboembolism was 0.9% for all the studies and 0.5, 0, 20, and 0% in groups a, b, c, and d, respectively; for hemorrhage, the overall rate was 3.4% (3.8, 2.6, 10, and 0% for the respective groups).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>In patients with mechanical heart valves, short-term LMWH therapy compares favorably with UH.</Disease>
<Disease>Data on mid- and long-term LMWH administration in these patients are sparse.</Disease>
<Disease>Further randomized studies are needed to confirm the safety and precise indications for the use of LMWH in patients with mechanical heart valves.</Disease>
<Disease>Topiramate-induced nephrolithiasis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Topiramate is a recently developed antiepileptic medication that is becoming more widely prescribed because of its efficacy in treating refractory seizures.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Urologists should be aware that this medication can cause metabolic acidosis in patients secondary to inhibition of carbonic anhydrase.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, a distal tubular acidification defect may result, thus impairing the normal compensatory drop in urine pH.</Disease>
<Disease>These factors can lead to the development of calcium phosphate nephrolithiasis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report the first two cases of topiramate-induced nephrolithiasis in the urologic literature.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Spironolactone: is it a novel drug for the prevention of amphotericin B-related hypokalemia in cancer patients?</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE:</Disease>
<Disease>Nephrotoxicity is the major adverse effect of amphotericin B (AmB), often limiting administration of full dosage.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Selective distal tubular epithelial toxicity seems to be responsible for the profound potassium wasting that is a major clinical side effect of treatment with AmB. Potassium depletion also potentiates the tubular toxicity of AmB.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This study was designed to assess the ability of spironolactone to reduce potassium requirements and to prevent hypokalemia in neutropenic patients on AmB treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>In this study 26 patients with various hematological disorders were randomized to receive either intravenous AmB alone or AmB and oral spironolactone 100 mg twice daily when developing a proven or suspected fungal infection.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>Patients receiving concomitant AmB and spironolactone had significantly higher plasma potassium levels than those receiving AmB alone (P = 0.0027).</Disease>
<Disease>Those patients receiving AmB and spironolactone required significantly less potassium supplementation to maintain their plasma potassium within the normal range (P = 0.022).</Disease>
<Disease>Moreover, urinary potassium losses were significantly less in patients receiving AmB and spironolactone than those receiving AmB alone (P = 0.040).</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>This study showed that spironolactone can reduce potassium requirements and prevent hypokalemia by reducing urinary potassium loss in neutropenic patients on AmB treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Dopamine D2 receptor signaling controls neuronal cell death induced by muscarinic and glutamatergic drugs.</Disease>
<Disease>Dopamine (DA), through D1/D2 receptor-mediated signaling, plays a major role in the control of epileptic seizures arising in the limbic system.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Excitotoxicity leading to neuronal cell death in the affected areas is a major consequence of seizures at the cellular level.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In this respect, little is known about the role of DA receptors in the occurrence of epilepsy-induced neuronal cell death.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Here we analyze the occurrence of seizures and neurotoxicity in D2R -/- mice treated with the cholinergic agonist pilocarpine.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We compared these results with those previously obtained with kainic acid (KA), a potent glutamate agonist.</Disease>
<Disease>Importantly, D2R -/- mice develop seizures at doses of both drugs that are not epileptogenic for WT littermates and show greater neurotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, pilocarpine-induced seizures result in a more widespread neuronal death in both WT and D2R -/- brains in comparison to KA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, the absence of D2R lowers the threshold for seizures induced by both glutamate and acetylcholine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Moreover, the dopaminergic control of epilepsy-induced neurodegeneration seems to be mediated by distinct interactions of D2R signaling with these two neurotransmitters.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Treatment of risperidone-induced hyperprolactinemia with a dopamine agonist in children.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>Risperidone, a potent antagonist of both serotonergic (5HT2A) and dopaminergic D2 receptors is associated with hyperprolactinemia in adults and children.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Chronically elevated prolactin levels in children with prolactinomas may be associated with arrested growth and development resulting in either delayed puberty or short stature.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These possibilities stress the importance of developing a safe and effective approach to drug-induced hyperprolactinemia in youth.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report the successful treatment of risperidone-induced hyperprolactinemia with cabergoline in youth.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>We undertook a retrospective case review of four children with risperidone-induced hyperprolactinemia treated with cabergoline.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS: Four males (age 6-11 years) with Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (fourth edition) bipolar disorder or psychoses, with risperidone-induced elevations in serum prolactin levels (57.5-129 ng/mL, normal 5-15 ng/mL), were treated with cabergoline (mean dose 2.13 +/- 0.09 mg/week).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>When serum prolactin levels normalized in all four subjects (mean 11.2 +/- 10.9 ng/mL), the cabergoline dose was reduced to 1 mg/week in three of four subjects.</Disease>
<Disease>The mean duration of therapy with cabergoline was 523.5 +/- 129.7 days, and the mean duration of therapy with risperidone was 788.5 +/- 162.5 days.</Disease>
<Disease>Cabergoline was well tolerated without adverse effects.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Cabergoline may be useful for the treatment of risperidone-induced hyperprolactinemia in youth; however, further research is needed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Cholestatic jaundice associated with the use of metformin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report a patient who developed cholestatic jaundice shortly after initiation of treatment with metformin hydrochloride.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Ultrasound of the liver and abdominal CT were normal.</Disease>
<Disease>An ERCP showed normal biliary anatomy.</Disease>
<Disease>A percutaneous liver biopsy was obtained showing marked cholestasis, with portal edema, ductular proliferation, and acute inflammation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Metformin hydrochloride was discontinued, and the patient's jaundice resolved slowly over a period of several months.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Given the onset of his jaundice 2 wk after the initiation of metformin, we believe that this case represents an example of metformin-associated hepatotoxicity, the first such case reported.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Electro-oculography, electroretinography, visual evoked potentials, and multifocal electroretinography in patients with vigabatrin-attributed visual field constriction.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>PURPOSE:</Disease>
<Disease>Symptomatic visual field constriction thought to be associated with vigabatrin has been reported.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The current study investigated the visual fields and visual electrophysiology of eight patients with known vigabatrin-attributed visual field loss, three of whom were reported previously.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Six of the patients were no longer receiving vigabatrin.</Disease>
<Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>The central and peripheral fields were examined with the Humphrey Visual Field Analyzer.</Disease>

<Disease>Full visual electrophysiology, including flash electroretinography (ERG), pattern electroretinography, multifocal ERG using the VERIS system, electro-oculography, and flash and pattern visual evoked potentials, was undertaken.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS: Seven patients showed marked visual field constriction with some sparing of the temporal visual field.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The eighth exhibited concentric constriction.</Disease>

<Disease>Most electrophysiological responses were usually just within normal limits; two patients had subnormal Arden electro-oculography indices; and one patient showed an abnormally delayed photopic b wave.</Disease>
<Disease>However, five patients showed delayed 30-Hz flicker b waves, and seven patients showed delayed oscillatory potentials.</Disease>
<Disease>Multifocal ERG showed abnormalities that sometimes correlated with the visual field appearance and confirmed that the deficit occurs at the retinal level.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Marked visual field constriction appears to be associated with vigabatrin therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The field defects and some electrophysiological abnormalities persist when vigabatrin therapy is withdrawn.</Disease>
<Disease>Conversion to rapamycin immunosuppression in renal transplant recipients: report of an initial experience.</Disease>
<Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>The aim of this study is to evaluate the effects of RAPA conversion in patients undergoing cyclosporine (CsA) or tacrolimus (Tac) toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>Twenty renal transplant recipients were switched to fixed dose rapamycin (RAPA) (5 mg/day) 0</Disease>
<Disease>to 204 months posttransplant.</Disease>
<Disease>Drug monitoring was not initially used to adjust doses.</Disease>

<Disease>The indications for switch were chronic CsA or Tac nephrotoxicity (12), acute CsA or Tac toxicity (3), severe facial dysmorphism (2), posttransplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD) in remission (2), and hepatotoxicity in 1.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Follow-up is 7 to 24 months.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>In the 12 patients switched because of chronic nephrotoxicity there was a significant decrease in serum creatinine [233+/-34 to 210+/-56 micromol/liter (P<0.05) at 6 months].</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Facial dysmorphism improved in two patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No relapse of PTLD was observed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Compared with the score at rest (1.3+/-0.3), a significant aggravation of the dyskinesia score was observed during speaking aloud (5.2+/-1.1, p<0.05), movements of right (4.5+/-1.0, p<0.05) and left (3.7+/-0.8, p<0.05) fingers, movements of the neck (5.1+/-1.0, p<0.05), and mental calculation (3.1+/-1.0, p<0.05).</Disease>

text: <Disease>Structural and functional impairment of mitochondria in adriamycin-induced cardiomyopathy in mice: suppression of cytochrome c oxidase II gene expression.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The use of adriamycin (ADR) in cancer chemotherapy has been limited due to its cumulative cardiovascular toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Earlier observations that ADR interacts with mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase (COX) and suppresses its enzyme activity led us to investigate ADR's action on the cardiovascular functions and heart mitochondrial morphology in Balb-c mice i.p. treated with ADR for several weeks.</Disease>
<Disease>At various times during treatment, the animals were assessed for cardiovascular functions by electrocardiography and for heart tissue damage by electron microscopy.</Disease>

<Disease>In parallel, total RNA was extracted from samples of dissected heart and analyzed by Northern blot hybridization to determine the steady-state level of three RNA transcripts encoded by the COXII, COXIII, and COXIV genes.</Disease>
<Disease>Similarly, samples obtained from the liver of the same animals were analyzed for comparative studies.</Disease>

<Disease>Our results indicated that 1) treatment of mice with ADR caused cardiovascular arrhythmias characterized by bradycardia, extension of ventricular depolarization time (tQRS), and failure of QRS at high concentrations (10-14 mg/kg body weight cumulative dose); 2) the heart mitochondria underwent swelling, fusion, dissolution, and/or disruption of mitochondrial cristae after several weeks of treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Such abnormalities were not observed in the mitochondria of liver tissue; and 3) among the three genes of COX enzyme examined, only COXII gene expression was suppressed by ADR treatment, mainly after 8 weeks in both heart and liver.</Disease>

<Disease>Knowing that heart mitochondria represent almost 40% of heart muscle by weight, we conclude that the deteriorating effects of ADR on cardiovascular function involve mitochondrial structural and functional impairment.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Enhanced bradycardia induced by beta-adrenoceptor antagonists in rats pretreated with isoniazid.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Effects of cisapride on symptoms and postcibal small-bowel motor function in patients with irritable bowel syndrome.</Disease>

text: <Disease>METHODS: Thirty-eight patients with IBS (constipation-predominant, n = 17; diarrhoea-predominant, n = 21) underwent 24-h ambulatory jejunal manometry before and after 12 week's treatment [cisapride, 5 mg three times daily (n = 19) or placebo (n = 19)].</Disease>

text: <Disease>In cisapride-treated diarrhoea-predominant patients the mean contraction amplitude was higher (29.3 +/- 3.2 versus 24.9 +/- 2.6 mm Hg, cisapride versus placebo (P < 0.001); pretreatment, 25.7 +/- 6.0 mm Hg), the mean contraction duration longer (3.4 +/- 0.2 versus 3.0 +/- 0.2 sec, cisapride versus placebo (P < 0.001); pretreatment, 3.1 +/- 0.5 sec), and the mean contraction frequency lower (2.0 +/- 0.2 versus 2.5 +/- 0.4 cont./min, cisapride versus placebo (P < 0.001); pretreatment, 2.5 +/- 1.1 cont./min] than patients treated with placebo.</Disease>

label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Diarrhoea-predominant IBS patients had a higher pain score after cisapride therapy</Disease>

text: <Disease>[score, 55 +/- 15 versus 34 +/- 12 mm, cisapride versus placebo (P < 0.05); pretreatment, 67 +/- 19 mm].</Disease>

<Disease>Protective effect of misoprostol on indomethacin induced renal dysfunction in elderly patients.</Disease>

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the possible protective effects of misoprostol on renal function in hospitalized elderly patients treated with indomethacin.</Disease>

<Disease>METHODS: Forty-five hospitalized elderly patients (> 65 years old) who required therapy with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAID) were randomly assigned to receive either indomethacin, 150 mg/day (Group A), or indomethacin 150 mg/day plus misoprostol at 0.6 mg/day (Group B).</Disease>

<Disease>Laboratory variables of renal function [serum creatinine, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and electrolytes] were evaluated before initiation of therapy and every 2 days, until termination of the study (a period of at least 6 days).</Disease>
<Disease>Response to treatment was estimated by the visual analog scale for severity of pain.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS: Forty-two patients completed the study, 22 in Group A and 20 in Group B. BUN and creatinine increased by > 50% of baseline levels in 54 and 45% of Group A patients, respectively, compared to only 20 and 10% of Group B patients (p < 0.05).</Disease>
<Disease>Potassium (K) increment of 0.6 mEq/l or more was observed in 50% of Group A, but in only 15% of Group B patients (p < 0.05).</Disease>

<Disease>The mean increments in BUN, creatinine, and K were reduced by 63, 80, and 42%, respectively, in Group B patients compared to Group A. Response to treatment did not differ significantly between the 2 groups.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Hospitalized elderly patients are at risk for developing indomethacin related renal dysfunction.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Addition of misoprostol can minimize this renal impairment without affecting pain control.</Disease>

text: <Disease>To quantify the effects of gentamicin, kanamycin and netilmicin on renal protein reabsorption and accumulation, these drugs were administered to rats intraperitoneally (30 mg/kg/day) for 7, 14 or 21 days.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia after liver transplantation.</Disease>

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>

<Disease>Unfractionated heparin sodium (UFH) or low-molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is used in anticoagulant protocols at several institutions to prevent thrombosis after liver transplantation.</Disease>

text: <Disease>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Disease>

text: <Disease>Platelet count was measured daily for 3 weeks.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>The average platelet counts preoperatively, and on POD 7, 14, and 21 were 65, 88, 149, and 169 x 10(9)/L, respectively.</Disease>

<Disease>The heparin-induced platelet aggregation test was negative in these patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The percentage of HIT antibody-positive patients was 0.5% preoperatively, 5.6% on POD 7, and 5.6% on POD 14.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>None of the subjects/patients developed UFH-related HIT.</Disease>

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>In our series, the occurrence of HIT after liver transplantation was uncommon.</Disease>

Disease

text: <Disease>In pre-nephrotic stage the plasma level of fatty acids, triacylglycerol and VLDL decreased while that of phospholipid, cholesteryl esters and HDL remained constant.</Disease>

<Disease>When asystole was recorded, drug infusion was stopped and a resuscitation sequence was begun.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Epinephrine 0.01 mg/kg was administered at 1-min intervals while external cardiac compressions were applied.</Disease>
<Disease>Resuscitation was considered successful when a systolic arterial pressure > or =100 mm</Disease>
<Disease>Hg was achieved within 5 min.</Disease>
<Disease>The cumulative doses of levobupivacaine and ropivacaine that produced seizures were similar and were larger than those of bupivacaine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The cumulative doses of levobupivacaine that produced dysrhythmias and asystole were smaller than the corresponding doses of ropivacaine, but they were larger than those of bupivacaine.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The number of successful resuscitations did not differ among groups.</Disease>
<Disease>However, a smaller dose of epinephrine was required in the Ropivacaine group than in the other groups.</Disease>

<Disease>We conclude that the systemic toxicity of levobupivacaine is intermediate between that of ropivacaine and bupivacaine when administered at the same rate and that ropivacaine-induced cardiac arrest appears to be more susceptible to treatment than that induced by bupivacaine or levobupivacaine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>22-oxacalcitriol suppresses secondary hyperparathyroidism without inducing low bone turnover in dogs with renal failure.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>

<Disease>Calcitriol therapy suppresses serum levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in patients with renal failure but has several drawbacks, including hypercalcemia and/or marked suppression of bone turnover, which may lead to adynamic bone disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A new vitamin D analogue, 22-oxacalcitriol (OCT), has been shown to have promising characteristics.</Disease>
<Disease>This study was undertaken to determine the effects of OCT on serum PTH levels and bone turnover in states of normal or impaired renal function.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS: Sixty dogs were either nephrectomized (Nx, N = 38) or sham-operated (Sham, N = 22).</Disease>
<Disease>The animals received supplemental phosphate to enhance PTH secretion.</Disease>

<Disease>Fourteen weeks after the start of phosphate supplementation, half of the Nx and Sham dogs received doses of OCT (three times per week); the other half were given vehicle for 60 weeks.</Disease>
<Disease>Thereafter, the treatment modalities for a subset of animals were crossed over for an additional eight months.</Disease>

<Disease>Biochemical and hormonal indices of calcium and bone metabolism were measured throughout the study, and bone biopsies were done at baseline, 60 weeks after OCT or vehicle treatment, and at the end of the crossover period.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>In Nx dogs, OCT significantly decreased serum PTH levels soon after the induction of renal insufficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In long-standing secondary hyperparathyroidism, OCT (0.03 microg/kg) stabilized serum PTH levels during the first months.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Serum PTH levels rose thereafter, but the rise was less pronounced compared with baseline than the rise seen in Nx control.</Disease>
<Disease>These effects were accompanied by episodes of hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In animals with normal renal function, OCT induced a transient decrease in serum PTH levels at a dose of 0.1 microg/kg, which was not sustained with lowering of the doses.</Disease>
<Disease>In Nx dogs, OCT reversed abnormal bone formation, such as woven osteoid and fibrosis, but did not significantly alter the level of bone turnover.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, OCT improved mineralization lag time, (that is, the rate at which osteoid mineralizes) in both Nx and Sham dogs.</Disease>

<Disease>CONCLUSIONS: These results indicate that even though OCT does not completely prevent the occurrence of hypercalcemia in experimental dogs with renal insufficiency, it may be of use in the management of secondary hyperparathyroidism because it does not induce low bone turnover and, therefore, does not increase the risk of adynamic bone disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Chemotherapy of advanced inoperable non-small cell lung cancer with paclitaxel: a phase II trial.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Paclitaxel (Taxol; Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, Princeton, NJ) has demonstrated significant antineoplastic activity against different tumor types, notably ovarian and breast carcinoma.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Two phase II trials of 24-hour paclitaxel infusions in chemotherapy-naive patients with stage IIIB or IV non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) reported response rates of 21% and 24%.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Leukopenia was dose limiting: as many as 62.5% of patients experienced grade 4 leukopenia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We investigated the efficacy and toxicity of a 3-hour paclitaxel infusion in a phase II trial in patients with inoperable stage IIIB or IV NSCLC.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The 58 patients treated (41 men and 17 women) had a median age of 59 years (age range, 25 to 75) and a performance status of 0 through 2.</Disease>
<Disease>Most patients (72.4%) had stage IV NSCLC.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Paclitaxel 225 mg/m2 was infused over 3 hours every 3 weeks with standard prophylactic premedication.</Disease>
<Disease>Of 50 patients evaluable for response, 12 (24%) had partial remission, 26 (52%) had no change, and 12 had disease progression (24%).</Disease>
<Disease>Hematologic toxicities were mild: only one patient (2%) developed grade 3 or 4 neutropenia, while 29% had grade 1 or 2.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Grade 1 or 2 polyneuropathy affected 56% of patients while only one (2%) experienced severe polyneuropathy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Similarly, grade 1 or 2 myalgia/arthralgia was observed in 63.2% of patients, but only 14.3% experienced grade 3 or 4.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Nausea and vomiting were infrequent, with 14% of patients experiencing grade 1 or 2 and only 2% experiencing grade 3 or 4.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Paclitaxel is thus an active single agent in this patient population, with a 3-hour infusion proving comparably effective to a 24-hour infusion and superior in terms of the incidence of hematologic and nonhematologic toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Further phase II studies with paclitaxel combined with other drugs active against NSCLC are indicated, and phase III studies comparing paclitaxel with standard chemotherapy remain to be completed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Cerebral hemorrhage associated with phenylpropanolamine in combination with caffeine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Phenylpropanolamine (PPA) is a drug that has been associated with serious side effects including stroke.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It is often combined with caffeine in diet preparations and "look-alike" pills.</Disease>

<Disease>In order to determine if PPA/caffeine can lead to stroke in normotensive and/or hypertensive rats, we administered the combination in six times the allowed human dose calculated on a per weight basis for the rats two times per day for five days.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Subarachnoid and cerebral hemorrhage was noted in 18% of the hypertensive rats.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A single PPA/caffeine administration (same dose) lead to acute hypertension in both the normotensive and hypertensive animals.</Disease>

Disease

text: <Disease>These results suggest that PPA/caffeine can lead to cerebral hemorrhage in previously hypertensive animals when administered in greater than the allowed dosage.</Disease>

<Disease>Long-term efficacy and toxicity of high-dose amiodarone therapy for ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Amiodarone was administered to 154 patients who had sustained, symptomatic ventricular tachycardia (VT) (n = 118) or a cardiac arrest (n = 36) and who were refractory to conventional antiarrhythmic drugs.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The loading dose was 800 mg/day for 6 weeks and the maintenance dose was 600 mg/day.</Disease>

<Disease>Sixty-nine percent of patients continued treatment with amiodarone and had no recurrence of symptomatic VT or ventricular fibrillation (VF) over a follow-up of 6 to 52 months (mean +/- standard deviation 14.2 +/- 8.2).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Six percent of the patients had a nonfatal recurrence of VT and were successfully managed by continuing amiodarone at a higher dose or by the addition of a conventional antiarrhythmic drug.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One or more adverse drug reactions occurred in 51% of patients.</Disease>
<Disease>Adverse effects forced a reduction in the dose of amiodarone in 41% and discontinuation of amiodarone in 10% of patients.</Disease>

<Disease>The most common symptomatic adverse reactions were tremor or ataxia (35%), nausea and anorexia (8%), visual halos or blurring (6%), thyroid function abnormalities (6%) and pulmonary interstitial infiltrates (5%).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Although large-dose amiodarone is highly effective in the long-term treatment of VT or VF refractory to conventional antiarrhythmic drugs, it causes significant toxicity in approximately 50% of patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, when the dose is adjusted based on clinical response or the development of adverse effects, 75% of patients with VT or VF can be successfully managed with amiodarone.</Disease>
label: Disease
