text: <Disease>Impact of alcohol exposure after pregnancy recognition on ultrasonographic fetal growth measures.</Disease>

<Disease>BACKGROUND: More than 3 decades after Jones and Smith (1973) reported on the devastation caused by alcohol exposure on fetal development, the rates of heavy drinking during pregnancy remain relatively unchanged.</Disease>
<Disease>Early identification of fetal alcohol exposure and maternal abstinence led to better infant outcomes.</Disease>
<Disease>This study examined the utility of biometry for detecting alcohol-related fetal growth impairment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>We obtained fetal ultrasound measures from routine ultrasound examinations for 167 pregnant hazardous drinkers who were enrolled in a brief alcohol intervention study.</Disease>

<Disease>The fetal measures for women who quit after learning of their pregnancies were compared with measures for women who continued some drinking throughout the course of their pregnancies.</Disease>

<Disease>Because intensity of alcohol consumption is associated with poorer fetal outcomes, separate analyses were conducted for the heavy (average of >or=5 drinks per drinking day) alcohol consumers.</Disease>

<Disease>Fetal measures from the heavy-exposed fetuses were also compared with measures from a nondrinking group that was representative of normal, uncomplicated pregnancies from our clinics.</Disease>
<Disease>Analyses of covariance were used to determine whether there were differences between groups after controlling for influences of gestational age and drug abuse.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS: Nearly half of the pregnant drinkers abstained after learning of their pregnancies.</Disease>

<Disease>When women reportedly quit drinking early in their pregnancies, fetal growth measures were not significantly different from a non-alcohol-exposed group, regardless of prior drinking patterns.</Disease>

<Disease>Any alcohol consumption postpregnancy recognition among the heavy drinkers resulted in reduced cerebellar growth as well as decreased cranial to body growth in comparison with women who either quit drinking or who were nondrinkers.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Amphetamine abuse was predictive of larger cranial to body growth ratios.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Alterations in fetal biometric measurements were observed among the heavy drinkers only when they continued drinking after becoming aware of their pregnancies.</Disease>

<Disease>Although the reliance on self-reported drinking is a limitation in this study, these findings support the benefits of early abstinence and the potential for ultrasound examinations in the detection of fetal alcohol effects.</Disease>
<Disease>Urinary symptoms and quality of life changes in Thai women with overactive bladder after tolterodine treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVES:</Disease>
<Disease>To study the urinary symptoms and quality of life changes in Thai women with overactive bladder (OAB) after tolterodine treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>MATERIAL AND METHOD:</Disease>

<Disease>Thirty women (aged 30-77 years) diagnosed as having OAB at the Gynecology Clinic, King Chulalongkorn Memorial Hospital from January to April 2004 were included in the present study.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Tolterodine 2 mg, twice daily was given.</Disease>
<Disease>After 8 weeks treatment, changes in micturition diary variables and tolerability were determined.</Disease>
<Disease>Short form 36 (SF36) questionaires (Thai version) were given before and after 8 weeks of treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>At 8 weeks, all micturition per day decreased from 16.</Disease>
<Disease>7 +/- 5. 3 to 6.</Disease>
<Disease>7 +/- 2.4 times per day.</Disease>
<Disease>The number of nocturia episodes decreased from 5.4 +/- 4.2 to 1.1 +/- 1.0 times per night.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The most common side effect was dry month in 5 cases (16.7%) with 2 cases reporting a moderate degree and 1 case with severe degree.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Only one case (3.3%) withdrew from the present study due to a severe dry mouth.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The SF-36 scores changed significantly in the domains of physical functioning, role function emotional, social function and mental heath.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Tolterodine was well tolerated and its effects improved the quality of life in Thai women with OAB.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Absence of acute cerebral vasoconstriction after cocaine-associated subarachnoid hemorrhage.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>INTRODUCTION:</Disease>
<Disease>Cocaine use has been associated with neurovascular complications, including arterial vasoconstriction and vasculitis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, there are few studies of angiographic effects of cocaine on human cerebral arteries.</Disease>

<Disease>Information on these effects could be obtained from angiograms of patients with cocaine-associated subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) who underwent angiography shortly after cocaine use.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>We screened patients with SAH retrospectively and identified those with positive urine toxicology for cocaine or its metabolites.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Quantitative arterial diameter measurements from angiograms of these patients were compared to measurements from control patients with SAH who were matched for factors known to influence arterial diameter.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Qualitative comparisons of small artery changes also were made.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS: Thirteen patients with positive cocaine toxicology were compared to 26 controls.</Disease>

<Disease>There were no significant differences between groups in the mean diameters of the intradural internal carotid, sphenoidal segment of the middle cerebral, precommunicating segment of the anterior cerebral, or basilar arteries (p greater than 0.05 for all comparisons, unpaired t-tests).</Disease>

<Disease>There also were no significant differences between groups when expressing diameters as the sum of the precommunicating segment of the anterior cerebral + sphenoidal segment of the middle cerebral + supraclinoid internal carotid artery + basilar artery divided by the diameter of the petrous internal carotid artery (p greater than 0.05, unpaired t-tests).</Disease>
<Disease>Qualitative assessments showed two arterial irregularities in the distal vasculature in each group.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>

<Disease>No quantitative evidence for narrowing of large cerebral arteries or qualitative angiographic evidence for distal narrowing or vasculitis could be found in patients who underwent angiography after aneurysmal SAH associated with cocaine use.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Atrial fibrillation following chemotherapy for stage IIIE diffuse large B-cell gastric lymphoma in a patient with myotonic dystrophy (Steinert's disease).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The authors describe the unusual association between diffuse B-cell gastric lymphoma and myotonic dystrophy, the most common form of adult muscular dystrophy, and sudden atrial fibrillation following one cycle of doxorubicin-based chemotherapy in the same patient.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Atrial fibrillation or other cardiac arrhythmias are unusual complications in patients treated with chemotherapy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The cardiac toxicity intrinsically associated with the aggressive chemotherapy employed could function as a triggering factor for the arrhythmia in the predisposed myocardium of this patient.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A phase II study of thalidomide in advanced metastatic renal cell carcinoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the toxicity and activity of thalidomide in patients with advanced metastatic renal cell cancer and to measure changes of one angiogenic factor, vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)165, with therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>PATIENTS AND METHODS: 29 patients were enrolled on a study of thalidomide using an intra-patient dose escalation schedule.</Disease>
<Disease>Patients began thalidomide at 400 mg/d and escalated as tolerated to 1200 mg/d by day 54.</Disease>
<Disease>Fifty-nine per cent of patients had had previous therapy with IL-2 and 52% were performance status 2 or 3.</Disease>
<Disease>Systemic plasma VEGF165 levels were measured by dual monoclonal ELISA in 8 patients.</Disease>

<Disease>RESULTS: 24 patients were evaluable for response with one partial response of 11 months duration of a patient with hepatic and pulmonary metastases (4%), one minor response, and 2 patients stable for over 6 months.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Somnolence and constipation were prominent toxicities and most patients could not tolerate the 1200 mg/day dose level.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Systemic plasma VEGF165 levels did not change with therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>These results are consistent with a low level of activity of thalidomide in renal cell carcinoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Administration of doses over 800 mg/day was difficult to achieve in this patient population, however lower doses were practical.</Disease>
<Disease>The dose-response relationship, if any, of thalidomide for renal cell carcinoma is unclear.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The striatum as a target for anti-rigor effects of an antagonist of mGluR1, but not an agonist of group II metabotropic glutamate receptors.</Disease>

<Disease>The aim of the present study was to find out whether the metabotropic receptor 1 (mGluR1) and group II mGluRs, localized in the striatum, are involved in antiparkinsonian-like effects in rats.</Disease>
<Disease>Haloperidol (1 mg/kg ip) induced parkinsonian-like muscle rigidity, measured as an increased resistance of a rat's hind foot to passive flexion and extension at the ankle joint.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>(RS)-1-aminoindan-1,5-dicarboxylic acid (AIDA; 0.5-15 microg/0.5 microl), a potent and selective mGluR1 antagonist, or (2R,4R)-4-aminopyrrolidine-2,4-dicarboxylate (2R,4R-APDC; 7.5-15 microg/0.5 microl), a selective group II agonist, was injected bilaterally into the striatum of haloperidol-treated animals.</Disease>
<Disease>AIDA in doses of 7.5-15 microg/0.5 microl diminished the haloperidol-induced muscle rigidity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In contrast, 2R,4R-APDC injections were ineffective.</Disease>
<Disease>The present results may suggest that the blockade of striatal mGluR1, but not the stimulation of group II mGluRs, may ameliorate parkinsonian muscle rigidity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Acute cholestatic hepatitis after exposure to isoflurane.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To report a case of acute cholestatic hepatitis following exposure to the inhalational anesthetic isoflurane.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CASE SUMMARY:</Disease>
<Disease>A 70-year-old healthy woman from Iraq developed acute cholestatic hepatitis 3 weeks following repair of the right rotator cuff under general anesthesia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>There was no evidence for viral, autoimmune, or metabolic causes of hepatitis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No other medications were involved except for dipyrone for analgesia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The alanine aminotransferase was elevated to a peak concentration of 1533 U/L and the serum bilirubin reached a peak of 17.0 mg/dL.</Disease>
<Disease>There was slow improvement over 4 months.</Disease>
<Disease>Accidental reexposure by the patient to dipyrone was uneventful.</Disease>
<Disease>DISCUSSION:</Disease>
<Disease>The clinical and histologic picture of this case resembles halothane hepatitis, which has a significant mortality rate.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Isoflurane, a common anesthetic agent, can cause severe cholestatic hepatitis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Calcitonin gene-related peptide levels during nitric oxide-induced headache in patients with chronic tension-type headache.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It has been proposed that nitric oxide (NO) induced headache in primary headaches may be associated with release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the present study we aimed to investigate plasma levels of CGRP during headache induced by the NO donor glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) in 16 patients with chronic tension-type headache and 16 healthy controls.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The subjects were randomly allocated to receive 0.5 microg/kg/min GTN or placebo over 20 min on two headache-free days.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Blood samples were collected at baseline, 10, 20 and 60 min after start of infusion.</Disease>

<Disease>Both patients and controls developed significantly stronger immediate headache on the GTN day than on the placebo day and the headache was significantly more pronounced in patients than in controls.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>There was no difference between the area under the CGRP curve (AUCCGRP) on GTN vs. placebo day in either patients (P=0.65) or controls (P=0.48).</Disease>
<Disease>The AUCCGRP recorded on the GTN day did not differ between patients and controls (P=0.36).</Disease>
<Disease>Both in patients and controls, CGRP levels changed significantly over time, on both the GTN and placebo days (P < 0.05).</Disease>
<Disease>The present study indicates that NO-induced immediate headache is not associated with release of CGRP.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Myocardial ischemia due to coronary artery spasm during dobutamine stress echocardiography.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Dobutamine stress echocardiography (DSE) is a useful and safe provocation test for myocardial ischemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Until now, the test has been focused only on the organic lesion in the coronary artery, and positive DSE has indicated the presence of significant fixed coronary artery stenosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The aim of the present study is to examine whether myocardial ischemia due to coronary spasm is induced by dobutamine.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We performed DSE on 51 patients with coronary spastic angina but without significant fixed coronary artery stenosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>All patients had anginal attacks at rest with ST elevation on the electrocardiogram (variant angina).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Coronary spasm was induced by intracoronary injection of acetylcholine, and no fixed coronary artery stenosis was documented on angiograms in all patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>DSE was performed with intravenous dobutamine infusion with an incremental doses of 5, 10, 20, 30, and 40 microg/kg/min every 5 minutes.</Disease>
<Disease>Of the 51 patients, 7 patients showed asynergy with ST elevation.</Disease>
<Disease>All 7 patients (13.7%) had chest pain during asynergy, and both chest pain and electrocardiographic changes were preceded by asynergy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These findings indicate that dobutamine can provoke coronary spasm in some patients with coronary spastic angina.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>When DSE is performed to evaluate coronary artery disease, not only fixed coronary stenosis, but also coronary spasm should be considered as a genesis of asynergy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Nitric oxide synthase expression in the course of lead-induced hypertension.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We recently showed elevated reactive oxygen species (ROS), reduced urinary excretion of NO metabolites (NOx), and increased NO sequestration as nitrotyrosine in various tissues in rats with lead-induced hypertension.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This study was designed to discern whether the reduction in urinary NOx in lead-induced hypertension is, in part, due to depressed NO synthase (NOS) expression.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Male Sprague-Dawley rats were randomly assigned to a lead-treated group (given lead acetate, 100 ppm, in drinking water and regular rat chow), a group given lead and vitamin E-fortified chow, or a normal control group given either regular food and water or vitamin E-fortified food for 12 weeks.</Disease>
<Disease>Tail blood pressure, urinary NOx excretion, plasma malondialdehyde (MDA), and endothelial and inducible NOS (eNOS and iNOS) isotypes in the aorta and kidney were measured.</Disease>

<Disease>The lead-treated group exhibited a rise in blood pressure and plasma MDA concentration, a fall in urinary NOx excretion, and a paradoxical rise in vascular and renal tissue eNOS and iNOS expression.</Disease>

<Disease>Vitamin E supplementation ameliorated hypertension, lowered plasma MDA concentration, and raised urinary NOx excretion while significantly lowering vascular, but not renal, tissue eNOS and iNOS expression.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Vitamin E supplementation had no effect on either blood pressure, plasma MDA, or NOS expression in the control group.</Disease>
<Disease>The study also revealed significant inhibition of NOS enzymatic activity by lead in cell-free preparations.</Disease>
<Disease>In conclusion, lead-induced hypertension in this model was associated with a compensatory upregulation of renal and vascular eNOS and iNOS expression.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This is, in part, due to ROS-mediated NO inactivation, lead-associated inhibition of NOS activity, and perhaps stimulatory actions of increased shear stress associated with hypertension.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Risk for valvular heart disease among users of fenfluramine and dexfenfluramine who underwent echocardiography before use of medication.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND: Because uncontrolled echocardiographic surveys suggested that up to 30% to 38% of users of fenfluramine and dexfenfluramine had valvular disease, these drugs were withdrawn from the market.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE:</Disease>

<Disease>To determine the risk for new or worsening valvular abnormalities among users of fenfluramine or dexfenfluramine who underwent echocardiography before they began to take these medications.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>DESIGN:</Disease>
<Disease>Cohort study.</Disease>
<Disease>SETTING:</Disease>
<Disease>Academic primary care practices.</Disease>
<Disease>PATIENTS: 46 patients who used fenfluramine or dexfenfluramine for 14 days or more and had echocardiograms obtained before therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>MEASUREMENTS:</Disease>
<Disease>Follow-up echocardiography.</Disease>

<Disease>The primary outcome was new or worsening valvulopathy, defined as progression of either aortic or mitral regurgitation by at least one degree of severity and disease that met U.S. Food and Drug Administration criteria (at least mild aortic regurgitation or moderate mitral regurgitation).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS: Two patients (4.3% [95% CI, 0.6% to 14.8%]) receiving fenfluramine-phentermine developed valvular heart disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One had baseline bicuspid aortic valve and mild aortic regurgitation that progressed to moderate regurgitation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The second patient developed new moderate aortic insufficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Users of diet medications are at risk for valvular heart disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, the incidence may be lower than that reported previously.</Disease>
<Disease>Carboplatin toxic effects on the peripheral nervous system of the rat.</Disease>
<Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>The most striking of carboplatin's advantages (CBDCA) over cisplatin (CDDP) is its markedly reduced rate of neurotoxic effects.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, the use of CBDCA higher-intensity schedules and the association with other neurotoxic drugs in polychemotherapy may cause some concern about its safety with respect to peripheral nervous system damage.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>MATERIALS AND METHODS: Two different schedules of CBDCA administration (10 mg/kg and 15 mg/kg i.p.</Disease>
<Disease>twice a week for nine times) were evaluated in Wistar rats.</Disease>
<Disease>Neurotoxicity was assessed for behavioral (tail-flick test), neurophysiological (nerve conduction velocity in the tail nerve), morphological, morphometrical and analytical effects.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>CBDCA administration induced dose-dependent peripheral neurotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pain perception and nerve conduction velocity in the tail were significantly impaired, particularly after the high-dose treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The dorsal root ganglia sensory neurons and, to a lesser extent, satellite cells showed the same changes as those induced by CDDP, mainly affecting the nucleus and nucleolus of ganglionic sensory neurons.</Disease>
<Disease>Moreover, significant amounts of platinum were detected in the dorsal root ganglia and kidney after CBDCA treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>

<Disease>CBDCA is neurotoxic in our model, and the type of pathological changes it induces are so closely similar to those caused by CDDP that it is probable that neurotoxicity is induced in the two drugs by the same mechanism.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This model can be used alone or in combination with other drugs to explore the effect of CBDCA on the peripheral nervous system.</Disease>

<Disease>Iatrogenic risks of endometrial carcinoma after treatment for breast cancer in a large French case-control study. F  d  ration Nationale des Centres de Lutte Contre le Cancer (FNCLCC).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Since tamoxifen is widely used in breast cancer treatment and has been proposed for the prevention of breast cancer, its endometrial iatrogenic effects must be carefully examined.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have investigated the association between endometrial cancer and tamoxifen use or other treatments in women treated for breast cancer in a case-control study.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Cases of endometrial cancer diagnosed after breast cancer (n = 135) and 467 controls matched for age, year of diagnosis of breast cancer and hospital and survival time with an intact uterus were included.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Women who had received tamoxifen were significantly more likely to have endometrial cancer diagnosed than those who had not (crude relative risk = 4.9, p = 0.0001).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Univariate and adjusted analyses showed that the risk increased with the length of treatment (p = 0.0001) or the cumulative dose of tamoxifen received (p = 0.0001), irrespective of the daily dose.</Disease>
<Disease>Women who had undergone pelvic radiotherapy also had a higher risk (crude relative risk = 7.8, p = 0.0001).</Disease>
<Disease>After adjusting for confounding factors, the risk was higher for tamoxifen users (p = 0.0012), treatment for more than 3 years (all p < 0.03) and pelvic radiotherapy (p = 0.012).</Disease>
<Disease>Women who had endometrial cancer and had received tamoxifen had more advanced disease and poorer prognosis than those with endometrial cancer who had not received this treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Our results suggest a causal role of tamoxifen in endometrial cancer, particularly when used as currently proposed for breast cancer prevention.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Pelvic radiotherapy may be an additional iatrogenic factor for women with breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Endometrial cancers diagnosed in women treated with tamoxifen have poorer prognosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Women who receive tamoxifen for breast cancer should be offered gynaecological surveillance during and after treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A long-term evaluation of the risk-benefit ratio of tamoxifen as a preventive treatment for breast cancer is clearly warranted.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Granulosa cell tumor of the ovary associated with antecedent tamoxifen use.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND: Increased attention has been focused recently on the estrogenic effects of tamoxifen.</Disease>
<Disease>Review of the literature reveals an association between tamoxifen use and gynecologic tumors.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CASE:</Disease>
<Disease>A 52-year-old postmenopausal woman was treated with tamoxifen for stage II estrogen receptor-positive breast carcinoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Her aspartate transaminase and alanine transaminase levels increase markedly after 6 months of tamoxifen use.</Disease>
<Disease>After an additional 17 months of elevated serum transaminases, the patient was found to have a stage Ic granulosa cell tumor of the ovary.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Patients with tamoxifen-induced liver dysfunction may be at increased risk for granulosa cell tumors because of alterations in tamoxifen metabolism.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A murine model of adenomyosis: the effects of hyperprolactinemia induced by fluoxetine hydrochloride, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, on adenomyosis induction in Wistar albino rats.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE:</Disease>
<Disease>The aim of this study was to investigate whether fluoxetine given to castrated and noncastrated rats caused hyperprolactinemia and its effects with respect to adenomyosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>DESIGN:</Disease>
<Disease>Fluoxetine, a serotonin reuptake inhibitor, was given to Wistar Albino rats for 98 days to produce hyperprolactinemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The drug was given to two groups consisting of castrated and noncastrated rats and compared to two groups of castrated and noncastrated controls.</Disease>
<Disease>Prolactin levels were measured and the uteri of the rats were removed for histopathological analysis at the end of 98 days.</Disease>
<Disease>SETTING:</Disease>
<Disease>Marmara University School of Medicine, Department of Histology and Embryology, Zeynep Kamil Women and Children's Hospital.</Disease>
<Disease>MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Serum prolactin levels, uterine histopathology.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>The prolactin levels of castrated and noncastrated groups treated with fluoxetine were statistically significantly higher when compared to their respective control groups.</Disease>
<Disease>Histological studies revealed 11 cases of adenomyosis, all within the noncastrated group receiving fluoxetine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>

<Disease>It was suggested that high serum prolactin levels cause degeneration of myometrial cells in the presence of ovarian steroids that results in a myometrial invasion by endometrial stroma.</Disease>
<Disease>This invasion eventually progresses to adenomyosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Effects of deliberate hypotension induced by labetalol with isoflurane on neuropsychological function.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The effect of deliberate hypotension on brain function measured by neuropsychological tests was studied in 41 adult patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Twenty-four patients were anaesthetized for middle-ear surgery with deliberate hypotension induced by labetalol with isoflurane (hypotensive group).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Seventeen patients without hypotension served as a control group.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mean arterial pressure was 77 +/- 2 mmHg (10.3 +/- 0.3 kPa) before hypotension and 50 +/- 0</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>mmHg (6.7 +/- 0.0 kPa) during hypotension in the hypotensive group, and 86 +/- 2 mmHg (11.5 +/- 0.3 kPa) during anaesthesia in the control group.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The following psychological tests were performed: four subtests of the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (similarities, digit span, vocabulary and digit symbol), Trail-Making tests A and B, Zung tests (self-rating anxiety scale and self-rating depression scale) and two-part memory test battery with immediate and delayed recall.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The tests were performed preoperatively and 2 days postoperatively.</Disease>
<Disease>There were no statistically significant differences between the groups in any of the tests in the changes from preoperative value to postoperative value.</Disease>
<Disease>The results indicate that hypotension induced by labetalol with isoflurane has no significant harmful effects on mental functions compared to normotensive anaesthesia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Auditory disturbance associated with interscalene brachial plexus block.</Disease>
<Disease>We performed an audiometric study in 20 patients who underwent surgery of the shoulder region under an interscalene brachial plexus block (IBPB).</Disease>
<Disease>Bupivacaine 0.75% with adrenaline was given followed by a 24-hr continuous infusion of 0.25% bupivacaine.</Disease>
<Disease>Three audiometric threshold measurements (0.25-18 kHz) were made: the first before IBPB, the second 2-6 h after surgery and the third on the first day after operation.</Disease>
<Disease>In four patients hearing impairment on the side of the block was demonstrated after operation, in three measurements on the day of surgery and in one on the following day.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The frequencies at which the impairment occurred varied between patients; in one only low frequencies (0.25-0.5 kHz) were involved.</Disease>
<Disease>The maximum change in threshold was 35 dB at 6 kHz measured at the end of the continuous infusion of bupivacaine.</Disease>
<Disease>This patient had hearing threshold changes (15-20 dB) at 6-10 kHz on the opposite side also.</Disease>
<Disease>IBPB may cause transient auditory dysfunction in the ipsilateral ear, possibly via an effect on sympathetic innervation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Midazolam compared with thiopentone as an induction agent.</Disease>
<Disease>In patients premedicated with scopolamine + morphine (+5 mg nitrazepam the evening before surgery),</Disease>
<Disease>the sleep-inducing effect of midazolam 0.15 mg/kg i.v. was clearly slower in onset than that of thiopentone 4.67 mg/kg i.v.</Disease>
<Disease>Somewhat fewer cardiovascular and local sequelae were found in the midazolam group, but, although apnoea occurred less often in the midazolam group it lasted longer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>On the whole, the differences between midazolam and thiopentone had no apparent clinical consequences.</Disease>
<Disease>Midazolam is a new alternative agent for induction in combination anaesthesia.</Disease>
<Disease>Cardiotoxic and possible leukemogenic effects of adriamycin in nonhuman primates.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>10 monkeys (macaques) received adriamycin by monthly intravenous injections at 12 mg/m2 (1 mg/kg).</Disease>
<Disease>8 of the 10 monkeys developed congestive heart failure at an average cumulative adriamycin dose (310 mg/m2) well below that considered the safe upper limit (550 mg/m2) in man.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Histologically, the myocardial lesions resembled those found in human anthracycline-induced cardiomyopathy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>1 of the 10 monkeys developed acute myeloblastic leukemia after receiving 324 mg/m2 of adriamycin; the 10th monkey is alive and well 26 months after the last dose of drug.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our results suggest that adriamycin is a more potent cardiotoxin in monkeys than in man, and that leukemia may be a consequence of prolonged treatment with this drug.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Doxorubicin cardiomyopathy in children with left-sided Wilms tumor.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Two children with Wilms tumor of the left kidney experienced severe anthracycline cardiomyopathy after irradiation to the tumor bed and conventional dosage of doxorubicin.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The cardiomyopathy is attributed 1) to the fact that radiation fields for left Wilms tumor include the lower portion of the heart and 2) to the interaction of doxorubicin and irradiation on cardiac muscle.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It is recommended that doxorubicin dosage be sharply restricted in children with Wilms tumor of the left kidney who receive postoperative irradiation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Promotional effects of testosterone and dietary fat on prostate carcinogenesis in genetically susceptible rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Germfree (GF)</Disease>
<Disease>Lobund strain Wistar (LW) rats, fed vegetable diet L-485, have developed prostate adenocarcinomas spontaneously (10% incidence) at average age 34 months.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Conventional LW rats, implanted with testosterone at age 4 months, developed a higher incidence of prostate cancer after an average interval of 14 months: 24% had developed gross tumors, and 40% when it included microscopic tumors.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Preliminary results indicate that testosterone-treated LW rats that were fed the same diet, which was supplemented with corn oil up to 20% fat, developed prostate cancer after intervals of 6-12 months.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Aged GF Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats have not developed prostate cancer spontaneously.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Conventional SD rats fed diet L-485 and treated with testosterone developed only prostatitis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Experimental designs should consider genetic susceptibility as a basic prerequisite for studies on experimental prostate cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mitomycin C associated hemolytic uremic syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mitomycin C associated Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is a potentially fatal but uncommon condition that is not yet widely recognised.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It consists of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia and progressive renal failure associated with mitomycin C treatment and affects about 10% of patients treated with this agent.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The renal failure usually develops about 8-10 mth after start of mitomycin C treatment and the mortality is approximately 60% from renal failure or pulmonary edema.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Renal lesions are similar to those seen in idiopathic HUS and include arteriolar fibrin thrombi, expanded subendothelial zones in glomerular capillary walls, ischemic wrinkling of glomerular basement membranes and mesangiolysis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The mechanism of action is postulated as mitomycin C-induced endothelial cell damage.</Disease>

<Disease>We describe the clinical course and pathological findings in a 65 yr-old man with gastric adenocarcinoma who developed renal failure and thrombocytopenia while on treatment with mitomycin C and died in pulmonary edema.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Continuous ambulatory ECG monitoring during fluorouracil therapy: a prospective study.</Disease>
<Disease>Although there have been anecdotal reports of cardiac toxicity associated with fluorouracil (5-FU) therapy, this phenomenon has not been studied in a systematic fashion.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We prospectively performed continuous ambulatory ECG monitoring on 25 patients undergoing 5-FU infusion for treatment of solid tumors in order to assess the incidence of ischemic ST changes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Patients were monitored for 23 +/- 4 hours before 5-FU infusion, and 98 +/- 9 hours during 5-FU infusion.</Disease>
<Disease>Anginal episodes were rare: only one patient had angina (during 5-FU infusion).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, asymptomatic ST changes (greater than or equal to 1 mm ST deviation) were common: six of 25 patients (24%) had ST changes before 5-FU infusion v 17 (68%) during 5-FU infusion (P less than .002).</Disease>

<Disease>The incidence of ischemic episodes per patient per hour was 0.05 +/- 0.02 prior to 5-FU infusion v 0.13 +/- 0.03 during 5-FU infusion (P less than .001); the duration of ECG changes was 0.6 +/- 0.3 minutes per patient per hour before 5-FU v 1.9 +/- 0.5 minutes per patient per hour during 5-FU (P less than .01).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>ECG changes were more common among patients with known coronary artery disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>There were two cases of sudden death, both of which occurred at the end of the chemotherapy course.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We conclude that 5-FU infusion is associated with a significant increase in silent ST segment deviation suggestive of ischemia, particularly among patients with coronary artery disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The mechanism and clinical significance of these ECG changes remain to be determined.</Disease>
<Disease>Lethal anuria complicating high dose ifosfamide chemotherapy in a breast cancer patient with an impaired renal function.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A sixty-year-old woman with advanced breast cancer, previously treated with cisplatin, developed an irreversible lethal renal failure with anuria, the day after 5 g/m2 bolus ifosfamide.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Postrenal failure was excluded by echography.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A prerenal component could have contributed to renal failure because of a transient hypotension, due to an increasing ascitis, occurring just before anuria.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, correction of the hemodynamic parameters did not improve renal function.</Disease>
<Disease>Ifosfamide is a known nephrotoxic drug with demonstrated tubulopathies.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We strongly suspect that this lethal anuria was mainly due to ifosfamide, occurring in a patient having received previous cisplatin chemotherapy and with poor kidney perfusion due to transient hypotension.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We recommend careful use of ifosfamide in patients pretreated with nephrotoxic chemotherapy and inadequate renal perfusion.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Central vein thrombosis and topical dipivalyl epinephrine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A report is given on an 83-year-old female who acquired central vein thrombosis in her seeing eye one day after having started topical medication with dipivalyl epinephrine for advanced glaucoma discovered in the other eye.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>From present knowledge about the effects of adrenergic eye drops on ocular blood circulation, it is difficult to suggest an association between the two events, which may be coincidental only.</Disease>
<Disease>Amelioration of bendrofluazide-induced hypokalemia by timolol.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The beta adrenergic blocking drug, timolol, tended to correct the hypokalemia of short-term bendrofluazide treatment in 6 healthy male subjects and although the effect was small it was significant.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Timolol also reduced the rise in plasma aldosterone and urine potassium excretion following bendrofluazide and increased the urine sodium/potassium ratio.</Disease>
<Disease>There was no evidence of a shift of potassium from the intracellular to the extracellular space.</Disease>
<Disease>A cross-sectional evaluation of the effect of risperidone and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors on bone mineral density in boys.</Disease>
<Disease>OBJECTIVE:</Disease>
<Disease>The aim of the present study was to investigate the effect of risperidone-induced hyperprolactinemia on trabecular bone mineral density (BMD) in children and adolescents.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHOD: Medically healthy 7- to 17-year-old males chronically treated, in a naturalistic setting, with risperidone were recruited for this cross-sectional study through child psychiatry outpatient clinics between November 2005 and June 2007.</Disease>
<Disease>Anthropometric measurements and laboratory testing were conducted.</Disease>
<Disease>The clinical diagnoses were based on chart review, and developmental and treatment history was obtained from the medical record.</Disease>

<Disease>Volumetric BMD of the ultradistal radius was measured using peripheral quantitative computed tomography, and areal BMD of the lumbar spine was estimated using dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>Hyperprolactinemia was present in 49% of 83 boys (n = 41) treated with risperidone for a mean of 2.9 years.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Serum testosterone concentration increased with pubertal status but was not affected by hyperprolactinemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>As expected, bone mineral content and BMD increased with sexual maturity.</Disease>

<Disease>After adjusting for the stage of sexual development and height and BMI z scores, serum prolactin was negatively associated with trabecular volumetric BMD at the ultradistal radius (P < .03).</Disease>

<Disease>Controlling for relevant covariates, we also found treatment with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) to be associated with lower trabecular BMD at the radius (P = .03) and BMD z score at the lumbar spine (P < .05).</Disease>
<Disease>These findings became more marked when the analysis was restricted to non-Hispanic white patients.</Disease>
<Disease>Of 13 documented fractures, 3 occurred after risperidone and SSRIs were started, and none occurred in patients with hyperprolactinemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>This is the first study to link risperidone-induced hyperprolactinemia and SSRI treatment to lower BMD in children and adolescents.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Future research should evaluate the longitudinal course of this adverse event to determine its temporal stability and whether a higher fracture rate ensues.</Disease>
<Disease>Seizures associated with levofloxacin: case presentation and literature review.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>PURPOSE:</Disease>

<Disease>We present a case of a patient who developed seizures shortly after initiating treatment with levofloxacin and to discuss the potential drug-drug interactions related to the inhibition of cytochrome P450 (CYP) 1A2 in this case, as well as in other cases, of levofloxacin-induced seizures.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>Several biomedical databases were searched including MEDLINE, Cochrane and Ovid.</Disease>
<Disease>The main search terms utilized were case report and levofloxacin.</Disease>
<Disease>The search was limited to studies published in English.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS: Six cases of levofloxacin-induced seizures have been reported in the literature.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Drug-drug interactions related to the inhibition of CYP1A2 by levofloxacin are likely involved in the clinical outcome of these cases.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Clinicians are exhorted to pay close attention when initiating levofloxacin therapy in patients taking medications with epileptogenic properties that are CYP1A2 substrates.</Disease>
<Disease>Mice lacking mPGES-1 are resistant to lithium-induced polyuria.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Cyclooxygenase-2 activity is required for the development of lithium-induced polyuria.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, the involvement of a specific, terminal prostaglandin (PG) isomerase has not been evaluated.</Disease>
<Disease>The present study was undertaken to assess lithium-induced polyuria in mice deficient in microsomal prostaglandin E synthase-1 (mPGES-1).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A 2-wk administration of LiCl (4 mmol.kg(-1).day(-1) ip) in mPGES-1 +/+ mice led to a marked polyuria with hyposmotic urine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This was associated with elevated renal mPGES-1 protein expression and increased urine PGE(2) excretion.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast, mPGES-1</Disease>
<Disease>-/- mice were largely resistant to lithium-induced polyuria and a urine concentrating defect, accompanied by nearly complete blockade of high urine PGE(2) and cAMP output.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Immunoblotting, immunohistochemistry, and quantitative (q) RT-PCR consistently detected a significant decrease in aquaporin-2 (AQP2) protein expression in both the renal cortex and medulla of lithium-treated +/+ mice.</Disease>
<Disease>This decrease was significantly attenuated in the -/- mice.</Disease>
<Disease>qRT-PCR detected similar patterns of changes in AQP2 mRNA in the medulla but not in the cortex.</Disease>
<Disease>Similarly, the total protein abundance of the Na-K-2Cl cotransporter (NKCC2) in the medulla but not in the cortex of the +/+ mice was significantly reduced by lithium treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast, the dowregulation of renal medullary NKCC2 expression was significantly attenuated in the -/- mice.</Disease>
<Disease>We conclude that mPGES-1-derived PGE(2) mediates lithium-induced polyuria likely via inhibition of AQP2 and NKCC2 expression.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Identification of a simple and sensitive microplate method for the detection of oversulfated chondroitin sulfate in heparin products.</Disease>
<Disease>Heparin is a commonly implemented anticoagulant used to treat critically ill patients.</Disease>

<Disease>Recently, a number of commercial lots of heparin products were found to be contaminated with an oversulfated chondroitin sulfate (OSCS) derivative that could elicit a hypotensive response in pigs following a single high-dose infusion.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Using both contaminated heparin products and the synthetically produced derivative, we showed that the OSCS produces dose-dependent hypotension in pigs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The no observed effect level (NOEL) for this contaminant appears to be approximately 1mg/kg, corresponding to a contamination level of approximately 3%.</Disease>

<Disease>We also demonstrated that OSCS can be identified in heparin products using a simple, inexpensive, commercially available heparin enzyme immunoassay (EIA) kit that has a limit of detection of approximately 0.1%, well below the NOEL.</Disease>
<Disease>This kit may provide a useful method to test heparin products for contamination with oversulfated GAG derivatives.</Disease>
<Disease>Doxorubicin cardiomyopathy-induced inflammation and apoptosis are attenuated by gene deletion of the kinin B1 receptor.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Clinical use of the anthracycline doxorubicin (DOX) is limited by its cardiotoxic effects, which are attributed to the induction of apoptosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To elucidate the possible role of the kinin B1 receptor (B1R) during the development of DOX cardiomyopathy, we studied B1R</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>knockout mice (B1R(-/-)) by investigating cardiac inflammation and apoptosis after induction of DOX-induced cardiomyopathy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>DOX control mice showed cardiac dysfunction measured by pressure-volume loops in vivo.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This was associated with a reduced activation state of AKT, as well as an increased bax/bcl2 ratio in Western blots, indicating cardiac apoptosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Furthermore, mRNA levels of the proinflammatory cytokine interleukin 6 were increased in the cardiac tissue.</Disease>

<Disease>In DOX B1R(-/-) mice, cardiac dysfunction was improved compared to DOX control mice, which was associated with normalization of the bax/bcl-2 ratio and interleukin 6, as well as AKT activation state.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These findings suggest that B1R is detrimental in DOX cardiomyopathy in that it mediates the inflammatory response and apoptosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These insights might have useful implications for future studies utilizing B1R</Disease>
<Disease>antagonists for treatment of human DOX cardiomyopathy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Hepatotoxicity associated with sulfasalazine in inflammatory arthritis: A case series from a local surveillance of serious adverse events.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>Spontaneous reporting systems for adverse drug reactions (ADRs) are handicapped by under-reporting and limited detail on individual cases.</Disease>

<Disease>We report an investigation from a local surveillance for serious adverse drug reactions associated with disease modifying anti-rheumatic drugs that was triggered by the occurrence of liver failure in two of our patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>Serious ADR reports have been solicited from local clinicians by regular postcards over the past seven years.</Disease>
<Disease>Patients', who had hepatotoxicity on sulfasalazine and met a definition of a serious ADR, were identified.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two clinicians reviewed structured case reports and assessed causality by consensus and by using a causality assessment instrument.</Disease>
<Disease>The likely frequency of hepatotoxicity with sulfasalazine was estimated by making a series of conservative assumptions.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS: Ten cases were identified: eight occurred during surveillance.</Disease>
<Disease>Eight patients were hospitalised, two in hepatic failure - one died after a liver transplant.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>All but one event occurred within 6 weeks of treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>Seven patients had a skin rash, three eosinophilia and one interstitial nephritis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Five patients were of Black British of African or Caribbean descent.</Disease>
<Disease>Liver enzymes showed a hepatocellular pattern in four cases and a mixed pattern in six.</Disease>
<Disease>Drug-related hepatotoxicity was judged probable or highly probable in 8 patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The likely frequency of serious hepatotoxicity with sulfasalazine was estimated at 0.4% of treated patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>

<Disease>Serious hepatotoxicity associated with sulfasalazine appears to be under-appreciated and intensive monitoring and vigilance in the first 6 weeks of treatment is especially important.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>An evaluation of amikacin nephrotoxicity in the hematology/oncology population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Amikacin is an aminoglycoside commonly used to provide empirical double gram-negative treatment for febrile neutropenia and other suspected infections.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Strategies of extended-interval and conventional dosing have been utilized extensively in the general medical population; however, data are lacking to support a dosing strategy in the hematology/oncology population.</Disease>

<Disease>To evaluate amikacin-associated nephrotoxicity in an adult hematology/oncology population, a prospective, randomized, open-label trial was conducted at a university-affiliated medical center.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Forty patients with a diagnosis consistent with a hematologic/oncologic disorder that required treatment with an aminoglycoside were randomized to either conventional or extended-interval amikacin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The occurrence of nephrotoxicity by means of an increase in serum creatinine and evaluation of efficacy via amikacin serum concentrations with respective pathogens were assessed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The occurrence of nephrotoxicity was similar between the conventional and extended-interval groups, at 10% and 5%, respectively (P = 1.00).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Six patients in the conventional group had a positive culture, compared with none in the extended-interval group (P = 0.002).</Disease>
<Disease>The occurrence of nephrotoxicity was similar between the two dosing regimens, but the distribution of risk factors was variable between the two groups.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Efficacy could not be assessed.</Disease>
<Disease>Memory function and serotonin transporter promoter gene polymorphism in ecstasy (MDMA) users.</Disease>

<Disease>Although 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA or ecstasy) has been shown to damage brain serotonin (5-HT) neurons in animals and possibly humans, little is known about the long-term consequences of MDMA-induced 5-HT neurotoxic lesions on functions in which 5-HT is involved, such as cognitive function.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Because 5-HT transporters play a key element in the regulation of synaptic 5-HT transmission it may be important to control for the potential covariance effect of a polymorphism in the 5-HT transporter promoter gene region (5-HTTLPR) when studying the effects of MDMA as well as cognitive functioning.</Disease>

<Disease>The aim of the study was to investigate the effects of moderate and heavy MDMA use on cognitive function, as well as the effects of long-term abstention from MDMA, in subjects genotyped for 5-HTTLPR.</Disease>
<Disease>A second aim of the study was to determine whether these effects differ for females and males.</Disease>

<Disease>Fifteen moderate MDMA users (<55 lifetime tablets), 22 heavy MDMA+ users (>55 lifetime tablets), 16 ex-MDMA+ users (last tablet > 1 year ago) and 13 controls were compared on a battery of neuropsychological tests.</Disease>
<Disease>DNA from peripheral nuclear blood cells was genotyped for 5-HTTLPR using standard polymerase chain reaction methods.</Disease>
<Disease>A significant group effect was observed only on memory function tasks (p = 0.04) but not on reaction times (p = 0.61) or attention/executive functioning (p = 0.59).</Disease>
<Disease>Heavy and ex-MDMA+ users performed significantly poorer on memory tasks than controls.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast, no evidence of memory impairment was observed in moderate MDMA users.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No significant effect of 5-HTTLPR or gender was observed.</Disease>

<Disease>While the use of MDMA in quantities that may be considered "moderate" is not associated with impaired memory functioning, heavy use of MDMA use may lead to long lasting memory impairments.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>No effect of 5-HTTLPR or gender on memory function or MDMA use was observed.</Disease>
<Disease>Aging process of epithelial cells of the rat prostate lateral lobe in experimental hyperprolactinemia induced by haloperidol.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The aim of the study was to examine the influence of hyperprolactinemia, induced by haloperidol (HAL) on age related morphology and function changes of epithelial cells in rat prostate lateral lobe.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The study was performed on sexually mature male rats.</Disease>
<Disease>Serum concentrations of prolactin (PRL) and testosterone (T) were measured.</Disease>
<Disease>Tissue sections were evaluated with light and electron microscopy.</Disease>
<Disease>Immunohistochemical reactions for Anti-Proliferating Cell Nuclear Antigen (PCNA) were performed.</Disease>
<Disease>In rats of the experimental group, the mean concentration of: PRL was more than twice higher, whereas T concentration was almost twice lower than that in the control group.</Disease>
<Disease>Light microscopy visualized the following: hypertrophy and epithelium hyperplasia of the glandular ducts, associated with increased PCNA expression.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Electron microscopy revealed changes in columnar epithelial cells, concerning organelles, engaged in protein synthesis and secretion.</Disease>
<Disease>Does supplemental vitamin C increase cardiovascular disease risk in women with diabetes?</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND: Vitamin C acts as a potent antioxidant; however, it can also be a prooxidant and glycate protein under certain circumstances in vitro.</Disease>
<Disease>These observations led us to hypothesize that a high intake of vitamin C in diabetic persons might promote atherosclerosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE:</Disease>
<Disease>The objective was to examine the relation between vitamin C intake and mortality from cardiovascular disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>DESIGN:</Disease>

<Disease>We studied the relation between vitamin C intake and mortality from total cardiovascular disease (n = 281), coronary artery disease (n = 175), and stroke (n = 57) in 1923 postmenopausal women who reported being diabetic at baseline.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Diet was assessed with a food-frequency questionnaire at baseline, and subjects initially free of coronary artery disease were prospectively followed for 15 y. RESULTS:</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>After adjustment for cardiovascular disease risk factors, type of diabetes medication used, duration of diabetes, and intakes of folate, vitamin E, and beta-carotene, the adjusted relative risks of total cardiovascular disease mortality were 1.0, 0.97, 1.11, 1.47, and 1.84 (P for trend < 0.01) across quintiles of total vitamin C intake from food and supplements.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Adjusted relative risks of coronary artery disease were 1.0, 0.81, 0.99, 1.26, and 1.91 (P for trend = 0.01) and of stroke were 1.0, 0.52, 1.23, 2.22, and 2.57 (P for trend < 0.01).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>When dietary and supplemental vitamin C were analyzed separately, only supplemental vitamin C showed a positive association with mortality endpoints.</Disease>
<Disease>Vitamin C intake was unrelated to mortality from cardiovascular disease in the nondiabetic subjects at baseline.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION: A high vitamin C intake from supplements is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease mortality in postmenopausal women with diabetes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Absolute and attributable risk of venous thromboembolism in women on combined cyproterone acetate and ethinylestradiol.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To achieve absolute risk estimates of venous thromboembolism (VTE) among women on cyproterone acetate plus ethinylestradiol (CPA/EE), and among women on combined oral contraceptives (COCs).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>From the Danish National Register of Patients (NRP), 1996 to 1998, the records of 1.1 million Danish women, ages 15 to 44 years, were searched for evidence of VTE.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>COC use was ascertained through mailed questionnaires.</Disease>
<Disease>Sales statistics of COCs and CPA/EE were provided through Danish Drug Statistics.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>During the time frame of the study, 330 women were found to have had VTE while on COCs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Of these women, 67 were on levonorgestrel-containing COCs.</Disease>
<Disease>Eleven were on CPA/EE.</Disease>

<Disease>The corresponding absolute risk of VTE was 3.4 (range, 3.1-3.8) per 10 000 women years among the women on COCs, 4.2 (range, 3.2-5.2) per 10 000 women years among women on levonorgestrel-containing COCs, and 3.1 (range, 1.3-4.9) per 10 000 women years among the women on CPA/EE.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Our results suggest the absolute risk of VTE among Danish women on COCs is similar to that among women taking CPA/EE.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Effect of lindane on hepatic and brain cytochrome P450s and influence of P450 modulation in lindane induced neurotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Oral administration of lindane (2.5, 5, 10 and 15 mg/kg, body weight) for 5 days was found to produce a dose-dependent increase in the activity of P450 dependent 7-ethoxyresorufin-O-deethylase (EROD), 7-pentoxyresorufin-O-dealkylase (PROD) and N-nitrosodimethylamine demethylase (NDMA-d) in rat brain and liver.</Disease>

<Disease>A significant increase in the hepatic and brain P450 monooxygenases was also observed when the duration of exposure of low dose (2.5 mg/kg) of lindane was increased from 5 days to 15 or 21 days.</Disease>
<Disease>As observed with different doses, the magnitude of induction in the activity of P450 monooxygenases was several fold higher in liver microsomes when compared with the brain.</Disease>
<Disease>Western blotting studies have indicated that the increase in the P450 enzymes could be due to the increase in the expression of P450 1A1/1A2, 2B1/2B2 and 2E1 isoenzymes.</Disease>

<Disease>In vitro studies using organic inhibitors specific for individual P450 isoenzymes and antibody inhibition experiments have further demonstrated that the increase in the activity of PROD, EROD and NDMA-d are due to the increase in the levels of P450 2B1/2B2, 1A1/1A2 and 2E1 isoenzymes, respectively.</Disease>

<Disease>Induction studies have further shown that while pretreatment of 3-methylcholanthrene (MC), an inducer of P4501A1/1A2, did not produce any significant effect in the incidence of lindane induced convulsions, pretreatment with phenobarbital (PB), an inducer of P450 2B1/2B2 or ethanol, an inducer of P450 2E1 catalysed reactions, significantly increased the incidence of lindane induced convulsions.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Nephrotoxic effects in high-risk patients undergoing angiography.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>The use of iodinated contrast medium can result in nephropathy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Whether iso-osmolar contrast medium is less nephrotoxic than low-osmolar contrast medium in high-risk patients is uncertain.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>We conducted a randomized, double-blind, prospective, multicenter study comparing the nephrotoxic effects of an iso-osmolar, dimeric, nonionic contrast medium, iodixanol, with those of a low-osmolar, nonionic, monomeric contrast medium, iohexol.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The study involved 129 patients with diabetes with serum creatinine concentrations of 1.5 to 3.5 mg per deciliter who underwent coronary or aortofemoral angiography.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The primary end point was the peak increase from base line in the creatinine concentration during the three days after angiography.</Disease>

<Disease>Other end points were an increase in the creatinine concentration of 0.5 mg per deciliter or more, an increase of 1.0 mg per deciliter or more, and a change in the creatinine concentration from day 0 to day 7.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>The creatinine concentration increased significantly less in patients who received iodixanol.</Disease>

<Disease>From day 0 to day 3, the mean peak increase in creatinine was 0.13 mg per deciliter in the iodixanol group and 0.55 mg per deciliter in the iohexol group (P=0.001; the increase with iodixanol minus the increase with iohexol, -0.42 mg per deciliter [95 percent confidence interval, -0.73 to -0.22]).</Disease>

<Disease>Two of the 64 patients in the iodixanol group (3 percent) had an increase in the creatinine concentration of 0.5 mg per deciliter or more, as compared with 17 of the 65 patients in the iohexol group (26 percent)</Disease>
<Disease>(P=0.002; odds ratio for such an increase in the iodixanol group, 0.09 [95 percent confidence interval, 0.02 to 0.41]).</Disease>
<Disease>No patient receiving iodixanol had an increase of 1.0 mg per deciliter or more, but 10 patients in the iohexol group (15 percent) did.</Disease>

<Disease>The mean change in the creatinine concentration from day 0 to day 7 was 0.07 mg per deciliter in the iodixanol group and 0.24 mg per deciliter in the iohexol group (P=0.003; value in the iodixanol group minus the value in the iohexol group, -0.17 mg per deciliter [95 percent confidence interval, -0.34 to -0.07]).</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Nephropathy induced by contrast medium may be less likely to develop in high-risk patients when iodixanol is used rather than a low-osmolar, nonionic contrast medium.</Disease>
