text: <Disease>However, yohimbine and meperidine reduced predominantly the dyskinetic movements.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Baclofen was also useful in one monkey against a more dystonic form of dyskinesia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Atropine converted the dystonic movements into chorea.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CCNU (lomustine) toxicity in dogs: a retrospective study (2002-07).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To describe the incidence of haematological, renal, hepatic and gastrointestinal toxicities in tumour-bearing dogs receiving 1-(2-chloroethyl)-3-cyclohexyl-1-nitrosourea (CCNU).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>DESIGN:</Disease>
<Disease>The medical records of 206 dogs that were treated with CCNU at the Melbourne Veterinary Specialist Centre between February 2002 and December 2007 were retrospectively evaluated.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS: Of the 206 dogs treated with CCNU, 185 met the inclusion criteria for at least one class of toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CCNU was used most commonly in the treatment of lymphoma, mast cell tumour, brain tumour, histiocytic tumours and epitheliotropic lymphoma.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Throughout treatment, 56.9% of dogs experienced neutropenia, 34.2% experienced anaemia and 14.2% experienced thrombocytopenia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Gastrointestinal toxicosis was detected in 37.8% of dogs, the most common sign of which was vomiting (24.3%).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Potential renal toxicity and elevated alanine transaminase (ALT) concentration were reported in 12.2% and 48.8% of dogs, respectively.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The incidence of hepatic failure was 1.2%.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS: CCNU-associated toxicity in dogs is common, but is usually not life threatening.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Neuroactive steroids protect against pilocarpine- and kainic acid-induced limbic seizures and status epilepticus in mice.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Several structurally related metabolites of progesterone (3 alpha-hydroxy pregnane-20-ones) and deoxycorticosterone (3 alpha-hydroxy pregnane-21-diol-20-ones) and their 3 beta-epimers were evaluated for protective activity against pilocarpine-, kainic acid- and N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA)-induced seizures in mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Steroids with the 3-hydroxy group in the alpha-position and 5-H in the alpha- or beta-configurations were highly effective in protecting against pilocarpine (416 mg/kg, s.c.)-induced limbic motor seizures and status epilepticus (ED50 values, 7.0-18.7 mg/kg, i.p.).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The corresponding epimers with the 3-hydroxy group in the beta-position were also effective but less potent (ED50 values, 33.8-63.5, i.p.).</Disease>

<Disease>Although the neuroactive steroids were considerably less potent than the benzodiazepine clonazepam in protecting against pilocarpine seizures, steroids with the 5 alpha,3 alpha-configuration had comparable or higher protective index values (TD50 for motor impairment divided by ED50 for seizure protection) than clonazepam, indicating that some neuroactive steroids may have lower relative toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Steroids with the 5 alpha,3 alpha- or 5 beta,3 alpha-configurations also produced a dose-dependent delay in the onset of limbic seizures induced by kainic acid (32 mg/kg, s.c.), but did not completely protect against the seizures.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, when a second dose of the steroid was administered 1 hr after the first dose, complete protection from the kainic acid-induced limbic seizures and status epilepticus was obtained.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The steroids also caused a dose-dependent delay in NMDA (257 mg/kg, s.c.)-induced lethality, but did not completely protect against NMDA seizures or lethality.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We conclude that neuroactive steroids are highly effective in protecting against pilocarpine- and kainic acid-induced seizures and status epilepticus in mice, and may be of utility in the treatment of some forms of status epilepticus in humans.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The safety and efficacy of combination N-butyl-deoxynojirimycin (SC-48334) and zidovudine in patients with HIV-1 infection and 200-500 CD4 cells/mm3.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We conducted a double-blind, randomized phase II study to evaluate the safety and activity of combination therapy with N-butyl-deoxynojirimycin (SC-48334) (an alpha-glucosidase I inhibitor) and zidovudine versus zidovudine alone.</Disease>

<Disease>Patients with 200 to 500 CD4 cells/mm3 who tolerated < or = 12 weeks of prior zidovudine therapy received SC-48334 (1000 mg every 8 h) and zidovudine (100 mg every 8 h) or zidovudine and placebo.</Disease>
<Disease>Sixty patients received combination therapy and 58, zidovudine and placebo.</Disease>
<Disease>Twenty-three patients (38%) and 15 (26%), in the combination and zidovudine groups, respectively, discontinued therapy (p = 0.15).</Disease>
<Disease>The mean SC-48334 steady-state trough level (4.04 +/- 0.99 micrograms/ml) was below the in vitro inhibitory concentration for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mean increase in CD4 cells at week 4 was 73.8 cells/mm3 and 52.4 cells/mm3 for the combination and zidovudine groups, respectively (p > 0.36).</Disease>

<Disease>For patients with prior zidovudine therapy, the mean change in CD4 cells in the combination and zidovudine groups was 63.7 cells/mm3 and 4.9 cells/mm3 at week 8 and 6.8 cells/mm3 and -45.1 cells/mm3 at week 16, respectively.</Disease>

<Disease>The number of patients with suppression of HIV p24 antigenemia in the combination and zidovudine groups was six (40%) and two (11%) at week 4 (p = 0.10) and five (45%) and two (14%) at week 24 (p = 0.08), respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>Diarrhea, flatulence, abdominal pain, and weight loss were common for combination recipients.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Recent preclinical and clinical studies with the thymidylate synthase inhibitor N10-propargyl-5,8-dideazafolic acid (CB 3717).</Disease>
<Disease>CB 3717, N10-propargyl-5,8-dideazafolic acid, is a tight-binding inhibitor of thymidylate synthase (TS) whose cytotoxicity is mediated solely through the inhibition of this enzyme.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Recent preclinical studies have focused on the intracellular formation of CB 3717 polyglutamates.</Disease>

<Disease>Following a 12-hour exposure of L1210 cells to 50 microM [3H]CB 3717, 30% of the extractable radioactivity could be accounted for as CB 3717 tetra- and pentaglutamate, as determined by high-pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC) analyses.</Disease>

<Disease>As inhibitors of isolated L1210 TS, CB 3717 di-, tri-, tetra- and pentaglutamate are 26-, 87-, 119- and 114-fold more potent than CB 3717, respectively, and their formation may, therefore, be an important determinant of CB 3717 cytotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In early clinical studies with CB 3717, activity has been seen in breast cancer, ovarian cancer, hepatoma, and mesothelioma.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Toxicities included hepatotoxicity, malaise, and dose-limiting nephrotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This latter effect is thought to be due to drug precipitation within the renal tubule as a result of the poor solubility of CB 3717 under acidic conditions.</Disease>
<Disease>In an attempt to overcome this problem, a clinical trial of CB 3717 administered with alkaline diuresis is under way.</Disease>
<Disease>Preliminary results at 400 and 500 mg/m2 suggest that a reduction in nephrotoxicity may have been achieved with only 1 instance of renal toxicity in 10 patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Hepatotoxicity and malaise are again the most frequent side effects.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Evidence of antitumor activity has been seen in 3 patients.</Disease>

<Disease>Pharmacokinetic investigations have shown that alkaline diuresis does not alter CB 3717 plasma levels or urinary excretion and that satisfactory urinary alkalinization can be readily achieved.</Disease>
<Disease>Ethopropazine and benztropine in neuroleptic-induced parkinsonism.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In a 12-week controlled study ethopropazine was compared to benztropine in the treatment of parkinsonism induced by fluphenazine enanthate in 60 schizophrenic outpatients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Ethopropazine and benztropine were found to be equally effective in controlling parkinsonian symptoms and were as efficacious as procyclidine, their previous antiparkinsonian drug.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, benztropine treated patients had a significant increase in tardive dyskinesia compared to their condition during procyclindine treatment, and significantly more anxiety and depression than ethopropazine treated patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This suggests that benztropine is not the anticholinergic drug of choice in the treatment of neuroleptic-induced parkinsonian symptoms, because of its more toxic central and peripheral atropinic effect.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Effect of alpha-tocopherol and deferoxamine on methamphetamine-induced neurotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Methamphetamine (MA)-induced dopaminergic neurotoxicity is believed to be associated with the increased formation of free radicals.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This study examined the effect of alpha-tocopherol (alpha-TC), a scavenger of reactive oxygen species, and deferoxamine (DFO), an iron chelator, on the MA-induced neurotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Male rats were treated with MA (10 mg/kg, every 2 h for four injections).</Disease>
<Disease>The rat received either alpha-TC (20 mg/kg) intraperitoneally for 3 days and 30 min prior to MA administration or DFO (50 mg/kg) subcutaneously 30 min before MA administration.</Disease>
<Disease>The concentrations of dopamine (DA), serotonin and their metabolites decreased significantly after MA administration, which was inhibited by the alpha-TC and DFO pretreatment.</Disease>
<Disease>alpha-TC and DFO attenuated the MA-induced hyperthermia as well as the alterations in the locomotor activity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The level of lipid peroxidation was higher and the reduced glutathione concentration was lower in the MA-treated rats.</Disease>
<Disease>These changes were significantly attenuated by alpha-TC and DFO.</Disease>
<Disease>This suggests that alpha-TC and DFO ameliorate the MA-induced neuronal damage by decreasing the level of oxidative stress.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Use of dexamethasone with mesna for the prevention of ifosfamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>AIM: Hemorrhagic cystitis (HC) is a limiting side-effect of chemotherapy with ifosfamide (IFS).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the study presented here, we investigated the use of dexamethasone in combination with mesna for the prevention of IFS-induced HC. METHODS:</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Male Wistar rats (150-200 g; 6 rats per group) were treated with saline or mesna 5 min (i.p.) before and 2 and 6 h after (v.o.) administration of IFS.</Disease>
<Disease>One, two or three doses of mesna were replaced with dexamethasone alone or with dexamethasone plus mesna.</Disease>
<Disease>Cystitis was evaluated 24 h after its induction by the changes in bladder wet weight and by macroscopic and microscopic analysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>The replacement of the last dose or the last two doses of mesna with dexamethasone reduced the increase in bladder wet weight induced by IFS by 84.79% and 89.13%, respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, it almost abolished the macroscopic and microscopic alterations induced by IFS.</Disease>
<Disease>Moreover, the addition of dexamethasone to the last two doses of mesna was more efficient than three doses of mesna alone when evaluated microscopically.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION: Dexamethasone in combination with mesna was efficient in blocking IFS-induced HC.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, the replacement of last two doses of mesna with saline or all of the mesna doses with dexamethasone did not prevent HC.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Behavioral effects of MK-801 on reserpine-treated mice.</Disease>
<Disease>The effects of dizocilpine (MK-801), a noncompetitive N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist, were studied on dopamine-related behaviors induced by reserpine treatments.</Disease>
<Disease>This study focuses on behavioral syndromes that may used as models for Parkinson's disease, or tardive dyskinesia, and its response after glutamatergic blockage.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Reserpine (1 mg/kg), administered once every other day for 4 days, produced increases in orofacial dyskinesia, tongue protrusion and vacuous chewing in mice, which are signs indicative of tardive dyskinesia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Reserpine also produced tremor and catalepsy, which are signs suggestive of Parkinson's disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>MK-801 (0.1 mg/kg), administered 30 min before the observation test, prevented the vacuous chewing movements, tongue protrusions and catalepsy induced by reserpine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, MK-801 injection produced a significant increase of tremor in reserpine-treated mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Reserpine (1 mg/kg), administered 90 min before the test and followed by apomophine injection (0.1 mg/kg) 5 min before the test, did not produce oral dyskinesia in mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>On the other hand, reserpine induced increases in tremor and catalepsy compared to control mice.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>MK-801 (0.1 mg/kg) administration attenuated the catalepsy and tremor induced by reserpine.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Pretreatment with reserpine (1 mg/kg) 24 h before the observation test produced increases in vacuous chewing movements and tongue protrusion, as well as increases in tremor and catalepsy, whereas MK-801 (0.1 mg/kg) injection 90 min before the test reversed the effects of reserpine.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These results show that reserpine produces different and abnormal movements, which are related to dose and schedule employed and can be considered as parkinsonian-like and tardive dsykinesia signs.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The glutamatergic blockage produced by NMDA can restore these signs, such as vacuous chewing movements, tongue protrusions, catalepsy and tremor according to the employed model.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Effect of glyceryl trinitrate on the sphincter of Oddi spasm evoked by prostigmine-morphine administration.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE:</Disease>
<Disease>In this study the effect of glyceryl trinitrate on the prostigmine-morphine-induced sphincter of Oddi spasm was evaluated in nine female patients with sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHOD:</Disease>

<Disease>Sphincter of Oddi spasm was induced by prostigmine-morphine administration (0.5 mg prostigmine intramuscularly and 10 mg morphine subcutaneously) and visualized by quantitative hepatobiliary scintigraphy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The entire procedure was repeated during glyceryl trinitrate infusion (Nitrolingual 1 microg/kg/min for 120 min).</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>

<Disease>Prostigmine-morphine provocation caused significant increases in the time to peak activity (Tmax) over the hepatic hilum (HH: 34.33 +/- 5.05 vs. 22.77 +/- 3.26) and the common bile duct (CBD: 60.44 +/- 5.99 vs. 40.0 +/- 2.88) and in the half-time of excretion (T1/2) over the liver parenchyma (LP: 120.04 +/- 16.01 vs. 27.37 +/- 2.19), HH (117.61 +/- 14.71 vs. 31.85 +/- 3.99) and CBD (158.11 +/- 9.18 vs. 40.1 +/- 6.24), indicating a complete spasm at the level of the sphincter of Oddi.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Glyceryl trinitrate infusion completely normalized the prostigmine-morphine-induced alterations in these quantitative parameters (TmaX over the LP: 11.33 +/- 1.13; over the HH: 18.88 +/- 1.48; and over the CBD: 36.22 +/- 1.92; and T1/2 over the LP: 28.21 +/- 1.83; over the HH: 33.42 +/- 3.10; and over the CBD: 41.66 +/- 6.33), suggesting an effective sphincter-relaxing effect of glyceryl trinitrate.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>These results provide the first evidence of the effectiveness of glyceryl trinitrate on the morphine-induced sphincter of Oddi spasm in humans.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Since glyceryl trinitrate is able to overcome even the drastic effect of morphine, it might be of relevance in the treatment of sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Effects of acute steroid administration on ventilatory and peripheral muscles in rats.</Disease>
<Disease>Occasional case reports have shown that acute myopathy may occur in patients treated with massive doses of corticosteroids.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mechanism of this myopathy is poorly understood.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Therefore, 60 male rats were randomly assigned to receive daily injection of saline (C), methylprednisolone (M), or triamcinolone (T) 80 mg/kg/d for 5 d. Nutritional intake, measured daily in 15 animals, showed a significant reduction of food intake in the steroid-treated groups (-50 and -79% in M and T, respectively).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This was associated with a similar loss in body weight.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the 45 remaining animals, diaphragm contractility and histopathologic features of several muscles were studied.</Disease>
<Disease>Weights of respiratory and peripheral muscles were similarly decreased after steroid treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>Maximal twitches of the diaphragm were lower in the C group (653 +/- 174 g/cm(2)) than in the M group (837 +/- 171 g/cm(2); p < 0.05) and the T group (765 +/- 145 g/cm(2), NS).</Disease>
<Disease>Half-relaxation time was prolonged in both steroid groups, and time to peak tension was longer with M, whereas tetanic tensions were similar.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Steroid treatment also induced a leftward shift of the force-frequency curve at 25 and 50 Hz when compared with saline treatment (p < 0.05).</Disease>

<Disease>ATPase staining of the diaphragm, scalenus medius, and gastrocnemius showed type IIb fiber atrophy in the steroid groups and also diaphragmatic type IIa atrophy with T, whereas histologic examinations revealed a normal muscular pattern with absence of necrosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Finally, a pair-fed (PF) study, performed in 18 rats (C, T, and PF), showed that muscle atrophy was considerably less pronounced in PF animals than in T-treated animals.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We conclude that (1) short-term treatment with massive doses of steroids induced severe respiratory and limb muscle wasting; (2) both types of steroids induced predominantly type IIb atrophy, resulting in the expected alterations in diaphragm contractile properties; (3) neither steroid caused muscle necrosis; (4) type IIb atrophy was not caused by acute nutritional deprivation alone.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Refractory cardiogenic shock and complete heart block after verapamil SR and metoprolol treatment. A case report.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A seventy-eight-year-old woman presented with complete heart block and refractory hypotension two days after a therapeutic dose of sustained-release verapamil with concomitant use of metoprolol.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The patient continued to remain hypotensive with complete heart block, even with multiple uses of intravenous atropine as well as high doses of pressor agents such as dopamine and dobutamine.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, shortly after the use of intravenous calcium chloride, the refractory hypotension and complete heart block resolved.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A phase I clinical study of the antipurine antifolate lometrexol (DDATHF) given with oral folic acid.</Disease>
<Disease>Lometrexol is an antifolate which inhibits glycinamide ribonucleotide formyltransferase (GARFT), an enzyme essential for de novo purine synthesis.</Disease>
<Disease>Extensive experimental and limited clinical data have shown that lometrexol has activity against tumours which are refractory to other drugs, notably methotrexate.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, the initial clinical development of lometrexol was curtailed because of severe and cumulative antiproliferative toxicities.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Preclinical murine studies demonstrated that the toxicity of lometrexol can be prevented by low dose folic acid administration, i.e. for 7 days prior to and 7 days following a single bolus dose.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This observation prompted a Phase I clinical study of lometrexol given with folic acid supplementation which has confirmed that the toxicity of lometrexol can be markedly reduced by folic acid supplementation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thrombocytopenia and mucositis were the major toxicities.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>There was no clear relationship between clinical toxicity and the extent of plasma folate elevation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Associated studies demonstrated that lometrexol plasma pharmacokinetics were not altered by folic acid administration indicating that supplementation is unlikely to reduce toxicity by enhancing lometrexol plasma clearance.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The work described in this report has identified for the first time a clinically acceptable schedule for the administration of a GARFT inhibitor.</Disease>
<Disease>This information will facilitate the future evaluation of this class of compounds in cancer therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Involvement of the mu-opiate receptor in peripheral analgesia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The intradermal injection of mu (morphine, Tyr-D-Ala-Gly-NMe-Phe-Gly-ol and morphiceptin), kappa (trans-3,4-dichloro-N-methyl-N[2-(1-pyrrolidinyl) cyclohexyl]benzeneactemide) and delta ([D-Pen2.5]-enkephalin and [D-Ser2]-[Leu]enkephalin-Thr) selective opioid-agonists, by themselves, did not significantly affect the mechanical nociceptive threshold in the hindpaw of the rat.</Disease>
<Disease>Intradermal injection of mu, but not delta or kappa opioid-agonists, however, produced dose-dependent inhibition of prostaglandin E2-induced hyperalgesia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The analgesic effect of the mu-agonist morphine was dose-dependently antagonized by naloxone and prevented by co-injection of pertussis toxin.</Disease>
<Disease>Morphine did not, however, alter the hyperalgesia induced by 8-bromo cyclic adenosine monophosphate.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We conclude that the analgesic action of opioids on the peripheral terminals of primary afferents is via a binding site with characteristics of the mu-opioid receptor and that this action is mediated by inhibition of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate second messenger system.</Disease>
<Disease>Adequate timing of ribavirin reduction in patients with hemolysis during combination therapy of interferon and ribavirin for chronic hepatitis C.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>Hemolytic anemia is one of the major adverse events of the combination therapy of interferon and ribavirin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Because of ribavirin-related hemolytic anemia, dose reduction is a common event in this therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In this clinical retrospective cohort study we have examined the suitable timing of ribavirin reduction in patients with hemolysis during combination therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS: Thirty-seven of 160 patients who had HCV-genotype 1b, had high virus load, and received 24-week combination therapy developed anemia with hemoglobin level <10 g/dl or anemia-related signs during therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>After that, these 37 patients were reduced one tablet of ribavirin (200 mg) per day.</Disease>
<Disease>After reduction of ribavirin, 27 of 37 patients could continue combination therapy for a total of 24 weeks (group A).</Disease>

<Disease>However, 10 of 37 patients with reduction of ribavirin could not continue combination therapy because their <8.5 g/dl hemoglobin values decreased to or anemia-related severe side effects occurred (group B).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We assessed the final efficacy and safety after reduction of ribavirin in groups A and B. RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>A sustained virological response (SVR) was 29.6% (8/27) in group A and 10% (1/10) in group B, respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>A 34.4% (12/27) of SVR + biological response in group A was higher than 10% (1/10) in group B ( P = 0.051), with slight significance.</Disease>

<Disease>With respect to hemoglobin level at the time of ribavirin reduction, a rate of continuation of therapy in patients with > or =10 g/dl hemoglobin was higher than that in patients with <10 g/dl ( P = 0.036).</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Reduction of ribavirin at hemoglobin level > or =10 g/dl is suitable in terms of efficacy and side effects.</Disease>
<Disease>Increased expression and apical targeting of renal ENaC subunits in puromycin aminonucleoside-induced nephrotic syndrome in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Nephrotic syndrome is often accompanied by sodium retention and generalized edema.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, the molecular basis for the decreased renal sodium excretion remains undefined.</Disease>
<Disease>We hypothesized that epithelial Na channel (ENaC) subunit dysregulation may be responsible for the increased sodium retention.</Disease>
<Disease>An experimental group of rats was treated with puromycin aminonucleoside (PAN; 180 mg/kg iv), whereas the control group received only vehicle.</Disease>
<Disease>After 7 days, PAN treatment induced significant proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, decreased urinary sodium excretion, and extensive ascites.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The protein abundance of alpha-ENaC and beta-ENaC was increased in the inner stripe of the outer medulla (ISOM) and in the inner medulla (IM) but was not altered in the cortex.</Disease>
<Disease>gamma-ENaC abundance was increased in the cortex, ISOM, and IM.</Disease>
<Disease>Immunoperoxidase brightfield-</Disease>

<Disease>and laser-scanning confocal fluorescence microscopy demonstrated increased targeting of alpha-ENaC, beta-ENaC, and gamma-ENaC subunits to the apical plasma membrane in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT2), connecting tubule, and cortical and medullary collecting duct segments.</Disease>

<Disease>Immunoelectron microscopy further revealed an increased labeling of alpha-ENaC in the apical plasma membrane of cortical collecting duct principal cells of PAN-treated rats, indicating enhanced apical targeting of alpha-ENaC subunits.</Disease>

<Disease>In contrast, the protein abundances of Na(+)/H(+) exchanger type 3 (NHE3), Na(+)-K(+)-2Cl(-) cotransporter (BSC-1), and thiazide-sensitive Na(+)-Cl(-) cotransporter (TSC) were decreased.</Disease>
<Disease>Moreover, the abundance of the alpha(1)-subunit of the Na-K-ATPase was decreased in the cortex and ISOM, but it remained unchanged in the IM.</Disease>

<Disease>In conclusion, the increased or sustained expression of ENaC subunits combined with increased apical targeting in the DCT2, connecting tubule, and collecting duct are likely to play a role in the sodium retention associated with PAN-induced nephrotic syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The decreased abundance of NHE3, BSC-1, TSC, and Na-K-ATPase may play a compensatory role to promote sodium excretion.</Disease>
<Disease>Does hormone therapy for the treatment of breast cancer have a detrimental effect on memory and cognition? A pilot study.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This pilot study examines whether hormone therapy for breast cancer affects cognition.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Patients participating in a randomised trial of anastrozole, tamoxifen alone or combined (ATAC) (n=94) and a group of women without breast cancer (n=35) completed a battery of neuropsychological measures.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Compared with the control group, the patients were impaired on a processing speed task (p=0.032) and on a measure of immediate verbal memory (p=0.026) after controlling for the use of hormone replacement therapy in both groups.</Disease>
<Disease>Patient group performance was not significantly related to length of treatment or measures of psychological morbidity.</Disease>
<Disease>The results showed specific impairments in processing speed and verbal memory in women receiving hormonal therapy for the treatment of breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Verbal memory may be especially sensitive to changes in oestrogen levels, a finding commonly reported in studies of hormone replacement therapy in healthy women.</Disease>
<Disease>In view of the increased use of hormone therapies in an adjuvant and preventative setting their impact on cognitive functioning should be investigated more thoroughly.</Disease>
<Disease>Association of nitric oxide production and apoptosis in a model of experimental nephropathy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>
<Disease>In recent studies increased amounts of nitric oxide (NO) and apoptosis have been implicated in various pathological conditions in the kidney.</Disease>
<Disease>We have studied the role of NO and its association with apoptosis in an experimental model of nephrotic syndrome induced by a single injection of adriamycin (ADR).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>The alteration in the NO pathway was assessed by measuring nitrite levels in serum/urine and by evaluating the changes in vascular reactivity of the isolated perfused rat kidney (IPRK) system.</Disease>
<Disease>Rats were stratified into control groups and ADR-induced nephropathy groups.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These two groups were then divided into: group 1, animals receiving saline; and group 2, animals receiving aminoguanidine (AG) which is a specific inhibitor of inducible-NO synthase.</Disease>
<Disease>On day 21, rats were sacrificed after obtaining material for biochemical analysis.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>Histopathological examination of the kidneys of rats treated with ADR revealed focal areas of mesangial proliferation and mild tubulointerstitial inflammation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>They also had significantly higher levels of proteinuria compared with control and treatment groups (P < 0.05).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Urine nitrite levels were significantly increased in the ADR-nephropathy group (P < 0.05).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the IPRK phenylephrine and acetylcholine related responses were significantly impaired in the ADR-nephropathy group.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Apoptosis was not detected in controls.</Disease>
<Disease>However, in the ADR-nephropathy group, numerous apoptotic cells were identified in the tubulointerstitial areas.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Double staining revealed numerous interstitial apoptotic cells to stain for ED1, a marker for monocytes/macrophages.</Disease>
<Disease>Treatment with AG prevented the impairment of renal vascular bed responses and reduced both urine nitrite levels and apoptosis to control levels.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>We suggest that interactions between NO and apoptosis are important in the pathogenesis of the ADR-induced nephrosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The attenuating effect of carteolol hydrochloride, a beta-adrenoceptor antagonist, on neuroleptic-induced catalepsy in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It is known that beta-adrenoceptor antagonists are effective in the treatment of akathisia, one of the extrapyramidal side effects that occur during neuroleptic treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Neuroleptic-induced catalepsy, a model of neuroleptic-induced extrapyramidal side effects, was considered suitable as a model for predicting neuroleptic-induced akathisia in humans, although neuroleptic-induced catalepsy was not considered a specific test for neuroleptic-induced akathisia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Therefore, the effects of carteolol, a beta-adrenoceptor antagonist, on haloperidol-induced catalepsy in rats were behaviorally studied and compared with those of propranolol and biperiden, a muscarinic receptor antagonist.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Carteolol, as well as propranolol and biperiden, inhibited the haloperidol-induced catalepsy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The inhibitory effect of carteolol was almost comparable to that of propranolol, but was weaker than that of biperiden.</Disease>
<Disease>Carteolol did not evoke postsynaptic dopamine receptor-stimulating behavioral signs such as stereotypy and hyperlocomotion in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Carteolol did not antagonize the inhibitory effects of haloperidol on apomorphine-induced stereotypy and locomotor activity in rats.</Disease>

<Disease>In addition, carteolol did not evoke 5-HT1A receptor-stimulating behavioral signs such as flat body posture and forepaw treading and did not inhibit 5-hydroxytryptophan-induced head twitch in rats.</Disease>
<Disease>Finally, carteolol did not inhibit physostigmine-induced lethality in rats.</Disease>

<Disease>These results strongly suggest that carteolol improves haloperidol-induced catalepsy via its beta-adrenoceptor antagonistic activity and is expected to be effective in the treatment of akathisia without attenuating neuroleptic-induced antipsychotic effects due to its postsynaptic dopamine receptor antagonistic activity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Penicillamine-induced rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A 67-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis presented rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) after 5 months of D-penicillamine (250 mg/day) treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Light microscopy study showed severe glomerulonephritis with crescent formation in 60% of the glomeruli and infiltration of inflammatory cells in the wall of an arteriole.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Immunofluorescence revealed scanty granular IgG, IgA and C3 deposits along the capillary walls and mesangium.</Disease>
<Disease>The patient was treated with steroid pulse, plasmapheresis, cyclophosphamide and antiplatelet agents.</Disease>
<Disease>A complete recovery of renal function was achieved in a few weeks.</Disease>

<Disease>This new case of RPGN in the course of D-penicillamine treatment emphasizes the need for frequent monitoring of renal function and evaluation of urinary sediment and proteinuria in these patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The prompt discontinuation of D-penicillamine and vigorous treatment measures could allow for a good prognosis as in this case.</Disease>
<Disease>Nature, time course and dose dependence of zidovudine-related side effects: results from the Multicenter Canadian Azidothymidine Trial.</Disease>
<Disease>To characterize the nature, time course and dose dependency of zidovudine-related side effects, we undertook a multicenter, prospective, dose-range finding study.</Disease>
<Disease>Our study group consisted of 74 HIV-positive homosexual men belonging to groups II B, III and IV C2 from the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) classification of HIV disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Following a 3-week observation period, volunteers were treated with zidovudine 600 mg/day for 18 weeks, 900 mg/day for 9 weeks and 1200 mg/day for 9 weeks, followed by a washout period of 6 weeks after which they were re-started on 1200 mg/day or the highest tolerated dose at 8-hourly intervals.</Disease>
<Disease>Subjects were randomly assigned to 4-hourly or 8-hourly regimens within CDC groups while taking 600 and 1200 mg/day.</Disease>
<Disease>Clinical and laboratory evaluations were performed at 3-week intervals.</Disease>
<Disease>Symptomatic adverse effects were present in 96% of subjects, most commonly nausea (64%), fatigue (55%) and headache (49%).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These were generally self-limited, reappearing briefly at each dose increment.</Disease>
<Disease>A decrease in hemoglobin occurred shortly after initiation of therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>This was not dose dependent and reversed rapidly upon discontinuation of treatment.</Disease>

<Disease>A red blood cell count decrease, a mean cell volume increase and a granulocyte count decrease developed early in a dose-independent fashion, reverting at least partially during the washout phase.</Disease>
<Disease>The decrease in reticulocyte count was dose related between 600 and 900 mg/day with no further change when the dose was escalated to 1200 mg/day.</Disease>
<Disease>Bone marrow changes occurred rapidly as demonstrated by megaloblastosis in 95% of 65 specimens at week 18.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Bilateral optic neuropathy due to combined ethambutol and isoniazid treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The case of a 40-year-old patient who underwent an unsuccessful cadaver kidney transplantation and was treated with ethambutol and isoniazid is reported.</Disease>
<Disease>A bilateral retrobulbar neuropathy with an unusual central bitemporal hemianopic scotoma was found.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Ethambutol was stopped and only small improvement of the visual acuity followed.</Disease>
<Disease>Isoniazid was discontinued later, followed by a dramatic improvement in the visual acuity.</Disease>
<Disease>The hazards of optic nerve toxicity due to ethambutol are known.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We emphasize the potential danger in the use of ethambutol and isoniazid.</Disease>

<Disease>Progestational agents and blood coagulation. VII. Thromboembolic and other complications of oral contraceptive therapy in relationship to pretreatment levels of blood coagulation factors: summary report of a ten-year study.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>During a ten-year period, 348 women were studied for a total of 5,877 patient months in four separate studies relating oral contraceptives to changes in hematologic parameters.</Disease>
<Disease>Significant increases in certain factors of the blood coagulation and fibrinolysin systems (factors I,II,VII,VIII,IX, and X and plasminogen) were observed in the treated groups.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Severe complications developed in four patients.</Disease>
<Disease>All four had an abnormal blood coagulation profile, suggesting "hypercoagulability" before initiation of therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Some of these findings represented the most extreme abnormalities seen in the entire group of patients; some increased further during therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>One of these patients developed a myocardial infarction before receiving any medication, shortly after the base-line values were obtained.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One patient developed retinopathy 19 months after she began therapy, and another developed thrombophlebitis after 27 months of therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The fourth patient developed thrombophlebitis 14 days after initiation of contraceptive therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>All four patients were of the A or AB blood group.</Disease>
<Disease>Previous studies suggested the possiblility of increased propensity for thromboembolic episodes in patients possessing the A antigen.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It appears from these data that hematologic work-ups may be useful in women who are about to start long-term oral contraceptive therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>Cardiac arrest in a child with cerebral palsy undergoing sevoflurane induction of anesthesia after preoperative clonidine.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Clonidine is a frequently administered alpha2-adrenergic agonist which can decrease heart rate and blood pressure.</Disease>
<Disease>We present a case of a 5-year-old child with cerebral palsy and seizure disorder, receiving clonidine for restlessness, who presented for placement of a baclofen pump.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Without the knowledge of the medical personnel, the patient's mother administered three doses of clonidine during the evening before and morning of surgery to reduce anxiety.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>During induction of anesthesia, the patient developed bradycardia and hypotension requiring cardiac resuscitation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>There are no previous reports of clonidine-associated cardiac arrest in a child undergoing induction of anesthesia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Effects of UMB24 and (+/-)-SM 21, putative sigma2-preferring antagonists, on behavioral toxic and stimulant effects of cocaine in mice.</Disease>
<Disease>Earlier studies have demonstrated that antagonism of sigma1 receptors attenuates the convulsive, lethal, locomotor stimulatory and rewarding actions of cocaine in mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In contrast, the contribution of sigma2 receptors is unclear because experimental tools to selectively target this subtype are unavailable.</Disease>
<Disease>To begin addressing this need, we characterized UMB24</Disease>
<Disease>(1-(2-phenethyl)-4-(2-pyridyl)-piperazine) and (+/-)-SM 21 (3alpha-tropanyl-2-(4-chorophenoxy)butyrate) in receptor binding and behavioral studies.</Disease>
<Disease>Receptor binding studies confirmed that UMB24 and (+/-)-SM 21 display preferential affinity for sigma2 over sigma1 receptors.</Disease>
<Disease>In behavioral studies, pretreatment of Swiss Webster mice with UMB24 or (+/-)-SM 21 significantly attenuated cocaine-induced convulsions and locomotor activity, but not lethality.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>When administered alone, (+/-)-SM 21 produced no significant effects compared to control injections of saline, but UMB24 had locomotor depressant actions.</Disease>

<Disease>Together, the data suggest that sigma2 receptor antagonists have the potential to attenuate some of the behavioral effects of cocaine, and further development of more selective, high affinity ligands are warranted.</Disease>
<Disease>Methimazole-induced cholestatic jaundice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Methimazole is a widely used and generally well-tolerated antithyroid agent.</Disease>
<Disease>A 43-year-old woman had severe jaundice and itching 1 month after receiving methimazole (10 mg tid) and propranolol (20 mg tid) for treatment of hyperthyroidism.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The patient continued treatment for another 4 days after the appearance of jaundice until she finished both medications.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>When seen at the emergency department 2 weeks later, she still had severe icterus, pruritus, and hyperbilirubinemia, formed mainly of the conjugated fraction.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Methimazole-induced cholestasis was diagnosed, and propranolol therapy was resumed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Over the following 9 days, the symptoms improved and plasma bilirubin levels were normal after 12 weeks without methimazole.</Disease>
<Disease>In rare cases within the first few weeks of therapy, this drug can cause severe and reversible cholestatic jaundice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Physicians and patients should be aware of this adverse effect so that, upon occurrence, they can discontinue methimazole therapy and avoid unnecessary invasive procedures.</Disease>
<Disease>Ciprofloxacin-induced acute interstitial nephritis and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Ciprofloxacin has been associated with several side effects including interstitial nephritis and hemolytic anemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The combination of both side effects is extremely rare.</Disease>
<Disease>In this report, we describe a case of ciprofloxacin-induced interstitial nephritis and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Hemolytic anemia improved after stopping the drug and initiation of steroid therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Unfortunately, acute interstitial nephritis was irreversible and the patient developed end-stage renal disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Contribution of sodium valproate to the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report the case of a 62-year-old man who was administered sodium valproate (VPA) and who subsequently developed the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>He had been taking VPA for treatment of idiopathic generalized tonic-clonic convulsions since he was 56 years old.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>After substituting VPA with zonisamide, the serum sodium level returned to normal.</Disease>
<Disease>We consider this episode of SIADH to be the result of a combination of factors including a weakness of the central nervous system and the long-term administration of VPA.</Disease>
label: Disease
