text: <Disease>Moreover, naloxazone significantly attenuated the morphine-induced hypotension and respiratory depression, whereas morphine-induced bradycardia was less affected.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Results indicate that subpopulations of mu receptors may mediate selective behavioral and cardiorespiratory responses to morphine.</Disease>
<Disease>Dexrazoxane protects against myelosuppression from the DNA cleavage-enhancing drugs etoposide and daunorubicin but not doxorubicin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>PURPOSE:</Disease>

<Disease>The anthracyclines daunorubicin and doxorubicin and the epipodophyllotoxin etoposide are potent DNA cleavage-enhancing drugs that are widely used in clinical oncology; however, myelosuppression and cardiac toxicity limit their use.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Dexrazoxane (ICRF-187) is recommended for protection against anthracycline-induced cardiotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN:</Disease>

<Disease>Because of their widespread use, the hematologic toxicity following coadministration of dexrazoxane and these three structurally different DNA cleavage enhancers was investigated: Sensitivity of human and murine blood progenitor cells to etoposide, daunorubicin, and doxorubicin +/- dexrazoxane was determined in granulocyte-macrophage colony forming assays.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Likewise, in vivo, B6D2F1 mice were treated with etoposide, daunorubicin, and doxorubicin, with or without dexrazoxane over a wide range of doses: posttreatment, a full hematologic evaluation was done.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>

<Disease>Nontoxic doses of dexrazoxane reduced myelosuppression and weight loss from daunorubicin and etoposide in mice and antagonized their antiproliferative effects in the colony assay; however, dexrazoxane neither reduced myelosuppression, weight loss, nor the in vitro cytotoxicity from doxorubicin.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>

<Disease>Although our findings support the observation that dexrazoxane reduces neither hematologic activity nor antitumor activity from doxorubicin clinically, the potent antagonism of daunorubicin activity raises concern; a possible interference with anticancer efficacy certainly would call for renewed attention.</Disease>
<Disease>Our data also suggest that significant etoposide dose escalation is perhaps possible by the use of dexrazoxane.</Disease>

<Disease>Clinical trials in patients with brain metastases combining dexrazoxane and high doses of etoposide is ongoing with the aim of improving efficacy without aggravating hematologic toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>If successful, this represents an exciting mechanism for pharmacologic regulation of side effects from cytotoxic chemotherapy.</Disease>
<Disease>Effects of the novel compound aniracetam (Ro 13-5057) upon impaired learning and memory in rodents.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The effect of aniracetam (Ro 13-5057, 1-anisoyl-2-pyrrolidinone) was studied on various forms of experimentally impaired cognitive functions (learning and memory) in rodents and produced the following effects: (1) almost complete prevention of the incapacity to learn a discrete escape response in rats exposed to sublethal hypercapnia immediately before the acquisition session; (2) partial (rats) or complete (mice) prevention of the scopolamine-induced short-term amnesia for a passive avoidance task; (3) complete protection against amnesia for a passive avoidance task in rats submitted to electroconvulsive shock immediately after avoidance acquisition; (4) prevention of the long-term retention- or retrieval-deficit for a passive avoidance task induced in rats and mice by chloramphenicol or cycloheximide administered immediately after acquisition; (5) reversal, when administered as late as 1 h before the retention test, of the deficit in retention or retrieval of a passive avoidance task induced by cycloheximide injected 2 days previously; (6) prevention of the deficit in the retrieval of an active avoidance task induced in mice by subconvulsant electroshock or hypercapnia applied immediately before retrieval testing (24 h after acquisition).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These improvements or normalizations of impaired cognitive functions were seen at oral aniracetam doses of 10-100 mg/kg.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Generally, the dose-response curves were bell-shaped.</Disease>
<Disease>The mechanisms underlying the activity of aniracetam and its 'therapeutic window' are unknown.</Disease>
<Disease>Piracetam, another pyrrolidinone derivative was used for comparison.</Disease>
<Disease>It was active only in six of nine tests and had about one-tenth the potency of aniracetam.</Disease>
<Disease>The results indicate that aniracetam improves cognitive functions which are impaired by different procedure and in different phases of the learning and memory process.</Disease>
<Disease>Nicotine potentiation of morphine-induced catalepsy in mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the present study, effects of nicotine on catalepsy induced by morphine in mice have been investigated.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Morphine but not nicotine induced a dose-dependent catalepsy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The response of morphine was potentiated by nicotine.</Disease>
<Disease>Intraperitoneal administration of atropine, naloxone, mecamylamine, and hexamethonium to mice reduced catalepsy induced by a combination of morphine with nicotine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Intracerebroventricular injection of atropine, hexamethonium, and naloxone also decreased catalepsy induced by morphine plus nicotine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Intraperitoneal administration of atropine, but not intraperitoneal or intracerebroventricular injection of hexamethonium, decreased the effect of a single dose of morphine.</Disease>

<Disease>It was concluded that morphine catalepsy can be elicited by opioid and cholinergic receptors, and the potentiation of morphine induced by nicotine may also be mediated through cholinergic receptor mechanisms.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Reduced cardiotoxicity and preserved antitumor efficacy of liposome-encapsulated doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide compared with conventional doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide in a randomized, multicenter trial of metastatic breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>PURPOSE:</Disease>

<Disease>To determine whether Myocet (liposome-encapsulated doxorubicin; The Liposome Company, Elan Corporation, Princeton, NJ) in combination with cyclophosphamide significantly reduces doxorubicin cardiotoxicity while providing comparable antitumor efficacy in first-line treatment of metastatic breast cancer (MBC).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>PATIENTS AND METHODS: Two hundred ninety-seven patients with MBC and no prior chemotherapy for metastatic disease were randomized to receive either 60 mg/m(2) of Myocet (M) or conventional doxorubicin (A), in combination with 600 mg/m(2) of cyclophosphamide (C), every 3 weeks until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Cardiotoxicity was defined by reductions in left-ventricular ejection fraction, assessed by serial multigated radionuclide angiography scans, or congestive heart failure (CHF).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Antitumor efficacy was assessed by objective tumor response rates (World Health Organization criteria), time to progression, and survival.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS: Six percent of MC patients versus 21% (including five cases of CHF) of AC patients developed cardiotoxicity (P =.0002).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Median cumulative doxorubicin dose at onset was more than 2,220 mg/m(2) for MC versus 480 mg/m(2) for AC (P =.0001, hazard ratio, 5.04).</Disease>
<Disease>MC patients also experienced less grade 4 neutropenia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Antitumor efficacy of MC versus AC was comparable: objective response rates, 43% versus 43%; median time to progression, 5.1% versus 5.5 months; median time to treatment failure, 4.6 versus 4.4 months; and median survival, 19 versus 16 months.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>

<Disease>Myocet improves the therapeutic index of doxorubicin by significantly reducing cardiotoxicity and grade 4 neutropenia and provides comparable antitumor efficacy, when used in combination with cyclophosphamide as first-line therapy for MBC.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Protective effect of a specific platelet-activating factor antagonist, BN 52021, on bupivacaine-induced cardiovascular impairments in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Administration of the local anaesthetic bupivacaine (1.5 or 2 mg/kg, i.v.)</Disease>
<Disease>to rats elicited a marked decrease of mean arterial blood pressure (MBP) and heart rate (HR) leading to death (in 67% or 90% of animals respectively).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Intravenous injection of the specific platelet-activating factor (PAF) antagonist BN 52021 (10 mg/kg), 30 min before bupivacaine administration (2 mg/kg i.v.) suppressed both the decrease of MBP and HR.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In contrast, doses of 1 mg/kg BN 52021 given 30 min before or 10 mg/kg administered 5 min before i.v. injection of bupivacaine were ineffective.</Disease>

<Disease>When BN 52021 (20 mg/kg i.v.) was injected immediately after bupivacaine (2 mg/kg), a partial reversion of the decrease of MBP and HR was observed, whereas the dose of 10 mg/kg was ineffective.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A partial recovery of bupivacaine-induced ECG alterations was observed after pretreatment of the rats with BN 52021.</Disease>

<Disease>Since the administration of BN 52021, at all doses studied, did not alter MBP and HR at the doses used, the bulk of these results clearly demonstrate a protective action of BN 52021, a specific antagonist of PAF, against bupivacaine-induced cardiovascular toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, consistent with its direct effect on heart, PAF appears to be implicated in bupivacaine-induced cardiovascular alterations.</Disease>

label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Increased extracellular concentrations of uridine (Urd) have been reported to reduce, in vitro, azidothymidine (AZT)-induced inhibition of human granulocyte-macrophage progenitor cells without impairment of its antihuman immunodeficiency virus (HIV) activity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Because of the clinical toxicities associated with chronic Urd administration, the ability of benzylacyclouridine (BAU) to effect, in vivo, AZT-induced anemia and leukopenia was assessed.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This agent inhibits Urd catabolism and, in vivo, increases the plasma concentration of Urd in a dose-dependent manner, without Urd-related toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In mice rendered anemic and leukopenic by the administration of AZT for 28 days in drinking water (1.5 mg/mL), the continued administration of AZT plus daily BAU (300 mg/kg, orally) partially reversed AZT-induced anemia and leukopenia (P less than .05), increased peripheral reticulocytes (to 4.9%, P less than .01), increased cellularity in the marrow, and improved megaloblastosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>When coadministered with AZT from the onset of drug administration, BAU reduced AZT-induced marrow toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In vitro, at a concentration of 100 mumol/L, BAU possesses minimal anti-HIV activity and has no effect on the ability of AZT to reverse the HIV-induced cytopathic effect in MT4 cells.</Disease>
<Disease>The clinical and biochemical implications of these findings are discussed.</Disease>
<Disease>Cyclophosphamide-induced cystitis in freely-moving conscious rats: behavioral approach to a new model of visceral pain.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>PURPOSE:</Disease>
<Disease>To develop a model of visceral pain in rats using a behavioral approach.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Cyclophosphamide (CP), an antitumoral agent known to produce toxic effects on the bladder wall through its main toxic metabolite acrolein, was used to induce cystitis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>CP was administered at doses of 50, 100 and 200 mg./kg.</Disease>
<Disease>i.p. to male rats, and their behavior observed and scored.</Disease>
<Disease>The effects of morphine (0.5 to 4 mg./kg. i.v.) on CP-induced behavioral modifications were tested administered alone and after naloxone (1 mg./kg. s.c.).</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, 90 minutes after CP injection, that is, at the time of administration of morphine, the bladder was removed in some rats for histological examination.</Disease>
<Disease>Finally, to show that the bladder is essential for the CP-induced behavioral modifications, female rats also received CP at doses of 200 mg./kg.</Disease>
<Disease>i.p. and of 20 mg.</Disease>
<Disease>by the intravesical route, and acrolein at doses of 0.5 mg.</Disease>
<Disease>by the intravesical route and of 5 mg./kg. i.v. RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>CP dose-relatedly induced marked behavioral modifications in male rats: breathing rate decrease, closing of the eyes and occurrence of specific postures.</Disease>
<Disease>Morphine dose-dependently reversed these behavioral disorders.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A dose of 0.5 mg./kg. produced a reduction of almost 50% of the behavioral score induced by CP 200 mg./kg.</Disease>
<Disease>This effect was completely prevented by pretreatment with naloxone.</Disease>
<Disease>At the time of administration of morphine, histological modifications of the bladder wall, such as chorionic and muscle layer edema, were observed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In female rats, CP 200 mg./kg.</Disease>
<Disease>i.p. produced the same marked behavioral modifications as those observed in male rats.</Disease>
<Disease>Administered at the dose of 20 mg.</Disease>
<Disease>intravesically, CP did not produce any behavioral effects, whereas acrolein at 0.5 mg.</Disease>
<Disease>intravesically induced behavioral modifications identical to those under CP 200 mg./kg.</Disease>
<Disease>i.p., with the same maximal levels.</Disease>
<Disease>Conversely, acrolein 5 mg./kg.</Disease>
<Disease>i.v. did not produce any behavioral effects at all.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>

<Disease>Overall, these results indicate that this experimental model of CP-induced cystitis may be an interesting new behavioral model of inflammatory visceral pain, allowing a better understanding of these painful syndromes and thus a better therapeutic approach to them.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In 3 patients a pre-existing neuralgia increased to excruciating intensity and in 2 of these cases myoclonus occurred simultaneously.</Disease>

Disease

text: <Disease>Although only few clinical descriptions of the relationship between hyperalgesia/myoclonus and high doses of morphine are available, experimental support from animal studies indicates that morphine, or its metabolites, plays a causative role for the observed behavioural syndrome.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The possible mechanisms are discussed and treatment proposals given suggesting the use of more efficacious opioids with less excitatory potency in these situations.</Disease>
<Disease>A prospective study of adverse reactions associated with vancomycin therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>A prospective evaluation of the efficacy and safety of vancomycin was conducted in 54 consecutive patients over a 16-month period.</Disease>
<Disease>Vancomycin was curative in 95% of 43 patients with proven infection.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Drugs were ceased in six patients because of adverse reactions; in three of these vancomycin was considered the likely cause.</Disease>
<Disease>Reactions included thrombophlebitis (20 of 54 patients), rash (4 of 54), nephrotoxicity (4 of 50), proteinuria (1 of 50) and ototoxicity (1 of 11 patients tested by audiometry).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Thrombophlebitis occurred only with infusion through peripheral cannulae; nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity were confined to patients receiving an aminoglycoside plus vancomycin.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We conclude that vancomycin, administered appropriately, constitutes safe, effective therapy for infections caused by susceptible bacteria.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Dextran-etodolac conjugates: synthesis, in vitro and in vivo evaluation.</Disease>
<Disease>Etodolac (E), is a non-narcotic analgesic and antiinflammatory drug.</Disease>

<Disease>A biodegradable polymer dextran has been utilized as a carrier for synthesis of etodolac-dextran conjugates (ED) to improve its aqueous solubility and reduce gastrointestinal side effects.</Disease>

<Disease>An activated moiety, i.e. N-acylimidazole derivative of etodolac (EAI), was condensed with the polysaccharide polymer dextran of different molecular weights (40000, 60000, 110000 and 200000).</Disease>
<Disease>IR spectral data confirmed formation of ester bonding in the conjugates.</Disease>
<Disease>Etodolac contents were evaluated by UV-spectrophotometric analysis.</Disease>
<Disease>The molecular weights were determined by measuring viscosity using the Mark-Howink-Sakurada equation.</Disease>
<Disease>In vitro hydrolysis of ED was done in aqueous buffers (pH 1.2, 7.4, 9) and in 80% (v/v) human plasma (pH 7.4).</Disease>
<Disease>At pH 9, a higher rate of etodolac release from ED was observed as compared to aqueous buffer of pH 7.4 and 80% human plasma (pH 7.4), following first-order kinetics.</Disease>
<Disease>In vivo investigations were performed in animals.</Disease>
<Disease>Acute analgesic and antiinflammatory activities were ascertained using acetic acid induced writhing model (mice) and carrageenan-induced rat paw edema model, respectively.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In comparison to control, E and ED1-ED4 showed highly significant analgesic and antiinflammatory activities (p <0.001).</Disease>

<Disease>Biological evaluation suggested that conjugates (ED1-ED4) retained comparable analgesic and antiinflammatory activities with remarkably reduced ulcerogenicity as compared to their parent drug--etodolac.</Disease>

text: <Disease>On transthoracic echocardiogram, she had moderate left ventricular dysfunction with regional variability and moderate mitral regurgitation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The recipient's heart showed the features of apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and myocarditis with abundant eosinophils.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Myocarditis is rare and eosinophilic myocarditis is rarer.</Disease>

Disease

text: <Disease>It is likely that the hypersensitivity (eosinophilic) myocarditis was related to dobutamine infusion therapy.</Disease>

text: <Disease>All- trans-retinoic acid-induced erythema nodosum in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Erythema nodosum associated with all- trans-retinoic acid (ATRA) for acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is very rare.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We describe four patients with classic APL who developed erythema nodosum during ATRA therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Fever and subsequent multiple painful erythematous nodules over extremities developed on D11, D16, D17, and D19, respectively, after ATRA therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The skin biopsy taken from each patient was consistent with erythema nodosum.</Disease>

<Disease>Fever subsided rapidly and the skin lesions regressed completely.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Delayed-onset heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND: Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia presents 5 to 12 days after heparin exposure, with or without arterial or venous thromboemboli.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Delayed recognition and treatment of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia contribute to poor patient outcomes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To describe and increase awareness of a clinical scenario in which the onset or manifestations of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia are delayed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>DESIGN:</Disease>
<Disease>Retrospective case series.</Disease>
<Disease>SETTING: Three large urban hospitals (with active cardiovascular surgery programs).</Disease>
<Disease>PATIENTS: 14 patients seen over a 3-year period in whom heparin-induced thrombocytopenia became apparent on delayed presentation with thromboembolic complications.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>MEASUREMENTS:</Disease>
<Disease>Platelet counts, onset of objectively determined thromboembolism, results of heparin-induced platelet factor 4 antibody tests, and outcomes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>

<Disease>Patients went home after hospitalizations that had included heparin exposure--in most cases, with no thrombocytopenia recognized--only to return to the hospital (median, day 14) with thromboembolic complications.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Thromboemboli were venous (12 patients, 7 with pulmonary emboli) or arterial (4 patients) or both.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Platelet counts were mildly decreased in all but 2 patients on second presentation.</Disease>

<Disease>On readmission, 11 patients received therapeutic heparin, which worsened the patients' clinical condition and, in all 11 cases, decreased the platelet count (mean at readmission, 143 x 10(9) cells/L; mean nadir after heparin re-exposure, 39 x 10(9) cells/L).</Disease>
<Disease>Results of serologic tests for heparin-induced antibodies were positive in all patients.</Disease>

<Disease>Subsequent treatments included alternative anticoagulants (11 patients), thrombolytic drugs (3 patients), inferior vena cava filters (3 patients) and, eventually, warfarin (11 patients).</Disease>
<Disease>Three patients died.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS: Delayed-onset heparin-induced thrombocytopenia is increasingly being recognized.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To avoid disastrous outcomes, physicians must consider heparin-induced thrombocytopenia whenever a recently hospitalized patient returns with thromboembolism; therapy with alternative anticoagulants, not heparin, should be initiated.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Valsartan, a new angiotensin II antagonist for the treatment of essential hypertension: a comparative study of the efficacy and safety against amlodipine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To compare the antihypertensive efficacy of a new angiotensin II antagonist, valsartan, with a reference therapy, amlodipine.</Disease>
<Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>One hundred sixty-eight adult outpatients with mild to moderate hypertension were randomly allocated in double-blind fashion and equal number to receive 80 mg valsartan or 5 mg amlodipine for 12 weeks.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>After 8 weeks of therapy, in patients whose blood pressure remained uncontrolled, 5 mg amlodipine was added to the initial therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>Patients were assessed at 4, 8, and 12 weeks.</Disease>
<Disease>The primary efficacy variable was change from baseline in mean sitting diastolic blood pressure at 8 weeks.</Disease>
<Disease>Secondary variables included change in sitting systolic blood pressure and responder rates.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS: Both valsartan and amlodipine were effective at lowering blood pressure at 4, 8, and 12 weeks.</Disease>
<Disease>Similar decreases were observed in both groups, with no statistically significant differences between the groups for any variable analyzed.</Disease>
<Disease>For the primary variable the difference was 0.5 mm Hg in favor of valsartan (p = 0.68; 95% confidence interval, -2.7 to 1.7).</Disease>
<Disease>Responder rates at 8 weeks were 66.7% for valsartan and 60.2% for amlodipine (p = 0.39).</Disease>
<Disease>Both treatments were well tolerated.</Disease>

<Disease>The incidence of drug-related dependent edema was somewhat higher in the amlodipine group, particularly at a dose of 10 mg per day (2.4% for 80 mg valsartan; 3.6% for 5 mg amlodipine; 0% for valsartan plus 5 mg amlodipine; 14.3% for 10 mg amlodipine).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>The data show that valsartan is at least as effective as amlodipine in the treatment of mild to moderate hypertension.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The results also show valsartan to be well tolerated and suggest that it is not associated with side effects characteristic of this comparator class, dihydropyridine calcium antagonists.</Disease>
<Disease>KF17837: a novel selective adenosine A2A receptor antagonist with anticataleptic activity.</Disease>
<Disease>KF17837 is a novel selective adenosine A2A receptor antagonist.</Disease>

<Disease>Oral administration of KF17837 (2.5, 10.0 and 30.0 mg/kg) significantly ameliorated the cataleptic responses induced by intracerebroventricular administration of an adenosine A2A receptor agonist, CGS 21680 (10 micrograms), in a dose-dependent manner.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>KF17837 also reduced the catalepsy induced by haloperidol (1 mg/kg i.p.) and by reserpine (5 mg/kg i.p.).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These anticataleptic effects were exhibited dose dependently at doses from 0.625 and 2.5 mg/kg p.o., respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>Moreover, KF17837 (0.625 mg/kg p.o.) potentiated the anticataleptic effects of a subthreshold dose of L-3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine (L-DOPA; 25 mg/kg i.p.)</Disease>
<Disease>plus benserazide (6.25 mg/kg i.p.).</Disease>

<Disease>These results suggested that KF17837 is a centrally active adenosine A2A receptor antagonist and that the dopaminergic function of the nigrostriatal pathway is potentiated by adenosine A2A receptor antagonists.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, KF17837 may be a useful drug in the treatment of parkinsonism.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Some central effects of repeated treatment with fluvoxamine.</Disease>

<Disease>We investigated the effect of repeated treatment with fluvoxamine, a selective serotonin uptake inhibitor, on behavioral effects of dopaminomimetics and methoxamine and on the animal behavior in the "behavioral despair" test.</Disease>
<Disease>A repeated treatment with fluvoxamine (twice daily for 14 days) potentiated in mice and in rats (weaker) the amphetamine-induced hyperactivity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The hyperactivity induced by nomifensine in mice remained unaffected by fluvoxamine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The stimulation of locomotor activity by intracerebroventricularly administered methoxamine was not affected by repeated treatment with fluvoxamine.</Disease>
<Disease>Given three times fluvoxamine had no effect on the immobilization time in the "behavioral despair" test in rats.</Disease>

<Disease>The results indicate that fluvoxamine given repeatedly acts differently than citalopram, another selective serotonin uptake inhibitor, and differs also from other antidepressant drugs.</Disease>
<Disease>Severe congestive heart failure patient on amiodarone presenting with myxedemic coma: a case report.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This is a case report of myxedema coma secondary to amiodarone-induced hypothyroidism in a patient with severe congestive heart failure (CHF).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To our knowledge and after reviewing the literature there is one case report of myxedema coma during long term amiodarone therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Myxedema coma is a life threatening condition that carries a mortality reaching as high as 20% with treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The condition is treated with intravenous thyroxine (T4) or intravenous tri-iodo-thyronine (T3).</Disease>
<Disease>Patients with CHF on amiodarone may suffer serious morbidity and mortality from hypothyroidism, and thus may deserve closer follow up for thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) levels.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This case report carries an important clinical application given the frequent usage of amiodarone among CHF patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The myriad clinical presentation of myxedema coma and its serious morbidity and mortality stresses the need to suspect this clinical syndrome among CHF patients presenting with hypotension, weakness or other unexplained symptoms.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Fear-potentiated startle, but not light-enhanced startle, is enhanced by anxiogenic drugs.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>RATIONALE AND OBJECTIVES:</Disease>
<Disease>The light-enhanced startle paradigm (LES) is suggested to model anxiety, because of the non-specific cue and the long-term effect.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In contrast, the fear-potentiated startle (FPS) is suggested to model conditioned fear.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, the pharmacological profiles of these two paradigms are very similar.</Disease>

<Disease>The present study investigated the effects of putative anxiogenic drugs on LES and FPS and aimed at determining the sensitivity of LES for anxiogenic drugs and to potentially showing a pharmacological differentiation between these two paradigms.</Disease>
<Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>Male Wistar rats received each dose of the alpha(2)-adrenoceptor antagonist yohimbine (0.25-1.0mg/kg), the 5-HT(2C) receptor agonist m-chlorophenylpiperazine (mCPP, 0.5-2.0mg/kg) or the GABA(A) inverse receptor agonist pentylenetetrazole (PTZ, 3-30mg/kg) and were subsequently tested in either LES or FPS.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>None of the drugs enhanced LES, whereas mCPP increased percentage FPS and yohimbine increased absolute FPS values.</Disease>

<Disease>Furthermore, yohimbine increased baseline startle amplitude in the LES, while mCPP suppressed baseline startle in both the LES and FPS and PTZ suppressed baseline startle in the FPS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast to findings in the FPS paradigm, none of the drugs were able to exacerbate the LES response.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, a clear pharmacological differentiation was found between LES and FPS.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Although cessation of sulphasalazine treatment resulted in improvements in fever, red eyes, chest pain, titer of C-reactive protein and volume of the pleural effusions, we initiated steroid therapy, because PR3-ANCA titer rose to 320 EU, eosinophil count increased to 1,100 cells/microl, and the pleural effusion remained.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Is phenytoin administration safe in a hypothermic child?</Disease>

text: <Disease>A male neonate with a Chiari malformation and a leaking myelomeningocoele underwent ventriculoperitoneal shunt insertion followed by repair of myelomeningocoele.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>During anaesthesia and surgery, he inadvertently became moderately hypothermic.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Following phenytoin administration, the patient developed acute severe bradycardia, refractory to atropine and adrenaline.</Disease>

<Disease>Amisulpride related tic-like symptoms in an adolescent schizophrenic.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Tic disorders can be effectively treated by atypical antipsychotics such as risperidone, olanzapine and ziprasidone.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, there are two case reports that show tic-like symptoms, including motor and phonic variants, occurring during treatment with quetiapine or clozapine.</Disease>

text: <Disease>We present a 15-year-old girl schizophrenic who developed frequent involuntary eye-blinking movements after 5 months of amisulpride treatment (1000 mg per day).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The tic-like symptoms resolved completely after we reduced the dose of amisulpride down to 800 mg per day.</Disease>

text: <Disease>However, her psychosis recurred after the dose reduction.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We then placed her on an additional 100 mg per day of quetiapine.</Disease>
<Disease>She has been in complete remission under the combined medications for more than one year and maintains a fair role function.</Disease>
<Disease>No more tic-like symptoms or other side effects have been reported.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Together with previously reported cases, our patient suggests that tic-like symptoms might occur in certain vulnerable individuals during treatment with atypical antipsychotics such as quetiapine, clozapine, or amisulpride.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Comparison of developmental toxicology of aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) in rats using selected dosing paradigms.</Disease>
<Disease>BACKGROUND:</Disease>

<Disease>Analysis of the literature for nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) suggests that a low incidence of developmental anomalies occurs in rats given NSAIDs on specific days during organogenesis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid</Disease>

<Disease>[ASA]), an irreversible cyclooxygenase 1 and 2 inhibitor, induces developmental anomalies when administered to Wistar rats on gestational day (GD) 9, 10, or 11 (Kimmel CA, Wilson JG, Schumacher HJ.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Teratology 4:15-24, 1971).</Disease>
<Disease>There are no published ASA studies using the multiple dosing paradigm of GDs 6 to 17.</Disease>

<Disease>Objectives of the current study were to compare results between Sprague-Dawley (SD) and Wistar strains when ASA is administered on GD 9, 10, or 11; to compare the malformation patterns following single and multiple dosings during organogenesis in SD rats; and to test the hypothesis that maternal gastrointestinal toxicity confounds the detection of low incidence malformations with ASA when a multiple dosing paradigm is used.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>ASA was administered as a single dose on GD 9 (0, 250, 500, or 625 mg/kg), 10 (0, 500, 625, or 750 mg/kg), or 11 (0, 500, 750, or 1000 mg/kg) and from GD 6 to GD 17 (0, 50, 125, or 250 mg/kg a day) in the multiple dose study to SD rats.</Disease>
<Disease>Animals were killed on GD 21, and fetuses were examined viscerally.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>

<Disease>The literature evaluation suggested that NSAIDs induce ventricular septal defects (VSDs) and midline defects (MDs) in rats and diaphragmatic hernia (DH), MDs, and VSDs in rabbits (Cook JC et al., 2003); hence, the present study focused on these malformations, even though ASA induces several other low-incidence malformations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In single dose studies, DH, MD, and VSD were induced on GDs 9 and 10.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>VSD also was noted following treatment on GD 11.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In contrast, DH and MD were noted in the multiple dose study design only in the high-dose group, and VSD was noted across all dose groups.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS: High concordance in major developmental anomalies between Wistar and SD rats were noted with the exception of VSD in the SD rats and hydrocephalus in the Wistar rats.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Variations and malformations were similar when ASA was administered as a single dose or during the period of organogenesis (GDs 6 to 17).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It was also evident that, by titrating the dose to achieve a maximum tolerated dose, malformations that normally occur at low incidence, as reported from previous single dose studies, could also be induced with ASA given at multiple doses.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Torsade de pointes induced by metoclopramide in an elderly woman with preexisting complete left bundle branch block.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>There is a growing list of drugs implicated in acquired long QT syndrome and torsade de pointes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, the torsadogenic potential of metoclopramide, a commonly used antiemetic and prokinetic drug, has not been reported in the literature, despite its chemical similarity to procainamide.</Disease>
<Disease>We report on a 92-year-old woman with preexisting complete left bundle branch block who developed torsade de pointes after intravenous and oral administration of metoclopramide.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This patient also developed torsade de pointes when cisapride and erythromycin were given simultaneously.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These two episodes were suppressed successfully after discontinuing the offending drugs and administering class IB drugs.</Disease>
<Disease>This is the first documentation that metoclopramide provokes torsade de pointes clinically.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Metoclopramide should be used cautiously in patients with a risk of torsade de pointes.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Apomorphine: an underutilized therapy for Parkinson's disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Apomorphine was the first dopaminergic drug ever used to treat symptoms of Parkinson's disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>While powerful antiparkinsonian effects had been observed as early as 1951, the potential of treating fluctuating Parkinson's disease by subcutaneous administration of apomorphine has only recently become the subject of systematic study.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A number of small scale clinical trials have unequivocally shown that intermittent subcutaneous apomorphine injections produce antiparkinsonian benefit close if not identical to that seen with levodopa and that apomorphine rescue injections can reliably revert off-periods even in patients with complex on-off motor swings.</Disease>

<Disease>Continuous subcutaneous apomorphine infusions can reduce daily off-time by more than 50% in this group of patients, which appears to be a stronger effect than that generally seen with add-on therapy with oral dopamine agonists or COMT inhibitors.</Disease>
<Disease>Extended follow-up studies of up to 8 years have demonstrated long-term persistence of apomorphine efficacy.</Disease>

<Disease>In addition, there is convincing clinical evidence that monotherapy with continuous subcutaneous apomorphine infusions is associated with marked reductions of preexisting levodopa-induced dyskinesias.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The main side effects of subcutaneous apomorphine treatment are related to cutaneous tolerability problems, whereas sedation and psychiatric complications play a lesser role.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Given the marked degree of efficacy of subcutaneous apomorphine treatment in fluctuating Parkinson's disease, this approach seems to deserve more widespread clinical use.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Fatal excited delirium following cocaine use: epidemiologic findings provide new evidence for mechanisms of cocaine toxicity.</Disease>

Disease

text: <Disease>We describe an outbreak of deaths from cocaine-induced excited delirium (EDDs) in Dade County, Florida between 1979 and 1990.</Disease>

text: <Disease>From a registry of all cocaine-related deaths in Dade County, Florida, from 1969-1990, 58 EDDs were compared with 125 victims of accidental cocaine overdose without excited delirium.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Compared with controls, EDDs were more frequently black, male, and younger.</Disease>

text: <Disease>They were less likely to have a low body mass index, and more likely to have died in police custody, to have received medical treatment immediately before death, to have survived for a longer period, to have developed hyperthermia, and to have died in summer months.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Nerve growth factor and prostaglandins in the urine of female patients with overactive bladder.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>PURPOSE:</Disease>

<Disease>We investigated changes in urinary NGF and PGs in women with OAB.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Disease>
<Disease>The study groups included 65 women with OAB and 20 without bladder symptoms who served as controls.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Evaluation included patient history, urinalysis, a voiding diary and urodynamic studies.</Disease>
<Disease>Urine samples were collected.</Disease>
<Disease>NGF, PGE2, PGF2alpha and PGI2 were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay and compared between the groups.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, correlations between urinary NGF and PG, and urodynamic parameters in patients with OAB were examined.</Disease>

<Disease>Urinary NGF, PGE2 and PGF2alpha were significantly increased in patients with OAB compared with controls (p <0.05).</Disease>

text: <Disease>However, urinary PGI2 was not different between controls and patients with OAB.</Disease>

text: <Disease>In patients with OAB urinary PGE2 positively correlated with volume at first desire to void and maximum cystometric capacity (p <0.05).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Urinary NGF, PGF2alpha and PGI2 did not correlate with urodynamic parameters in patients with OAB.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>NGF and PGs have important roles in the development of OAB symptoms in female patients.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Urinary levels of these factors may be used as markers to evaluate OAB symptoms.</Disease>

<Disease>Postoperative myalgia after succinylcholine: no evidence for an inflammatory origin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A common side effect associated with succinylcholine is postoperative myalgia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The pathogenesis of this myalgia is still unclear; inflammation has been suggested but without convincing evidence.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We designed the present study to investigate whether an inflammatory reaction contributes to this myalgia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The incidence and severity of succinylcholine-associated myalgia was determined in 64 patients pretreated with saline or dexamethasone before succinylcholine (n = 32 for each).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Incidence and severity of myalgia did not differ significantly between the two groups: 15 patients in the dexamethasone group complained of myalgia compared with 18 patients in the saline group, and severe myalgia was reported by five patients and three patients, respectively (not significant).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>At 48 h after surgery, 12 patients in both groups still suffered from myalgia (not significant).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, interleukin-6 (IL-6) as an early marker of inflammation was assessed in a subgroup of 10 patients pretreated with saline.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We found an increase of IL-6 for only three patients, but only one patient reported myalgia; no relationship between myalgia and the increase of IL-6 was found.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In conclusion, there is no evidence for an inflammatory origin of succinylcholine-associated myalgia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>IMPLICATIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Administration of dexamethasone before succinylcholine was not effective in decreasing the incidence or the severity of succinylcholine-induced postoperative myalgia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Furthermore, there was no significant relationship between postoperative myalgia and time course of interleukin-6 concentrations, a marker of inflammation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Pretreatment with dexamethasone is not justified to prevent postoperative myalgia after succinylcholine.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Ketamine in war/tropical surgery (a final tribute to the racemic mixture).</Disease>

<Disease>A technique of continuous intravenous anaesthesia with ketamine was used successfully during the Somalia civil war in 1994 and in north Uganda in 1999 for 64 operations in 62 patients, aged from 6 weeks to 70 years, undergoing limb and abdominal surgery including caesarian sections and interventions in neonates.</Disease>

<Disease>Operations lasting up to 2h could be performed in the absence of sophisticated equipment such as pulse oximeters or ventilators in patients on spontaneous ventilation breathing air/oxygen only.</Disease>

<Disease>After premedication with diazepam, glycopyrrolate and local anaesthesia, and induction with standard doses of ketamine, a maintenance dose of 10-20 microg/kg/min of ketamine proved safe and effective.</Disease>
<Disease>Emphasis was placed on bedside clinical monitoring, relying heavily on the heart rate.</Disease>

<Disease>Diazepam, unless contraindicated or risky, remains the only necessary complementary drug to ketamine as it buffers its cardiovascular response and decreases the duration and intensity of operative and postoperative hallucinations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Local anaesthetic blocks were useful in decreasing the requirement for postoperative analgesia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>An antisialogue was usually unnecessary in operations lasting up to 2 h, glycopyrrolate being the best choice for its lowest psychotropic and chronotropic effects, especially in a hot climate.</Disease>

<Disease>Experience in war/tropical settings suggests this technique could be useful in civilian contexts such as outdoor life-saving emergency surgery or in mass casualties where, e.g. amputation and rapid extrication were required.</Disease>
<Disease>Steroid structure and pharmacological properties determine the anti-amnesic effects of pregnenolone sulphate in the passive avoidance task in rats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pregnenolone sulphate (PREGS) has generated interest as one of the most potent memory-enhancing neurosteroids to be examined in rodent learning studies, with particular importance in the ageing process.</Disease>
<Disease>The mechanism by which this endogenous steroid enhances memory formation is hypothesized to involve actions on glutamatergic and GABAergic systems.</Disease>

<Disease>This hypothesis stems from findings that PREGS is a potent positive modulator of N-methyl-d-aspartate receptors (NMDARs) and a negative modulator of gamma-aminobutyric acid(A) receptors (GABA(A)Rs).</Disease>
<Disease>Moreover, PREGS is able to reverse the amnesic-like effects of NMDAR and GABA(A)R ligands.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To investigate this hypothesis, the present study in rats examined the memory-altering abilities of structural analogs of PREGS, which differ in their modulation of NMDAR and/or GABA(A)R function.</Disease>

<Disease>The analogs tested were: 11-ketopregnenolone sulphate (an agent that is inactive at GABA(A)Rs and NMDARs), epipregnanolone ([3beta-hydroxy-5beta-pregnan-20-one] sulphate, an inhibitor of both GABA(A)Rs and NMDARs), and a newly synthesized (-) PREGS enantiomer (which is identical to PREGS in effects on GABA(A)Rs and NMDARs).</Disease>
<Disease>The memory-enhancing effects of PREGS and its analogs were tested in the passive avoidance task using the model of scopolamine-induced amnesia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Both PREGS and its (-) enantiomer blocked the effects of scopolamine.</Disease>

<Disease>The results show that, unlike PREGS, 11-ketopregnenolone sulphate and epipregnanolone sulphate failed to block the effect of scopolamine, suggesting that altering the modulation of NMDA receptors diminishes the memory-enhancing effects of PREGS.</Disease>

<Disease>Moreover, enantioselectivity was demonstrated by the ability of natural PREGS to be an order of magnitude more effective than its synthetic enantiomer in reversing scopolamine-induced amnesia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These results identify a novel neuropharmacological site for the modulation of memory processes by neuroactive steroids.</Disease>
<Disease>Preliminary efficacy assessment of intrathecal injection of an American formulation of adenosine in humans.</Disease>

<Disease>BACKGROUND: Preclinical studies of intrathecal adenosine suggest it may be effective in the treatment of acute and chronic pain in humans, and preliminary studies in volunteers and patients with a Swedish formulation of adenosine suggests it may be effective in hypersensitivity states but not with acute noxious stimulation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The purpose of this study was to screen for efficacy of a different formulation of adenosine marketed in the US, using both acute noxious stimulation and capsaicin-evoked mechanical hypersensitivity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS:</Disease>

<Disease>Following Food and Drug Administration and institutional review board approval and written informed consent, 65 volunteers were studied in two trials: an open-label, dose-escalating trial with intrathecal adenosine doses of 0.25-2.0 mg and a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of adenosine, 2 mg.</Disease>

<Disease>Cerebrospinal fluid was obtained for pharmacokinetic analysis, and pain ratings in response to acute heat stimuli and areas of mechanical hyperalgesia and allodynia after intradermal capsaicin injection were determined.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>

<Disease>Adenosine produced no effect on pain report to acute noxious thermal or chemical stimulation but reduced mechanical hyperalgesia and allodynia from intradermal capsaicin injection for at least 24 h. In contrast, residence time of adenosine in cerebrospinal fluid was short (< 4 h).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>These results show selective inhibition by intrathecal adenosine of hypersensitivity, presumed to reflect central sensitization in humans after peripheral capsaicin injection.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The long-lasting effect is consistent with that observed in preliminary reports of patients with chronic neuropathic pain and is not due to prolonged residence of adenosine in cerebrospinal fluid.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Effect of lithium maintenance therapy on thyroid and parathyroid function.</Disease>
<Disease>OBJECTIVES:</Disease>
<Disease>To assess changes induced by lithium maintenance therapy on the incidence of thyroid, parathyroid and ion alterations.</Disease>
<Disease>These were evaluated with respect to the duration of lithium therapy, age, sex, and family history (whether or not the patient had a first-degree relative with thyroid disease).</Disease>

text: <Disease>DESIGN: Prospective study.</Disease>

<Disease>Affective Disorders Clinic at St. Mary's Hospital, Montreal.</Disease>
<Disease>PATIENTS: One hundred and one patients (28 men and 73 women) with bipolar disorder receiving lithium maintenance therapy ranging from 1 year's to 32 years' duration.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The control group consisted of 82 patients with no psychiatric or endocrinological diagnoses from the hospital's out-patient clinics.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Contribution of the glycine site of NMDA receptors in rostral and intermediate-caudal parts of the striatum to the regulation of muscle tone in rats.</Disease>
<Disease>The aim of the present study was to assess the contribution of the glycine site of NMDA receptors in the striatum to the regulation of muscle tone.</Disease>

<Disease>Muscle tone was examined using a combined mechanoand electromyographic method, which measured simultaneously the muscle resistance (MMG) of the rat's hind foot to passive extension and flexion in the ankle joint and the electromyographic activity (EMG) of the antagonistic muscles of that joint: gastrocnemius and tibialis anterior.</Disease>
<Disease>Muscle rigidity was induced by haloperidol (2.5 mg/kg i.p.).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>5,7-dichlorokynurenic acid (5,7-DCKA), a selective glycine site antagonist, injected in doses of 2.5 and 4.5 microg/0.5 microl bilaterally, into the rostral region of the striatum, decreased both the haloperidol-induced muscle rigidity (MMG) and the enhanced electromyographic activity (EMG).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>5,7-DCKA injected bilaterally in a dose of 4.5 microg/0.5 microl into the intermediate-caudal region of the striatum of rats not pretreated with haloperidol had no effect on the muscle tone.</Disease>

<Disease>The present results suggest that blockade of the glycine site of NMDA receptors in the rostral part of the striatum may be mainly responsible for the antiparkinsonian action of this drug.</Disease>
<Disease>Efficacy and tolerability of lovastatin in 3390 women with moderate hypercholesterolemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of lovastatin in women with moderate hypercholesterolemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>DESIGN:</Disease>
<Disease>The Expanded Clinical Evaluation of Lovastatin (EXCEL)</Disease>

<Disease>Study, a multicenter, double-blind, diet- and placebo-controlled trial, in which participants were randomly assigned to receive placebo or lovastatin at doses of 20 or 40 mg once daily, or 20 or 40 mg twice daily for 48 weeks.</Disease>
<Disease>SETTING:</Disease>
<Disease>Ambulatory patients recruited by 362 participating centers throughout the United States.</Disease>
<Disease>PATIENTS: Women (n = 3390) from the total cohort of 8245 volunteers.</Disease>
<Disease>MEASUREMENTS:</Disease>

<Disease>Plasma total, low-density lipoprotein (LDL), and high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, and triglycerides; and laboratory and clinical evidence of adverse events monitored periodically throughout the study.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>

<Disease>Among women, lovastatin (20 to 80 mg/d) produced sustained (12- to 48-week), dose-related changes (P < 0.001): decreases in LDL cholesterol (24% to 40%) and triglycerides (9% to 18%), and increases in HDL cholesterol (6.7% to 8.6%).</Disease>

<Disease>Depending on the dose, from 82% to 95% of lovastatin-treated women achieved the National Cholesterol Education Program goal of LDL cholesterol levels less than 4.14 mmol/L (160 mg/dL), and 40% to 87% achieved the goal of 3.36 mmol/L (130 mg/dL).</Disease>
<Disease>Successive transaminase elevations greater than three times the upper limit of normal occurred in 0.1% of women and were dose dependent above the 20-mg dose.</Disease>

<Disease>Myopathy, defined as muscle symptoms with creatine kinase elevations greater than 10 times the upper limit of normal, was rare and associated with the highest recommended daily dose of lovastatin (80 mg).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Estrogen-replacement therapy appeared to have no effect on either the efficacy or safety profile of lovastatin.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Lovastatin is highly effective and generally well tolerated as therapy for primary hypercholesterolemia in women.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The protective effect of oral administration of the thiol compound sodium 2-mercaptoethane sulphonate (MESNA) against urothelial toxicity induced by ifosfamide (IF) was tested in a group of 45 patients with inoperable lung cancer under treatment with IF (2250 mg/m2 on days 2-5) as part of a polychemotherapy regimen repeated in a 4-week cycle.</Disease>

Disease

text: <Disease>MESNA was given orally on the days of treatment with IF in 3 doses of 840 mg/m2, each administered at 0 hr (= injection of IF), 4 hr and 8 hr p.i.</Disease>
<Disease>Out of a total of 88 courses of this treatment we observed 10 episodes of asymptomatic microscopic haematuria and no episodes of gross haematuria.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In this group of 45 patients under protection with MESNA there were 5 complete remissions and 9 partial remissions (total 31%).</Disease>
<Disease>A further group of 25 patients under polychemotherapy with IF were treated by conventional prophylactic measures (raised fluid intake and forced diuresis).</Disease>

<Disease>In this group there were 1 complete and 5 partial remissions (total 24%), but nearly all patients developed either gross haematuria and/or symptoms of bladder irritation (cystitis and pollakisuria).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>There were no appreciable differences between the MESNA series and the conventional prophylaxis series with respect to either haematological or systemic toxicity of the cytostatic treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our results support the view that MESNA, given orally in conjunction with combined cytostatic regimens which include IF, simplifies the treatment and provides optimum protection for the urinary epithelium.</Disease>

text: <Disease>To investigate the initial potassium loss and development of hypokalaemia during the administration of an oral diuretic, metabolic balance studies were performed in ten patients with essential hypertension who had shown hypokalaemia under prior oral diuretic treatment.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Chlorthalidone (50 mg daily) was given for 14 days.</Disease>
<Disease>Six patients received a normal-sodium diet and four a low-sodium (17 mmol/day) diet.</Disease>
<Disease>All patients had a normal initial total body potassium (40K).</Disease>
<Disease>The electrolyte balances, weight, bromide space, plasma renin activity, and aldosterone secretion rate were measured.</Disease>
<Disease>In both groups a potassium deficit developed, with proportionally larger losses from the extracellular than from the intracellular compartment.</Disease>

<Disease>In the normal-sodium group the highest mean potassium deficit was 176 mmol on day 9, after which some potassium was regained; in the low-sodium group the highest deficit was 276 mmol on day 13.</Disease>

<Disease>The normal-sodium group showed an immediate but temporary rise of the renin and aldosterone levels; in the low-sodium group renin and aldosterone increased more slowly but remained elevated.</Disease>

<Disease>It is concluded that dietary sodium restriction increases diuretic-induced potassium loss, presumably by an increased activity of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, while sodium delivery to the distal renal tubules remains sufficiently high to allow increased potassium secretion.</Disease>
<Disease>Dynamic response of blood vessel in acute renal failure.</Disease>

<Disease>The hemodynamics of oxytocin and other vasoactive agents during neuraxial anesthesia for cesarean delivery: findings in six cases.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Oxytocin-induced hypotension at cesarean delivery may be incorrectly attributed to blood loss.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Intraocular pressure in patients with uveitis treated with fluocinolone acetonide implants.</Disease>

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE: To report the incidence and management of elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) in patients with uveitis treated with the fluocinolone acetonide (FA) intravitreal implant.</Disease>

<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>

<Disease>During the 3-year follow-up, 71.0% of implanted eyes had an IOP increase of 10 mm Hg or more than baseline and 55.1%, 24.7%, and 6.2% of eyes reached an IOP of 30 mm Hg or more, 40 mm Hg or more, and 50 mm Hg or more, respectively.</Disease>

<Disease>Topical IOP-lowering medication was administered in 74.8% of implanted eyes, and IOP-lowering surgeries, most of which were trabeculectomies (76.2%), were performed on 36.6% of implanted eyes.</Disease>
<Disease>Intraocular pressure-lowering surgeries were considered a success (postoperative IOP of 6-21 mm</Disease>
<Disease>Hg with or without additional IOP-lowering medication) in 85.1% of eyes at 1 year.</Disease>
<Disease>The rate of hypotony (IOP </= 5 mm Hg) following IOP-lowering surgery (42.5%) was not different from that of implanted eyes not subjected to surgery (35.4%) (P = .09).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Elevated IOP is a significant complication with the FA intravitreal implant but may be controlled with medication and surgery.</Disease>
<Disease>Pallidal stimulation: an alternative to pallidotomy?</Disease>
<Disease>A resurgence of interest in the surgical treatment of Parkinson's disease (PD) came with the rediscovery of posteroventral pallidotomy by Laitinen in 1985.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Laitinen's procedure improved most symptoms in drug-resistant PD, which engendered wide interest in the neurosurgical community.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Another lesioning procedure, ventrolateral thalamotomy, has become a powerful alternative to stimulate the nucleus ventralis intermedius, producing high long-term success rates and low morbidity rates.</Disease>
<Disease>Pallidal stimulation has not met with the same success.</Disease>

<Disease>According to the literature pallidotomy improves the "on" symptoms of PD, such as dyskinesias, as well as the "off" symptoms, such as rigidity, bradykinesia, and on-off fluctuations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Pallidal stimulation improves bradykinesia and rigidity to a minor extent; however, its strength seems to be in improving levodopa-induced dyskinesias.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Stimulation often produces an improvement in the hyper- or dyskinetic upper limbs, but increases the "freezing" phenomenon in the lower limbs at the same time.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Considering the small increase in the patient's independence, the high costs of bilateral implants, and the difficulty most patients experience in handling the devices, the question arises as to whether bilateral pallidal stimulation is a real alternative to pallidotomy.</Disease>
<Disease>Case report: Dexatrim (Phenylpropanolamine) as a cause of myocardial infarction.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Phenylpropanolamine (PPA) is a sympathetic amine used in over-the-counter cold remedies and weight-control preparations worldwide.</Disease>
<Disease>Its use has been associated with hypertensive episodes and hemorrhagic strokes in younger women.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Several reports have linked the abuse of PPA with myocardial injury, especially when overdose is involved.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We report here the first case of Dexatrim (PPA)-induced myocardial injury in a young woman who was using it at recommended doses for weight control.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, we review the 7 other cases of PPA related myocardial injury that have been reported so far.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Physicians and patients should be alert to the potential cardiac risk associated with the use of PPA, even at doses generally considered to be safe.</Disease>

<Disease>Activation of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase contributes to development of doxorubicin-induced heart failure.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Activation of the nuclear enzyme poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) by oxidant-mediated DNA damage is an important pathway of cell dysfunction and tissue injury in conditions associated with oxidative stress.</Disease>
<Disease>Increased oxidative stress is a major factor implicated in the cardiotoxicity of doxorubicin (DOX), a widely used antitumor anthracycline antibiotic.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, we hypothesized that the activation of PARP may contribute to the DOX-induced cardiotoxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Using a dual approach of PARP-1 suppression, by genetic deletion or pharmacological inhibition with the phenanthridinone PARP inhibitor PJ34, we now demonstrate the role of PARP in the development of cardiac dysfunction induced by DOX.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>PARP-1+/+ and PARP-1-/- mice received a single injection of DOX (25 mg/kg i.p).</Disease>
<Disease>Five days after DOX administration, left ventricular performance was significantly depressed in PARP-1+/+ mice, but only to a smaller extent in PARP-1-/- ones.</Disease>
<Disease>Similar experiments were conducted in BALB/c mice treated with PJ34 or vehicle.</Disease>
<Disease>Treatment with a PJ34 significantly improved cardiac dysfunction and increased the survival of the animals.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition PJ34 significantly reduced the DOX-induced increase in the serum lactate dehydrogenase and creatine kinase activities but not metalloproteinase activation in the heart.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, PARP activation contributes to the cardiotoxicity of DOX.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>PARP inhibitors may exert protective effects against the development of severe cardiac complications associated with the DOX treatment.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Fluconazole-induced torsade de pointes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE:</Disease>
<Disease>To present a case of fluconazole-associated torsade de pointes (TDP) and discuss fluconazole's role in causing TDP.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CASE SUMMARY:</Disease>

<Disease>A 68-year-old white woman with Candida glabrata isolated from a presacral abscess developed TDP eight days after commencing oral fluconazole The patient had no other risk factors for TDP, including coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathy, congestive heart failure, and electrolyte abnormalities There was a temporal association between the initiation of fluconazole and TDP.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The TDP resolved when fluconazole was discontinued; however, the patient continued to have premature ventricular contractions and nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) until six days after drug cessation DISCUSSION:</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Use of the Naranjo probability scale indicates a probable relationship between the use of fluconazole and the development of TDP.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The possible mechanism is depression of rapidly activating delayed rectifier potassium currents.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In our patient, there was no other etiology identified that could explain QT prolongation or TDP The complete disappearance of NSVT and premature ventricular contractions followed by normalization of QT interval after the drug was stopped strongly suggests fluconazole as the etiology.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS:</Disease>
<Disease>Clinicians should be aware that fluconazole, even at low doses, may cause prolongation of the QT interval, leading to TDP.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Serial electrocardiographic monitoring may be considered when fluconazole is administered in patients who are at risk for ventricular arrhythmias.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>High-dose methylprednisolone may do more harm for spinal cord injury.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Probing peripheral and central cholinergic system responses.</Disease>
<Disease>OBJECTIVE:</Disease>

<Disease>The pharmacological response to drugs that act on the cholinergic system of the iris has been used to predict deficits in central cholinergic functioning due to diseases such as Alzheimer's disease, yet correlations between central and peripheral responses have not been properly studied.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This study assessed the effect of normal aging on (1) the tropicamide-induced increase in pupil diameter, and (2) the reversal of this effect with pilocarpine.</Disease>
<Disease>Scopolamine was used as a positive control to detect age-dependent changes in central cholinergic functioning in the elderly.</Disease>
<Disease>DESIGN: Randomized double-blind controlled trial.</Disease>
<Disease>PARTICIPANTS: Ten healthy elderly (mean age 70) and 9 young (mean age 33) volunteers.</Disease>
<Disease>INTERVENTIONS: Pupil diameter was monitored using a computerized infrared pupillometer over 4 hours.</Disease>
<Disease>The study involved 4 sessions.</Disease>
<Disease>In 1 session, tropicamide (20 microL, 0.01%) was administered to one eye and placebo to the other.</Disease>

<Disease>In another session, tropicamide (20 microL, 0.01%) was administered to both eyes, followed 23 minutes later by the application of pilocarpine (20 microL, 0.1%) to one eye and placebo to the other.</Disease>
<Disease>All eye drops were given in a randomized order.</Disease>

<Disease>In 2 separate sessions, a single dose of scopolamine (0.5 mg, intravenously) or placebo was administered, and the effects on word recall were measured using the Buschke Selective Reminding Test over 2 hours.</Disease>
<Disease>OUTCOME MEASURES:</Disease>
<Disease>Pupil size at time points after administration of tropicamide and pilocarpine; scopolamine-induced impairment in word recall.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>There was no significant difference between elderly and young volunteers in pupillary response to tropicamide at any time point (p > 0.05).</Disease>

<Disease>The elderly group had a significantly greater pilocarpine-induced net decrease in pupil size 85, 125, 165 and 215 minutes after administration, compared with the young group (p < 0.05).</Disease>
<Disease>Compared with the young group, the elderly group had greater scopolamine-induced impairment in word recall 60, 90 and 120 minutes after administration (p < 0.05).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>There is an age-related pupillary response to pilocarpine that is not found with tropicamide.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, pilocarpine may be useful to assess variations in central cholinergic function in elderly patients.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Absence of effect of sertraline on time-based sensitization of cognitive impairment with haloperidol.</Disease>

text: <Disease>This double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled study evaluated the effects of haloperidol alone and haloperidol plus sertraline on cognitive and psychomotor function in 24 healthy male subjects.</Disease>
<Disease>METHOD:</Disease>
<Disease>All subjects received placebo on Day 1 and haloperidol 2 mg on Days 2 and 25.</Disease>

<Disease>From Days 9 to 25, subjects were randomly assigned to either sertraline (12 subjects) or placebo (12 subjects); the sertraline dose was titrated from 50 to 200 mg/day from Days 9 to 16, and remained at 200 mg/day for the final 10 days of the drug administration period.</Disease>
<Disease>Cognitive function testing was performed before dosing and over a 24-hour period after dosing on Days 1, 2, and 25.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS:</Disease>
<Disease>Impairment of cognitive function was observed 6 to 8 hours after administration of haloperidol on Day 2 but was not evident 23 hours after dosing.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>When single-dose haloperidol was given again 25 days later, greater impairment with earlier onset was noted in several tests in both treatment groups, suggesting enhancement of this effect.</Disease>
<Disease>There was no indication that sertraline exacerbated the impairment produced by haloperidol since an equivalent effect also occurred in the placebo group.</Disease>
<Disease>Three subjects (2 on sertraline and 1 on placebo) withdrew from the study because of side effects.</Disease>
<Disease>Ten subjects in each group reported side effects related to treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>The side effect profiles of sertraline and of placebo were similar.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION:</Disease>
<Disease>Haloperidol produced a clear profile of cognitive impairment that was not worsened by concomitant sertraline administration.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Increased plasma malondialdehyde was also recorded in two other groups of animals subjected to the same experimental model, one receiving 20 mg/kg b.w. of the cyclooxygenase inhibitor acetylsalicylate intravenously immediately before ischemia, the other receiving 650 micrograms/kg b.w. of the hypotensive drug nitroprusside at a flow rate of 103 microliters/min intravenously during ischemia, although in this latter group malondialdehyde was significantly higher.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The present data indicate that the determination of malondialdehyde, oxypurines, and nucleosides in peripheral blood, may be used to monitor the metabolic alterations of tissues occurring during ischemic phenomena.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)</Disease>

<Disease>Epileptogenic properties of enflurane and their clinical interpretation.</Disease>

<Disease>Enhanced stimulus-induced neurotransmitter overflow in epinephrine-induced hypertensive rats is not mediated by prejunctional beta-adrenoceptor activation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The present study examines the effect of 6-day epinephrine treatment (100 micrograms/kg per h, s.c.) on stimulus-induced (1 Hz) endogenous neurotransmitter overflow from the isolated perfused kidney of vehicle- and epinephrine-treated rats.</Disease>
<Disease>Renal catecholamine stores and stimulus-induced overflow in the vehicle-treated group consisted of norepinephrine only.</Disease>

<Disease>However, epinephrine treatment resulted in the incorporation of epinephrine into renal catecholamine stores such that approximately 40% of the catecholamine present was epinephrine while the norepinephrine content was reduced by a similar degree.</Disease>
<Disease>Total tissue catecholamine content of the kidney on a molar basis was unchanged.</Disease>

<Disease>Stimulus-induced fractional overflow of neurotransmitter from the epinephrine-treated kidneys was approximately twice normal and consisted of both norepinephrine and epinephrine in proportions similar to those found in the kidney.</Disease>
<Disease>This difference in fractional overflow between groups was not affected by neuronal and extraneuronal uptake blockade.</Disease>
<Disease>Propranolol had no effect on stimulus-induced overflow in either group.</Disease>
<Disease>Phentolamine increased stimulus-induced overflow in both groups although the increment in overflow was greater in the epinephrine-treated group.</Disease>
<Disease>In conclusion, chronic epinephrine treatment results in enhanced fractional neurotransmitter overflow.</Disease>

<Disease>However, neither alterations in prejunctional beta-adrenoceptor influences nor alterations in neuronal and extraneuronal uptake mechanisms appear to be responsible for this alteration.</Disease>

<Disease>Furthermore, data obtained with phentolamine alone do not suggest alpha-adrenoceptor desensitization as the cause of the enhanced neurotransmitter overflow after epinephrine treatment.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Water intoxication associated with oxytocin administration during saline-induced abortion.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Four cases of water intoxication in connection with oxytocin administration during saline-induced abortions are described.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The mechanism of water intoxication is discussed in regard to these cases.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Oxytocin administration during midtrimester-induced abortions is advocated only if it can be carried out under careful observations of an alert nursing staff, aware of the symptoms of water intoxication and instructed to watch the diuresis and report such early signs of the syndrome as asthenia, muscular irritability, or headaches.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The oxytocin should be given only in Ringers lactate or, alternately, in Ringers lactate and a 5 per cent dextrose and water solutions.</Disease>
<Disease>The urinary output should be monitored and the oxytocin administration discontinued and the serum electrolytes checked if the urinary output decreases.</Disease>
<Disease>The oxytocin should not be administered in excess of 36 hours.</Disease>
<Disease>If the patient has not aborted by then the oxytocin should be discontinued for 10 to 12 hours in order to perform electrolyte determinations and correct any electrolyte imbalance.</Disease>
